<div class="pages">
<div id="page-1133493">
<h3><a name="page-1133493">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 001)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>1</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1860-10-30'>Oct<sup>r</sup> 30, 1860</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo W<sup>m</sup> Bond Esq</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup> &amp;c.</p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>I send you 50 pro<span class='line-break'></span>prietors tickets.</p>
<p>Also deeds for <a href='/pages/subjects/59188' title='Bradford, Duncan'>Duncan Bradford, Esq<sup>r</sup></a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59189' title='Faden, Mary A.'>Mary A. Faden</a>, and of Passageway to<span class='line-break'> </span>Eunice M. [Condly?]</p>
<p>The deed ordered in name of Charlotte<span class='line-break'> </span>[Gynand?] cannot be made without putting<span class='line-break'> </span>the title of the lot in her name. By refer<span class='line-break'></span>ring to the catalogue you will perceive<span class='line-break'> </span>she only represents it. I believe <a href='/pages/subjects/54833' title='Bowditch, J. Ingersoll'>J. Ingersoll<span class='line-break'> </span>Bowditch</a> is one of the Trustees under the<span class='line-break'> </span>wills - a man impatient of forms - and<span class='line-break'> </span>I should not be surprized if he sh<sup>d</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>refuse to do anything about it. The<span class='line-break'> </span>addition should be conveyed to the party<span class='line-break'> </span>in whom the legal estate of the lot has<span class='line-break'> </span>vested.</p>
<p>Is there not some mistake about<span class='line-break'> </span>the passagway to <a href='/pages/subjects/54772' title='Gould, Benjamin A. (1787-1859)'>B.A. Gould</a> which<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a> has described? I remember<span class='line-break'> </span>that in <a href='/pages/subjects/54772' title='Gould, Benjamin A. (1787-1859)'>Mr. Gould</a>'s lifetime this whole<span class='line-break'> </span>space about 9 to 11 ft. was divided between<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54772' title='Gould, Benjamin A. (1787-1859)'>Mr G.</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/52529' title='Bigelow, Jacob'>Dr. Bigelow</a>, and you will see<span class='line-break'> </span>on the catalogue that each has 85 [ft?].<span class='line-break'> </span>It may that ^<sup> <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a></sup> <del>he</del> has discovered more land.</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>Left margin: <a href='/pages/subjects/59192' title='Thayer, Elizabeth C.'>Mrs. Eliz. C. Thayer</a> sh<sup>d</sup> pay $1.00 more for new deed record.</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1860-10-30'>Oct<sup>r</sup>. 30/60</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jona. Mann Esq</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup> Mt Auburn</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you please<span class='line-break'> </span>examine the lots described on<span class='line-break'> </span>the accompanying blanks, <a href='/pages/subjects/59193' title='Lot 457'>-457,</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59194' title='Lot 479'>479 &amp;</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/59195' title='Lot 480'>480, -</a> and send me<span class='line-break'> </span>the blanks filled out. Also<span class='line-break'> </span>state what in your judgement<span class='line-break'> </span>should be charged for the<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>perpetual</ins> care of each.<span class='line-break'> </span>We are aware that they <span class='line-break'> </span>are in the same enclosure,<span class='line-break'> </span>but the contracts, if made,<span class='line-break'> </span>must be distinct.</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133494">
<h3><a name="page-1133494">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 002)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>2</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1860-10-31'>Oct 31, 1860</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59198' title='Emerson, Henry'>Henry Emerson Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>When you last called<span class='line-break'> </span>at my office about the bill<span class='line-break'> </span>due to Mt Auburn, you said<span class='line-break'> </span>you would see <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr. Mann</a> the<span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup>, and attend to it. This was<span class='line-break'> </span>some months since. I have<span class='line-break'> </span>asked the Sup<sup>t</sup> several times if<span class='line-break'> </span>you had seen him, and he<span class='line-break'> </span>said , <ins>no</ins>; and that he did not<span class='line-break'> </span>consider that he had anything<span class='line-break'> </span>to do about bill placed in<span class='line-break'> </span>my hands for collection.</p>
<p>I must consequently again<span class='line-break'> </span>call your attention to this unset<span class='line-break'></span>tled account, and request<span class='line-break'> </span>that you neglect it no longer.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary of<span class='line-break'> </span>Mt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1860-10-31'>Oct 31, 1860</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/85149' title='Ordway, John P.'>Mr John P. Ordway</a>,</p>
<p>Your note of <date when='1860-10-05'>Oct 5</date> is before<span class='line-break'> </span>me—in which you say—this "I shall<span class='line-break'> </span>be absent for about a week<span class='line-break'> </span>longer, after which time will see<span class='line-break'> </span>you."</p>
<p>Twenty Eight days or <ins>four</ins> weeks<span class='line-break'> </span>have elapsed without your fulfilling<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>this</ins> promise—like many that have<span class='line-break'> </span>gone before it. Now this may<span class='line-break'> </span>all be innocent enough on your<span class='line-break'> </span>part, but I have come to the<span class='line-break'> </span>opinion that it is mere imposition,<span class='line-break'> </span>and unworthy of both of us. You<span class='line-break'> </span>have, at various times, intimated <span class='line-break'> </span>that you were ready to arrange<span class='line-break'> </span>a place for gradual payment;<span class='line-break'> </span>and this you have totally neglected.</p>
<p>I shall bring the matter to the<span class='line-break'> </span>attention of the Trustees next Monday,<span class='line-break'> </span>and let them say what they think<span class='line-break'> </span>should be done.</p>
<p>Yours  <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133495">
<h3><a name="page-1133495">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 003)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>3</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1860-11-22'>Nov. 22/60</date><span class='line-break'> </span>Mr. <a href='/pages/subjects/52579' title='Safford, Truman H.'>T. H. Safford</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you<span class='line-break'> </span>please enclose <a href='/pages/subjects/59208' title='Raymond, Mr.'>Mr. Raymond's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>bill which I left with you<span class='line-break'> </span>as he has called for them. I met<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/66870' title='Apple, Anthony'>Mr. Apple</a> and he insists that he<span class='line-break'> </span>took care of the lot for the years '58,<span class='line-break'> </span>'59 and '60. If that is so, then $2<span class='line-break'> </span>should be refunded from what the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation has received on the '57 bill<span class='line-break'> </span>paid twice.</p>
<p>I wish also you would make <span class='line-break'> </span>out a bill of $15 (I think it was)<span class='line-break'> </span>charged some two or three years since<span class='line-break'> </span>against <a href='/pages/subjects/59201' title='Brown, John'>Mr John [N.?] Brown</a> of Charles<span class='line-break'></span>town, for foundation to monument<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp;c.-<a href='/pages/subjects/59204' title='Lot 888'>lot 888-</a> The bill has been lost<span class='line-break'> </span>and I would like another with the<span class='line-break'> </span>date and charge.</p>
<p>Yours truly <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>.<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1860-12-26'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 26, 1860</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59202' title='Marsh, Levi H.'>Levi H. Marsh Esq</a></p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Proprietors of the Cemetery of<span class='line-break'> </span>Mount Auburn, have directed<span class='line-break'> </span>me to inform you that the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation will contract to keep<span class='line-break'> </span>in perpetual repair and preser<span class='line-break'></span>vation lots numbered <a href='/pages/subjects/59193' title='Lot 457'><!--Lot-->457,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/59203' title='Lot 459'><!--Lot-->459</a><span class='line-break'> </span>and <a href='/pages/subjects/59195' title='Lot 480'><!--Lot-->480</a> in the Cemetery as the<span class='line-break'> </span>lowest rate fixed by the By-laws,<span class='line-break'> </span>viz. there hundred dollars for each<span class='line-break'> </span>lot.</p>
<p>I am very truly yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133496">
<h3><a name="page-1133496">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 004)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>4</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1860-12-26'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 26/60</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/80049' title='Richmond, Edward'>Edw<sup>d</sup> Richmond Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>You will remember<span class='line-break'> </span>that you once called at my<span class='line-break'> </span>office in reference to a suppozed<span class='line-break'> </span>encroachment of <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'><!--Mann-->the Sup<sup>t</sup> of Mt<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn</a> upon your lots. It<span class='line-break'> </span>now appears that he had done<span class='line-break'> </span>so, and I see by the order of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'><!--Bond-->the Treasuser</a> upon me for a <span class='line-break'> </span>new deed to you, that it is <span class='line-break'> </span>proposed to correct the mistake<span class='line-break'> </span>by refunding to you the price of<span class='line-break'> </span>the land which has been taken.</p>
<p>I have made a deed to you<span class='line-break'> </span>of 470 ft. Please bring to me<span class='line-break'> </span>your old deed, and reconvey of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation, and take the new<span class='line-break'> </span>deed.</p>
<p>Truly yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary<span class='line-break'> </span>Mt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1860-12-26'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 26, 1860</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59206' title='Lindsey, Alfred O.'>Mr Alfred O. Lindsey</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54284' title='Charlestown, MA'>Charlestown</a> Mass</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A long, long time<span class='line-break'> </span>ago you were to let me know<span class='line-break'> </span>about making a deed of the space<span class='line-break'> </span>around your lot- to whom the deed<span class='line-break'> </span>should be made. The year is just<span class='line-break'> </span>departing, and I wish to finish<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>every</ins> old matter. I cannot<span class='line-break'> </span>help charging you with <ins>some</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>negligence; for it was well under<span class='line-break'></span>stood between us that the thing<span class='line-break'> </span>should be finished up when<span class='line-break'> </span>last I saw you.</p>
<p>Will you attend to it this<span class='line-break'> </span>week.</p>
<p>Truly yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec<sup>y</sup> of Prop<sup>s</sup> Mt Auburn</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133497">
<h3><a name="page-1133497">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 005)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>5</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1860-12-31'>Dec 31 /60</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59206' title='Lindsey, Alfred O.'>Mr. A. O. Lindsey</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54284' title='Charlestown, MA'>Charlestown</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, I see<span class='line-break'> </span>that you do not yet apprehend <span class='line-break'> </span>the nature of the difficulty in making<span class='line-break'> </span>the deed. It is nothing as to title<span class='line-break'> </span>that your mother was designated <span class='line-break'> </span>to represent the lot -- that does not <span class='line-break'> </span>vest any title in her. I only wish <span class='line-break'> </span>to know the facts. If your father<span class='line-break'> </span>left no will, the deed should be<span class='line-break'> </span>made to the heirs at law. If he made<span class='line-break'> </span>one, just show me a copy, and<span class='line-break'> </span>I will advise you whether it <span class='line-break'> </span>ought to be made in the same<span class='line-break'> </span>way. The deed of the addition should<span class='line-break'> </span>be to the same person or persons<span class='line-break'> </span>that hold the original, by law.<span class='line-break'> </span>Your mother would still represent<span class='line-break'> </span>it, until the appointment should<span class='line-break'> </span>be received.</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133498">
<h3><a name="page-1133498">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 006)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>6</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-01-08'>Jany. 8<sup>th</sup> 61</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59210' title='Alger, Francis'>Francis Alger Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, Last month you<span class='line-break'> </span>had quite a number of removals<span class='line-break'> </span>made to your <a href='/pages/subjects/59216' title='Lot 2123'>lot <!--2123--></a>in Mt Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>which all appear to be correctly<span class='line-break'> </span>stated, excepting that relating to<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59211' title='French, Thomas N.'>Thomas N. French</a>, who died Jany. 4<span class='line-break'> </span>1847, which is deficient<span class='line-break'> </span>in respect to <ins>the age.</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>I wish to complete our reg<span class='line-break'></span>ister, and will thank you<span class='line-break'> </span>if you can furnish this item.</p>
<p>Truly yours,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary of M</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59212' title='Fuller, Mr.'>Mr. Fuller</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Inasmuch<span class='line-break'> </span>as the proper authorization<span class='line-break'> </span>from the City Regr. is attached<span class='line-break'> </span>to the order for interment herewith<span class='line-break'> </span>sent, which was signed by you.<span class='line-break'> </span>I have thought it better to send<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>this</ins> to you for <a href='/pages/subjects/61699' title='Sanborn, Mrs.'>Mrs Sanborn's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>signature, instead as a new<span class='line-break'> </span>blank. Consequently I have<span class='line-break'> </span>rubbed out your signature,<span class='line-break'> </span>which was with pencil, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>will thank you to obtain hers<span class='line-break'> </span>as early as convenient.</p>
<p>Truly Yours,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec<sup>y</sup> Mnt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St <span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-01-05'>Jany 5/61</date><span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133499">
<h3><a name="page-1133499">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 007)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>7</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>. <date when='1861-01-08'>Jany. 8/61</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59217' title='Sawin, Nathaniel D.'>Mr. Nath<sup>l</sup> D. Sawin</a>.</p>
<p>Dear Sir, Please send or <span class='line-break'> </span>leave word at my office, <ins>"by return<span class='line-break'> </span>of Mail,"</ins> the name of the parents<span class='line-break'> </span>of a stillborn child interred in<span class='line-break'> </span>your <a href='/pages/subjects/25004541' title='Lot 2911'>lot no. 2911</a>, in Mt Auburn, <span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1860-04-13'>April 13, 1860</date>.</p>
<p>We are making up the register<span class='line-break'> </span>of internments for the year, with<span class='line-break'> </span>the index, and the order for in<span class='line-break'></span>terment, signed by yourself,<span class='line-break'> </span>does not give this information,<span class='line-break'> </span>which is necessary to complete the<span class='line-break'> </span>record. My attention was called <span class='line-break'> </span>to it when making up the register<span class='line-break'> </span>for that month, but it had since<span class='line-break'> </span>escaped my recollection. There need<span class='line-break'> </span>be no feeling of delicacy in giving us<span class='line-break'> </span>information for the official record of<span class='line-break'> </span>facts.</p>
<p>Your reply as soon as convenient<span class='line-break'> </span>after getting this will oblige.</p>
<p>Yours truly <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary of Mt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-01-08'>Jany. 8. 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59219' title='Coburn, E. N., Mr.'>Mr E. N. Coburn</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, Will you<span class='line-break'> </span>please ascertain for me, if you<span class='line-break'> </span>do not know of your own know<span class='line-break'></span>ledge, the name of the father or<span class='line-break'> </span>mother of a stillborn child which<span class='line-break'> </span>you buried at Mt Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>on the <date when='1860-04-07'>7<sup>th</sup> day of April 1860</date>,<span class='line-break'> </span>in the lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/59220' title='Davis, Betsey'>Betsey Davis</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/59221' title='Lot 183'>No 183</a><span class='line-break'> </span>on <a href='/pages/subjects/59222' title='Larch Avenue'>Larch Avenue</a>. This name is<span class='line-break'> </span>not given in the order for inter<span class='line-break'></span>ment, which is signed by <a href='/pages/subjects/59223' title='Houghton, C.'>C. Hough<span class='line-break'></span>ton</a>. I should think, although it is hard<span class='line-break'> </span>to make it out. The order for <span class='line-break'> </span>interment should always give <span class='line-break'> </span>the ^<sup>name of the</sup> parent of such child, if the child<span class='line-break'> </span>received no name, which is more gen<span class='line-break'></span>erally the case.</p>
<p>Please reply by return of mail,<span class='line-break'> </span>as I am making up the index and am<span class='line-break'> </span>in haste to complete it.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>secretary of Mt Auburn</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133500">
<h3><a name="page-1133500">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 008)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>8</p>
<p>33 School St. , <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-01-10'>Jany. [10?] 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59224' title='Shedd, Varnun A., Mrs.'>Mrs V. A. Shedd</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53204' title='Watertown, MA'>Watertown</a> Mass</p>
<p>Dear Madam, I lately made<span class='line-break'> </span>a deed to you as proprietor of<span class='line-break'> </span>lot No. 3058 in Mt Auburn under<span class='line-break'> </span>the name of <a href='/pages/subjects/59224' title='Shedd, Varnun A., Mrs.'>Mrs <ins>Vernon</ins> A Shedd</a>.</p>
<p>In making up the register of interments,<span class='line-break'> </span>I have past discovered that the order<span class='line-break'> </span>for the interment of your husband gives<span class='line-break'> </span>him the name of <a href='/pages/subjects/59225' title='Shedd, Varnun A.'><ins>Varnum</ins> A Shedd</a>.</p>
<p>Of course one or the other must<span class='line-break'> </span>be wrong. Will you please state,<span class='line-break'> </span>by return of mail, which name<span class='line-break'> </span>is correct, and oblige</p>
<p>Yours truly<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-01-23'>Jany. 23/61</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/56692' title='Wadsworth, Alexander'>Alex<sup>r</sup> Wadsworth</a>, Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir, I have seen <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>Mann,</a> and sought an expla<span class='line-break'></span>nation of the changes made upon<span class='line-break'> </span>the plan, or rather, required to be<span class='line-break'> </span>made by his mistake in not <span class='line-break'> </span>using the old numbers. He says<span class='line-break'> </span>it was his mistake, which he sought<span class='line-break'> </span>to rectify at the Treasurer's office before<span class='line-break'> </span>the deeds were ordered, but found<span class='line-break'> </span>it was too late.</p>
<p>The <a href='/pages/subjects/59226' title='Lot 3013'>number 3013</a> has been given to<span class='line-break'> </span>what was <a href='/pages/subjects/59227' title='Lot 537'><!--Lot-->537</a> on Olive Path, and<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59228' title='Lot 3054'><!--Lot-->3054</a> to what was <a href='/pages/subjects/59229' title='Lot 2139'><!--Lot-->2139</a> (not<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59230' title='Lot 2137'><!--Lot-->2137</a> as you state) on Hibiscus Path.</p>
<p>As nobody has been harmed, <span class='line-break'> </span>I see no need of going to the Trus<span class='line-break'></span>tees -but simply to erase a <ins>location</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>opposite to the old numbers in the<span class='line-break'> </span>catalogue, and put the new number in<span class='line-break'> </span>the plan in place of the old. Nothing <span class='line-break'> </span>else now, of course, can be done.</p>
<p>If you are unwilling to make<span class='line-break'> </span>the change without a vote, please notify<span class='line-break'> </span>me before <ins>next</ins> Monday, and I will<span class='line-break'> </span>have you authorized.</p>
<p>Truly yours <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133501">
<h3><a name="page-1133501">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 009)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>9</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-01-28'>Jany. 28, 1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/56692' title='Wadsworth, Alexander'>Alex<sup>r</sup> Wadsworth Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,<span class='line-break'> </span>The following action<span class='line-break'> </span>was had at the meeting of the Trustees<span class='line-break'> </span>of Mt. Auburn, today, upon your<span class='line-break'> </span>request.-</p>
<p>"Upon information by the surveyor, <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/56692' title='Wadsworth, Alexander'>Mr. Wadsworth</a>, that <a href='/pages/subjects/59227' title='Lot 537'>lot numbered <span class='line-break'> </span>537</a> on <a href='/pages/subjects/59901' title='Olive Path'>Olive Path</a> had been sold <span class='line-break'> </span>as <a href='/pages/subjects/59226' title='Lot 3013'>lot 3013,</a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/59229' title='Lot 2139'>2139</a> on <a href='/pages/subjects/59902' title='Hibiscus Path'>Hibiscus <span class='line-break'> </span>Path</a> had been sold as <a href='/pages/subjects/59228' title='lot 3054'>lot 3054</a>, <span class='line-break'> </span>and that <a href='/pages/subjects/59903' title='Lot 2933'>lot 2933</a> had been re<span class='line-break'></span>moved from [Harebell?] Path to <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59904' title='Spruce Avenue'>Spruce Avenue</a>, and as deeds<span class='line-break'> </span>had been made accordingly.</p>
<p>Voted that <a href='/pages/subjects/56692' title='Wadsworth, Alexander'>Mr Wadsworth</a> <span class='line-break'> </span>be authorized to make the above <span class='line-break'> </span>named corrections upon the <span class='line-break'> </span>plans."</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-01-28'>Jany. 28. 1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54774' title='Little, Charles C.'>Messrs Little</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>&amp; Nazro,</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Com<sup>ee</sup> on Finance</p>
<p>Gentlemen, at the adjourned <span class='line-break'> </span>meeting of the Trustees of this cem<span class='line-break'></span>etery of Mount Auburn held <span class='line-break'> </span>this day, the Treasurer stated that <span class='line-break'> </span>the care of the <ins>repair fund</ins> had be<span class='line-break'></span>come somewhat onerous without <span class='line-break'> </span>any compensation being allowed <span class='line-break'> </span>him therefor: and he requested the <span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees to consider whether any<span class='line-break'></span>thing should be allowed him <span class='line-break'> </span>for that duty.</p>
<p>Voted - therefor<span class='line-break'></span>That this question be referred to <span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee on Finance, to report<span class='line-break'> </span>thereon at the next meeting.</p>
<p>Very respectfully yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133502">
<h3><a name="page-1133502">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 010)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>10</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-02-02'>Feby 2/61</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59908' title='White, Charles'>Mr Char. White</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59911' title='Chelsea, MA'>Chelsea Mass</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, I send you an<span class='line-break'> </span>order from the interment of the<span class='line-break'> </span>late <a href='/pages/subjects/59910' title='Cobb, William'>W<sup>m</sup> Cobb</a>, which you <span class='line-break'> </span>returned without the signature of<span class='line-break'> </span>any one who could be authorized<span class='line-break'> </span>to sign upon the [disease?] of the prop<sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>and will thank you, if any of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59910' title='Cobb, William'>Mr. Cobb's</a> family are living<span class='line-break'> </span>in <a href='/pages/subjects/59911' title='Chelsea, MA'>Chelsea</a>, to have it signed<span class='line-break'> </span>and returned to me.</p>
<p>If no one is living there, I<span class='line-break'> </span>will thank you to inform me <span class='line-break'> </span>where I can address the family,<span class='line-break'> </span>or next of kin.</p>
<p>Please always be partic<span class='line-break'></span>ular to have the order for<span class='line-break'> </span>internment signed by the pro<span class='line-break'></span>prieter or a person having proper<span class='line-break'> </span>authority.  If you have not a<span class='line-break'> </span>copy of our Catalogue and By-laws,<span class='line-break'> </span>call <a href='/pages/subjects/59912' title='Cohen'>Cohen</a> in [town?] &amp; you shall<span class='line-break'> </span>have one. Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Secy. Mt. A.</p>
<p>33 School St, <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-02-01'>Feby 1</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/72709' title='Eaton, Joseph B.'>Jos. B. Eaton Esq</a><span class='line-break'> </span>117 Milk St</p>
<p>Dear Sir,<span class='line-break'> </span>I am instructed<span class='line-break'> </span>by the Committee on Lots before whom<span class='line-break'> </span>your application to <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>C.P. Curtis Esq</a><span class='line-break'> </span>has been laid, to say that the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation will assume the<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual care of <a href='/pages/subjects/59914' title='Lot 345'>Lot No. 345</a><span class='line-break'> </span>in Mt Auburn, standing in the<span class='line-break'> </span>name of <a href='/pages/subjects/59915' title='Gale, Lydia S.'>Lydia S. Gale</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>for the sum of three hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>and fifty dollars $350.</p>
<p>I am<span class='line-break'> </span>very respy. yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Prop<sup>s</sup> Mt Auburn</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133503">
<h3><a name="page-1133503">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 011)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-02-09'>March 9 /61</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59925' title='Bernard, J. M.'>J.M. Bernard</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir, I have inquired <span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a> with regard<span class='line-break'> </span>to your bill for foundation,<span class='line-break'> </span>and ascertained what the usual<span class='line-break'> </span>charges are to others, at only fair<span class='line-break'> </span>rates; and am satisfied that the<span class='line-break'> </span>charge to you is not high, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>that it cannot be done for<span class='line-break'> </span>much less without a loss to the cor<span class='line-break'></span>poration. I am satisfied that<span class='line-break'> </span>you have been entirely misled<span class='line-break'> </span>by <a href='/pages/subjects/59926' title='Wentworth, Mr.'>Mr. Wentworth</a> as to the propriety<span class='line-break'> </span>of the charge; but inasmuch as<span class='line-break'> </span>you have obtained the idea <span class='line-break'> </span>that the charge is exorbitant, for<span class='line-break'> </span>the sake of satisfying you, I will<span class='line-break'> </span>put the bill at the lowest possible<span class='line-break'> </span>figure, and call it thirteen dollars.</p>
<p>This will afford us profit, but I<span class='line-break'> </span>hope will satisfy you.</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133504">
<h3><a name="page-1133504">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 012)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>12</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-04-05'>April 5, 1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jona. Mann Esq</a>.<span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup> Mt Auburn Cemetery</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The special Com<sup>ee</sup> to which<span class='line-break'> </span>has been referred the matter of inves<span class='line-break'></span>tigating the Superintendent's accounts &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>books, have directed me to request<span class='line-break'> </span>your presence at an adjourned<span class='line-break'> </span>meeting of the Board of Trustees, to <span class='line-break'> </span>be held at this office on Monday<span class='line-break'> </span>the <date when='1861-04-08T15:30:00'>8<sup>th</sup> day of April, at <ins>3 1/2</ins> o'clock<span class='line-break'> </span>p.m.</date> prepared to answer to <span class='line-break'> </span>charges contained in a report of<span class='line-break'> </span>said committee, to wit:__<span class='line-break'> </span>"That <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Jonathan Mann</a>, the<span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent, has paid bills for<span class='line-break'> </span>articles furnished to the Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>on which large discounts have<span class='line-break'> </span>been allowed in settlement for the<span class='line-break'> </span>bills with <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a> when said <span class='line-break'> </span>discount was not entered on the</p>
<p>bill, but it was receipted for the<span class='line-break'> </span>full amount, as first rendered:-<span class='line-break'> </span>that an examination of the books<span class='line-break'> </span>in reference to particular bills <span class='line-break'> </span>shows that the full amount or <span class='line-break'> </span>[part?] of the bills have been<span class='line-break'> </span>charged to the Corporation, while<span class='line-break'> </span>there appears to be no discount <span class='line-break'> </span>or allowance on said bills<span class='line-break'> </span>credited:-</p>
<p>That this charge, unless disproved<span class='line-break'> </span>by <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a>, shows that he has<span class='line-break'> </span>acted an direct violation of a well<span class='line-break'> </span>known by-law of the Corporation."</p>
<p>Respectfully yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133505">
<h3><a name="page-1133505">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 013)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>13</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-04-06'>April 6. 1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59933' title='Brewer, Gardner'>Gardner Brewer</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your recent application<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Trustees of the Cemetery of Mount Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>for permission to ride into the grounds on horse<span class='line-break'></span>back, from time to time was duly presented to<span class='line-break'> </span>the Board; and I can best acquaint you with<span class='line-break'> </span>their action thereore by sending you the accompan<span class='line-break'> </span>nying <ins>blank </ins> card of admission with the rules<span class='line-break'> </span>annexed thereto, which I trust you may find<span class='line-break'> </span>satisfactory. You will perceive the Board was<span class='line-break'> </span>anxious to make a rule which should be appli<span class='line-break'></span>cable to all cases.-</p>
<p>If this shall meet your views, I shall be<span class='line-break'> </span>ready at any time to give you the needful authority.</p>
<p>I am<span class='line-break'> </span>very respy your [?]<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133506">
<h3><a name="page-1133506">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 014)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-04-06'>April 6, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59938' title='Bacon, John'>Dr John Bacon</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>In reference to your<span class='line-break'> </span>inquiry for what sum the Trustees<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Cemetery of Mount Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>would assume the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>care of your <a href='/pages/subjects/59939' title='Lot 2354'>lot numbered 2354</a>,-<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee on Lots have<span class='line-break'> </span>instructed me to inform you, that<span class='line-break'> </span>they have had the same under<span class='line-break'> </span>consideration, and will contract<span class='line-break'> </span>with you for three hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars. -</p>
<p>Very respectfully &amp; truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-05-06'>April 6, 1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>C. P. Curtis Esq</a>.<span class='line-break'> </span>Chairman Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The reply of the Com<sup>ee</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots to the inquiry for what<span class='line-break'> </span>sum the Trustees will assume the <span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual care of the <a href='/pages/subjects/60690' title='Warren, Pelham W.'>Pelham W. Warren</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59940' title='Lot 1030'>lot (no. 1030)</a>, also <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a>'s note<span class='line-break'> </span>advising that it be first put in<span class='line-break'> </span>order by grading and sodding at<span class='line-break'> </span>an expense of $20, has been received.<span class='line-break'> </span>This would require $200 in addition<span class='line-break'> </span>to the $100 already devoted to the lot.-</p>
<p>If you can find means to bring the<span class='line-break'> </span>condition of the lot and these facts to<span class='line-break'> </span>the attention of the <a href='/pages/subjects/59941' title='Warren, Charles H.'>Hon. Chas. H. Warren</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>as I the other day suggested in conver<span class='line-break'></span>sation with you, perhaps something<span class='line-break'> </span>may be done. <a href='/pages/subjects/64112' title='Goodwin, William W.'>Mr W<sup>m</sup> W. Goodwin</a> of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59943' title='Harvard College'>Harv. Coll.</a> assured me that any funds<span class='line-break'> </span>from which to increase this appropriation<span class='line-break'> </span>were entirely wanting.</p>
<p>Very respectfully yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>14<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133507">
<h3><a name="page-1133507">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 015)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>15</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-04-09'>April 9, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jona. Mann Esq</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup> Mt Auburn Cemetery</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your communication of this date<span class='line-break'> </span>was laid before the Board of Trustees,<span class='line-break'> </span>upon which it was voted -<span class='line-break'> </span>That this Board will hear any explana<span class='line-break'></span>tion from <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a>, whenever the President<span class='line-break'> </span>shall call a meeting for that purpose - <span class='line-break'> </span>that he shall have free access to the books<span class='line-break'> </span>at this office, and that the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>investigation of his accounts shall furnish<span class='line-break'> </span>him, so far as they may be able, with spec<span class='line-break'></span>ifications of the charges made against him.</p>
<p>The following votes were also adopted,<span class='line-break'> </span>"That from and after this date <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a><span class='line-break'> </span>be instructed not to receive or pay any money<span class='line-break'> </span>for account of the Corporation, and also that <span class='line-break'> </span>he shall make no contracts without the<span class='line-break'> </span>knowledge and approval of the Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots, until further order of this Board.</p>
<p>(over)</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133508">
<h3><a name="page-1133508">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 016)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>16</p>
<p>"Voted, that the Committee chosen to investi<span class='line-break'></span>gate the Superindentant's accounts be author<span class='line-break'></span>ized to appoint temporarily, a clerk or <span class='line-break'> </span>clerks to receive and disburse moneys<span class='line-break'> </span>at Mount Auburn, and a person to <span class='line-break'> </span>take charge of the <a href='/pages/subjects/57664' title='Entrance Gateway'><!--entrance-->Gate</a>."</p>
<p>Respy &amp; truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133509">
<h3><a name="page-1133509">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 017)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>17</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when=''>May 6, 1860</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jon<sup>a</sup> Mann</a> Esq, Sup<sup>t</sup> &amp; [?] -</p>
<p>Dear Sirs,</p>
<p>By^<sup>reading</sup> the following action of the Board<span class='line-break'> </span>of Trustees of Mount Auburn, at the monthly meeting<span class='line-break'> </span>held this day, you will receive notice from me.</p>
<p>A communication was read from <a href='/pages/subjects/79959' title='Smith, Jerome V. C.'>Dr J.V.C Smith</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>to the affect that he had been informed by <a href='/pages/subjects/59951' title='Lunt, E. L., Mr.'>Mr E.L. Lunt</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>a painter, that <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a>, the Superintendent, had demanded<span class='line-break'> </span>of him a percentage on his labor there, for the privilege<span class='line-break'> </span>allowed him of working on the premises. -</p>
<p>Upon motion by <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a>, it was voted<span class='line-break'> </span>that when this meeting adjourn, it be next Monday,<span class='line-break'> </span>at 10 oclock A.M. to hear such testimony as the said<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59951' title='Lunt, E. L., Mr.'>E.L. Lunt</a> may give in regard to the allegation said to be<span class='line-break'> </span>made by him, and for the transaction of any other business<span class='line-break'> </span>that may come before the Board; and that the Secretary<span class='line-break'> </span>be directed to require the attendance of <a href='/pages/subjects/59951' title='Lunt, E. L., Mr.'>Mr Lunt</a> on the<span class='line-break'> </span>day, and also to notify <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a> that he will be<span class='line-break'> </span>expected to attend that meeting, and make <del>his</del> answer<span class='line-break'> </span>to the above named charge, and to the following charges -<span class='line-break'> </span>to wit; of short credits in the following accounts viz. of <a href='/pages/subjects/59952' title='Thayer, Nathaniel'>Nathan<span class='line-break'></span>iel Thayer</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/59953' title='Drake, Tisdale'>Tisdale Drake</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/59954' title='Cooper, R. W. T.'>R.W.T. Cooper</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/59955' title='Reed, Benjamin T.'>Benj. T.<span class='line-break'> </span>Reed</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/25005796' title='Whall, Joseph B.'>J.B. Whall's</a> Estate, and <a href='/pages/subjects/55006' title='Wales, Thomas B.'>T.B. Wales</a>; and of receiving<span class='line-break'> </span>compensation for his services from <a href='/pages/subjects/59958' title='Borland, John'>John Borland</a>.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133510">
<h3><a name="page-1133510">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 018)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>18</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-05-07'>May 7. 1861.</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59951' title='Lunt, E. L., Mr.'>Mr E.L. Lunt</a>,</p>
<p>Sir,</p>
<p>By a vote of the Trustees of the <span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery of Mount Auburn, at a meeting held<span class='line-break'> </span>yesterday, I was directed to request your attend<span class='line-break'></span>ance at an adjourned meeting of their Board,<span class='line-break'> </span>to be held on <date when='1861-05-13T10:00:00'>Monday next (13<sup>th</sup>next) at<span class='line-break'> </span>10 o'clock A.M.</date> at this office, no. 51 Niles<span class='line-break'> </span>Block, (entrance 33 School St.) to state what<span class='line-break'> </span>you know in regard to any demand at<span class='line-break'> </span>any time made by <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jonathan Mann</a>, the Super<span class='line-break'></span>intendent of said Cemetery, of any person<span class='line-break'> </span>or persons, in the nature of a commission<span class='line-break'> </span>upon work done by them in the Cemetery on<span class='line-break'> </span>account of individual proprietors: And I was<span class='line-break'> </span>further directed to inform you that you would<span class='line-break'> </span>be paid for your time.</p>
<p>You will please be particularly careful to<span class='line-break'> </span>communicate with no one upon this subject.</p>
<p>Your attendance at the time and place will <span class='line-break'> </span>be depended on.</p>
<p>By order of the Board,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133511">
<h3><a name="page-1133511">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 019)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>19</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-05-15'>May 15, 1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jonathan Mann</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your communication of<span class='line-break'> </span>this date addresssed to the Trustees of Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn Cemetery was laid before the Board<span class='line-break'> </span>at their meeting this afternoon, and the fol<span class='line-break'></span>lowing was their action thereon.</p>
<p>Voted that the resignation of <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jona. Mann</a><span class='line-break'> </span>as Superintendent of Mount Auburn be<span class='line-break'> </span>accepted, this Board having no reference by<span class='line-break'> </span>this act to any other portion of the subject<span class='line-break'> </span>matter of <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a>'s communication of this<span class='line-break'> </span>date, in which his resignation is tendered.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a> stated that he was informed by<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59961' title='Merwin, Mr.'>Mr Merwin</a>, counsel for <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a>, that <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>Mann</a> was ready to serve the Trustees until the works<span class='line-break'> </span>in progress at Mount Aubrun should be completed,<span class='line-break'> </span>if such was the pleasure of the Trustees: - and</p>
<p>Upon motion by <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a>, it was<span class='line-break'> </span>voted that the Committee on Grounds be authorized<span class='line-break'> </span>to employ <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a>, or any other person, as they may<span class='line-break'> </span>see fit, until the further order of this Board.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133512">
<h3><a name="page-1133512">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 020)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-05-16'>May 16/61</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59967' title='Carnes, N. G.'>N. G. Carnes Esq.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of Ap. 25<sup>th</sup>, with<span class='line-break'> </span>Mount Auburn bills enclosed, was<span class='line-break'> </span>only rec<sup>d</sup>. In behalf of the Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>that addressed you I will say that<span class='line-break'> </span>the legers do not show any other im<span class='line-break'></span>portant bills, and unless you<span class='line-break'> </span>have since found others, you need<span class='line-break'> </span>not be at the trouble to examine.<span class='line-break'> </span>I return the bill of $144.50 which<span class='line-break'> </span>I find correct.</p>
<p>I have asked the Superintendant<span class='line-break'> </span>as to the bill of $14. He says it was<span class='line-break'> </span>intended for you, and that he<span class='line-break'> </span>confounded your name with<span class='line-break'> </span>another on our catalogue. I <span class='line-break'> </span>therefore make a copy with your<span class='line-break'> </span>name, and enclose, which I<span class='line-break'> </span>will receipt for you when you<span class='line-break'> </span>remit.</p>
<p>Very truly yours,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-05-16'>May 16, 1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span>33 School St</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59964' title='Sanderson, Ede, Mrs.'>Mrs Ede Sanderson</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>Your request to know for<span class='line-break'> </span>what sum the Trustees of<span class='line-break'> </span>Mount Auburn Cemetery would<span class='line-break'> </span>assume the perpetual care of<span class='line-break'> </span>your <a href='/pages/subjects/59965' title='Lot 1883'>lot, No. 1833</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/59966' title='Acanthus Path'>Acanthus<span class='line-break'> </span>Path</a>, was duly laid before the<span class='line-break'> </span>Committee on Lots, who have<span class='line-break'> </span>charge of the subject, and they<span class='line-break'> </span>have directed me to inform you<span class='line-break'> </span>that the Corporation will contract<span class='line-break'> </span>with you for the perpetual repair<span class='line-break'> </span>of said lot for the sum of<span class='line-break'> </span>three hundred dollars.</p>
<p>At any time when you shall signify<span class='line-break'> </span>it, I shall be ready to prepare the<span class='line-break'> </span>necessary document for your signa<span class='line-break'></span>ture.</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133513">
<h3><a name="page-1133513">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 021)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-05-18'>May 18/61</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59967' title='Carnes, N. G.'>N.G. Carnes</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of yesterday is at<span class='line-break'> </span>hand. As the Superintendant has<span class='line-break'> </span>resigned, and the amt. stated in<span class='line-break'> </span>the bill sent is the same for the<span class='line-break'> </span>year 1860, as the one sent you,<span class='line-break'> </span>I take the responsibility to say<span class='line-break'> </span>that I will receipt their bill &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>the one for 1859: and I doubt<span class='line-break'> </span>not that the charge for 1860 is<span class='line-break'> </span>the one I sent you was intended<span class='line-break'> </span>to cover the item of painting.</p>
<p>I will return the receipted<span class='line-break'> </span>bills upon the arrival of your<span class='line-break'> </span>check for $64, on some bank or <span class='line-break'> </span>[brokerage?] here or in Mass. bills.</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-05-16'>May 16, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60426' title='Safford, De Forest'>Mr. De Forest Safford</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Gatekeeper, pro tem,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have this day issued <span class='line-break'> </span>a ticket to <a href='/pages/subjects/59970' title='Brewer, Andrew'>Andrew Brewer</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Esq. permitting him to ride into <span class='line-break'> </span>Mt Auburn on horseback <span class='line-break'> </span>for the term of one year. You <span class='line-break'> </span>therefore please open to him if <span class='line-break'> </span>he is personally known to you,<span class='line-break'> </span>otherwise he will show you his <span class='line-break'> </span>ticket once.</p>
<p>I send one of the <ins> blank </ins>per<span class='line-break'></span>mits that you can see under <span class='line-break'> </span>what rules such admission <span class='line-break'> </span>has been granted</p>
<p>Respy. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J.Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>21<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133514">
<h3><a name="page-1133514">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 022)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>The two next leaves had matter copied<span class='line-break'> </span>on them belonging to another book, by accident,<span class='line-break'> </span>and have been transferred [?].</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59967' title='Carnes, N. G.'>N.G. Carnes</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-05-21'>May 21, 1861</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of yesterday is<span class='line-break'> </span>rec<sup>d</sup>. I perceive that I did not<span class='line-break'> </span>take your meaning from your last<span class='line-break'> </span>note. Your inference is that as $2 of<span class='line-break'> </span>the $7 in 1859 was for painting, that'll<span class='line-break'> </span>care of the lot for 1860, <ins>without</ins> painting<span class='line-break'> </span>sh<sup>d</sup> be [both?] $5. Inferences are uncertain<span class='line-break'> </span>things. I notice in the 1860 bill the ex<span class='line-break'></span>pression <ins>"Bedding plants"</ins> &amp; care of lot,<span class='line-break'> </span>now I do not know that <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'><!--Mann-->the Superinten<span class='line-break'></span>dent</a> did not mean to charge you the<span class='line-break'> </span>additional $2 for the care of the plants in<span class='line-break'> </span>winter; nor do I know that he <ins>did</ins>.</p>
<p>In the absence of any positive infor<span class='line-break'></span>mation on the matter, I think we<span class='line-break'> </span>may as ^<sup>well</sup> settle it as you have under<span class='line-break'></span>stood it, without however making <span class='line-break'> </span>this any precedent for future char<span class='line-break'></span>ges.</p>
<p>I enclose the card of our new <ins>gar<span class='line-break'></span>dener</ins> - an office additional to Superintendent of<span class='line-break'> </span>lots is well spoken of &amp; I doubt not would<span class='line-break'> </span>do rightly by you, if you wish to commit<span class='line-break'> </span>the care of your lot to him.</p>
<p>Very truly yrs<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>22</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133515">
<h3><a name="page-1133515">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 025)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>Boston <date when='1861-07-03'>July 3, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr J. Mann</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a><span class='line-break'> </span>has asked me to request you<span class='line-break'> </span>to send him a plan of<span class='line-break'> </span>the additions to <a href='/pages/subjects/59977' title='Towne, William B.'>W<sup>m</sup> B. Towne's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>lot, which were paid for in<span class='line-break'> </span>June 1859 - having been reported<span class='line-break'> </span>as "350 ft. for passageways and<span class='line-break'> </span>ornamental ground."</p>
<p>Please give the measurements<span class='line-break'> </span>of each - their length and width,<span class='line-break'> </span>distinguishing between passageways<span class='line-break'> </span>and ornamental ground, so that<span class='line-break'> </span>it can be known how much<span class='line-break'> </span>is for each.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>25</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133516">
<h3><a name="page-1133516">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 026)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>26</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-08-06'>August 6<sup>th</sup> 1861</date>.<span class='line-break'> </span>Mr. <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jonathan Mann</a>,</p>
<p>Sir,</p>
<p>By instruction of the Board of<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees of The Proprietors of the Cemetery of<span class='line-break'> </span>Mount Auburn, "I enclose to you herewith a<span class='line-break'> </span>copy of the Report of the Committee of said Board<span class='line-break'> </span>appointed to examine the books kept and the<span class='line-break'> </span>accounts rendered by you as Superintendent, in<span class='line-break'> </span>which Report there is claimed to be due from you <span class='line-break'> </span>to the said Corporation, the sum of  <ins> nine thousand<span class='line-break'> </span>five hundred and thirty eight dollars and sixty three cents,</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>($9,538.63).</p>
<p>I have also appended to the aforesaid copy a copy<span class='line-break'> </span>of the votes theron adopted by said Board.</p>
<p>In obedience therefore to my instructions, you <span class='line-break'> </span>are hereby required by me in the same and on<span class='line-break'> </span>behalf of the Corporation, to pay over to said Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>the aforesaid sum of <ins> nine thousand five hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>and thirty eight dollars and sixty three cents.<span class='line-break'> </span>($9,538.63)</ins>.  In so doing, the Treasurer will allow<span class='line-break'> </span>you any sum which you may have placed in<span class='line-break'> </span>his hands on account of any deficiency which <span class='line-break'> </span>should be discovered in your accounts with said<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133517">
<h3><a name="page-1133517">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 027)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>27</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'><!--Jonathan Mann-->You</a> will perceive from the action of the Trustees<span class='line-break'> </span>that the examination of the books is to be continued <span class='line-break'> </span>until completed, and you will therefore please hold  <span class='line-break'> </span>yourself in readiness to pay over any other moneys<span class='line-break'> </span>that may hereafter, in said examination, be  <span class='line-break'> </span>found to be due from you to said Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation.  </p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133518">
<h3><a name="page-1133518">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 028)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-09-18'>Sept <sup>r</sup> 18.1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/80051' title='Raymond, Freeborn F.'>F F Raymond</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have with <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'><!--Winsor-->the<span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent</a> measured your brother's<span class='line-break'> </span>lot in Mt Auburn.</p>
<p>It measures across the front <span class='line-break'> </span>and rear <ins>inside</ins> of the curb -<span class='line-break'> </span>17 feet and the two sides are<span class='line-break'> </span>21 feet strong. i.e. 21x17=357f.</p>
<p>This is off more than was<span class='line-break'> </span>reported as sold to <a href='/pages/subjects/64173' title='Raymond, Thatcher R.'>Mr Raymond</a>, <span class='line-break'> </span>as an addition. The curb is of ex<span class='line-break'></span>pensive work, and of course he<span class='line-break'> </span>must have known that he had<span class='line-break'> </span>enclosed some fifty feet over his first<span class='line-break'> </span>purchase.</p>
<p>You will not expect the lot to be<span class='line-break'> </span>good without a deed of this: nor<span class='line-break'> </span>can it be expected that the Corp<sup>n</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>will relinquish their claim to pay.</p>
<p>As the by-laws protect any gra<span class='line-break'></span>tuitous disposition of lots, or land.</p>
<p>Yours truly<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133519">
<h3><a name="page-1133519">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 029)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-10-17'>Oct. 17, 1861.</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59981' title='Penniman, George'>Geo Penniman</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup> <a href='/pages/subjects/66004' title='Granite Railway Company'>Granite Railway Co.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have been instructed to<span class='line-break'> </span>forward you a copy of a vote of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Trustees of Mount Auburn Cem<span class='line-break'></span>etery, passed at a meeting of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Board <date when='1861-10-07'>Oct. 7, 1861</date>. - which is<span class='line-break'> </span>as follows: -</p>
<p>"Voted that the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Grounds be instructed by the<span class='line-break'> </span>Board to give notice to the con<span class='line-break'></span>tractors for the granite front of<span class='line-break'> </span>the <a href='/pages/subjects/59983' title='Hazel Dell'>new catacomb tombs</a> in<span class='line-break'> </span>course of construction between<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59984' title='Rosebay Avenue'>Rosebay<!--Ave--></a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/59985' title='Culvert Avenue'>Culvert Ave<span class='line-break'></span>nues</a>, that this Corporation <span class='line-break'> </span>will not accept said granite<span class='line-break'> </span>front on account of imperfections<span class='line-break'> </span>in the stones, and for defective<span class='line-break'> </span>construction."</p>
<p>I am<span class='line-break'> </span>Resp.y yours,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>Austin J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary of Mount Aub.<span class='line-break'> </span>Cem.ly</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-09-18'>Sept<sup>r</sup> 18, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59986' title='Bacon, William B.'>W<sup>m</sup>. B. Bacon</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>It appears from<span class='line-break'> </span>a recent interment in <a href='/pages/subjects/59987' title='Bacon, Danielo G.'>Mr D.G. Bacon's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>lot in Mt Auburn, that your<span class='line-break'> </span>numbers upon the lot have not<span class='line-break'> </span>been made to correspond with<span class='line-break'> </span>those of your deeds, and as in the<span class='line-break'> </span>Catalogue of Proprietors. I have<span class='line-break'> </span>ascertained that the numbers<span class='line-break'> </span>have been cut upon the Stone;<span class='line-break'> </span>hence it is impracticable to attempt<span class='line-break'> </span>correction there.</p>
<p>The only course, therefore, left<span class='line-break'> </span>for you is to transfer your deed<span class='line-break'> </span>to your brother, &amp; he the same to<span class='line-break'> </span>you. Unless you do this, some<span class='line-break'> </span>future interment will be the occasion<span class='line-break'> </span>of a mortifying blunder by opening a<span class='line-break'> </span>grave in the wrong lot.</p>
<p>I will attend to the matter for<span class='line-break'> </span>you at any time; but shall have<span class='line-break'> </span>to charge you for the<span class='line-break'> </span>record.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
<p>29</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133520">
<h3><a name="page-1133520">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 030)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-11-02'>Novem<sup>r</sup> 2. 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59990' title='Willis, Stillman'>Stillman Willis</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you authorize <span class='line-break'> </span>me to let <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a>, our<span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup>, have four 8 inch<span class='line-break'> </span>granite posts set on the<span class='line-break'> </span>corners of your 6 lots on<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/55287' title='Lawn Avenue'>Lawn Avenue</a> - <a href='/pages/subjects/59991' title='Lot 2940'>2940</a> to<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59992' title='Lot 2945'>2945</a> inclusive, that your<span class='line-break'> </span>bounds may be established.</p>
<p>We have sold the last lot<span class='line-break'> </span>left on <a href='/pages/subjects/59993' title='Laburnum Path'>Laburnum Path</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>and wish to have all these<span class='line-break'> </span>lots put on the new survey:<span class='line-break'> </span>but wooden sticks are very liable<span class='line-break'> </span>to be misplaced.</p>
<p>The expense to you will not <span class='line-break'> </span>exceed $10. -</p>
<p>Please reply and oblige.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-10-24'>Oct. 24, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59994' title='Foss, Jacob'>Jacob Foss</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54284' title='Charlestown, MA'>Charlestown</a>.</p>
<p>Dear Sir, I am <span class='line-break'> </span>instructed by the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots in the Cemetery of Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn to notify you that<span class='line-break'> </span>they have considered your<span class='line-break'> </span>application in reference to the<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>perpetual</ins> care of <a href='/pages/subjects/59995' title='Lot 719'>lots 719</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/59996' title='Lot 720'>&amp; 720,</a><span class='line-break'> </span>and that they will in behalf<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation contract with<span class='line-break'> </span>you for such care of <a href='/pages/subjects/59995' title='lot 719'>lot 719</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>for the sum of $600, and <span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/59996' title='lot 720'>lot 720</a> for the sum of<span class='line-break'> </span>$400.</p>
<p>I am very respectfully<span class='line-break'> </span>Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>30</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133521">
<h3><a name="page-1133521">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 031)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a> has asked<span class='line-break'> </span>me to write you a note,<span class='line-break'> </span>inquiring whether it is <span class='line-break'> </span>true that the work was done<span class='line-break'> </span>upon the Bradford lot<span class='line-break'> </span>without your knowledge.</p>
<p>As there is a meeting next<span class='line-break'> </span>Monday, when <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a><span class='line-break'> </span>proposes to bring up this<span class='line-break'> </span>matter, with a view to afford<span class='line-break'> </span>the <a href='/pages/subjects/59998' title='Tileston, Sarah A.'>Tileston</a>'s some remedy,<span class='line-break'> </span>your reply before that will<span class='line-break'> </span>much oblige him.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secy</p>
<p>Please address your answer to me.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-10-31'>Oct 31, 1861</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jona. Mann Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59998' title='Tileston, Sarah A.'>Miss Sarah A.<span class='line-break'> </span>Tileston</a>, prop<sup>r</sup> or daughter of the<span class='line-break'> </span>prop<sup>r</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/59999' title='Lot 2317'>lot 2317</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/60000' title='Sylvan Path'>Sylvan Path</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>but which fronts towards <a href='/pages/subjects/60001' title='Walnut Avenue'>Walnut<span class='line-break'> </span>Avenue</a>, has written <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>complaining of the obstruction<span class='line-break'> </span>to a passage way from 2<sup>d</sup> Avenue<span class='line-break'> </span>to this lot by means of the<span class='line-break'> </span>manner in which the lot of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60002' title='Bradford, Alden'>Alden Bradford</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/60003' title='Lot 176'>no 176</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/60001' title='Walnut Avenue'>Walnut<span class='line-break'> </span>Avenue</a>, is enclosed. - <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>Curtis</a> was informed by <a href='/pages/subjects/59998' title='Tileston, Sarah A.'>Miss<span class='line-break'> </span>Tileston</a> that you expressed<span class='line-break'> </span>surprize at seeing the <a href='/pages/subjects/60002' title='Bradford, Alden'>Bradford</a><span class='line-break'> </span>posts set as they were, and<span class='line-break'> </span>gave her to understand that<span class='line-break'> </span>you were not consulted<span class='line-break'> </span>about it, and were<span class='line-break'> </span>ignorant of it at the time.</p>
<p>31</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133522">
<h3><a name="page-1133522">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 032)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-11-12'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 12/61</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60004' title='Brigham, O. A., Mr.'>Mr O.A. Brigham</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'><!--Winsor-->The Superintendent</a><span class='line-break'> </span>has requested me to say to you<span class='line-break'> </span>that he cannot give you a square<span class='line-break'> </span>lot where you staked on <a href='/pages/subjects/60005' title='Pyrola Path'>Pyrola<span class='line-break'> </span>Path</a> without pushing your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>westward about <ins>four feet</ins>,<span class='line-break'> </span>as the curvature of the path makes<span class='line-break'> </span>an angle there which would be<span class='line-break'> </span>wasted unless more space is<span class='line-break'> </span>preserved to make a triangular<span class='line-break'> </span>lot between you and the next lot<span class='line-break'> </span>eastward.</p>
<p>He will not therefore stake it out<span class='line-break'> </span>until he hears further from<span class='line-break'> </span>you.-</p>
<p>As I do not find your name<span class='line-break'> </span>in the Directory, I am obliged to write<span class='line-break'> </span>instead of seeing you and explaining.</p>
<p>Please call in &amp; see me, or go and<span class='line-break'> </span>see him at your earliest con<span class='line-break'></span>venience.</p>
<p>Yours respy.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
