<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-11-07'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 7, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60006' title='Upham, Francis W.'>Mr Francis W. Upham</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A deed of a<span class='line-break'> </span>lot of land in Mt Auburn,<span class='line-break'> </span>from <a href='/pages/subjects/60007' title='Shannon, Abbie M.'>Abbie M. Shannon</a> to your<span class='line-break'></span>self was left at my office more<span class='line-break'> </span>than a year and a half since<span class='line-break'> </span>for record. As the transfer<span class='line-break'> </span>does not give your location,<span class='line-break'> </span>and as I was out of the office at<span class='line-break'> </span>the time, the deed was left, I have <span class='line-break'> </span>never been able to complete<span class='line-break'> </span>the record, nor to return you<span class='line-break'> </span>the deed.</p>
<p>If this note reaches you,<span class='line-break'> </span>please call and get your<span class='line-break'> </span>deed.</p>
<p>Yours respy.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt Auburn</p>
<p>32</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133523">
<h3><a name="page-1133523">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 033)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-11-12'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 12/61 </date></p>
<p>Mr <a href='/pages/subjects/60011' title='Wellington, Andrew'>Andrew Wellington</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60012' title='Winchester, MA'>Winchester, Mass.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, I find that <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'><!--Winsor-->the Superintendent of Mt Auburn</a> has<span class='line-break'> </span>reported ^<sup>an addition to</sup> <del>a</del> lot to <a href='/pages/subjects/60013' title='Nichols, Jacob J.'>Jacob J. Nichols</a> -<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60014' title='Lot 350'>Lot 350</a> on <a href='/pages/subjects/54338' title='Indian Ridge Path'>Indian Ridge Path</a>.</p>
<p>This lot stands on our record<span class='line-break'> </span>in name of <a href='/pages/subjects/60015' title='Wellington, Peter'>Peter Wellington</a> <span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/60016' title='East Lexington, MA'>E. Lexington</a>, and I do not<span class='line-break'> </span>find on our record any evi<span class='line-break'></span>dence of his decease: until which<span class='line-break'> </span>event, no deed can be made<span class='line-break'> </span>to another party, unless he trans<span class='line-break'></span>fers his lot to such party, first; as <span class='line-break'> </span>our charter makes lots indivisible.</p>
<p>If the deed of the addition sh<sup>d</sup> be made<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/60013' title='Nichols, Jacob J.'>Mr Nichols</a>, you perceive the title<span class='line-break'> </span>of a portion would be in him, &amp; the<span class='line-break'> </span>other part in <a href='/pages/subjects/60015' title='Wellington, Peter'>Mr Wellington</a>. If Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>W. <ins>has</ins> deceased the deed can be<span class='line-break'> </span>made to the heirs at law, or devisees<span class='line-break'> </span>under the will, according as his property<span class='line-break'> </span>is left.</p>
<p>If you will see me, I can <span class='line-break'> </span>better advise you abt. it.</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133524">
<h3><a name="page-1133524">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 034)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-11-12'>Nov 12/61 [1861]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60028' title='Parker, Mason Good'>Mason G. Parker</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I find that your<span class='line-break'> </span>lot &amp; that of <a href='/pages/subjects/60029' title='Lawrence, James K.'>Mr Jas. K. Lawrence</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>on <a href='/pages/subjects/60030' title='Oak Avenue'>Oak Av.</a> are wrongly num<span class='line-break'></span>bered on the lot &amp; on the plan<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60031' title='Lot 2807'>2807</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/60032' title='Lot 2808'>2808</a>.</p>
<p>These numbers should have cor<span class='line-break'></span>responded with those of your deeds<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60033' title='Lot 2806'>2806</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/60031' title='Lot 2807'>2807</a>. The mistake appears<span class='line-break'> </span>to have been the result of some previous<span class='line-break'> </span>misnumbering.</p>
<p>I wish to correct it so that<span class='line-break'> </span>no mistake will arise hereafter upon<span class='line-break'> </span>any interment.</p>
<p>Please therefore inform me whether<span class='line-break'> </span>your lot or that of Mr L. is more<span class='line-break'> </span>northerly - that is <ins>towards</ins> <a href='/pages/subjects/57593' title='Auburn Lake'>the <ins>Lake</ins></a> -<span class='line-break'> </span>and I will have the numbered located<span class='line-break'> </span>accordingly.</p>
<p>Also inform me whether any, and<span class='line-break'> </span>what interments have been made<span class='line-break'> </span>in the lots, that the Register of Inter<span class='line-break'></span>ments may be corrected.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a></p>
<p><date when='1861-11-12'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 12, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60035' title='Foster, Joshua T.'>Joshua T. Foster</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60036' title='Medford, MA'>Medford</a> Mass.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your lot appears<span class='line-break'> </span>to have been wrongly numbered<span class='line-break'> </span>on the lot &amp; on the plan for the<span class='line-break'> </span>whole time which you have<span class='line-break'> </span>owned <a href='/pages/subjects/60037' title='Lot 2811'>lot 2811</a> - while<span class='line-break'> </span>your deed is of <a href='/pages/subjects/60032' title='lot 2808'>2808</a>.</p>
<p>I have taken steps towards<span class='line-break'> </span>the necessary correction, on the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot and on the Register of<span class='line-break'> </span>the ^<sup>three</sup> interments which you<span class='line-break'> </span>made - so as to corres<span class='line-break'></span>pond with your deed - <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60032' title='lot 2808'>2808</a>.</p>
<p>I merely notify you that <span class='line-break'> </span>you may not be surprized to<span class='line-break'> </span>see a change of number.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>34</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133525">
<h3><a name="page-1133525">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 035)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>35</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1861-11-23'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 23, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60038' title='Converse, J. W.'>J.W. Converse</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>Ex<sup>or</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/25005796' title='Whall, Joseph B.'>J.B. Whall</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Sir, Our Corporation is<span class='line-break'> </span>having a new survey of the Cemetery on an<span class='line-break'> </span>enlarged scale, and it is impossible to show<span class='line-break'> </span>those lots which have no visible bounds.<span class='line-break'> </span>The Whall lot, although containing a<span class='line-break'> </span>very expensive structure, has no stone<span class='line-break'> </span>or other posts to mark the corners; and<span class='line-break'> </span>as the backs are quite high &amp; slope in<span class='line-break'> </span>different directions the measurement<span class='line-break'> </span>at any time is not quite so easy.</p>
<p>Every proprietor's deed requires him to<span class='line-break'> </span>put down permanent bounds of stone<span class='line-break'> </span>or iron.</p>
<p>Will you authorize four posts<span class='line-break'> </span>to be put down at the corners? - this<span class='line-break'> </span>expense will not exceed $10. -</p>
<p>Will you also have our Surveyor<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/56692' title='Wadsworth, Alexander'>Mr Wadsworth</a>, make a plan to<span class='line-break'> </span>enter in our portfolio, for the sake<span class='line-break'> </span>of more minute &amp; accurate descrip<span class='line-break'></span>tion than can be shown on our<span class='line-break'> </span>ordinary plan?</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt Auburn Cemy</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-11-25'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 25, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60039' title='Appleton, William W.'>Mr W<sup>m</sup> W. Appleton</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I shall have again<span class='line-break'> </span>to remind you of the fact I<span class='line-break'> </span>mentioned to you a few days since,<span class='line-break'> </span>that the body of your child had<span class='line-break'> </span>remained in our <a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>Receiving Tomb</a><span class='line-break'> </span>far beyond the time allowed -<span class='line-break'> </span>and of your promise to go to<span class='line-break'> </span>Mt Auburn between the <date when='1861-11-12'>12<sup>th</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>of Nov<sup>r</sup></date> (when I saw you) and<span class='line-break'> </span>the <date when='1861-11-20'>20<sup>th</sup></date> to select a lot and<span class='line-break'> </span>take steps for the removal.</p>
<p>I trust you will set it<span class='line-break'> </span>down for the first fair day.</p>
<p>Yours resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133526">
<h3><a name="page-1133526">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 036)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-01-07'>Jany. 7. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60192' title='Bullard, Asa, Rev.'>Rev. Asa Bullard</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>have considered your application<span class='line-break'> </span>to know for what sum the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation will assume the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>care of the Fessenden Lot, <a href='/pages/subjects/60193' title='Lot 777'>No. 777</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>in Mount Auburn, after the fence<span class='line-break'> </span>shall have been renewed, and a<span class='line-break'> </span>new die set to the monument, as<span class='line-break'> </span>suggested by you; and have instructed<span class='line-break'> </span>me to inform you that they will<span class='line-break'> </span>contract therefor for the sum of<span class='line-break'> </span>($150) one hundred and fifty<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars.</p>
<p>Very truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-12-20'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 20, 1861</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60194' title='Little, George W.'>Geo. W. Little</a> Esq.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54284' title='Charlestown, MA'>Charlestown</a> Mass.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have ascertained that<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60195' title='Haynes, Benjamin'>Benj. Haynes</a>, in whose name I<span class='line-break'> </span>recently issued a deed of <a href='/pages/subjects/60196' title='Lot 3162'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>No 3162</a> in the Cemetery of Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn, died some time prior<span class='line-break'> </span>to the date of s<sup>d</sup> deed - to wit -<span class='line-break'> </span>in July last, and the deed<span class='line-break'> </span>is consequently void.</p>
<p>I presume you did not an<span class='line-break'></span>ticipate the effect of a deed thus<span class='line-break'> </span>surviving to him. If you will<span class='line-break'> </span>bring the deed to me at your<span class='line-break'> </span>early convenience, I will see<span class='line-break'> </span>how we can remedy the difficulty.</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Prop</p>
<p>36</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133527">
<h3><a name="page-1133527">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 037)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-01-07'>Jany. 7. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60201' title='Packard, Sylvanus'>Silvanus Packard</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>have considered your application to know<span class='line-break'> </span>for what sum the Corporation will<span class='line-break'> </span>assume perpetual care of your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>and that of <a href='/pages/subjects/60202' title='Tufts, Charles'>Mr Charles Tufts</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60203' title='Lot 2869'>nos. 2869</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/60204' title='Lot 2870'>&amp; 2870</a> in Mount Auburn.</p>
<p>They have considered the massive<span class='line-break'> </span>character of the work and the thorough<span class='line-break'> </span>manner in which it is done, and<span class='line-break'> </span>your wishes in respect to the mode<span class='line-break'> </span>of keeping the lots in order, as also<span class='line-break'> </span>your purpose to reconvey the lots,<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>in trust</ins>, to the Corporation, with a<span class='line-break'> </span>limitation for the interments to be<span class='line-break'> </span>made: and have instructed me<span class='line-break'> </span>to inform you that they will<span class='line-break'> </span>contract therefor, for the sum of<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>five hundred dollars</ins> for each lot.</p>
<p>I suppose you will notify <a href='/pages/subjects/60202' title='Tufts, Charles'>Mr Tufts,</a><span class='line-break'> </span>or I will do so if you desire.</p>
<p>Very truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-01-07'>Jany. 7.  1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60205' title='Cushman, Charles'>Chas. Cushman</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>have considered your application<span class='line-break'> </span>to know for what sum the Corpora<span class='line-break'></span>tion will assume the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>care of your <a href='/pages/subjects/60206' title='Lot 2833'>lot, 2833</a>, in Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn, upon the basis of your<span class='line-break'> </span>statement; and have instructed me<span class='line-break'> </span>to inform you that they will<span class='line-break'> </span>accept of the care of said lot in<span class='line-break'> </span>its present condition, including the<span class='line-break'> </span>bronze gates expected by you, for<span class='line-break'> </span>the sum of <ins>five hundred dollars</ins>.</p>
<p>When the monument is proposed,<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee will consider whether<span class='line-break'> </span>any addition ought to be made.</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>37</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133528">
<h3><a name="page-1133528">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 038)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-01-13'>Jany. 13. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60213' title='Pratt, E. B., Mrs.'>Mrs E.B. Pratt</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I perceive by the will<span class='line-break'> </span>of your late husband, you are made<span class='line-break'> </span>not only the Executrix, but also the<span class='line-break'> </span>residuary devisee of his estate; under<span class='line-break'> </span>which position (as no other clause<span class='line-break'> </span>in the will relates to it) the lot in<span class='line-break'> </span>the Cemetery of Mount Auburn, which<span class='line-break'> </span>is declared by our Charter to be real<span class='line-break'> </span>estate, passes to you in fee.-</p>
<p>In accordance, therefore, with said<span class='line-break'> </span>provision in the charter and our by<span class='line-break'></span>laws on the subject, you are hereby<span class='line-break'> </span>apprised that it will be proper,<span class='line-break'> </span>if you desire the recognition of such <span class='line-break'> </span>transfer, to have a record made of<span class='line-break'> </span>it upon the Special Transfer records<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation.</p>
<p>If you decide to have the record made<span class='line-break'> </span>send the deed of the lot, and I will<span class='line-break'> </span>also certify thereon to the record.</p>
<p>The fee is the usual one of $1.00.</p>
<p>Very resp. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-01-13'>Jany. 13. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60214' title='Thayer, Margaret'>Mrs Elijah Thayer</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I perceive by the will <span class='line-break'> </span>of your late husband, you are made both<span class='line-break'> </span>the Executrix and <ins>residuary devisee</ins> of his estate,<span class='line-break'> </span>under which disposition, (as no other clause <span class='line-break'> </span>in the will relates to it) his lot in the<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery of Mount Auburn, which is<span class='line-break'> </span>declared by our charter to be real estate,<span class='line-break'> </span>passes to you in fee.-</p>
<p>In accordance, therefore, with said provis<span class='line-break'></span>ion in the charter, and our by-laws on<span class='line-break'> </span>the subject, you are hereby apprised<span class='line-break'> </span>that it will be proper, if you desire<span class='line-break'> </span>the recognition of your proprietorship<span class='line-break'> </span>therein, to have a record made of this<span class='line-break'> </span>devise upon the Special Transfer Records<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation at this office. If you<span class='line-break'> </span>so decide, send me the deed of the lot,<span class='line-break'> </span>and I will make the record and certify<span class='line-break'> </span>the same on the deed.-</p>
<p>The usual fee is $1.-</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec. of Mt Auburn</p>
<p>38</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133529">
<h3><a name="page-1133529">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 039)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-01-13'>Jany. 13/62</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60216' title='Perkins, S. S., Mr.'>Mr S.S. Perkins</a>,</p>
<p>Sir,</p>
<p>Sometime since, at<span class='line-break'> </span>your request, I took a bill which<span class='line-break'> </span>you owe the Corporation, to confer<span class='line-break'> </span>with the proper officers about a<span class='line-break'> </span>reduction of the charge, and soon<span class='line-break'> </span>after notified you that I was<span class='line-break'> </span>prepared to answer you: but <span class='line-break'> </span>you have taken no notice of my<span class='line-break'> </span>answer that I am aware of.-</p>
<p>If you were ready to settle the<span class='line-break'> </span>bill, as you professed to be, I<span class='line-break'> </span>trust you will make it manifest,<span class='line-break'> </span>as it is more than a year<span class='line-break'> </span>old, and must be paid.</p>
<p>Yours resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y  Prop<sup>r</sup> of<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery of Mount Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1862-01-13'>Jany. 13, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60217' title='Glover, Joseph B.'>Jos. B. Glover</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>Ex<sup>or</sup> Est. <a href='/pages/subjects/59944' title='Ward, Winthrop'>Winthrop Ward</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I perceive by the will<span class='line-break'> </span>of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/59944' title='Ward, Winthrop'>Mr Ward</a>, that he directs<span class='line-break'> </span>the reconveyance of his lot in Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn Cemetery to our Coporation,<span class='line-break'> </span>with a limitation of the burial right,<span class='line-break'> </span>and that $300 be given to the Trustees<span class='line-break'> </span>to keep said lot in <del>perpetual</del> repair.</p>
<p>Shall I follow the usual course on<span class='line-break'> </span>all contracts with living persons, and<span class='line-break'> </span>bring the matter before the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots who are charged with all con<span class='line-break'></span>tracts of this nature, and if they see<span class='line-break'> </span>no objection to accepting also trust<span class='line-break'> </span>the manner and for the amount indica<span class='line-break'></span>ted by <a href='/pages/subjects/59944' title='Ward, Winthrop'>Mr Ward</a>, are you pre<span class='line-break'></span>pared to execute the needful<span class='line-break'> </span>papers?</p>
<p>Very Resp.y yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Prop<sup>rs</sup> Cem. Mt. Au</p>
<p>39</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133530">
<h3><a name="page-1133530">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 040)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1862-01-20'>Jany 20, 1862</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I see not impropriety in <span class='line-break'> </span>considering that <a href='/pages/subjects/60223' title='Lot 790'>Lot 790</a> in Mount <span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn, in accordance with your <span class='line-break'> </span>wish, passed directly to your son <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60224' title='Welles, Arnold Francis'>Wells, Mr. Mr Wells</a>.  But as he the sole <span class='line-break'> </span>heir at law of this late father <span class='line-break'> </span>which I was not aware of <span class='line-break'> </span>I sent the blank petition, that <span class='line-break'> </span>form becomes unneccessary and <span class='line-break'> </span>instead thereof he is entitled to <span class='line-break'> </span>file his affidavit that he is <span class='line-break'> </span>sole heir at law, which as is <span class='line-break'> </span>noted upon our records and <span class='line-break'> </span>the name entered in the catalogue.</p>
<p>I have therefore prepared said<span class='line-break'> </span>affidavit, and if he will call at this office. I need desire<span class='line-break'> </span>him but in short time . The [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>fee therefor is $1.-</p>
<p>Very respy yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>Hon <a href='/pages/subjects/25007519' title='Winthrop, Robert Charles'>R.C. Winthrop</a></p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-01-16'>Jany. 16,1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60226' title='Gridley, Eunice M.'>Miss E.M Gridley</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I have drawn <span class='line-break'> </span>up a document as nearly in accord<span class='line-break'></span>ance with our conversation and <span class='line-break'> </span>your supposed wishes as I have <span class='line-break'> </span>been able to make it.</p>
<p>I was not quite sure of the <span class='line-break'> </span>Christian name of your sister, and <span class='line-break'> </span>you will see that I have inserted <span class='line-break'> </span>it in pencil.</p>
<p>If it is satisfactory, I will wait <span class='line-break'> </span>upon you at your house, or you <span class='line-break'> </span>can come down, as you prefer.- <span class='line-break'> </span>If you desire any further alterations <span class='line-break'> </span>I shall be happy to listen to what <span class='line-break'> </span>you may wish.</p>
<p>If you should come down pre<span class='line-break'></span>pared to finish, you will need your <span class='line-break'> </span>policy, and the deed of the lot.</p>
<p>Very respl.y yours <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>40</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133531">
<h3><a name="page-1133531">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 041)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-01-20'>Jany. 20. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60227' title='Burroughs, John'>John Burroughs</a> Esq.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60228' title='Germantown, PA'>Germantown, Pa</a>.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 16<sup>th</sup> came to<span class='line-break'> </span>hand Saturday. As you are<span class='line-break'> </span>residuary legatee of <a href='/pages/subjects/60229' title='Burroughs, William'>W<sup>m</sup> Burroughs,</a><span class='line-break'> </span>his lot in Mount Auburn, will<span class='line-break'> </span>thereby pass to you, a record<span class='line-break'> </span>of which devise should be made<span class='line-break'> </span>on our Special Transfer Record.</p>
<p>As I find a copy of the<span class='line-break'> </span>will filed in the Probate office<span class='line-break'> </span>in this county, I have all the<span class='line-break'> </span>materials necessary for such<span class='line-break'> </span>record. If you wish me<span class='line-break'> </span>to record it, and certify to<span class='line-break'> </span>your title, please send me<span class='line-break'> </span>the deed of the lot, and I<span class='line-break'> </span>will return the same property<span class='line-break'> </span>authenticated. The regular fee<span class='line-break'> </span>therefor is $1.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-01-20'>Jany 20. 1862</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60230' title='Fisher, Eugene Augustus'>Eugene A. Fisher</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I was not before<span class='line-break'> </span>aware that you were the sole<span class='line-break'> </span>heir at law of <a href='/pages/subjects/60231' title='Fisher, Willard N.'>Willard N.<span class='line-break'> </span>Fisher</a>, which being the case,<span class='line-break'> </span>the designation of yourself as repre<span class='line-break'></span>sentative of <a href='/pages/subjects/60232' title='Lot 892'>lot 892</a> in Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn becomes unnecessary. But<span class='line-break'> </span>another course is indicated in our<span class='line-break'> </span>by-laws, which is for you to file<span class='line-break'> </span>with the Corporation an affidavit<span class='line-break'> </span>that you are the sole heir at<span class='line-break'> </span>law of the late prop<sup>r</sup> that your<span class='line-break'> </span>title may appear on our<span class='line-break'> </span>records and in the catalogue.</p>
<p>I shall be prepared to receive<span class='line-break'> </span>such affidavit at any time you<span class='line-break'> </span>may call on me. The regular<span class='line-break'> </span>fee therefor is $1.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>41</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133532">
<h3><a name="page-1133532">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 042)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-01-20'>Jany. 20, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60233' title='Richardson, Samuel, Dr.'>Dr. Richardson</a></p>
<p>Sir, In the order for <span class='line-break'> </span>the interment of your late wife, <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60234' title='Richardson, Mary, Mrs.'>Mrs. Mary Richardson</a>, in the lot <span class='line-break'> </span>of [Symuel?]Gardner, in Mt. Auburn, <span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1861-10-12'>Oct. 12, 1861</date>, the blank for her <span class='line-break'> </span>age was not filled. Thinking <span class='line-break'> </span>there had been neglect on the part <span class='line-break'> </span>of the undertaker,  or town clerk, <span class='line-break'> </span>I wrote to each of them, and <span class='line-break'> </span>learned that one of them you<span class='line-break'> </span>"could not tell", and the other <span class='line-break'> </span>you refused to tell, if the reply <span class='line-break'> </span>"no matter" "no consequence" is <span class='line-break'> </span>to be thus construed.-</p>
<p>As it is not only our wish <span class='line-break'> </span>but our duty to make our <span class='line-break'> </span>Register of Interments complete <span class='line-break'> </span>in every particular, where it <span class='line-break'> </span>is possible to do so, I must</p>
<p>request that you will <span class='line-break'> </span>furnish us with the desired<span class='line-break'> </span>information. I should be <span class='line-break'> </span>very unwilling to suppose you <span class='line-break'> </span>had any motive for withholding <span class='line-break'> </span>this information, as I am not <span class='line-break'> </span>aware of any such case of <span class='line-break'> </span>refusal ever before occurring. <span class='line-break'> </span>and we should prefer to <span class='line-break'> </span>believe that this is a mistake <span class='line-break'> </span>about this.-</p>
<p>We wish to close our record <span class='line-break'> </span>for the year, at once, and <span class='line-break'> </span>trust you will furnish this fact <span class='line-break'> </span>for our Register; or we shall be <span class='line-break'> </span>obliged to note in the place <span class='line-break'> </span>where it should be stated such <span class='line-break'> </span>information as has already been <span class='line-break'> </span>furnished  as a reason for the omission.</p>
<p>Yours respectfully</p>
<p>42</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133533">
<h3><a name="page-1133533">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 043)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>43</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-01-30'>Jany. 30. 1862</date></p>
<p>Hon. <a href='/pages/subjects/25007519' title='Winthrop, Robert Charles'>R. C. Winthrop</a>.</p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>I ought ere this to have replied<span class='line-break'> </span>to your punctual and obliging notes of the <date when='1862-01-16'>16<sup>th</sup></date> and<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1862-01-25'>25<sup>th</sup></date> just, in relation to the lot of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/60224' title='Welles, Arnold Francis'>Arnold<span class='line-break'> </span>F. Welles</a>, besides which I learn, you were at the<span class='line-break'> </span>trouble to call twice at my office. I inferred from<span class='line-break'> </span>the expression on the petition-"son and only sur<span class='line-break'></span>viving child" - although the inference was not<span class='line-break'> </span>a necessary one, that <a href='/pages/subjects/60224' title='Welles, Arnold Francis'>Mr Welles</a> died intestate, leaving<span class='line-break'> </span>but one child; and after learning there was a<span class='line-break'> </span>will, had intended writing you that the affidavit<span class='line-break'> </span>was not the proper course in such cases, when<span class='line-break'> </span>I received your [?]</p>
<p>I have the proper extract from the Records at<span class='line-break'> </span>the Probate office, and therefore need not trouble you<span class='line-break'> </span>to send me a copy of the will, for the purpose of<span class='line-break'> </span>making a record of the special transfer under the<span class='line-break'> </span>operation of the will and in accordance with our by-laws.</p>
<p>This I can make. But if you will send me<span class='line-break'> </span>the deed of the lot, I will endorse thereon the</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133534">
<h3><a name="page-1133534">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 044)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>44</p>
<p>certificate of record.</p>
<p>It is doubtless, as you remark, unusual for<span class='line-break'> </span>one to put on record the evidence of his title, <span class='line-break'> </span>to real estate.  This usually becomes apparent from<span class='line-break'> </span>his possession.  But it is a matter of great con<span class='line-break'></span>venience to proprietors to be able to so with reference <span class='line-break'> </span>to lots in our Cemetery, where there are upwards<span class='line-break'> </span>of 3000 proprietors, each of whom has a fee, it<span class='line-break'> </span>is true, but whose interest is limited by, and must <span class='line-break'> </span>be held in subordination to such by-laws as are<span class='line-break'> </span>made by the Trustees.  Every lot owner, I think, will<span class='line-break'> </span>see, upon a moment's reflection, how necessary is the<span class='line-break'> </span>proper record of these titles, that the officers and<span class='line-break'> </span>servants of the Corporation may have the requisite<span class='line-break'> </span>knowledge to guide them in their duties, as none of<span class='line-break'> </span>them can be supposed to have so wide an acquaintence<span class='line-break'> </span>with mankind as to remove this necessity.</p>
<p>That <a href='/pages/subjects/60247' title='Welles, George Derby'>George Derby W.</a> is the <ins>only</ins> surviving <span class='line-break'> </span>child of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/60224' title='Welles, Arnold Francis'>Mr Welles</a> does not appear from<span class='line-break'> </span>the will itself, and, hence, an affidavit, in addition<span class='line-break'> </span>to the record of the clause of the will, might seem<span class='line-break'> </span>to be necessary.  Indeed it could be the course in <span class='line-break'> </span>almost every case where there is no documentary evidence<span class='line-break'> </span>at hand. I have no right, as recording officer,</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133535">
<h3><a name="page-1133535">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 045)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1861-02-07'>Feby. 7. 1861.</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo. W<sup>m</sup> Bond</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have made the inquiry<span class='line-break'> </span>which you requested of the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots: viz for what sum the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation will assume perpetual care<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/60249' title='Lot 1611'>lot 1611</a> in Mt Auburn Cemetery <span class='line-break'> </span>owned by <a href='/pages/subjects/60250' title='Pierce, Sarah K.'>Sarah K. Pierce</a>.</p>
<p>The Committee have had a sur<span class='line-break'></span>vey of the lot - have considered the<span class='line-break'> </span>question and instructed me to<span class='line-break'> </span>inform Mrs Pierce through you<span class='line-break'> </span>that will contract for the <ins>perpetual</ins> <span class='line-break'> </span>care of said lot for <ins>two hundred</ins>  <span class='line-break'> </span><ins>dollars</ins>.-</p>
<p>Resp.y your Ob<sup>t</sup> Servt</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-02-06'>Feby. 6. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60251' title='Hayward, James'>James Hayward</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your application to<span class='line-break'> </span>know for what sum this Cor<span class='line-break'> </span>poration will assume the per<span class='line-break'> </span>petual care of your <a href='/pages/subjects/60252' title='Lot 840'>lot no 840</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>in Mount Auburn Cemetery, has<span class='line-break'> </span>been duly considered by the<span class='line-break'> </span>Committee on Lots, who are<span class='line-break'> </span>authorized to make all contracts<span class='line-break'> </span>therefor; and they have instructed<span class='line-break'> </span>me to inform you that the<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees will accept the<span class='line-break'> </span>trust for the sum of three<span class='line-break'> </span>hundred dollars.-</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Prop<sup>rs</sup> Cemetery of<span class='line-break'> </span>Mt Auburn</p>
<p>45</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133536">
<h3><a name="page-1133536">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 046)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-02-13'>Feby. 13. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60268' title='Bacon, J. C.'>J. C. Bacon</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>In compliance with<span class='line-break'> </span>your request, I send you the<span class='line-break'> </span>accompanying blank form for dona<span class='line-break'> </span>tion for the <ins>perpetual</ins> care of<span class='line-break'> </span>a lot in Mount Auburn.</p>
<p>In order to ascertain ^<sup>for</sup> what sum<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation will contract with<span class='line-break'> </span>you for said purpose, a survey<span class='line-break'> </span>will have to made of this lot<span class='line-break'> </span>by the Superintendent, and its condition<span class='line-break'> </span>and character reported to the Com<sup>ee</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots, who must determine the <span class='line-break'> </span>sum requisite for the purpose.-</p>
<p>If you wish me to have these<span class='line-break'> </span>preliminaries attended to at any time,<span class='line-break'> </span>send me word, and I will put<span class='line-break'> </span>the matter in train for you. There<span class='line-break'> </span>is no expense, except of the sum given &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>the usual fee for recording.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a>, Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-02-13'>Feby. 13. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60333' title='Wade, Reuben S.'>R.S. Wade</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The claim which<span class='line-break'> </span>you desired me to present to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots for land paid for<span class='line-break'> </span>by you at the full price, but not<span class='line-break'> </span>enclosed in your lot, I laid before<span class='line-break'> </span>them last month, in a written state<span class='line-break'></span>ment. I have just received <span class='line-break'> </span>the decision of the Com<sup>ee</sup>, which is<span class='line-break'> </span><ins> adverse </ins> to your claim.-</p>
<p>You can see the papers in the<span class='line-break'> </span>case, if you will call upon me;<span class='line-break'> </span>and if any injustice has been done<span class='line-break'> </span>you in stating the facts, I doubt<span class='line-break'> </span>not there will be an open ear<span class='line-break'> </span>to your own view. If you are<span class='line-break'> </span>still aggrieved, I suppose an appeal<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Board is your right; if you think<span class='line-break'> </span>it practicable.</p>
<p>I have only to say, that I have endeavored to give the Com<sup>ee</sup> a correct<span class='line-break'> </span>statement of the facts,<span class='line-break'> </span>and with fairness to you.</p>
<p>Yours resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt Au.</p>
<p>46</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133537">
<h3><a name="page-1133537">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 047)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>47</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>. <date when='1862-02-13'>Feby. 13. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60332' title='Richardson, Jeffrey'>Hon. J. Richardson</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have made and<span class='line-break'> </span>sent to the Treasurer two deeds<span class='line-break'> </span>of the passageways, and have<span class='line-break'> </span>notified <a href='/pages/subjects/56692' title='Wadsworth, Alexander'>Mr Wadsworth</a> of the<span class='line-break'> </span>width of passage next to <a href='/pages/subjects/60333' title='Wade, Reuben S.'>Wade.</a></p>
<p>The passage next to <a href='/pages/subjects/60201' title='Packard, Sylvanus'>Packard</a><span class='line-break'> </span>I have made 70 f. @ 33 1/3 = 23.33<span class='line-break'> </span>next to Wade 87 f. @ 22 2/9 = <ins>29.33</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>$52.66</p>
<p>Wade had made a claim of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation, which I need not stop<span class='line-break'> </span>to explain here; but by the decision<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Comm<sup>ee</sup> on Lots the claim<span class='line-break'> </span>is disallowed, and I have<span class='line-break'> </span>consequently estimated the space<span class='line-break'> </span>between him and you as 5 f. 8 in wide<span class='line-break'> </span>in front &amp; 5 f. 4 in in rear, measuring<span class='line-break'> </span>from the <ins>inside</ins> of his curb - which, after<span class='line-break'> </span>deducting the 2 1/2 ft wide which<span class='line-break'> </span>was conveyed to him, leaves<span class='line-break'> </span>3 f. 2 in. wide in front for you &amp; 2 f. 10 in.<span class='line-break'> </span>in rear, or an average width of<span class='line-break'> </span>3 feet, which by 29 f. long gives 87 f.<span class='line-break'> </span>This I have asked permission<span class='line-break'> </span>to amend the report to, at 22 2/4 in.<span class='line-break'> </span>per foot or 1/3 of 4/8 - which <span class='line-break'> </span>I trust may be satisfactory <span class='line-break'> </span>to you. - I would not have<span class='line-break'> </span>altered the measurement of  it,<span class='line-break'> </span>but for my belief that if the<span class='line-break'> </span>plan which <a href='/pages/subjects/56692' title='Wadsworth, Alexander'>Mr Wadsworth</a><span class='line-break'> </span>is making shows that width,<span class='line-break'> </span>you would prefer to have your<span class='line-break'> </span>deeds agree.</p>
<p>Very resp.y &amp; truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133538">
<h3><a name="page-1133538">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 048)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-03-04'>March 4, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60334' title='Brinley, Edward'>Edward Brinley</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of the 1st inst.<span class='line-break'> </span>was rec<sup>d</sup> yesterday. I have no definite<span class='line-break'> </span>recollection of your lot, although I<span class='line-break'> </span>spent some time there late in the <span class='line-break'> </span>Autumn completing our great survey.<span class='line-break'> </span>It is pleasantly (although rather pub<span class='line-break'></span>licly) located near the junction of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60335' title='Poplar Avenue'>Poplar<!--Ave--></a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/60336' title='Willow Avenue'>Willow Avenues</a>.<span class='line-break'> </span>The present price of land is 50 cts per<span class='line-break'> </span>foot, and yours would probably be worth<span class='line-break'> </span>$250. I don't suppose you could call<span class='line-break'> </span>the improvements worth much. It might<span class='line-break'> </span>not tempt one much even at that price,<span class='line-break'> </span>but if you desire, when the snow is<span class='line-break'> </span>off, I will look at the lot and give<span class='line-break'> </span>you more particular answer. - It might<span class='line-break'> </span>be well, meantime, if you have determined<span class='line-break'> </span>to sell, to give me an idea of what you will<span class='line-break'> </span>take for it, in case I should have any in<span class='line-break'></span>quiry for such a lot.</p>
<p>My last catalogue was of <date when='1860-06'>June 1860</date>,<span class='line-break'> </span>which I think you have: if not, I will<span class='line-break'> </span>send.</p>
<p>Yours very truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>48</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133539">
<h3><a name="page-1133539">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 049)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-04-11'>March 11. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60339' title='Wyman, Rufus'>Mr Rufus Wyman</a><span class='line-break'> </span>refr. of <a href='/pages/subjects/60340' title='Lot 133'>lot 133</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/60336' title='Willow Avenue'>Willow Av</a>. has just<span class='line-break'> </span>called on me in reference to the<span class='line-break'> </span>circular addressed to him about<span class='line-break'> </span>the bounds of his lot.</p>
<p>You will remember that it was<span class='line-break'> </span>opened last week for <a href='/pages/subjects/60341' title='Wyman, Lizzie Aspinwall'>Dr. Wyman's daugh<span class='line-break'></span>ter</a>. This lot &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/60342' title='Lot 296'>296,</a> that of<a href='/pages/subjects/60343' title='Howe, Joseph N.'> Jos.<span class='line-break'> </span>N. Howe</a> are together without any<span class='line-break'> </span>passage between, and measure 900f.<span class='line-break'> </span>or 450 f. each. - We drove stakes<span class='line-break'> </span>thirty feet each way - making 120 linear<span class='line-break'> </span>feet round the lots.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60339' title='Wyman, Rufus'>Mr Wyman</a> would like to have<span class='line-break'> </span>you make an estimate on filling and<span class='line-break'> </span>grading up somewhat, and putting a<span class='line-break'> </span>suitable curb round the lots. <span class='line-break'> </span>The monument is so large and bold,<span class='line-break'> </span>that all the parties interested<span class='line-break'> </span>have come to the conclusion that<span class='line-break'> </span>no enclosure other than a curb<span class='line-break'> </span>will answer the purposes. I sug<span class='line-break'></span>gested it was possible to put a<span class='line-break'> </span>suitable curb on at $2 per foot -<span class='line-break'> </span>but was not certain that that<span class='line-break'> </span>sum would put one on heavy<span class='line-break'> </span>enough for so large an area.</p>
<p>He thinks it would do to fill up<span class='line-break'> </span>a foot. I don't know whether the<span class='line-break'> </span>monument would bear so much -<span class='line-break'> </span>should doubt it: but it ought to<span class='line-break'> </span>come up enough to protect it from<span class='line-break'> </span>parties crossing to &amp; from the Indian<span class='line-break'> </span>Ridge.</p>
<p>I wish you would look at<span class='line-break'> </span>the lots, if the snow is down enough, and<span class='line-break'> </span>make up your mind what would look<span class='line-break'> </span>best, and make some estimate on<span class='line-break'> </span>the thing. He seemed to think $240 a<span class='line-break'> </span>considerable sum - but probably is not<span class='line-break'> </span>used to the thing, and will change his<span class='line-break'> </span>mind before he gets through.</p>
<p>He says he will call in again in <span class='line-break'> </span>a few days.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p>[obscured]<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>49</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133540">
<h3><a name="page-1133540">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 050)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-03-17'>March 17,  1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60333' title='Wade, Reuben S.'>R.S. Wade</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I read the letter,<span class='line-break'> </span>which you handed me ad<span class='line-break'></span>dressed you by <a href='/pages/subjects/60355' title='Woodcock, Mr.'>Mr Woodcock</a><span class='line-break'> </span>on the 17<sup>th</sup> ulh., to <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Chairman of the Comm. on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>within a day or two after you<span class='line-break'> </span>were here, and told him you<span class='line-break'> </span>were anxious the Comm. should<span class='line-break'> </span>have what you regarded as<span class='line-break'> </span>material to the case - <a href='/pages/subjects/60355' title='Woodcock, Mr.'>Mr Woodcock's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>interview with his <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Mr Mann</a>.</p>
<p>He, however, did not regard<span class='line-break'> </span>it as good ground for changing the<span class='line-break'> </span>decision of the Comm<sup>ee</sup>, as the prop<sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>or his agent should have insisted<span class='line-break'> </span>on his rights while it was an open<span class='line-break'> </span>question. He says the land is<span class='line-break'> </span>there - it was yours to use or not<span class='line-break'> </span>as you saw fit - that the<span class='line-break'> </span>the land is there still but of<span class='line-break'> </span>no use to the Corporation as it<span class='line-break'> </span>cannot be sold.</p>
<p>I felt very sure such would<span class='line-break'> </span>be the view taken, and therefore<span class='line-break'> </span>preferred you should see the Comm<sup>ee</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>yourself, as I prefer that you should<span class='line-break'> </span>have the opportunity of satisfying your<span class='line-break'></span>self that the subject has been fairly<span class='line-break'> </span>presented, which you can hardly have<span class='line-break'> </span>without acting as your own counsel.</p>
<p>I wish now, if you are not<span class='line-break'> </span>entirely satisfied with the decision<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Comm<sup>ee</sup>, you would see<span class='line-break'> </span>them yourself.</p>
<p>If you do not wish to urge the matter<span class='line-break'> </span>further, I suppose you will be ready<span class='line-break'> </span>to pay the Treas<sup>r</sup> the bill due<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation.</p>
<p>Very respy.</p>
<p>Your humb<sup>le</sup> servant</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
<p>50</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133541">
<h3><a name="page-1133541">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 051)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-03-17'>March 17, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60217' title='Glover, Joseph B.'>Jos. B. Glover</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>have considered the questions whether<span class='line-break'> </span>they will guarantee the <ins>perpetual</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>care of the lot of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/59944' title='Ward, Winthrop'>Winthrop<span class='line-break'> </span>Ward</a> for the sum specified in<span class='line-break'> </span>his will; and have unanimously<span class='line-break'> </span>come to the conclusion that they<span class='line-break'> </span>cannot give such guaranty for <span class='line-break'> </span>less than $600. The monument<span class='line-break'> </span>is quite elaborate, and they are<span class='line-break'> </span>unwilling to assume the risk for<span class='line-break'> </span>less than the sum named.-</p>
<p>But they are willing to receive<span class='line-break'> </span>the $300 named in the will on<span class='line-break'> </span>the usual terms stated in the<span class='line-break'> </span>by-laws, <ins>without</ins> their guaranty<span class='line-break'> </span>of perpetual care. In this case,<span class='line-break'> </span>they simply expend the income,<span class='line-break'> </span>in hand so there still be of<span class='line-break'> </span>no use to the responsible beyond<span class='line-break'> </span>amount - nor for the care<span class='line-break'> </span>of the lot beyond the failure of<span class='line-break'> </span>the fund, if it should ever become<span class='line-break'> </span>worthless by no fault of theirs.</p>
<p>Proprietors, however, often consider<span class='line-break'> </span>a donation in this way perfectly<span class='line-break'> </span>safe. There are more in number,<span class='line-break'> </span>that wish the guaranty.-</p>
<p>But I do not understand<span class='line-break'> </span>the clause of <a href='/pages/subjects/59944' title='Ward, Winthrop'>Mr Ward's</a> will<span class='line-break'> </span>on this subject as requiring<span class='line-break'> </span>a guaranty. He certainly took<span class='line-break'> </span>the responsibility of giving $300,<span class='line-break'> </span>without inquiring of the other<span class='line-break'> </span>party to contract for guaranty<span class='line-break'> </span>of perpetual repair, and must<span class='line-break'> </span>therefore be presumed not to have<span class='line-break'> </span>intended that to be required, as we<span class='line-break'> </span>must also suppose that he had<span class='line-break'> </span>seen the by-laws in print.-</p>
<p>If you prefer to make up the amount<span class='line-break'> </span>to what the Comm<sup>ee</sup> name, such a<span class='line-break'> </span>contract can be made.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>51</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133542">
<h3><a name="page-1133542">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 052)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>52</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-03-18'>March 18<sup>th</sup>/62</date></p>
<p>Hon. <a href='/pages/subjects/55029' title='Silsbee, Nathaniel'>Nath<sup>l</sup> Silsbee</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup> <a href='/pages/subjects/59943' title='Harvard College'>Harv. Coll.-</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, The subject referred to in the<span class='line-break'> </span>accompanying circular is not now for the first time<span class='line-break'> </span>brought to the notice of the "Pres. &amp; Fellows"</p>
<p>I find upon the records of our Board of Trustees,<span class='line-break'> </span>three years since (<date when='1859-02'>Feby. 1859.</date>) the following as the Report of a<span class='line-break'> </span>Com<sup>ee</sup> to whom the subject was ref<sup>d</sup>.</p>
<p>"The Committee to whom was referred the memorial<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/60399' title='Lawrence, Amos Adams'>Mr Lawrence, Treas<sup>r</sup></a> of <a href='/pages/subjects/59943' title='Harvard College'>Harv<sup>d</sup> College</a>, respecting the <span class='line-break'> </span>boundaries of the lot in the Cemetery belonging to that Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation - with full power.</p>
<p>Reported that they had arranged with the Treas<span class='line-break'></span>urer of the College that said lot should be surveyed, and<span class='line-break'> </span>that is should be optional with him whether the monuments<span class='line-break'> </span>now said to encroach upon the lands of this Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>should be removed within the present bounds, or whether<span class='line-break'> </span>sufficient land should be exchanged from another<span class='line-break'> </span>part of said lot to be equivalent to the land now<span class='line-break'> </span>occupied by said monuments."</p>
<p>And the report was accepted - and here,<span class='line-break'> </span>it now appears, the matter ended. -</p>
<p>The lot in question (<a href='/pages/subjects/53608' title='Lot 330'>no. 330</a> in the Cemetery) is</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133543">
<h3><a name="page-1133543">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 053)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>53</p>
<p>situated near the <a href='/pages/subjects/60404' title='Tower Hill'>Tower Hill</a> and occupying a portion of<span class='line-break'> </span>what is called <a href='/pages/subjects/60405' title='Harvard Hill'>Harvard Hill</a> is encircled by <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60406' title='Amaranth Path'>Amaranth Path</a>; and contained 5.226 square feet.<span class='line-break'> </span>It contains the monuments of <a href='/pages/subjects/60407' title='Kirkland, John Thornton'>Pres. Kirkland</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/60408' title='Ashman, John Hooker'>John<span class='line-break'> </span>Hooker Ashman</a>, and quite a number of mon<span class='line-break'></span>uments of students, and is and must continue<span class='line-break'> </span>to be a spot hallowed in the memories of<span class='line-break'> </span>many. Unfortunately, however, no permanent<span class='line-break'> </span>bounds were ever erected, as the ground<span class='line-break'> </span>slopes to the path which is narrow, in time the<span class='line-break'> </span>visible outlines of the lot have become difficult<span class='line-break'> </span>to find. At the request of the Treas<sup>r</sup>at the time men<span class='line-break'></span>tioned, our Sup<sup>t</sup> put down some small stakes<span class='line-break'> </span>with a view of showing as nearly as could be, the former<span class='line-break'> </span>location of this lot. These I found partly remaining when<span class='line-break'> </span>I viewed the spot with the surveyors in December last;<span class='line-break'> </span>but as the matter had been left in the partially ar<span class='line-break'></span>ranged state referred to above, it was useless for<span class='line-break'> </span>us to attempt anything, until we could ascertain what<span class='line-break'> </span>your Corporation will do in the matter.</p>
<p>The result is- we have a plan of great beauty<span class='line-break'> </span>and accuracy, as yet without this lot being indicated.</p>
<p>Will you please bring this matter before the Corporation,<span class='line-break'> </span>and have such action taken as will vest in you this<span class='line-break'> </span>power, if need be, to do what is requisite when Spring<span class='line-break'> </span>opens. I think, if you would enclose the lot with<span class='line-break'> </span>a neat granite edgestone, it would add greatly to its beauty<span class='line-break'> </span>and permanance.</p>
<p>I am very resp.y yours  <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133544">
<h3><a name="page-1133544">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 054)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-03-24'>March 24, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79343' title='Childs, Ebenezer Larkin'>E.L. Childs</a> Esq.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54469' title='Washington, DC'>Washington D.C.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have just sent<span class='line-break'> </span>a line to <a href='/pages/subjects/60414' title='Capen, N., Mr.'>Mr [Nahura?] Capen</a><span class='line-break'> </span>who is said to be in <a href='/pages/subjects/54469' title='Washington, DC'>Washington, <!--DC--></a><span class='line-break'> </span>respecting the Larkin lot in Mt<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn. Lest my note should<span class='line-break'> </span>not find him there, I will say<span class='line-break'> </span>that I have an appliciation<span class='line-break'> </span>to know the least sum the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot will be sold for (if still for<span class='line-break'> </span>sale) with the fund of $400<span class='line-break'> </span>applied to both <a href='/pages/subjects/60415' title='Lot 1806'>lots - 1806</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/60416' title='Lot 1807'>&amp; 1807.</a><span class='line-break'> </span>I think you named $500, and<span class='line-break'> </span>when I last saw you, I think<span class='line-break'> </span>you said the whole matter should<span class='line-break'> </span>be left in <a href='/pages/subjects/60414' title='Capen, N., Mr.'>Mr Capen's</a> hands.</p>
<p>The person inquiring, I believe,<span class='line-break'> </span>is a man of means, and will<span class='line-break'> </span>await your reply.</p>
<p>Very respy yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-04-16'>April 16, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60417' title='Bacon, Thomas C.'>Thos. C. Bacon</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots have considered your ap<span class='line-break'></span>plication to know for what sum<span class='line-break'> </span>this Corporation will assume<span class='line-break'> </span>the <ins>perpetual</ins> care of your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>and tomb; and have instructed<span class='line-break'> </span>me to notify you that they are<span class='line-break'> </span>ready to contract for the<span class='line-break'> </span>same on payment of the sum<span class='line-break'> </span>of ($400) four hundred dollars.</p>
<p>Ready to serve you  &amp; am</p>
<p>Very respy. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary Prop<sup>rs</sup> Mt Auburn</p>
<p>54</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133545">
<h3><a name="page-1133545">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 055)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>55</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-04-07'>April 7, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79343' title='Childs, Ebenezer Larkin'>E.L. Childs Esq.</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54469' title='Washington, DC'>Washington D.C.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of <date when='1862-04-26'>March 26<sup>th</sup></date> in<span class='line-break'> </span>reply to my inquiry about the <a href='/pages/subjects/60942' title='Larkin, Thomas C.'>Larkin</a> lot was<span class='line-break'> </span>rec<sup>d</sup>. I have shown your note to the gen<span class='line-break'></span>tleman who inquired about the lot. He has taken<span class='line-break'> </span>occasion to see <a href='/pages/subjects/60754' title='Wright, Otis'>Mr Wright</a>, who, he says, is per<span class='line-break'></span>fectly satisfied to have him for a co-tenant, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>he seemed to be satisfied with <a href='/pages/subjects/60754' title='Wright, Otis'>Mr Wright.</a></p>
<p>He has instructed me to offer you $500 for the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot, if you will decide the matter yourself at once.<span class='line-break'> </span>If you decline to do this, and wish instructions<span class='line-break'> </span>from California, he withdraws this offer. In that<span class='line-break'> </span>case, he will give only $400. He is willing to make<span class='line-break'> </span>this difference for an immediate decision, as he has a<span class='line-break'> </span>body deposited in our <a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>Receiving Tomb</a> and is anxious<span class='line-break'> </span>to make a removal soon to the lot which he may pur<span class='line-break'></span>chase. As you have the deed in your hands executed, and<span class='line-break'> </span>your authority to sell does not appear to have been revoked. I<span class='line-break'> </span>should think you ought to take the responsibility of a decision.<span class='line-break'> </span>There are few people; when looking for lots, that are willing to wave<span class='line-break'> </span>the uncertainties of California correspondence. In this case,<span class='line-break'> </span>inquirer is a gentleman of large means, I understand, and<span class='line-break'> </span>probably is willing to pay a premium for having his own wishes<span class='line-break'> </span>met. - I think this is really a good opportunity for the <a href='/pages/subjects/60942' title='Larkin, Thomas C.'>Larkin</a> heirs.<span class='line-break'> </span>Hoping to hear what is your decision.</p>
<p>I am very respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133546">
<h3><a name="page-1133546">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 056)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>56</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-04-28'>April 28.1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79343' title='Childs, Ebenezer Larkin'>E.L. Childs</a> Esq.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54469' title='Washington, DC'>Washington D.C.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, It is some two or<span class='line-break'> </span>three years since the lot of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/60942' title='Larkin, Thomas C.'>Thos.<span class='line-break'> </span>C. Larkin</a> was mentioned to me by you<span class='line-break'> </span>as one for sale. We have had several<span class='line-break'> </span>letters pass on this subject &amp; on the<span class='line-break'> </span>endowment, and I have made several<span class='line-break'> </span>efforts for the sale of it, and at last<span class='line-break'> </span>found a customer who has taken<span class='line-break'> </span>it at your price: and has paid over<span class='line-break'> </span>the $500 to <a href='/pages/subjects/60943' title='Erving, Mr.'>Mr Erving</a> and I suppose<span class='line-break'> </span>the money has reached you before<span class='line-break'> </span>this time.</p>
<p>As <a href='/pages/subjects/60943' title='Erving, Mr.'>Mr Erving</a> appeared to have no<span class='line-break'> </span>instructions but to deliver the deed, I<span class='line-break'> </span>said nothing to him about my services,<span class='line-break'> </span>and concluded it was best to<span class='line-break'> </span>suggest the matter directly to you<span class='line-break'> </span>only. If you are satisfied to<span class='line-break'> </span>pay me $5., I shall think, and<span class='line-break'> </span>hope it may so appear to you, that<span class='line-break'> </span>the fee was well earned.-</p>
<p>I urged the sale to <a href='/pages/subjects/60944' title='Pierce, Mr.'>Mr Pierce</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>because I believed it as much<span class='line-break'> </span>for the interest of the Larkin<span class='line-break'> </span>Estate as for him - for it would<span class='line-break'> </span>be seldom that I could find<span class='line-break'> </span>a man willing to pay $500 for<span class='line-break'> </span>a lot situated just as this one<span class='line-break'> </span>is. People do not like a double ter<span class='line-break'></span>race, nor to occupy a lot in<span class='line-break'> </span>common with a stranger, and<span class='line-break'> </span>I have found most persons object<span class='line-break'> </span>to this lot for those reasons.</p>
<p>I find the deed antedates the<span class='line-break'> </span>contract for repair of lot, but as<span class='line-break'> </span>that cont. same with the lot,<span class='line-break'> </span>regardless of ownership, the date is<span class='line-break'> </span>immaterial. -</p>
<p>I have the honor to be<span class='line-break'> </span>Very respy. your Ob<sup>nt</sup> Servant</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133547">
<h3><a name="page-1133547">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 057)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-05-05'>May 5, 1862</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>At the meeting of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees of Mount Auburn held<span class='line-break'> </span>this day, it was</p>
<p>Voted - "That the Com<span class='line-break'></span>mitee on Grounds be authorized<span class='line-break'> </span>to pay <a href='/pages/subjects/57826' title='Shedd &amp; Edson'>Messrs Shedd &amp; Edson</a><span class='line-break'> </span>the sum of seven hundred &amp; thirty two<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; 86/100 dollars ($732.86) in addition<span class='line-break'> </span>to the sum of of $730 already paid,<span class='line-break'> </span>for which the contract was made,<span class='line-break'> </span>it being understood that they have<span class='line-break'> </span>actually expended in cash $1,482.86<span class='line-break'> </span>in completing the survey of the Cem<span class='line-break'></span>etery; it also being understood<span class='line-break'> </span>that they are to correct all errors<span class='line-break'> </span>that may be found in the survey<span class='line-break'> </span>and plans, if any, free of <span class='line-break'> </span>charge." -</p>
<p>A true copy<span class='line-break'> </span>Attest <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo W<sup>m</sup> Bond Esq</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-05-06'>May 6/62</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60950' title='Livermore, Oliver'>O. Livermore Esq.</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60948' title='Brighton, MA'>Brighton, Mass</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I am directed<span class='line-break'> </span>by the Committee on Lots to notify<span class='line-break'> </span>you that you can have liberty<span class='line-break'> </span>to construct a Catacomb tomb<span class='line-break'> </span>on your lot in Mount Auburn<span class='line-break'></span><a href='/pages/subjects/60949' title='Lot 2195'>no. 2195</a> - on payment of the usual<span class='line-break'> </span>sum for a tomb privilege - fifty dollars.<span class='line-break'> </span>$50. The face of the tomb to be on<span class='line-break'> </span>a line with the <a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>Receiving Tomb</a>, and<span class='line-break'> </span>the whole to be executed according to the<span class='line-break'> </span>23<sup>d</sup> &amp; 24<sup>th</sup> articles of the By-laws.</p>
<p>The By-laws you will find in<span class='line-break'> </span>your copy of the catalogue (edition of<span class='line-break'> </span>1860) which I presume you have.</p>
<p>Yours resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt Auburn</p>
<p>57</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133548">
<h3><a name="page-1133548">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 058)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-05-06'>May 6, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>At the meeting of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees of Mount Auburn held<span class='line-break'> </span>yesterday, the following vote was passed.</p>
<p>"That the Committee on Lots be<span class='line-break'> </span>authorized to grant to the purchasers<span class='line-break'> </span>of lots the privilege of constructing<span class='line-break'> </span>tombs and catacombs within the<span class='line-break'> </span>same at prices to be fixed by the<span class='line-break'> </span>Committee - not less than fifty dollars<span class='line-break'> </span>for each tomb or catacomb: - and they<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be further authorized to<span class='line-break'> </span>grant to proprietors of lots here<span class='line-break'></span>tofore purchased the same privilege<span class='line-break'> </span>at the same price, not less than <span class='line-break'> </span>fifty dollars for each tomb, which<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be constructed according<span class='line-break'> </span>to Articles 23<sup>d</sup> and 24<sup>th</sup> of the By-laws."</p>
<p>By the foregoing you will see<span class='line-break'> </span>that $50, at least, is required to be<span class='line-break'> </span>paid in all cases, and that thus<span class='line-break'> </span>the old rule (or rather exception) of no<span class='line-break'> </span>charge in cases of <ins>catacomb</ins> tombs<span class='line-break'> </span>is virtually abrogated.-</p>
<p>I have sent <a href='/pages/subjects/60950' title='Livermore, Oliver'>Mr Livermore,</a> of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60948' title='Brighton, MA'>Brighton</a>, the reply of the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots, that he has permission to con<span class='line-break'></span>struct a Catacomb tomb in <a href='/pages/subjects/60949' title='Lot 2195'>Lot<span class='line-break'> </span>2195</a> on payment of fifty dollars,<span class='line-break'> </span>($50.) the face of the tomb to <span class='line-break'> </span>be on a line with that of the<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>Receiving Tomb</a> - the whole to be<span class='line-break'> </span>executed according to the 23<sup>d</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>and 24<sup>th</sup> articles of the<span class='line-break'> </span>By-laws.-</p>
<p>Of course the financial part <span class='line-break'> </span>of that transaction must be attended<span class='line-break'> </span>to before <a href='/pages/subjects/60951' title='O&apos;Donnell'>O'Donnell</a> can do anything.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>58</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133549">
<h3><a name="page-1133549">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 059)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 Schol St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-05-07'>May 7, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/63912' title='Lowell, Charles Russell, II'>C.R. Lowell</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
