<p>In sending the ac<span class='line-break'></span>companying notice to some two or three<span class='line-break'> </span>hundred of our proprietors whose lots<span class='line-break'> </span>are therein described, your lot was<span class='line-break'> </span>casually overlooked - as it did not<span class='line-break'> </span>get on to my notes. But not only<span class='line-break'> </span>is <a href='/pages/subjects/63913' title='Lot 323'>Lot 323</a> deficient of proper bounds<span class='line-break'> </span>if it has any, but <a href='/pages/subjects/63914' title='Lot 1443'>lot 1443</a> - that<span class='line-break'> </span>of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/63915' title='Putnam, Samuel R.'>S. R. Putnam</a> - is not<span class='line-break'> </span>located at all on our plans, although<span class='line-break'> </span>I have seen it on a lithograph<span class='line-break'> </span>plan directly behind <a href='/pages/subjects/63913' title='lot 323'>lot 323</a>. The only<span class='line-break'> </span>plan however which we rely on does not<span class='line-break'> </span>contain it. The deed describes its<span class='line-break'> </span>situation thus - "adjoining <a href='/pages/subjects/63913' title='lot 323'>lot 323</a> on<span class='line-break'> </span>the southerly and westerly sides of the same."</p>
<p>It is therefore entirely evident that<span class='line-break'> </span>it must be laid out anew if it<span class='line-break'> </span>ever has been at all, [or where?]<span class='line-break'> </span>find a proof and this should<span class='line-break'> </span>be done previous to any other<span class='line-break'> </span>work that may be desired.</p>
<p>I made a verbal statement<span class='line-break'> </span>of this a few days since to your<span class='line-break'> </span>brother, <a href='/pages/subjects/63916' title='Lowell, James Russell'>James R.</a>, in consequence of<span class='line-break'> </span>receiving a written request from<span class='line-break'> </span>him that <a href='/pages/subjects/63917' title='O&apos;Brien'>O'Brien</a> should do<span class='line-break'> </span>some work on the lot: but he<span class='line-break'> </span>asked that I should put the<span class='line-break'> </span>statement in writing. While con<span class='line-break'></span>versing with him, it occurred to<span class='line-break'> </span>me, and I mentioned to him, that<span class='line-break'> </span>you were the representative of the lot - <span class='line-break'> </span>recently appointed upon the application,<span class='line-break'> </span>of the several heirs. I left him without<span class='line-break'> </span>any definite understanding of whether this<span class='line-break'> </span>matter would receive his attention,<span class='line-break'> </span>and therefore communicate the facts<span class='line-break'> </span>to you, as perhaps I ought to have <span class='line-break'> </span>done in the first instance, but as<span class='line-break'> </span>a matter of courtesy called on<span class='line-break'> </span>him.</p>
<p>59<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133550">
<h3><a name="page-1133550">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 060)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>The laying out of lots and putting<span class='line-break'> </span>down their bounds is the proper duty of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation and cannot be delegated<span class='line-break'> </span>to others; and should precede any<span class='line-break'> </span>other work to be done on a lot.-</p>
<p>If the <a href='/pages/subjects/63958' title='Putnam, Mary Lowell'><!--Mary Traill Spence Lowell-->Putnam</a> lot can be laid out<span class='line-break'> </span>in a regular manner on one of the other<span class='line-break'> </span>side of <a href='/pages/subjects/63913' title='Lot 323'>lot 323</a>, four 8 inch granite<span class='line-break'> </span>posts will answer as the bounds for<span class='line-break'> </span>both lots- costing, with their setting,<span class='line-break'> </span>$8.-</p>
<p>I will issue a permit to <a href='/pages/subjects/63917' title='O&apos;Brien'>O'Brien</a><span class='line-break'> </span>at any time for the work you wish,<span class='line-break'> </span>after we can determine the location.</p>
<p>By the way, please specify the<span class='line-break'> </span>"other work", which you add to<span class='line-break'> </span>the building of "catacombs." The reason<span class='line-break'> </span>will appear in the copy of the rules<span class='line-break'> </span>enclosed rule.-</p>
<p>very truly<span class='line-break'> </span>Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1862-05-17'>May 17, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/63930' title='Hilton, James'>Mr Jas. Hilton</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, I send the<span class='line-break'> </span>petition which I drew up for<span class='line-break'> </span>the signatures of your brothers<span class='line-break'> </span>and sisters in <a href='/pages/subjects/63931' title='Acton, MA'>Acton</a>. I supposed<span class='line-break'> </span>you would call for it before leaving<span class='line-break'> </span>town.</p>
<p>When you return the petition,<span class='line-break'> </span>please send me $2 for recording<span class='line-break'> </span>deed &amp; going to <a href='/pages/subjects/53203' title='Cambridge, MA'>Cambridge</a> &amp; elsewhere<span class='line-break'> </span>in searching for it. I think you<span class='line-break'> </span>will agree that I fully earned<span class='line-break'> </span>the money.</p>
<p>I shall record the deed as<span class='line-break'> </span>it is, and if we can even catch<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63932' title='Drew, Thomas J.'>Mr. Thos. J. Drew</a> we will make<span class='line-break'> </span>him cure it, if possible- but a<span class='line-break'> </span>new deed cannot be given now<span class='line-break'> </span>because <a href='/pages/subjects/63933' title='Drew, Thomas J., Mrs.'>Mrs Drew</a> is dead, and it's<span class='line-break'> </span>rule of the Corporation do not allow any other<span class='line-break'> </span>person than the Corporation to make a deed<span class='line-break'> </span>to several heirs.</p>
<p>Yours Truly,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133551">
<h3><a name="page-1133551">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 061)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-06-10'>June 10, 1862</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63791' title='Sumner, C. P., Mrs.'>Mrs. C. P. Sumner</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I have communicated<span class='line-break'> </span>your request to have your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>taken care of for the present year;<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63792' title='Spooner, William H., Jr.'>Mr. W<sup>m</sup> H. Spooner Jr.</a>, the Gardener,<span class='line-break'> </span>will take charge of the same<span class='line-break'> </span>for ($3) three dollars. I was<span class='line-break'> </span>requested by the lady who called<span class='line-break'> </span>yesterday to return this infor<span class='line-break'></span>mation.</p>
<p>Very truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y<span class='line-break'> </span>Mt Auburn</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-06-04'>June 4, 1862</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo. W<sup>m</sup> Bond</a> Esq Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>At the meeting of the Trustees of Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn <date when='1862-06-02'>June 2<sup>d</sup> 1862</date>, the following votes were<span class='line-break'> </span>passed;-</p>
<p>"That the Committee on Grounds be au<span class='line-break'></span>thorized to raise the upper part of <a href='/pages/subjects/58209' title='Asa Gray Garden'>the<span class='line-break'> </span>Lawn</a> one &amp; a half feet higher than<span class='line-break'> </span>it has already been raised, and<span class='line-break'> </span>at an expense not exceeding $500.-"</p>
<p>That the Committee on Grounds<span class='line-break'> </span>be authorized to complete the <a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>Receiving<span class='line-break'> </span>Tomb</a> now in progress, or a part<span class='line-break'> </span>thereof, as they think proper,<span class='line-break'> </span>at an expense not exceeding three<span class='line-break'> </span>thousand five hundred dollars.<span class='line-break'> </span>($3,500).-</p>
<p>That the Treasurer be authorized<span class='line-break'> </span>to pay to <a href='/pages/subjects/63792' title='Spooner, William H., Jr.'>Mr Spooner</a> the amt of said <a href='/pages/subjects/63792' title='Spooner, William H., Jr.'>Spooner's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>note to <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jona. Mann</a>, amtg. to $250 and interest, being<span class='line-break'> </span>one of the votes secured by the mortgage of the <a href='/pages/subjects/61312' title='Greenhouse'>Greenhouse</a><span class='line-break'> </span>now owned by the Trustees, upon the said note being deliver<span class='line-break'> </span>[?} the Treas- canceled." [?]</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133552">
<h3><a name="page-1133552">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 062)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-07-14'>July 14, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60217' title='Glover, Joseph B.'>Jos. B. Glover</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Since meeting you three<span class='line-break'> </span>days since, I have handed the<span class='line-break'> </span>survey of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/66868' title='Ward, James O.'>Mr. Ward's</a> lot in<span class='line-break'> </span>Mt Auburn, &amp; the report of the Com.<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots thereon to <a href='/pages/subjects/65205' title='Andrews, William T.'>Mr. Andrews</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>and requested him to see the other<span class='line-break'> </span>members of the Committee with a<span class='line-break'> </span>view to a revision of their former<span class='line-break'> </span>decision.- The papers have been<span class='line-break'> </span>returned to us with the Committee's<span class='line-break'> </span>decision endorsed-to the effect<span class='line-break'> </span>that the Corporation will assume<span class='line-break'> </span>the perpetual care of said lot for<span class='line-break'> </span>$500- the fence to be painted as<span class='line-break'> </span>often as once in three years if<span class='line-break'> </span>required."</p>
<p>Truly yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-07-14'>July 14/62</date></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I enclose the accom<span class='line-break'></span>panying circular, which has been<span class='line-break'> </span>sent to some too hundred of our pro<span class='line-break'></span>prietors (out of say 3200) whose lots have<span class='line-break'> </span>never been permanently marked with<span class='line-break'> </span>bounds; and responses have ben quite<span class='line-break'> </span>generally given directing granite posts to<span class='line-break'> </span>be set.</p>
<p>Besides your own proper lot enclosed<span class='line-break'> </span>with iron fence you have five lots<span class='line-break'> </span>exclusive of the one purchased for <a href='/pages/subjects/63953' title='Peabody, Mr.'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>Peabody</a>, which, as laid out on our<span class='line-break'> </span>plan with passageway intervening<span class='line-break'> </span>would require about 20 posts.</p>
<p>No bounds have even been affixed<span class='line-break'> </span>until we drove temporary wooden<span class='line-break'> </span>stakes last autumn.-</p>
<p>I will wait upon you, if you<span class='line-break'> </span>desire further explanation, as I could<span class='line-break'> </span>show you upon a rough outline,<span class='line-break'> </span>in five minutes, the position of<span class='line-break'> </span>things.</p>
<p>Very Resp.y yours,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>Austin J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary Mt A</p>
<p>To<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63954' title='Appleton, Samuel, Mrs.'>Mrs Sam<sup>l</sup> Appleton</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133553">
<h3><a name="page-1133553">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 063)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-07-25'>July 25. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54775' title='Kuhn, George H.'>G.H. Kuhn</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A survey of <a href='/pages/subjects/63958' title='Putnam, Mary Lowell'>Mrs<span class='line-break'> </span>Putnam's</a> lot in Mt Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>has been reported to the Comm<sup> ee </sup><span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots and they agree to accept<span class='line-break'> </span>the bequest for the repair of said<span class='line-break'> </span>lot in perpetuity.</p>
<p>I write merely to notify<span class='line-break'> </span>you that all things are ready<span class='line-break'> </span>on part of the Corporation, and<span class='line-break'> </span>not to urge  haste on your<span class='line-break'> </span>part.-</p>
<p>When you are ready, I will<span class='line-break'> </span>send the usual document for<span class='line-break'> </span>execution by you.</p>
<p>Truly yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secy Mt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1862-07-25'>July 25. 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65937' title='Washburn, Emory'>Hon. Emory Washburn</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have caused a<span class='line-break'> </span>survey of the lot in Mt Auburn of<span class='line-break'> </span>the late <a href='/pages/subjects/53154' title='Lombard, Israel'>Israel Lombard</a> to be reported<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Committee on Lots, and they have<span class='line-break'> </span>replied that the Corporation will<span class='line-break'> </span>accept the bequest of <a href='/pages/subjects/53154' title='Lombard, Israel'>Mr Lombard</a><span class='line-break'> </span>according to the provisions of his will.</p>
<p>It is Evident from the clause<span class='line-break'> </span>referred to that he did not con<span class='line-break'></span>template a guaranty of perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>repair. The Trustees will accept it<span class='line-break'> </span>and apply the income as directed.</p>
<p>I enclose a contract in the<span class='line-break'> </span>regular form, which I suppose should<span class='line-break'> </span>be signed by the Ex<sup> ors </sup> or a majority<span class='line-break'> </span>of them. After Execution, it is re<span class='line-break'></span>corded and returned to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Ex<sup> ors </sup></p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>63</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133554">
<h3><a name="page-1133554">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 064)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>that more land has been<span class='line-break'> </span>enclosed than the proprietor is<span class='line-break'> </span>entitiled to, to require him or her<span class='line-break'> </span>to remove the fence from the land<span class='line-break'> </span>trespassed on. They do not nec<span class='line-break'></span>essarily exercise that right, <span class='line-break'> </span>unless the trespass is injurious<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Corporation or to some other<span class='line-break'> </span>proprietor.</p>
<p>In this case, the space between<span class='line-break'> </span>your lot and <a href='/pages/subjects/63797' title='Bradford, Mr.'>Mr Bradford's</a>, by<span class='line-break'> </span>reason of this Encroachment, is too<span class='line-break'> </span>narrow at the rear end of the lots:<span class='line-break'> </span>and I am instructed by the Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots to notify you that<span class='line-break'> </span>they expect the obstruction to be re<span class='line-break'></span>moved. This they have the right<span class='line-break'> </span>to require of the proprietor at his or<span class='line-break'> </span>her own expense. Under certain<span class='line-break'> </span>circumstances, perhaps they would<span class='line-break'> </span>authorize it to be done at the<span class='line-break'> </span>expense of the Corporation. I<span class='line-break'> </span>should like to confer with you<span class='line-break'> </span>on the subject at an early day.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-10-06'>Oct. 6. 1862</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63792' title='Spooner, William H., Jr.'>Mr W<sup>m</sup>. H. Spooner</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Trustees, this<span class='line-break'> </span>day voted to accede to your<span class='line-break'> </span>request so far as relates to<span class='line-break'> </span>your resignation as Gardener<span class='line-break'> </span>is concerned:<span class='line-break'> </span>And that the Treas<sup> r </sup> be<span class='line-break'> </span>authorized to cancel the<span class='line-break'> </span>case with you upon a<span class='line-break'> </span>full settlement of all <del>accounts</del><span class='line-break'> </span>amounts due from you to<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation, and upon<span class='line-break'> </span>a surrender, by you, in good<span class='line-break'> </span>order, of the leased premises.</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt Auburn</p>
<p>64<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133555">
<h3><a name="page-1133555">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 065)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>65</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-10-06'>Oct. 6 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D.L. Winsor Esq.</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup> [?]</p>
<p>Dear Sir,-</p>
<p>The Trustees of <span class='line-break'> </span>Mount Auburn today chose <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63799' title='Derby, James, Jr.'>James Derby, Jr.</a> as Gatekeeper <span class='line-break'> </span>for the remainder of <a href='/pages/subjects/60426' title='Safford, De Forest'>Mr. Safford's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>year---upon a salary of <span class='line-break'> </span>four hundred dollars.</p>
<p>It was also voted,<span class='line-break'> </span>"[?] the additional sum of 75 dlr<span class='line-break'> </span>per week be paid him to enable <span class='line-break'> </span>him to compensate a substitute <span class='line-break'> </span>whom he shall procure to <span class='line-break'> </span>him from his duties as Gatekeep<span class='line-break'> </span>one half of every Sabbath. Said <span class='line-break'> </span>substitute must (in the judgment of <span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee on Interments and <span class='line-break'> </span>the Superindent) be as [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>and competent as <a href='/pages/subjects/63799' title='Derby, James, Jr.'>Mr. Derby</a>.</p>
<p>The Trustees also adopted the <span class='line-break'> </span>recommendation of the Special <span class='line-break'> </span>Com<sup>ee</sup> upon <a href='/pages/subjects/63792' title='Spooner, William H., Jr.'>Mr. Spooner's</a> com<span class='line-break'></span>munication-in terms<span class='line-break'></span>to accede to <a href='/pages/subjects/63792' title='Spooner, William H., Jr.'>Mr. Spooner's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>his relinquishment of the office <span class='line-break'> </span>of Gardener, and that the Trea<span class='line-break'></span>urer be authorized to cancel <span class='line-break'> </span>the lease with <a href='/pages/subjects/63792' title='Spooner, William H., Jr.'>Mr. Spooner</a>, upon <span class='line-break'> </span>a full settlement of all amounts <span class='line-break'> </span>due the Corporation from <a href='/pages/subjects/63792' title='Spooner, William H., Jr.'>Mr. <span class='line-break'> </span>Spooner</a>, and a surrender by <span class='line-break'> </span>him in good order of the <span class='line-break'> </span>leased premises:-</p>
<p>that the office of Gardener <span class='line-break'> </span>be abolished, and that the <span class='line-break'> </span>care and superintendence of <span class='line-break'> </span>lots be committed to the Super<span class='line-break'></span>intendent in such manner<span class='line-break'> </span>and under such directions as<span class='line-break'> </span>the Trustees shall prescribe.</p>
<p>The carrying out the above orders<span class='line-break'> </span>was committed to Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/65205' title='Andrews, William T.'>Andrews</a>, <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63802' title='Rand, Edward S.'>Rand</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/62841' title='Cheever, James'>Cheever</a> (the old Com<sup>ee</sup>) <span class='line-break'> </span>with power to make such purchases <span class='line-break'> </span>and arragements as may be nec<span class='line-break'></span>essary in the premises.</p>
<p>Truly yours,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>Only on a [?]be made of the late fee for substitute<span class='line-break'> </span>on the Sabbath as he produces [?] from the payment of.-</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133556">
<h3><a name="page-1133556">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 067)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>67</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-10-30'>Oct.<sup>r</sup> 30, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/63803' title='Burbank, James, Mrs.'>Mrs. James Burbank</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63804' title='New Orleans, LA'>New Orleans, La.</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam, <a href='/pages/subjects/63805' title='Hall, James'>Mr James Hall</a>, of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, informs me that you wish to sell the lot<span class='line-break'> </span>in Mount Auburn Cemetery - <a href='/pages/subjects/63806' title='Lot 2660'>No 2660</a> - belonging to the<span class='line-break'> </span>estate of your late husband, and that you have forwarded<span class='line-break'> </span>him written authority for that purpose.</p>
<p>I suppose you were not aware that the lots in<span class='line-break'> </span>our Cemetery are declared by the Charter of the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>to the <ins>real</ins> estate; and as such they descend, upon the death<span class='line-break'> </span>of the proprietor, to his heirs at law - that is the children.<span class='line-break'> </span>A widow has <ins>dower</ins> or <ins>third</ins> of the husband's real estate <ins>for life.</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>but we never regard the dower in a lot in the Cemetery.</p>
<p>The case then is, as I understand, that your children are<span class='line-break'> </span>all minors, and cannot convey any real estate by which they<span class='line-break'> </span>will be bound when they come to their majority; and you<span class='line-break'> </span>cannot convey it for them.-</p>
<p>The only course then that can be pursued is to<span class='line-break'> </span>apply to the Probate Court in the County where the estate is<span class='line-break'> </span>situated for the appointment of a guardian to the children:<span class='line-break'> </span>and that guardian must be an inhabitant of Mass<span class='line-break'></span>achusetts. He then applies to the Court for leave to <span class='line-break'> </span>sell the estate, which leave being granted, he can<span class='line-break'> </span>convey the lot by a deed that will be valid and<span class='line-break'> </span>forever bind their heirs. Unless this course is pu<span class='line-break'></span>sued, it will not be easy to find a purchaser.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133557">
<h3><a name="page-1133557">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 068)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>68</p>
<p>Indeed, I doubt whether any one could be found <span class='line-break'> </span>who would take sale title.</p>
<p>Advising with <a href='/pages/subjects/63805' title='Hall, James'>Mr Hall</a> we have both come<span class='line-break'> </span>to the conclusion that it will save time to send <span class='line-break'> </span>you the necessary papers to be executed there<span class='line-break'> </span>and returned by the first mail and leave will<span class='line-break'> </span>be obtained, doubtless, at the first can't that sits<span class='line-break'> </span>after the section of the same to him. If there should<span class='line-break'> </span>ever be occasion to appoint a guardian in <a href='/pages/subjects/63804' title='New Orleans, LA'>New Orleans</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>(I understand there is none now) the proceeds can be<span class='line-break'> </span>passed over to him. Until then it will be the duty<span class='line-break'> </span>of the person appointed to hold the funds and use<span class='line-break'> </span>them for the benefit of you and your family according<span class='line-break'> </span>to his best discretion, anything to protect the portions,<span class='line-break'> </span>a sell is his dower for <ins>third</ins> of <ins>inheritance</ins> and not<span class='line-break'> </span>investments regard the dower in a lot in the Cemetery approval.<span class='line-break'> </span>The case has it, as I understand, ^<ins>of the children</ins> if it is correct now in<span class='line-break'></span>all minor, are heard, and fill out the date of birth, as<span class='line-break'> </span>directed at the upon - <ins>day</ins>, <ins>month</ins>, &amp; <ins>year</ins>. We did not know<span class='line-break'> </span>exactly how many of the children are over 14. Those over 14<span class='line-break'> </span>can and should nominate their own guardian. You perceive<span class='line-break'> </span>a blank for that purpose below <a href='/pages/subjects/63805' title='Hall, James'>Mr Hall's</a> signature.<span class='line-break'> </span>Write in the names of those above 14 after the words- "Personally<span class='line-break'> </span>appeared the above named", and have them acknowledge to same<span class='line-break'> </span>before a magistrate. Sign your own name at the bottom<span class='line-break'> </span>and that paper is complete.</p>
<p>Turn to the bottom of 2<sup>d</sup> page of paper, no 2, and sign your<span class='line-break'> </span>name there and the work is done, Return the documents to <a href='/pages/subjects/63805' title='Hall, James'>Mr Hall</a><span class='line-break'> </span>or me, as he shall direct.</p>
<p>Very respy. your<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y Mt.A.</p>
<p>In page no. 2, I will write in the names of the children after its return to me. I shall be<span class='line-break'> </span>able to write them correctly from your giving of them correctly from page 1.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133558">
<h3><a name="page-1133558">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 069)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>69</p>
<p>Indeed, I doubt whether any one could be found<span class='line-break'> </span>who would take said title.</p>
<p>Advising with <a href='/pages/subjects/63805' title='Hall, James'>Mr Hall</a>, we have both come<span class='line-break'> </span>to the conclusion that it will save time to send<span class='line-break'> </span>you the necessary papers to be executed there<span class='line-break'> </span>and returned by the first mail, and leave will<span class='line-break'> </span>be obtained, doubtless, at the first court that sits<span class='line-break'> </span>after the return of the same to him.- If there should<span class='line-break'> </span>ever be occasion to appoint a guardian in <a href='/pages/subjects/63804' title='New Orleans, LA'>New Orleans</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>(I understand there is none now,) the proceeds can be<span class='line-break'> </span>passed over to him. Until then it will be the duty<span class='line-break'> </span>of the person appointed to hold the funds, and use<span class='line-break'> </span>them for the benefit of you and your family according<span class='line-break'> </span>to his best discretion, as you perceive the petition to<span class='line-break'> </span>sell is for the purpose of <ins>maintenance</ins> and not<span class='line-break'> </span>investment. If this course meets your approval,<span class='line-break'> </span>please insert the correct name ^<sup>of the children</sup> (if not correct now) in<span class='line-break'> </span>the paper marked 1, and fill out the dates of birth, as<span class='line-break'> </span>directed at the top - <ins>day</ins>, <ins>month</ins>, &amp; <ins>year</ins>. We did not know<span class='line-break'> </span>exactly how many of the children are over 14. Those over 14,<span class='line-break'> </span>can and must nominate their own guardian. You perceive<span class='line-break'> </span>a blank for that purpose below <a href='/pages/subjects/63805' title='Hall, James'>Mr Hall's</a> signature.<span class='line-break'> </span>Write in the names of those above 14, after the words - "Personally<span class='line-break'> </span>appeared the above-named", and have them acknowledge the same<span class='line-break'> </span>before a magistrate. Sign your own name at the bottom,<span class='line-break'> </span>and that paper is complete.</p>
<p>Turn to the bottom of 2<sup>d</sup> page of paper, no 2, and sign your<span class='line-break'> </span>name there, and the work is done. Return the documents to <a href='/pages/subjects/63805' title='Hall, James'>Mr Hall</a><span class='line-break'> </span>or me, as he shall direct.</p>
<p>Very respy. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. Auburn</p>
<p>In paper no. 2, I will write in the names of the children after its return to me. I shall be able<span class='line-break'> </span>to write them correctly, from your giving them correctly in paper no 1.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133559">
<h3><a name="page-1133559">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 070)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1862-11-10'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 10, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/63808' title='Crane, B. F.'>B. F. Crane</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/83601' title='Central Park'>Com<sup>ee</sup> on Central Park</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of <date when='1862-11-04'>4<sup>th</sup></date> [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>relating to the swan which was<span class='line-break'> </span>last year loaned to our Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation has just been handed to me.</p>
<p>We have been quite unfortunate <span class='line-break'> </span>so far in swan-raising. The female<span class='line-break'> </span>laid two eggs last spring &amp; they were<span class='line-break'> </span>set under a goose as she would<span class='line-break'> </span>not set. One cygnet was<span class='line-break'> </span>hatched &amp; came to the age of two<span class='line-break'> </span>or three weeks, &amp;, died.</p>
<p>Under the circumstances we should<span class='line-break'> </span>like a further loan of the male<span class='line-break'> </span>bird if you feel inclined to<span class='line-break'> </span>grant it - say another year.</p>
<p>I have confirmed with the President<span class='line-break'> </span>[last line of text not visible on scan]</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1862-11-10'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 10, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/63809' title='Bridges, A.'>A. Bridges</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 6<sup>th</sup> to<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63810' title='Hasting, Mr.'>Mr. Hasting's</a> was handed me on<span class='line-break'> </span>Saturday. Will you have the<span class='line-break'> </span>kindness to forward to <a href='/pages/subjects/63808' title='Crane, B. F.'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>Crane</a> the accompanying note.</p>
<p>Very truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span>A. J. Coolidge<span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. A.</p>
<p>70</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133560">
<h3><a name="page-1133560">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 071)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1862-12-04'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 4, 1862</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/63811' title='Murray, Washington'>Washington Murray</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir, Yours of <date when='1862-11-18'>18<sup>th</sup></date> alt. giving <span class='line-break'> </span>me the desired information respecting <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/101912' title='Dana, Nancy'>Mrs Dana</a> was rec<sup>d</sup> for which I <span class='line-break'> </span>thank you.</p>
<p>I enclose the usual blank <span class='line-break'> </span>for respresentation of lot of dec<sup>d</sup> prop.<span class='line-break'> </span>The charter regulation and by-law you <span class='line-break'> </span>will see at the bottom, in a note.</p>
<p>I suppose in this case, as 1 lot<span class='line-break'> </span>is left in Cemet. to Edward, Stephen, <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/101911' title='Dana, William P. W.'>W<sup>m</sup><!--Dana--></a> &amp; Samuel, one of them will <span class='line-break'> </span>be designated to represent it, upon<span class='line-break'> </span>the request of the other.  I think, too, as the <span class='line-break'> </span>whole family are equally interested in <span class='line-break'> </span>the lot, it is proper for all children <span class='line-break'> </span>to whom it is convenient to present <span class='line-break'> </span>the blank for signature, to exercise <span class='line-break'> </span>their privilege in nominating the person <span class='line-break'> </span>whom they think can most conveniently <span class='line-break'> </span>attend to the duty - small, perhaps, <span class='line-break'> </span>ordinarily, but one which it will <span class='line-break'> </span>be pleasant to feel there will <span class='line-break'> </span>be no embarrassment in the <span class='line-break'> </span>performance of, as often as it<span class='line-break'> </span>arises. The representative, you are<span class='line-break'> </span>doubtless aware, is the proper for<span class='line-break'> </span>son to give any orders, <ins>in writing</ins>,<span class='line-break'> </span>whenever any work is to be done,<span class='line-break'> </span>or an interment to be made.</p>
<p>As you are a member of the bar,<span class='line-break'> </span>for then explanation will be unnec<span class='line-break'></span>essary. Indeed, none would be needed,<span class='line-break'> </span>but our practices perhaps a little<span class='line-break'> </span>anomalous.</p>
<p>Since you wrote me, I have seen<span class='line-break'> </span>a very handsome ^<sup>obit.</sup> notice of <a href='/pages/subjects/101912' title='Dana, Nancy'>Mrs Dana</a><span class='line-break'> </span>in the <a href='/pages/subjects/63813' title='Christian Watchman &amp; Reflector'>Christian Watchman &amp; Reflector</a> - which<span class='line-break'> </span>of course interested me as I am too<span class='line-break'> </span>a Baptist. My father was well acquain<span class='line-break'></span>ted with the Winchester family. He is now<span class='line-break'> </span>75 yrs old - has survived the most of them. The<span class='line-break'> </span>widow of <a href='/pages/subjects/57584' title='Winchester, William P.'>W<sup>m</sup> P.</a> is a neighbor of ours.</p>
<p>Return the petition at your convenience.</p>
<p>Very truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. A.</p>
<p>71</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133561">
<h3><a name="page-1133561">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 072)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1862-12-05'>Dec. 5, 1862</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63814' title='Hatfield, Charles H., Mrs.'>Mrs. Chas. H. Hatfield</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I am informed by <span class='line-break'> </span>the Treas<sup>r</sup> that you have <span class='line-break'> </span>recently deposited with him $100 <span class='line-break'> </span>for the repair of your lot in <span class='line-break'> </span>Mt. Auburn; under the terms <span class='line-break'> </span>of trust adopted by the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation.</p>
<p>It will, of course, be necessary <span class='line-break'> </span>to put this into the form of a <span class='line-break'> </span>contract, which should be re<span class='line-break'></span>corded on the books of the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation.</p>
<p>If you will call in almost <span class='line-break'> </span>any day - say not before 12 o'clock <span class='line-break'> </span>I shall be pretty sure to be here. I <span class='line-break'> </span>am sometimes detained out of <span class='line-break'> </span>town in the morning, and do not <span class='line-break'> </span>get in till near noon.</p>
<p>Yours respectfully,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary of Mt. A.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-02-28'>Feb. 28, 1863</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63814' title='Hatfield, Charles H., Mrs.'>Mrs. Chas. H. Hatfield</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I have had the <span class='line-break'> </span>usual survey and report upon your <span class='line-break'> </span>lot in Mt. Auburn &amp; had submitted <span class='line-break'> </span>the same with your inquiry to the <span class='line-break'> </span>Committee on Lots, to ascertain for what <span class='line-break'> </span>sum they would <ins>guaranty</ins> the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>repair of the same: and after <span class='line-break'> </span>consideration of the matter they have <span class='line-break'> </span>authorized me to notify you that <span class='line-break'> </span>they will make such contract <span class='line-break'> </span>for <ins>three hundred</ins> dollars - that <span class='line-break'> </span>is for two hundred dollars besides <span class='line-break'> </span>what you have paid already.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>72</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133562">
<h3><a name="page-1133562">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 073)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1863-02-28'>Feby. 28, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/63815' title='Davenport, Charles'>Chas. Davenport</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I send you the <span class='line-break'> </span>duplicate copy of plan of your <span class='line-break'> </span>lots in Mt. Auburn filed by <span class='line-break'> </span>me with plans of the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation, with approval of the <span class='line-break'> </span>Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots.</p>
<p>Also the duplicate copies of <span class='line-break'> </span>the first plan made by <a href='/pages/subjects/56692' title='Wadsworth, Alexander'>Mr. <span class='line-break'> </span>Wadsworth</a>, which you decided <span class='line-break'> </span>not to file. -</p>
<p>My charge is $100 which <span class='line-break'> </span>you may please send <span class='line-break'> </span>and oblige.</p>
<p>Yours truly,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-05-02'>May 2, 1863</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/57826' title='Shedd &amp; Edson'>Messrs Shedd &amp; Edson</a></p>
<p>Gentlemen,</p>
<p>I regret that I have <span class='line-break'> </span>again to call your attention to the <span class='line-break'> </span>fact that the survey and entry upon <span class='line-break'> </span>the place of lots sold last year in the <span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery has not yet been made. The<span class='line-break'> </span>season when the result of such survey <span class='line-break'> </span>and delineation becomes most valuable <span class='line-break'> </span>to the Corporation has come.</p>
<p>I do not quite understand the <span class='line-break'> </span>ground on which the delay is to be <span class='line-break'> </span>justified.</p>
<p>Yours truly, <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>73</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133563">
<h3><a name="page-1133563">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 074)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-05-27'>May 27/63</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63818' title='Thacher, B.'>B. Thacher</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>In order to render <span class='line-break'> </span>our Register of Interments complete, <span class='line-break'> </span>which I am now endeavoring to <span class='line-break'> </span>do, will you please send me <span class='line-break'> </span>the <ins>age</ins> (in years, mos. &amp; ds.) of <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/63819' title='Tacher, Mary'>Mrs. Mary Thacher</a>, whose body <span class='line-break'> </span>was interred in your lot in <span class='line-break'> </span>Mt. Auburn on the 17<sup>th</sup> of Jany. <span class='line-break'> </span>last.</p>
<p>No other fact was wanting on <span class='line-break'> </span>your order. By your prompt reply <span class='line-break'> </span>you will will oblige.</p>
<p>Yours truly,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>Confidential</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-05-28'>May 28, 1863</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Chas. G. Nazro</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclose a notice <span class='line-break'> </span>to a Special Com<sup>ee</sup> of which you are <span class='line-break'> </span>Chairman, accompanied with some <span class='line-break'> </span>facts bearing upon the matter.-</p>
<p>Two or three days since, I <span class='line-break'> </span>sent to <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr. Curtis</a>, at his request, <span class='line-break'> </span>a paper containing some reasons for <span class='line-break'> </span>uniting the offices of Secretary &amp; Treas<sup>r</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>in the same person, if the Trustees <span class='line-break'> </span>should find no sufficient imped<span class='line-break'></span>iment. These were in substance what <span class='line-break'> </span>I had previously expressed to him, <span class='line-break'> </span>when it was supposed two years since <span class='line-break'> </span>then would be some change with <span class='line-break'> </span>the duties, and possibly in the person, <span class='line-break'> </span>of Treasurer.-</p>
<p>I think this ^<sup>course</sup> would be the one <span class='line-break'> </span>most satisfactory to the Corporation and <span class='line-break'> </span>Proprietors.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr. Curtis</a> stated that the wished</p>
<p>74<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133564">
<h3><a name="page-1133564">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 075)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>send the paper referred to<span class='line-break'> </span>yourself.  If you have received<span class='line-break'> </span>it, (you will no doubt, if you have not)<span class='line-break'> </span>I desire to say, that I should not<span class='line-break'> </span>have ventured to submit the views<span class='line-break'> </span>there expressed, but for the full known fact<span class='line-break'> </span>that <a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Mr Bond</a>'s large private bu<span class='line-break'></span>siness renders the office one of no<span class='line-break'> </span>importance to him - indeed it would<span class='line-break'> </span>be a hindrance, if he must keep one<span class='line-break'> </span>in attendance all the time. I believe it<span class='line-break'> </span>would be better to pay one person well,<span class='line-break'> </span>and let the Corporation have the benefit of<span class='line-break'> </span>his services, than give one third pay to<span class='line-break'> </span>two persons, and be entitled to only a<span class='line-break'> </span>fraction of their time.</p>
<p>I have no practice to conflict with the<span class='line-break'> </span>discharge of the duties of both offices, and<span class='line-break'> </span>I feel that I can shortly make the<span class='line-break'> </span>duties of Treasurer, as well as I may<span class='line-break'> </span>already have become acquainted with those of<span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary.</p>
<p>I ought to earn $1500 per annum,<span class='line-break'> </span>and I see no reason why I should<span class='line-break'> </span>so long have been inattentive to the<span class='line-break'> </span>suggestions of prudence. But the fact is<span class='line-break'> </span>this: I <ins>dislike change</ins>, and have always<span class='line-break'> </span>borne the reputation, where I have a taste<span class='line-break'> </span>for any duty, of working without ^<sup>sufficient</sup> pay. I<span class='line-break'> </span>think I should probably continue to do<span class='line-break'> </span>so, did not the necessities of the times<span class='line-break'> </span>and my advancing steps in life admonish<span class='line-break'> </span>me. It is, however a somewhat serious<span class='line-break'> </span>matter for one to abandon (or nearly so)<span class='line-break'> </span>the profession in which he has embarked,<span class='line-break'> </span>for an office, however lucrative, which<span class='line-break'> </span>in the nature of things lasts but a<span class='line-break'> </span>few years. And I ought not to do this,<span class='line-break'> </span>without feeling that I shall not, in the<span class='line-break'> </span>end, regret it. I do not think I should<span class='line-break'> </span>regret it if I can ^<sup>aid in</sup> accomplishing for our<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery what I have in view- the estab<span class='line-break'></span>lishment of it, in general and detail, upon<span class='line-break'> </span>a moneyed basis that will make it in<span class='line-break'> </span>future generations still the delightful<span class='line-break'> </span>spot of resort for the citizen and stranger.</p>
<p>Believing you will be governed by<span class='line-break'> </span>your convictions of what is most for the interest<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation you represent.</p>
<p>I am very resp.y<span class='line-break'> </span>your ob<sup>t</sup> serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>75</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133565">
<h3><a name="page-1133565">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 076)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>76</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-05-28'>May 28, 1863</date></p>
<p>Messrs	<a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>C.G. Nazro</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Chas. P. Curtis</a>		<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/62841' title='Cheever, James'>James Cheever</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Committee</p>
<p>Gentlemen,</p>
<p>The Trustees of Mount Auburn <span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery at their last meeting, <date when='1863-05-04'>May 4<sup>th</sup></date>, upon motion <span class='line-break'> </span>by <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Mr Nazro</a>, adopted the following vote:</p>
<p>“That the expediency of increasing the compensation <span class='line-break'> </span>of the Secretary be referred to a special committee of <span class='line-break'> </span>three persons, and upon nomination by the Chair, <span class='line-break'> </span>Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Nazro</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Curtis</a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/62841' title='Cheever, James'>Cheever</a> were so chosen.”-</p>
<p>As this vote appears to have reference to myself, <span class='line-break'> </span>I know you will kindly receive a word or two in<span class='line-break'> </span>addition to the official notice thereof.-</p>
<p>The duties of the Secretary have from year to year <span class='line-break'> </span>been growing in importance to the Corporation and the indiv<span class='line-break'></span>idual members, so that one may easily and laboriously <span class='line-break'> </span>spend nearly the whole of this time to the advantage of the <span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation.  The duties directly entailed by the By-laws <span class='line-break'> </span>give but a faint idea of the time and skill that is <span class='line-break'> </span>called into service in faithfully carrying out what be<span class='line-break'></span>comes necessary for one filling the place of Secretary.  <span class='line-break'> </span>Information in relation to purchase, to work, to the manage<span class='line-break'></span>ment of things by the Corporation, the ever active necessity of<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133566">
<h3><a name="page-1133566">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 077)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>77</p>
<p>explaining the details of operations, and of all [aging?] prejudices, or of <span class='line-break'> </span>soothing the minds of those who fancy [calculable?] neglect of <span class='line-break'> </span>their wishes- the presentation to proprietors of the desirable- <span class='line-break'> </span>ness, and often the necessity of their making provision for <span class='line-break'> </span>the perpetual care of their lots, and the frequent con<span class='line-break'></span>ferences which ensue before the accomplishment of this in <span class='line-break'> </span>each case together with the considerable correspondence which <span class='line-break'> </span>the faithful performance of duty requires is all, consuming<span class='line-break'> </span>amount of time that would not be supposed by any<span class='line-break'></span>one unless he observed the modus <ins>operandi</ins> with his own <span class='line-break'> </span>eyes.</p>
<p>The recent issue of "permits for work” to proprietors<span class='line-break'> </span>takes very much more time than was anticipated, often <span class='line-break'> </span><ins>hours</ins> in each day.  The proper keeping of the Register of <span class='line-break'> </span>Internment (these are in <ins>duplicate</ins>, and have to be made out <span class='line-break'> </span>by one hand, which, I never delegate any further than copying <span class='line-break'> </span>and then always compare with the original) require much <span class='line-break'> </span>time each month and several days each year for the <ins>index</ins>.  <span class='line-break'> </span>Here also, a considerable correspondence becomes necessary for sup<span class='line-break'></span>plying omissions and correcting errors.</p>
<p>The keeping a proper record of the disposition of estates of <span class='line-break'> </span>dec<sup>d</sup> proprietors, so far as relates to their lots, and the passing <span class='line-break'> </span>to whom they descend or are devised, is one of the most <span class='line-break'> </span>important duties discharged by the Secretary- one not laid down <span class='line-break'> </span>in the By-laws, but which he cannot avoid devoting much<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>time</ins> to in order to render the information available to the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation for all time.  I have been in the habit, for several years, of <span class='line-break'> </span>spending some time at the Registries of Probate in the different<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133567">
<h3><a name="page-1133567">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 078)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>78</p>
<p>counties to get from the record this information which it is<span class='line-break'> </span>impossible to receive in any other way. In this way, too,<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation are apprized of the legacies or endowments of lots<span class='line-break'> </span>made by the dec<sup>d</sup> proprietor.</p>
<p>But I need not go on enumerating the services which <span class='line-break'> </span>have always appeared to me to be rendered necessary to do justice <span class='line-break'> </span>to the place. Some man ought to do it, or negligence and decay <span class='line-break'> </span>ensue. The Secretary's office (for these are records &amp; documents) <span class='line-break'> </span>is supposed to be the repository of this information, and he is expected<span class='line-break'> </span>to consider the correspondence, publish orders, -</p>
<p>If it be asked,- can he properly attend to the duties <span class='line-break'> </span>of his office, and (if a lawyer) find much time for other practices<span class='line-break'> </span>I answer - No. I have no doubt I work more hours than <span class='line-break'> </span>two thirds of the lawyers and my experience in seeking to econ<span class='line-break'></span>mize labor as much as possible, in this office for more <span class='line-break'> </span>than eight years, ought to [enable?] me to known.</p>
<p>If the offices of Secretary and Treasurer could be brought <span class='line-break'> </span>together, duties could be better systematized and more economically<span class='line-break'> </span>and effectually performed, and give general satisfaction to the Proprietors. <span class='line-break'> </span>But of that the Trustees must Judge.-</p>
<p>From the nature of the case, nearly all my time is now required <span class='line-break'> </span>for which I receive - Salary - per annum $500.<span class='line-break'> </span>Fees for making deeds -day - $100.<span class='line-break'> </span>Individual records &amp; tranfers - say-- <ins>30</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>$630</p>
<p>Of this I have to pay heat of office $150.<span class='line-break'> </span>Care of room &amp; postage  52. - <span class='line-break'> </span>Fuel &amp; lights - say <ins>23.</ins><span class='line-break'> </span><ins>225.</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>leaving - $405</p>
<p>My income for all other services cannot amount to<span class='line-break'> </span>$100 per annum - The sum connected with the lawsuit of the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>vs.  <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>J. Mann</a> are an exception<span class='line-break'> </span>Very respectfully, <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133568">
<h3><a name="page-1133568">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 079)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-05-29'>May 29, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>C.P. Curtis Esq</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Chairman Comm<sup>ee</sup> on Lots</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Mr <a href='/pages/subjects/58375' title='Brigham, Levi'>Levi Brigham</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>proprietor of <a href='/pages/subjects/64070' title='Lot 1290'>lot numbered 1290</a> on<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59585' title='Pine Avenue'>Pine Av<sup>e</sup></a> desires to know for<span class='line-break'> </span>what sum the Corporation will<span class='line-break'> </span>contract to keep his lot in<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual Repair. I enclose<span class='line-break'> </span>the Supt's description of said lot.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>At the meeting of the Trustees <span class='line-break'> </span>of Mount Auburn Cemetery,<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1863-05-04'>May 4, 1863</date>, the following<span class='line-break'> </span>vote was passed.</p>
<p>"That the Committee chosen to<span class='line-break'> </span>prosecute the claim <del>against</del><span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation against <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jon<sup>a</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>Mann</a> be instructed to make<span class='line-break'> </span>a report at the next meeting,<span class='line-break'> </span>of their proceedings in the suit,<span class='line-break'> </span>and of the expenses thus far<span class='line-break'> </span>incurred from the commencement<span class='line-break'> </span>of the investigation of his accounts.</p>
<p>[Attest?] <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>Austin J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>79</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133569">
<h3><a name="page-1133569">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 080)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-05-30'>May 30, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64079' title='Chambre, Albert St. John'>Rev<sup>d</sup> A. St. John Chambre</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64080' title='Newark, NJ'>Newark N.J.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The order of <date when='1863-04-10'>10<sup>th</sup> April<span class='line-break'> </span>1863</date> for interment of a child in Mt Auburn,<span class='line-break'> </span>signed by you, gives me the means &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>for the first time of writing you to correct<span class='line-break'> </span>^<sup>the record of</sup> an interment of child made <date when='1860-05-28'>May 28, 1860</date> in same lot. As the record<span class='line-break'> </span>was deficient in two particulars, and<span class='line-break'> </span>as the child's body appears to have come<span class='line-break'> </span>from <a href='/pages/subjects/64080' title='Newark, NJ'>Newark N.J.</a> I have concluded<span class='line-break'> </span>it ^<sup>too</sup> must have been your child, to<span class='line-break'> </span>a sufficient extent to ask these two<span class='line-break'> </span>questions - 1<sup>st</sup> <ins>if it was your child, and<span class='line-break'> </span>the name</ins> (if any): 2<sup>d</sup> the <ins>date of its still<span class='line-break'></span>birth</ins>. I believe it is the only deficiency<span class='line-break'> </span>in our record for that year, and I did<span class='line-break'> </span>not have your address, or I should have<span class='line-break'> </span>corrected it.</p>
<p>Your early reply will oblige.</p>
<p>Yours resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y<span class='line-break'> </span>of Mt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1863-06-07'>June 1, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65277' title='Drake, Jeremy'>J. Drake Esq.<sup>r</sup></a> Executor of late<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64082' title='Mumford, Sophia'>Sophia Mumford</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your request has been<span class='line-break'> </span>attended to, and I am<span class='line-break'> </span>instructed by the Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>to notify you that this Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation will contract to keep<span class='line-break'> </span>said lot (<a href='/pages/subjects/64083' title='Lot 126'>no. 126</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/60336' title='Willow Avenue'>Willow Av<sup>e</sup></a>)<span class='line-break'> </span>in perpetual repair for the <span class='line-break'> </span>sum of $300 three hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars, provided it is first <span class='line-break'> </span>put in complete order.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>80</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133570">
<h3><a name="page-1133570">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 081)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-06-02'>June 2<sup>d</sup> 1863</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/58375' title='Brigham, Levi'>Levi Brigham</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots have instructed me<span class='line-break'> </span>to report to you that they<span class='line-break'> </span>have taken your application<span class='line-break'> </span>into consideration, and that this<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation will contract for the<span class='line-break'> </span>Perpetual care of your <a href='/pages/subjects/64070' title='Lot 1290'>lot No.<span class='line-break'> </span>1290</a>. <a href='/pages/subjects/59585' title='Pine Avenue'>Pine Avenue</a> for the sum<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>six hundred</ins> dollars.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>Austin J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-06-05'>June 5, 1863</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>have instructed me to notify you<span class='line-break'> </span>that this Corporation will con<span class='line-break'></span>tract for the perpetual repair<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/64089' title='Lot 1935'>Lot No. 1935</a>, belonging to <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64090' title='Carpenter, James'>James Carpenter</a>, located upon<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/61226' title='Lupine Path'>Lupine Path</a>, for three hun<span class='line-break'></span>dred dollars, the proprietor <span class='line-break'> </span>first causing the lot to be <span class='line-break'> </span>resodded.</p>
<p>I should have notified you <span class='line-break'> </span>yesterday, as requested, had I<span class='line-break'> </span>not inadvertently left the venue,<span class='line-break'> </span>containing your address with<span class='line-break'> </span>the Superintendant, and being<span class='line-break'> </span>unable to recollect your name<span class='line-break'> </span>and place of business.-</p>
<p>Very Truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Proprietors of Mt Auburn</p>
<p>To<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64091' title='Coburn, L. A.'>L.A. Coburn</a>Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>25 Milk St</p>
<p>81<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133571">
<h3><a name="page-1133571">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 082)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-06-06'>June 6, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64106' title='Bradford, George R.'>Geo. R. Bradford</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The addition of 15 ft.<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/64107' title='Lot 755'>lot 755</a> in Mt Auburn, was re<span class='line-break'></span>ported to you. As the title of the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot is in the heirs of your late<span class='line-break'> </span>father, the deed should be made<span class='line-break'> </span>to the heirs generally, unless there<span class='line-break'> </span>is a good reason for putting the title<span class='line-break'> </span>into one person, which can be <span class='line-break'> </span>done by a transfer by the other heirs<span class='line-break'> </span>to such person. I see no need of<span class='line-break'> </span>this however, as you represent the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot, and act for the heirs.</p>
<p>Shall I make the deed to "the<span class='line-break'> </span>heirs at law of <a href='/pages/subjects/64108' title='Bradford, John'>John Bradford</a>," or<span class='line-break'> </span>do with any other course?</p>
<p>Very truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-07-04'>July 4, 1863</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your son, <a href='/pages/subjects/64109' title='Perkins, C. D.'>C.D. Perkins</a>, was here<span class='line-break'> </span>two or three days since, on his way west<span class='line-break'></span>ward, and informed me that <a href='/pages/subjects/64111' title='Perkins, Frederick'>his<span class='line-break'> </span>brother<!--Frederick Perkins--></a> died intestate, leaving no wife<span class='line-break'> </span>nor children, and that you are<span class='line-break'> </span>his heir at law.</p>
<p>As lots in Mt Auburn are<span class='line-break'> </span>declared by the Charter to be <ins>real estate</ins>,<span class='line-break'> </span>this lot by operation of law falls to<span class='line-break'> </span>you.- The Trustees some years since<span class='line-break'> </span>passed a by law, that any person<span class='line-break'> </span>claiming to be the sole heir of a deceased<span class='line-break'> </span>proprietor, may put presumptive ev<span class='line-break'></span>idence of his title to said lot on our<span class='line-break'> </span>records by filing an <ins>affidavit</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>of such claim. I have prepared<span class='line-break'> </span>such paper, and sent it herewith.<span class='line-break'> </span>When you have executed and returned<span class='line-break'> </span>it to me, I will put your name upon<span class='line-break'> </span>our record. The fee for such affid<sup>t</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>and record is $1.00, which you can<span class='line-break'> </span>remit with the paper.-</p>
<p>Your son remarked that he should<span class='line-break'> </span>probably have this lot; but that does<span class='line-break'> </span>not do away with the need of this. If he<span class='line-break'> </span>does take the conveyance, he must acquire it<span class='line-break'> </span>from you.  Yours very respy. <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a>, Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64110' title='Perkins, Gaius'>Gains Perkins</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64113' title='South Woodstock, VT'>So. Woodstock Vt.</a></p>
<p>82</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133572">
<h3><a name="page-1133572">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 083)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1863-07-18'>July 18, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64112' title='Goodwin, William W.'>Mr W<sup>m</sup>.  W. Goodwin</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I find, upon looking at<span class='line-break'> </span>our files, a survey of the Warren<span class='line-break'> </span>lot was made under date of Feby 3<sup>d</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>1861, and upon it the Comm<sup>ee</sup>  on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots enclosed their readings to<span class='line-break'> </span>make a contract for the Perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>Repair of the same for <ins>three<span class='line-break'> </span>hundred dollars</ins>. I have seen<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a>, Chairman of the Comm<sup>ee</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>this morning, and he says they will<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>now</ins> undertake the contract for that,<span class='line-break'> </span>although, since that date, they have<span class='line-break'> </span>generally raised their estimates a<span class='line-break'> </span>considerable per cent.</p>
<p>If therefore you are ready to pay <span class='line-break'> </span>the additional $200, we can finish<span class='line-break'> </span>the matter.</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. A.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-07-21'>July 21, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64110' title='Perkins, Gaius'>Gains Perkins</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>So. Woodstock Vt.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>On the 14<sup>th</sup>, I sent<span class='line-break'> </span>you an affidavit to swear to<span class='line-break'> </span>at <a href='/pages/subjects/64113' title='South Woodstock, VT'>S. Woodstock Vt.</a> - claiming to be<span class='line-break'> </span>the father's sole heir at law of <a href='/pages/subjects/64111' title='Perkins, Frederick'>Fred.<span class='line-break'> </span>Perkins</a>, &amp; suggested that you<span class='line-break'> </span>could send the regular fee for such<span class='line-break'> </span>service viz. $1.00, when you returned<span class='line-break'> </span>the document. The Affidavit I<span class='line-break'> </span>have received this morning, but<span class='line-break'> </span>no money, which I suppose<span class='line-break'> </span>may have been accidentally left<span class='line-break'> </span>out.</p>
<p>Your attention to the same<span class='line-break'> </span>is requested.</p>
<p>Truly  yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>83</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133573">
<h3><a name="page-1133573">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 084)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-07-31'>July 31, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64115' title='Phillips, William H.'>Mr. W<sup>m</sup>  H. Phillips</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/72694' title='Newton Corner, MA'>Newton Corner, Mass</a>.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>On the 11<sup>th</sup> of May<span class='line-break'> </span>last, you interred in <a href='/pages/subjects/64116' title='Lot 698'>lot no.<span class='line-break'> </span>698</a> in Mt Auburn represented <span class='line-break'> </span>by <a href='/pages/subjects/64117' title='Snow, Henry A.'>Henry A. Snow</a>, doing business<span class='line-break'> </span>at 94 Devonshire St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, the <span class='line-break'> </span>body of ---------------------------------.</p>
<p>The gatekeeper informs me that you<span class='line-break'> </span>promised to return him the order<span class='line-break'> </span>for interment with the town permit,<span class='line-break'> </span>but have failed to do so.-</p>
<p>I send you the enclosed<span class='line-break'> </span>blank which you will please<span class='line-break'> </span>fill out - annex the town permit,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; return same to me, and I will<span class='line-break'> </span>get Mr Snow's signature, if<span class='line-break'> </span>that is all you have been waiting<span class='line-break'> </span>for. Such neglect as this should<span class='line-break'> </span>not occur again.</p>
<p>Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary Mt. A.</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1863-08-12'>Aug.12, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97392' title='Brown, D. Jay'>D. Jay Brown</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>You will please<span class='line-break'> </span>order the Superintendents of Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn to put in some granite<span class='line-break'> </span>boundary posts upon your <a href='/pages/subjects/64119' title='Lot 3287'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>No 3287</a>, unless you are about<span class='line-break'> </span>to make some other kind of<span class='line-break'> </span>enclosure. Our rules enforce this<span class='line-break'> </span>as a condition in the deed.<span class='line-break'> </span>As your lot is of irregular form, <span class='line-break'> </span>the difficulty of making an accu<span class='line-break'></span>rate survey and of preserving the <span class='line-break'> </span>visibility of your bounds, unless the<span class='line-break'> </span>rule is complied with is greatly<span class='line-break'> </span>increased.</p>
<p>I cannot make a deed for<span class='line-break'> </span>you until I have the the form and <span class='line-break'> </span>measure of the same from our sur<span class='line-break'></span>veyors, and they will not survey<span class='line-break'> </span>it, until permanent boundaries<span class='line-break'> </span>are erected.-</p>
<p>Please see <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. Winsor</a> and have<span class='line-break'> </span>the matter attended to.</p>
<p>Yours most Respy</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p>84<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133574">
<h3><a name="page-1133574">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 085)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-09-12'>Sept. 12. 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Chas. P. Curtis</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>Chairman Comm<sup>ee</sup>  on Lots</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclosed the Supt<sup>d</sup>  Rep<sup>t</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>of present condition of lot no 1175, also<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/64120' title='Lot 1875'>lots 1875</a> to <a href='/pages/subjects/64121' title='Lot 1878'><!--Lot-->1878</a> inclusive for which<span class='line-break'> </span>latter a contract is sought to be <span class='line-break'> </span>made including all the lots in one<span class='line-break'> </span>sum.</p>
<p>You perceive <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. Winsor's</a> sug<span class='line-break'></span>gestion of 700 or 750 for the whole.-</p>
<p>The by-law (p. 48 of Catalogue sc.) now stands<span class='line-break'> </span>thus - "The Trustees may also <ins>guarantee</ins> the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>repair of lots containing 300 feet &amp; upwards, on pay<span class='line-break'></span>ment to the Treas<sup>r</sup> of a sum not less than $300,<span class='line-break'> </span>and of lots containing less than 300 feet on the pay<span class='line-break'></span>ment of a sum not less than $100."</p>
<p>Each of these four lots contains 300 feet.-<span class='line-break'> </span>hence the by-law would require $1200.-</p>
<p>For lots contiguous and in one enclosure,<span class='line-break'> </span>I am compelled to think the by-law is impracti<span class='line-break'></span>cable. As it stood at first, $300 was the least<span class='line-break'> </span>sum which could be accepted for the guaranty<span class='line-break'> </span>upon <ins>any</ins> lot.
