Then came applications<span class='line-break'> </span>for the perpetual care of small lots,<span class='line-break'> </span>lots on which very small expense would<span class='line-break'> </span>be required; and an amendment was<span class='line-break'> </span>tasked on <date when='1859-10-03'>Oct. 3. 1859</date>, providing that for<span class='line-break'> </span>lots of ^<sup>not</sup> less than 100 feet a sum not less<span class='line-break'> </span>than $100 should be required.</p>
<p>And now comes another case, where<span class='line-break'> </span>it is obvious that two, three, or more<span class='line-break'> </span>contiguous lots improved in the same<span class='line-break'> </span>manner, and at the same time, can<span class='line-break'> </span>be taken for a much less sum than<span class='line-break'> </span>if situated in different parts of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery.</p>
<p>The truth is that the number of square<span class='line-break'> </span>feet in a given lot, or enclosure containing<span class='line-break'> </span>two or more lots, is a very poor standard<span class='line-break'> </span>for fixing the requisite amount, because<span class='line-break'> </span>it may cost more to take care of one<span class='line-break'> </span>lot with 100 feet with its appurtenances,<span class='line-break'> </span>than another lot with 200 or 300 feet.<span class='line-break'> </span>Besides, the statement of a sum in<span class='line-break'> </span>the catalogue operates to mislead per<span class='line-break'></span>sons who do not read carefully. They<span class='line-break'> </span>come with $300 fixed in mind, and<span class='line-break'> </span>when $500 or $600 is asked, they appear<span class='line-break'> </span>to be greatly surprised and disappointed.</p>
<p>85</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133575">
<h3><a name="page-1133575">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 086)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>If you will suffer the suggestion,<span class='line-break'> </span>I think the 2<sup>d</sup> clause of Art. 29 of the by<span class='line-break'></span>laws - p. 48 ^<sup>to the end of the first sentence,</sup> should be amended to read -</p>
<p>"The Trustees may also <ins>guarantee</ins> the<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual repair of lots on the pay<span class='line-break'></span>ment to the Treasurer of such sum,<span class='line-break'> </span>in each case, as the Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots shall deem sufficient."</p>
<p>As the least sum that can be received<span class='line-break'> </span>at all is $100, there would seem to be no<span class='line-break'> </span>danger in leaving this clause without the<span class='line-break'> </span>minimum limit of $100, as the Comm<sup>ee</sup>  on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>would not be very likely to <ins>guarantee</ins> per<span class='line-break'></span>petual care for a smaller sum than they are<span class='line-break'> </span>at liberty to accept at any rate, viz $100.</p>
<p>I would advise that the first clause should<span class='line-break'> </span>remain as it now stands.</p>
<p>The application upon the lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/64133' title='Skinner, Sarah'>Mrs. Skinner</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64122' title='Lot 1175'>no. 1175</a>, made by <a href='/pages/subjects/64123' title='Lee, William R.'>Col. W<sup>m</sup>. R. Lee</a>, I suppose<span class='line-break'> </span>can be acted on at once.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt Auburn</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-09-15'>Sept. 15. 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64124' title='Curtis, J. H.'>Mr J.H. Curtis</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir, I went with the<span class='line-break'> </span>Supt. this morning &amp; measured the<span class='line-break'> </span>two lots named by you on <a href='/pages/subjects/61120' title='Arethusa Path'>Arethusa<span class='line-break'> </span>Path</a> and found that they were<span class='line-break'> </span>good for two lots with space in<span class='line-break'></span>tervening of 400 feet each.- But a<span class='line-break'> </span>gentleman spoke to him two or three<span class='line-break'> </span>days since, and did not wish<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a> to sell them until he<span class='line-break'> </span>could see him once more. He<span class='line-break'> </span>wished for two lots. I believe the Super<span class='line-break'></span>intendents agreed not to sell them until<span class='line-break'> </span>he should come out again. I<span class='line-break'> </span>think that whoever agrees to take<span class='line-break'> </span>the whole piece solid will be likely<span class='line-break'> </span>to get it. We measured on the front<span class='line-break'> </span>from inside to inside of curb 54 1/2 feet.<span class='line-break'> </span>The back line would measure a little more.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. A.C.</p>
<p>86</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133576">
<h3><a name="page-1133576">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 087)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-09-15'>Sept. 15. 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64123' title='Lee, William R.'>Col. W<sup>m</sup>  R. Lee</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have submitted <span class='line-break'> </span>to the Committee on Lots your request,<span class='line-break'> </span>to know you what sum this Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>will assume the perpetual care<span class='line-break'> </span>of lot <a href='/pages/subjects/64122' title='Lot 1175'>No. 1175</a> in the Cemetery belonging<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/64133' title='Skinner, Sarah'>Mrs. Sarah Skinner</a> and have<span class='line-break'> </span>this reply. The Committee on Lots will<span class='line-break'> </span>recommend the Trustees to guarantee the<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual care of this Lot <ins>after it has<span class='line-break'> </span>been put in repair satisfactory to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent</ins>, for $300.</p>
<p>The Superintendent in his report of the<span class='line-break'> </span>condition of the lot, after describing it in<span class='line-break'> </span>other particulars says: -“The lot is all<span class='line-break'> </span>moss!  Requires grading, and fence wants <span class='line-break'> </span>some slight repairs, and also painting, with<span class='line-break'> </span>cost $25 to put it in good order.”</p>
<p>Your most respectfully<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>Austin J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. A. Cem.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-09-17'>Sept.<sup>r</sup>17, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D. L. Winsor</a>, Sup<sup>t</sup>  Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The price proposed by the Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>for Perpetual care of <a href='/pages/subjects/66008' title='Lot 1676'>lot no. 1676</a> on<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59584' title='Cypress Avenue'>Cypress Av.</a> owned by [devisees?] of late <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64134' title='Baxter, Sarah'>Sarah Baxter</a>, of <a href='/pages/subjects/62295' title='Newton, MA'>Newton</a>, viz $400, having<span class='line-break'> </span>been accepted by the Sec<sup>y</sup> and trustee, he,<span class='line-break'> </span>wishes to pay over not only that but<span class='line-break'> </span>the same necessary for <ins>present</ins> repair, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>for the care of lot, as ordered, this year,<span class='line-break'> </span>in one sum; and it has been agreed<span class='line-break'> </span>with him that the lot shall be put<span class='line-break'> </span>into the condition, immediately, which<span class='line-break'> </span>you think proper, for its acceptance,<span class='line-break'> </span>and the amount be made [up?] and sent to<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64135' title='Stephens, H. C.'>Mr. H. C. Stephens</a> for payment.</p>
<p>You said in the report of condition, under<span class='line-break'> </span>quest 7<sup>th</sup> “nothing except ‘tis set in brimstone, <span class='line-break'> </span>which eventually destroys the stone.”</p>
<p>You are authorized to put it in the <span class='line-break'> </span>requisite condition, and add to that charge<span class='line-break'> </span>the care for present year.  The parties are<span class='line-break'> </span>very anxious to have this done at once.</p>
<p>Make bill to “Estate of <a href='/pages/subjects/64136' title='Baxter, Daniel'><ins>Daniel</ins> Baxter</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>deceased.”</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>87</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133577">
<h3><a name="page-1133577">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 088)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-09-17'>Sept. 17, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/69248' title='Dooley, John'>John Dooley</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>172 Water St <a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I notice that <a href='/pages/subjects/64141' title='Lot 1789'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>numbered 1789</a> situated upon <a href='/pages/subjects/61278' title='Sorrel Path'>Sorrel<span class='line-break'> </span>Path</a> in our Cemetery appears to be<span class='line-break'> </span>unoccupied, and a gentleman who <span class='line-break'> </span>wishes to purchase a lot in the<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery would perhaps take<span class='line-break'> </span>a fancy to this lot if you should<span class='line-break'> </span>wish to part with it. I cannot,<span class='line-break'> </span>of course, presume, from the fact<span class='line-break'> </span>of your removal to <a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>that such is the case; but as<span class='line-break'> </span>lots are so often transferred on<span class='line-break'> </span>account of the removal of the pro<span class='line-break'></span>prietor, I knew you would not<span class='line-break'> </span>take it amiss, should I inquire<span class='line-break'> </span>if you desire to dispose of it.</p>
<p>If you should, please name<span class='line-break'> </span>the price, and I will confer<span class='line-break'> </span>further with you about it, if<span class='line-break'> </span>your price is satisfactory.</p>
<p>Very Respy. Yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y of Mt Auburn</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-09-18'>Sept. 18, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D.L. Winsor</a>, Sup<sup>t</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Proprietor of <a href='/pages/subjects/64043' title='Lot 1170'>lot no.<span class='line-break'> </span>1170</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/61210' title='Ivy Path'>Ivy Path</a>, accepts the contract<span class='line-break'> </span>offered by the Com<sup>ee</sup>  on Lots to keep<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot in perpetual repair for $300.<span class='line-break'> </span>"after it has been put in repair sat<span class='line-break'></span>isfactory to the Superintendent."</p>
<p>In your report you say - "The lot is<span class='line-break'> </span>all moss! requires grading, and fence<span class='line-break'> </span>wants some slight repairs, and also painting -<span class='line-break'> </span>will cost $25. to put it in good order."</p>
<p>Will you then have what is <span class='line-break'> </span>requisite done as soon as possible.<span class='line-break'> </span>Make and send the bill to me, which<span class='line-break'> </span>will be notice when we can com<span class='line-break'></span>plete the contract. Make bill to <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64133' title='Skinner, Sarah'>Mrs. Sarah Skinner</a>.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. A.</p>
<p>88</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133578">
<h3><a name="page-1133578">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 089)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-09-23'>Sept 23 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/103994' title='Kettell, G. A.'>G.A. Kettell</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64142' title='Willard, Julia'>Julia Willard</a> was<span class='line-break'> </span>interred in <a href='/pages/subjects/64143' title='Lot 2924'>lot no 2924</a> Mt Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>on the 27<sup>th</sup> ultimo. But no order<span class='line-break'> </span>was signed by the proprietor <a href='/pages/subjects/64144' title='Willard, Elisha W.'>Elisha<span class='line-break'> </span>W. Willard</a>, nor were the particulars<span class='line-break'> </span>of age, date &amp; place of death given.<span class='line-break'> </span>I find at the bottom of a partly filled<span class='line-break'> </span>blank order, returned to me in the file<span class='line-break'> </span>for ^<sup>the</sup> August record, this memo.-</p>
<p>"<a href='/pages/subjects/64144' title='Willard, Elisha W.'>Mr Willard</a> will send permit as soon<span class='line-break'> </span>as he can get it from the west."</p>
<p>I am informed that <a href='/pages/subjects/64144' title='Willard, Elisha W.'>Mr Willard's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>son is at your house. Under<span class='line-break'> </span>the circumstances, will you have<span class='line-break'> </span>the kindness to see that the requirement<span class='line-break'> </span>of the properly executed order is met?</p>
<p>If you wish any blank for the<span class='line-break'> </span>purpose, I will furnish you.</p>
<p>Truly yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. Au.</p>
<p>I send you the blank to save you trouble of sending.</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-09-23'>Sept 23 1863</date></p>
<p>Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/64145' title='Vinal, R. A.'>R.A. <!--Vinal--></a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/64146' title='Vinal, Quincy Adams'>Q.A. Vinal</a></p>
<p>Gentlemen,</p>
<p>There would seem to be<span class='line-break'> </span>some doubt, if not confusion, about the<span class='line-break'> </span>location of <a href='/pages/subjects/64147' title='Lot 2767'>lots 2767</a> to <a href='/pages/subjects/64148' title='Lot 2771'>2771</a> in Mt<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn. On our plan the numbers stand in<span class='line-break'> </span>certain positions, without any intermediate<span class='line-break'> </span>boundary lines. Each lot contains 300 ft.<span class='line-break'> </span>and the lines should be shown, else errors<span class='line-break'> </span>may be made in making interments.</p>
<p>Before me is the order of "<a href='/pages/subjects/64149' title='Vinal, Robert '>Rob<sup>t</sup> Vinal</a><span class='line-break'> </span>by <a href='/pages/subjects/64150' title='Vinal, A. E.'>A.E. Vinal</a>" for the interment on<span class='line-break'> </span>the 27<sup>th</sup> of August, of <a href='/pages/subjects/64151' title='Vinal, Harrie Dunbury'>Harrie Dunbury Vinal</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>"in <a href='/pages/subjects/64152' title='Lot 2770'>lot no. <ins>2770</ins></a>, owned by <a href='/pages/subjects/64149' title='Vinal, Robert'>Rob<sup>t</sup> Vinal</a>."</p>
<p>Now <a href='/pages/subjects/64152' title='lot 2770'>lot 2770</a> belongs to <a href='/pages/subjects/64153' title='Burt, William Lathrop'>Mr Burt</a><span class='line-break'> </span>and the undertaker tells me that the<span class='line-break'> </span>interment was made in what he under<span class='line-break'></span>stands to be <a href='/pages/subjects/64153' title='Burt, William Lathrop'>Mr Burt's</a> lot.-</p>
<p>One of two things is then obvious - that<span class='line-break'> </span>either the interment was wrong, or the<span class='line-break'> </span>order for it should be corrected.</p>
<p>Will one of you see me - almost any<span class='line-break'> </span>day after 12 noon.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary of Mt. Au.</p>
<p>89</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133579">
<h3><a name="page-1133579">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 090)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-10-01'>Octo. 1. 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64154' title='Hallet, Henry S.'>Henry S. Hallet</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A gentleman called<span class='line-break'> </span>here yesterday to inquire about the tomb<span class='line-break'> </span>for sale, in <a href='/pages/subjects/59983' title='Hazel Dell'>Hazel Dell</a>, owned by our Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation, and recollecting your sale on<span class='line-break'> </span>Monday, I at once said, "I suppose<span class='line-break'> </span>you are connected with the gentleman<span class='line-break'> </span>who called Monday in making this<span class='line-break'> </span>inquiry." He said "No, he had inquired<span class='line-break'> </span>of me previously about this tomb &amp; <span class='line-break'> </span>other locations" - which fact I had<span class='line-break'> </span>forgotten. He wishes the refusal of <span class='line-break'> </span>the tomb at our price - $2,000 - for 24<span class='line-break'> </span>hours. I told him, I could not <span class='line-break'> </span>do anything without seeing <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt.<span class='line-break'> </span>Winsor</a>, which I would do this<span class='line-break'> </span>morning, and answer him today <span class='line-break'> </span>at 12 o'clock.</p>
<p>Upon seeing the Sup<sup>t</sup> this<span class='line-break'> </span>morning, I learned that you<span class='line-break'> </span>had proposed to bring your friend<span class='line-break'> </span>out to see it, and wished the refusal<span class='line-break'> </span>of the tomb for three or four<span class='line-break'> </span>days, and that he had<span class='line-break'> </span>promised you that he would<span class='line-break'> </span>not dispose of it without giving<span class='line-break'> </span>you notice.</p>
<p>I therefore write you, to say<span class='line-break'> </span>that we shall be compelled to <span class='line-break'> </span>ask you to decide in the matter<span class='line-break'> </span>today or tomorrow as another<span class='line-break'> </span>gentleman stands ready (I think)<span class='line-break'> </span>to take it, and only asked for<span class='line-break'> </span>today.</p>
<p>This is not intended to hasten<span class='line-break'> </span>you, on a false alarm - but as<span class='line-break'> </span>we have another <ins>bona-fide</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>bidder, we must look after the<span class='line-break'> </span>interests of the Corporation in this<span class='line-break'> </span>matter.</p>
<p>Yours very resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y of Mt Auburn</p>
<p>90</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133580">
<h3><a name="page-1133580">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 091)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-10-12'>Octo. 12, 1863</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64156' title='Thayer, J. B.'>J. B. Thayer</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64157' title='Stephens, Mr.'>Mr Stephens</a> has<span class='line-break'> </span>just called upon me and<span class='line-break'> </span>desired me to send you<span class='line-break'> </span>the amount required in figures,<span class='line-break'> </span>for the perpetual care of the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/64134' title='Baxter, Sarah'>Sarah Baxter</a>, dec<sup>d</sup> in<span class='line-break'> </span>Mt Auburn, for repairs,<span class='line-break'> </span>care of <a href='/pages/subjects/64158' title='Lot 1863'>lot for 1863</a>, and<span class='line-break'> </span>drawing &amp; recording papers &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>services, - and he assents<span class='line-break'> </span>to the amount named by<span class='line-break'> </span>me - viz - $440.75</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-10-12'>Oct. 12, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64112' title='Goodwin, William W.'>W<sup>m</sup> W. Goodwin</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Enclosed you<span class='line-break'> </span>find the contract for the per<span class='line-break'></span>petual repair of the Warren<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/59940' title='Lot 1030'>lot 1030</a> - which has<span class='line-break'> </span>been duly executed &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>recorded.</p>
<p>At your convenience,<span class='line-break'> </span>please enclose to $2.<span class='line-break'> </span>for drawing papers, getting<span class='line-break'> </span>executed &amp; making record.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary Mt. A</p>
<p>91</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133581">
<h3><a name="page-1133581">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 092)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-10-12'>Oct. 12, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54775' title='Kuhn, George H.'>Geo. H. Kuhn</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>In looking over our<span class='line-break'> </span>papers &amp; records, I find that no<span class='line-break'> </span>transfer back to the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>was made of <a href='/pages/subjects/60668' title='Lot 473'>lot 473</a> in Mount<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn, as contemplated in<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64019' title='Putnam, Catherine'>Miss Putnam's</a> will. The<span class='line-break'> </span>contract for perpetual repair<span class='line-break'> </span>was executed in <date when='1862-09'>Sept. 1862</date> &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>duly recorded, but the record of<span class='line-break'> </span>the devise of her lot to the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation escaped me at the time,<span class='line-break'> </span>and I suppose did you too.</p>
<p>If you have the deed, you<span class='line-break'> </span>can make a transfer, on the page, as<span class='line-break'> </span>ex<sup>or</sup> "in accordance with the provisions of<span class='line-break'> </span>her will", to the Corporation. If you<span class='line-break'> </span>can call any day after 12 o'clock, at<span class='line-break'> </span>your convenience, I shall probably be<span class='line-break'> </span>in: or I will wait upon you<span class='line-break'> </span>at your office.</p>
<p>Yours very respy,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1863-10-19'>Octo. 19, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/58439' title='Raymond, Edward A.'>Edw<sup>d</sup> A. Raymond</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Some time since<span class='line-break'> </span>you were apprized of the fact<span class='line-break'> </span>that your lot in our Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64020' title='Lot 21'>no 21</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/61237' title='Myrtle Path'>Myrtle Path</a>, had<span class='line-break'> </span>been accidentally covered by another<span class='line-break'> </span>lot, for want of bounds or other<span class='line-break'> </span>mark designating the location of<span class='line-break'> </span>yours.</p>
<p>We have a new plan rapidly<span class='line-break'> </span>being engraved and shall soon also<span class='line-break'> </span>issue a new catalogue, and<span class='line-break'> </span>we should like to have you select<span class='line-break'> </span>another location now during the open<span class='line-break'> </span>season, partly for the reason<span class='line-break'> </span>above named that our new issue may<span class='line-break'> </span>be as free from error as possible but<span class='line-break'> </span>more especially as our most eligible<span class='line-break'> </span>land is being rapidly taken, which<span class='line-break'> </span>fact shortens the range for your choice.<span class='line-break'> </span>Your attention will oblige.</p>
<p>Yours respy. <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>92</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133582">
<h3><a name="page-1133582">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 093)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> 33 School St. <date when='1863-10-23'>Oct. 23. 1863</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64029' title='Greenwood, Hannah M.'>Mrs Hannah M. Greenwood</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I have been unusually busy this week,<span class='line-break'> </span>and although I took the minutes of the <span class='line-break'> </span>monument Monday to send you, have<span class='line-break'> </span>been presented from doing so until now.</p>
<p>I have had the monument removed<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/64030' title='McDonald, Alexander'>Alex<sup>r</sup> M<sup>c</sup> Donald's</a> marble works<span class='line-break'> </span>for cleanings.-</p>
<p>The free stone plinth resting upon the <span class='line-break'> </span>underground foundation is 27 inches<span class='line-break'> </span>square - or 2ft. 3 inches; and that or <span class='line-break'> </span>an inch or two more - say 28 or 29 inches<span class='line-break'> </span>should be the size of the foundation.<span class='line-break'> </span>To secure the monument against heaving by <span class='line-break'> </span>frost, the foundation should be three feet<span class='line-break'> </span>deep of cobble stones, beneath, with flat <span class='line-break'> </span>stones on top secured with mortar<span class='line-break'> </span>and made perfectly level. A mason<span class='line-break'> </span>who understands his trade, will<span class='line-break'> </span>know how to do this, or any decent<span class='line-break'> </span>mechanic.</p>
<p>As to the weight of the monument<span class='line-break'> </span>and plinth, <a href='/pages/subjects/64030' title='McDonald, Alexander'>Mr M<sup>c</sup>Donald</a> estimated<span class='line-break'> </span>to be about 1800 or 1900 - call it<span class='line-break'> </span>one ton. A team of two horses would<span class='line-break'> </span>draw it quite easily. One horse<span class='line-break'> </span>could do it, if the road is not<span class='line-break'> </span>much uphill, and muddy.<span class='line-break'> </span>Perhaps you can arrange with<span class='line-break'> </span>some one who comes down to<span class='line-break'> </span>market, to take it in on his<span class='line-break'> </span>return. He should have two<span class='line-break'> </span>or three cloths or bark mats<span class='line-break'> </span>to keep it from chafing.</p>
<p>I will have the remains, also<span class='line-break'> </span>at <a href='/pages/subjects/64030' title='McDonald, Alexander'>Mr M<sup>c</sup>Donald's</a>.</p>
<p>If you can give me the number<span class='line-break'> </span>of your <del>monument</del> lot in the <span class='line-break'> </span>new Cemetery - if you have<span class='line-break'> </span>numbers there, <a href='/pages/subjects/64030' title='McDonald, Alexander'>Mr M<sup>c</sup>Donald</a><span class='line-break'> </span>will cut it on the plinth,<span class='line-break'> </span>where now 895 in. He will<span class='line-break'> </span>remove the 895 by cutting out<span class='line-break'> </span>a little pannel, which will<span class='line-break'> </span>not disfigure it. I will let<span class='line-break'> </span>it remain however until you reply.</p>
<p>Please sign these papers - orders for<span class='line-break'> </span>removal, and return them to me; and <span class='line-break'> </span>say whether you wish a member cat. &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>what. I will notify you when all is ready.</p>
<p>Yours truly, <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>93</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133583">
<h3><a name="page-1133583">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 094)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-10-29'>Oct. 29. 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Chas P. Curtis</a> Esq<sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>Chairman Com. on Lots</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64159' title='Adams, Simon P.'>Mr. S. P. Adams</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>proprietor of <a href='/pages/subjects/64160' title='Lot 776'>lot no 776</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/61234' title='Moss Path'>Moss Path</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>which contains  new tomb, has requested<span class='line-break'> </span>me to ascertain for what sum the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation will guaranty the perpet<span class='line-break'></span>ual repair of said lot. -</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64161' title='Willis, Nathaniel'>Dea. Nath<sup>l</sup> Willis</a>, Proprietor<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/64171' title='Lot 972'>lot no 972</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/59904' title='Spruce Avenue'>Spruce Av<sup>e</sup></a> has made<span class='line-break'> </span>a similar request.-</p>
<p>I submit herewith the report<span class='line-break'> </span>upon each of these lots made by the <span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent.</p>
<p>Very respy. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-10-30'>Oct. 30. 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64159' title='Adams, Simon P.'>S.P. Adams</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have laid before the<span class='line-break'> </span>Committee on Lots your application to<span class='line-break'> </span>know for what sum this Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>will guaranty the perpetual care of<span class='line-break'> </span>your lot and tomb in the Cemetery - <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64160' title='Lot 776'>No. 776</a> on <a href='/pages/subjects/61234' title='Moss Path'>Moss Path</a>- and they have<span class='line-break'> </span>instructed me to notify you that they<span class='line-break'> </span>will recommend the Trustees to assume<span class='line-break'> </span>such obligation for the sum of<span class='line-break'> </span>five hundred dollars ($500.)</p>
<p>I am most Resp.y<span class='line-break'> </span>your ob<sup>t</sup> serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y Mt. A. Cemetery</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133584">
<h3><a name="page-1133584">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 095)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-10-30'>Oct 30, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64161' title='Willis, Nathaniel'>Dea. Nath<sup>l</sup> Willis</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have laid before<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee on Lots your application<span class='line-break'> </span>to know for what sum this Cor<span class='line-break'></span>poration will guaranty the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>care of the lot owned by you in the<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery, <a href='/pages/subjects/64171' title='Lot 972'>No 972</a> on <a href='/pages/subjects/59904' title='Spruce Avenue'>Spruce Av<sup>e</sup></a><span class='line-break'> </span>and they have instructed me to<span class='line-break'> </span>notify you that they will recom<span class='line-break'></span>mend the Trustees to assume such <span class='line-break'> </span>obligation for the sum of six hun<span class='line-break'></span>dred dollars. ($600.).</p>
<p>Very resply<span class='line-break'> </span>yours Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secty. Mt. A. Cemy</p>
<p>95</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133585">
<h3><a name="page-1133585">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 096)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-11-02'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 2, 1863</date>.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D.L. Winsor</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup> Mt Auburn,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,  The following votes were passed at the<span class='line-break'> </span>meeting of the Trustees held today.</p>
<p>"That the Secretary send to the Superintendent the statement<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Committee on Lots on several lots referred to in their<span class='line-break'> </span>report which need repairs, with the amount of the fund<span class='line-break'> </span>for each lot according to the last report of the Treasurer,<span class='line-break'> </span>and instruct him to cause such repairs as may be<span class='line-break'> </span>necessary within the income of the funds upon the lots<span class='line-break'> </span>not guarantied, and to put the guarantied lots<span class='line-break'> </span>in order."</p>
<p>"That the Superintendent be requested to furnish<span class='line-break'> </span>the Secretary with a list of lots in the Cemetery which<span class='line-break'> </span>appear to have been neglected by the proprietors, and<span class='line-break'> </span>for which no contract of repair has been made with<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation."</p>
<p>(see over)</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133586">
<h3><a name="page-1133586">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 097)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>In accordance with the first vote, I submit the<span class='line-break'> </span>following lots which are to be kept in order by<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation, under the guaranty, without regard to<span class='line-break'> </span>the surplus income in each case.</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th><a href='/pages/subjects/64172' title='Lot 214'><!--Lot-->214</a>.</th> <th><a href='/pages/subjects/64173' title='Raymond, Thatcher R.'>T.R. Raymond</a> -</th> <th>Fund $300.</th> <th>surplus income Dec. 31/62</th> <th>$11.59<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/56311' title='Lot 313'><!--Lot-->313</a>.</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/53237' title='Story, Joseph'>J. Story</a> -</td> <td>" 1000.-</td> <td>" " "</td> <td>$1226.73</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/67836' title='Lot 994'><!--Lot-->994</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/25000834' title='Eldredge, Hezekiah'>H. Eldridge</a></td> <td>" 300.-</td> <td>[indecipherable] - " "</td> <td>5.43</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/64176' title='Lot 1430'><!--Lot-->1430</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/60690' title='Warren, Pelham W.'>P.W. Warren</a></td> <td>" 300.-</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/64177' title='Lot 1496'><!--Lot-->1496</a></td> <td>- <a href='/pages/subjects/64178' title='Austin, Agnes'>Agnes Austin</a></td> <td>" 300.-</td> <td>Surplus " "</td> <td>50.99</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> The following lots are <ins>not</ins> guarantied - But<span class='line-break'> </span>are to be kept as well as the funds will permit -</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th><a href='/pages/subjects/64179' title='Lot 1'><!--Lot-->1</a>.</th> <th><a href='/pages/subjects/53606' title='Fuller, Henry H.'>H.H. Fuller</a></th> <th>Fund $200.</th> <th>Surplus Income Dec 31/62</th> <th>25.24<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> </table> <table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th><a href='/pages/subjects/60755' title='Lot 1556'><!--Lot-->1556</a></th> <th><a href='/pages/subjects/60696' title='Fuller, Abraham W.'>A.W. Fuller</a></th> <th>Fund $200</th> <th>- Surplus Income Dec 31/62</th> <th>76.79<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> </table> <table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th><a href='/pages/subjects/61551' title='Lot 1408'><!--Lot-->1408</a></th> <th>- <a href='/pages/subjects/53605' title='Burgess, Deborah'>D. Burgess</a> -</th> <th>" $100.</th> <th>Defic.y of " "</th> <th>1.67<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> </table> <table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th><a href='/pages/subjects/62010' title='Lot 2004'><!--Lot-->2004</a>.</th> <th><a href='/pages/subjects/64180' title='Reed, Henry Albert'>H. A. Reed</a></th> <th>" $100</th> <th>Surplus " "</th> <th>11.88<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> </table> The second vote contemplates the sending of a notice<span class='line-break'> </span>to the proprietors of the lots referred to in as effectual manner<span class='line-break'> </span>as the same can be done; and you will please<span class='line-break'> </span>have such a list made, with a statement of what is<span class='line-break'> </span>needed in each case as soon as your engagements<span class='line-break'> </span>will permit.</p>
<p>Very truly yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
</div>
</div>

<div id="page-1133587">
<h3><a name="page-1133587">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 098)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>98</p>
<p>This belongs to preceding page &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>line out with it—</p>
<p>- needs banking</p>
<p>- under repairs—</p>
<p>- wants sod. There are so many trees upon this lot that it will require<span class='line-break'> </span>sodding every two years.</p>
<p>out of order—</p>
<p>- Part of bank requires sod—</p>
<p>The iron fence around these lots is in a state of decomposition, where<span class='line-break'> </span>the iron is connected with the granite. All the granite around the lots, as also<span class='line-break'> </span>the steps,  should be taken up and relaid.-</p>
<p>not in order—</p>
<p>not in order —</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133588">
<h3><a name="page-1133588">Copying Book: Secretary&#39;s Letters, 1860 (page 099)</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1863-11-11'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 11. 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65123' title='Locke, O.'>O. Locke Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65124' title='Meyer, Mr.'>Mr Meyer</a> has<span class='line-break'> </span>agreed to take your lot, <ins>with</ins><span class='line-break'> </span><ins>the fence</ins>, at the price named ^<sup>$400</sup>, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>since he has so agreed, I have <span class='line-break'> </span>seen it, and (between you and me)<span class='line-break'> </span>must say, it is well sold.-<span class='line-break'> </span>The fence is quite rusty &amp; the lot a<span class='line-break'> </span>good deal out of repair. Your name<span class='line-break'> </span>is cast into the gate, so that,<span class='line-break'> </span>I think he will have to have <span class='line-break'> </span>a new gate.</p>
<p>I write you now to have you<span class='line-break'> </span>sign and return to me the <ins>two</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>orders for removal. I find <ins>two</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>bodies there instead of one as you<span class='line-break'> </span>named, &amp; they stand upon our record<span class='line-break'> </span>at the dates mentioned. Phoebe<span class='line-break'> </span>was 7 months old &amp; Anna 6 weeks.</p>
<p>I shall have them both put into<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>one</ins> <ins>box</ins>, say three feet long; unless you<span class='line-break'> </span>direct otherwise. When you write tell<span class='line-break'> </span>me how to send it to you.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-11-20'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 20. 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65125' title='Bliss, Eliza A.'>Mrs. E.A. Bliss</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Madam, Yours<span class='line-break'> </span>of <date when='1863-11-18'>18<sup>th</sup></date> has come to hand. I<span class='line-break'> </span>was at Mt Auburn this morning,<span class='line-break'> </span>and noticed that the <ins>number</ins> of your<span class='line-break'> </span>lot is cut upon the marble monument.<span class='line-break'> </span>So that you will need only the four<span class='line-break'> </span>8 inch boundary posts. I write this<span class='line-break'> </span>morning, lest you should be under<span class='line-break'> </span>a misapprehension as to the expense<span class='line-break'> </span>that may be incurred by a compliance<span class='line-break'> </span>with our rule. The whole cost to you<span class='line-break'> </span>of these four posts set will be but<span class='line-break'> </span>eight dollars $8.:- and we do not<span class='line-break'> </span>propose to put you to any other expense<span class='line-break'> </span>than what you may voluntarily incur.</p>
<p>If you wish the amount to remain until<span class='line-break'> </span>Spring, just say so,-  we can set the posts<span class='line-break'> </span>and let the bill wait that long, if any<span class='line-break'> </span>particular accommodation.</p>
<p>The cost of cut the grass through the season<span class='line-break'> </span>is usually $3. or $5 if some plants are set in<span class='line-break'> </span>the border. - The Corporation cuts the grass on<span class='line-break'> </span>all lots not cared for at the expense of the prop<sup>rs</sup>,<span class='line-break'> </span>about twice a year <ins>without</ins> charge, but<span class='line-break'> </span>this is not often enough to keep lots green.<span class='line-break'> </span>About once in ten years a lot wants new sodding,<span class='line-break'> </span>cost about $15 to $20, for manure, sod &amp; work.</p>
<p>We have had your name in our records &amp; on our last catalogue <a href='/pages/subjects/65125' title='Bliss, Eliza A.'><ins>Eliza </ins> A. Bliss</a>. A few days<span class='line-break'> </span>since a clerk of our [Mission?] told me it was <ins>Elizabeth</ins>. I don't know how this mistake came<span class='line-break'> </span>to be made. I see that you signed the affidavit which I prepared two or three years since<span class='line-break'> </span>without correcting it.</p>
<p>Yours resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>99</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133589">
<h3><a name="page-1133589">CB01_0100</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-11-20'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 20. 1863</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65126' title='Skinner, C. F.'>C.F. Skinner</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 13<sup>th</sup> last<span class='line-break'> </span>was rec<sup>d</sup>. The expense of setting four<span class='line-break'> </span>8 inch posts on your lot will be<span class='line-break'> </span>($8.00) eight dollars and whatever<span class='line-break'> </span>additional cost may be incurred by<span class='line-break'> </span>us for cutting No. 76 on a granite front<span class='line-break'> </span>the whole will not exceed $10: <ins>probably</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>not more than $9.00.</p>
<p>You say you "should prefer<span class='line-break'> </span>to sell the lot." I think that can<span class='line-break'> </span>be effected, if you will say what<span class='line-break'> </span>you are willing to sell it for.</p>
<p>All we ask for land around that<span class='line-break'> </span>point is 50 cents per foot = $150 for<span class='line-break'> </span>a lot of 300 feet, which is the<span class='line-break'> </span>size of 76. - It is rather late this<span class='line-break'> </span>autumn, but still I might dispose<span class='line-break'> </span>of it before winter.</p>
<p>If you choose, you can<span class='line-break'> </span>[use?] either course - say<span class='line-break'> </span>what you will take for it now<span class='line-break'> </span>in cash - or at any time <ins>within<span class='line-break'> </span>6 mos.</ins> as soon as a sale can<span class='line-break'> </span>be effected, giving me the privilege<span class='line-break'> </span>of grading it and putting it in<span class='line-break'> </span>a saleable condition. I should<span class='line-break'> </span>prefer the latter mode. You will<span class='line-break'> </span>be safe under it, as the land<span class='line-break'> </span>cannot run away - cannot deterior<span class='line-break'></span>ate in value, and cannot be<span class='line-break'> </span>conveyed away from you.</p>
<p>I shall be pleased to<span class='line-break'> </span>hear from you on the<span class='line-break'> </span>subject.</p>
<p>In this way two things will be<span class='line-break'> </span>secured - you will dispose of what<span class='line-break'> </span>you do not wish for, and the<span class='line-break'> </span>appearance of the grounds will be<span class='line-break'> </span>improved.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>100</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133590">
<h3><a name="page-1133590">CB01_0101</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-11-28'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 28.   3</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>C.P. Curtis Esq</a><sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>Chairman Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65195' title='Loring, Caleb W.'>Mr C. W. Loring</a><span class='line-break'> </span>has applied in behalf of the heirs of<span class='line-break'> </span>the late <a href='/pages/subjects/65196' title='Blake, Sally Stanton'>Mrs Joshua Blake</a> to know<span class='line-break'> </span>for what sum the Corporation will<span class='line-break'> </span>assume the care of the lot owned<span class='line-break'> </span>by them - <a href='/pages/subjects/65197' title='Lot 408'>no. 408</a>, corner of <a href='/pages/subjects/61210' title='Ivy Path'>Ivy &amp;</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/61124' title='Aster Path'>Aster<span class='line-break'> </span>Paths</a>, containing 645 square feet. It seems<span class='line-break'> </span>that <a href='/pages/subjects/65196' title='Blake, Sally Stanton'>Mrs Blake</a> left with her will a paper <span class='line-break'> </span>signed by herself, which she may have sup<span class='line-break'></span>posed had the effect of a codicil duly ex<span class='line-break'></span>ecuted, but was not so executed, contain<span class='line-break'> </span>a desire or request that $400 should<span class='line-break'> </span>be appropriated to the care of said lot<span class='line-break'> </span>Whatever may be done, the consent of<span class='line-break'> </span>the heirs will have to be obtained.</p>
<p>You will see by the accompanying<span class='line-break'> </span>report from the Superintendent, that<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot is contained in one enclosure<span class='line-break'> </span>with the lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/65198' title='Hallet, George'>Geo. Hallet's</a> heirs,<span class='line-break'> </span>(<a href='/pages/subjects/65199' title='Lot 407'>no. 407</a>) and having one monument<span class='line-break'> </span>in common, so that the more practicable<span class='line-break'> </span>method would appear to be the<span class='line-break'> </span>care of both lots together.</p>
<p>While therefore it will be well for<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee to indicate the sum<span class='line-break'> </span>for which they will recommend the<span class='line-break'> </span>undertaking for <ins>both</ins> lots, the Blake<span class='line-break'> </span>heirs will perhaps expect you<span class='line-break'> </span>also to say for what sum you will<span class='line-break'> </span>assume the care of their lot.</p>
<p>Very Resp. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p>101</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133591">
<h3><a name="page-1133591">CB01_0102_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-12-07'>Dec. 7, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65200' title='Cotting, Charles U.'>C. U. Cotting</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have conferred with<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee on Lots of our Cemetery,<span class='line-break'> </span>upon the question proposed by you -<span class='line-break'> </span>whether they would allow <a href='/pages/subjects/65201' title='Willard, Susan L.'>Mrs Willard</a><span class='line-break'> </span>to take charge of her <a href='/pages/subjects/65202' title='Lot 801'>lot ^<sup>no. 801</sup></a>, during her lifetime,<span class='line-break'> </span>and would place to her credit a certain<span class='line-break'> </span>proportion of the income of the fund of<span class='line-break'> </span>three hundred and fifty ($350) dollars<span class='line-break'> </span>to meet any bills which she may authorize<span class='line-break'> </span>for such care: ~</p>
<p>And I am authorized to say that they<span class='line-break'> </span>will assent to this arrangement, and<span class='line-break'> </span>will place <ins>five per centum</ins> of such<span class='line-break'> </span>principal to her credit for such care.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y of Mt Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>Cem.y</p>
<p>33 School St <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a></p>
<p><date when='1863-12-09'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 9, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65203' title='Blood, Arvilla'>Mrs. John Blood</a></p>
<p>Madam,</p>
<p>I wrote you some <span class='line-break'> </span>weeks since asking you if you <span class='line-break'> </span>had decided whether to take your <span class='line-break'> </span>lot in the rectangular form, in<span class='line-break'> </span>which it was first reported, ie,<span class='line-break'> </span>15 ft by 20 ft or whether to extend<span class='line-break'> </span>one side of it back according to<span class='line-break'> </span>the land there is there, as recom<span class='line-break'></span>mended you by the Superintendents<span class='line-break'> </span>and have received no reply <span class='line-break'> </span>from you.-</p>
<p>It is important that I should <span class='line-break'> </span>be informed, until which time<span class='line-break'> </span>I can make you no deed.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary of Mt Auburn</p>
<p>Please send your reply to <ins>me.</ins>.</p>
<p>102</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133592">
<h3><a name="page-1133592">CB01_0103</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-12-07'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 7, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65195' title='Loring, Caleb W.'>C.W. Loring</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have submitted to the "Committee on Lots"<span class='line-break'> </span>of our Corporation, consisting of Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Chas. P. Curtis</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Edw<sup>d</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>Austin</a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/65205' title='Andrews, William T.'>W<sup>m</sup>. T. Andrews</a>, your question - "for what sum<span class='line-break'> </span>they will recommend the Trustees to contract for the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>care of lot <a href='/pages/subjects/65197' title='Lot 408'>no. 408</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/61210' title='Ivy Path'>Ivy Path</a>, belonging to heirs of the late<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65206' title='Blake, Joshua'>Joshua Blake</a>": - and subjoin a copy of their reply: -<span class='line-break'> </span>premising, however, that the Blake lot is contained within<span class='line-break'> </span>the same enclosure as lot <a href='/pages/subjects/65199' title='Lot 407'>no. 407</a>, belonging to heirs of the<span class='line-break'> </span>late <a href='/pages/subjects/65198' title='Hallet, George'>George Hallet</a>, having a monument in common to both<span class='line-break'> </span>lots, erected to the memory of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/65207' title='Stanton, Francis'>Francis Stanton</a>, and<span class='line-break'> </span>that the care of both lots as one seems to be the only practicable<span class='line-break'> </span>mode of arrangement: Size of <a href='/pages/subjects/65199' title='Lot 407'>lots viz. 407</a> has 511 feet &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/65197' title='Lot 408'><!--Lot-->408</a> has<span class='line-break'> </span>645 feet = 1156 square feet.</p>
<p>"The Committee on Lots will recommend the Trustees to<span class='line-break'> </span>guarantee the perpetual care and preservation of the two lots, <a href='/pages/subjects/65199' title='Lot 407'>nos.<span class='line-break'> </span>407</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/65197' title='Lot 408'>&amp; 408</a> for one thousand ($1000) dollars. As there is a<span class='line-break'> </span>handsome monument to <a href='/pages/subjects/65207' title='Stanton, Francis'>Mr Francis Stanton</a>, standing<span class='line-break'> </span>in the middle of the triangle, the Committee think it will<span class='line-break'> </span>be best for all parties that there should be one<span class='line-break'> </span>Bond embracing the whole of both lots; but</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133593">
<h3><a name="page-1133593">CB01_0104</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>104</p>
<p>if the proprietors prefer to have two bonds, the<span class='line-break'> </span>Committee will issue them. The Trustees, however, will<span class='line-break'> </span>not contract for the preservation of one lot alone.”</p>
<p>The above reply, of course, is not intended<span class='line-break'> </span>to deprive any proprietor from exercising a right conferred <span class='line-break'> </span>by the by-laws of depositing any sum not less than $100 with<span class='line-break'> </span>[the] Corporation, the income of which will be devoted to the<span class='line-break'> </span>care of his or her lot, upon the usual terms of trust; <span class='line-break'> </span>It relates only to the <ins>guaranty</ins> of perpetual care.-</p>
<p>I am very respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a>, Secy of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Prop<sup>rs</sup> Cem.y of Mt. Auburn</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, ------- <date when='1863-12-17'>De<sup>r</sup> 17  1863</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,<span class='line-break'> </span>Will you be so kind as <span class='line-break'> </span>to confer with <a href='/pages/subjects/65211' title='Hemenway, Mary Tileston'>Mrs. Hemenway</a> <span class='line-break'> </span>as to the reconveyance of her ^<sup>burial</sup> lots with <span class='line-break'> </span>a view to receive a deed of the <span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation of the whole in one lot.</p>
<p>The transfer of <a href='/pages/subjects/65212' title='Lot 2297'>lot 2297</a> from <a href='/pages/subjects/65213' title='Merrill, Lewis F.'>L.F. <span class='line-break'> </span>Merrill</a> ran to the Corporation, &amp; has not <span class='line-break'> </span>since been conveyed to <a href='/pages/subjects/65211' title='Hemenway, Mary Tileston'>Mrs. H.<!--Hemenway--></a>- <a href='/pages/subjects/65214' title='Lot 1463'>Lot 1463</a> <span class='line-break'> </span>stands in the name of <a href='/pages/subjects/65215' title='Hemenway, Augustus'>Augustus Hemenway</a>. <span class='line-break'> </span>The two old lots contained 600 square feet.- <span class='line-break'> </span>Her lot as curbed contains 790 square feet. <span class='line-break'> </span>She must pay the Corporation for <ins>190 feet</ins> <span class='line-break'> </span>of land, and as the land is all enclosed in one <span class='line-break'> </span>curb, it is impraticable to have more than one <span class='line-break'> </span>number, which should be her old one <a href='/pages/subjects/65214' title='Lot 1463'>– 1463.</a> <span class='line-break'> </span>As lots are indivisible, on order to preserve unity of <span class='line-break'> </span>title, I see no way but for the Trustees of <a href='/pages/subjects/65215' title='Hemenway, Augustus'>Mr H<!--Hemenway--></a><span class='line-break'> </span>to reconvey <a href='/pages/subjects/65214' title='Lot 1463'><!--lot-->1463</a> to the Corporation, &amp; a new deed be <span class='line-break'> </span>made to <a href='/pages/subjects/65211' title='Hemenway, Mary Tileston'>Mrs. H.<!--Hemenway--></a> of 790 feet.</p>
<p>Very rspfly yours <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J.Coolidge</a></p>
<p>I have fact rec<sup>d</sup> &amp; recorded the deed of ornamental grounds &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/58208' title='Alice Fountain'><!--Alice-->fountain</a><span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/65211' title='Hemenway, Mary Tileston'>Mrs. H.<!--Hemenway--></a>  - which she will probably receive tomorrow or next day.<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133594">
<h3><a name="page-1133594">CB01_0105</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-12-17'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 17, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D. L. Winsor</a> Sup<sup>t</sup>  Mt. A. C.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a> -<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/81482' title='Shedd, J. H., Mr.'>Mr Shedd's</a> surveyor -- gives me<span class='line-break'> </span>as the contents of <a href='/pages/subjects/65211' title='Hemenway, Mary Tileston'>Mrs Mary<span class='line-break'> </span>Hemenway's</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/58208' title='Alice Fountain'>lot - inside mea<span class='line-break'></span>sure of the curb, &amp; taking into<span class='line-break'> </span>account the curvature</a> - <ins>790 Square<span class='line-break'> </span>feet</ins>. He says the posts are some<span class='line-break'> </span>18 or 20 inches, which is rather<span class='line-break'> </span>a large allowance - but <del>it is</del> per<span class='line-break'></span>haps you did not intend to include<span class='line-break'> </span>any portion of them in the survey.-</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65211' title='Hemenway, Mary Tileston'>Mrs. H.</a> bought lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/65213' title='Merrill, Lewis F.'>Lewis F. Merrill</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>which with her own made 600 feet.-</p>
<p>Will you therefore please report<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>190 feet</ins> in addition to her <a href='/pages/subjects/65214' title='Lot 1463'>lot 1463</a>.</p>
<p>We shall probably receive the transfers,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; convey where all in one deed.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-12-18'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 18, 1863</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Not knowing from whom<span class='line-break'> </span>the deed to <a href='/pages/subjects/65211' title='Hemenway, Mary Tileston'>Mrs Hemenway</a> came<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Mr Bond</a>, but knowing that<span class='line-break'> </span>all the negotiations with her were<span class='line-break'> </span>through you, I take the liberty to<span class='line-break'> </span>return the deed to her through you,<span class='line-break'> </span>it and a copy of the place having<span class='line-break'> </span>been duly recorded by me.</p>
<p>Very respy. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52529' title='Bigelow, Jacob'>Dr J. Bigelow</a></p>
<p>105</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133595">
<h3><a name="page-1133595">CB01_0106_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-12-19'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 19, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57824' title='Wolcott, J. Huntington'>J. Huntington Wolcott</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have shown<span class='line-break'> </span>two plans of your lot in Mt<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn to <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a> viz a<span class='line-break'> </span>tracing of the <ins>present</ins> location,<span class='line-break'> </span>and one of the <ins>proposed</ins> location,<span class='line-break'> </span>and stated as fairly as possible<span class='line-break'> </span>your views.</p>
<p>He wished me to leave them<span class='line-break'> </span>with him, and to say to you<span class='line-break'> </span>that he would be pleased to<span class='line-break'> </span>confer with you about the matter.</p>
<p>I accordingly do so.</p>
<p>Very respectfully<span class='line-break'> </span>You Ob<sup>t</sup>  Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y of Mt Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr C.P. Curtis</a>, 16 Court St.<span class='line-break'> </span>[indecipherable sentence off page]</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-12-19'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 19, 1863</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I sent you the Contract<span class='line-break'> </span>drawn up as agreed upon for the<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual care of lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/65201' title='Willard, Susan L.'>Mrs Susan<span class='line-break'> </span>L. Willard</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/65202' title='Lot 801'>no 801</a>.-</p>
<p>Please get <a href='/pages/subjects/65201' title='Willard, Susan L.'>Mrs Willard's</a> signa<span class='line-break'></span>ture, and when you have the Treas<sup>rs</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>receipt for the amount; return the<span class='line-break'> </span>document to me for completion &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>record.</p>
<p>The main body of the instrument <span class='line-break'> </span>must, I think be considered an <ins>agreement</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>subject to a stamp duty of <ins>5 cts</ins> &amp; the<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>certificate</ins> of the Com<sup>ee</sup> on lots 5 cts<span class='line-break'> </span>more.-</p>
<p>My charge will be $2.-</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65200' title='Cotting, Charles U.'>C. U. Cotting</a> Esq.<span class='line-break'> </span>2 Joy St Building [?]</p>
<p>106</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133596">
<h3><a name="page-1133596">CB01_0107</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-12-26'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 26, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo. W<sup>m</sup>  Bond</a> Esq<sup>r</sup>, Treas<sup>r</sup> .</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I send in a package<span class='line-break'> </span>thirty four checks which have been ordered.<span class='line-break'> </span>Deeds ordered for <a href='/pages/subjects/65224' title='Colburn, George W.'>Geo. W. Colburn</a>-<span class='line-break'> </span>Heirs of <a href='/pages/subjects/65225' title='Lowell, Charles'>Chas. Lowell</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/62119' title='Lee, Thomas J.'>Thos. J Lee</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>4 <a href='/pages/subjects/65226' title='Upham Bros.'>Upham Bros.</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65227' title='Brown, Susan'>Susan Brown</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65228' title='Allen, Lydia M.'>Lydia M. Allen</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65229' title='Caulk, Mary B.'>Mary B. Caulk</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65230' title='Noyes, Harriet'>Harriet Noyes</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65231' title='Prescott, Ruth W.'>Ruth W. Prescott</a>.<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/65232' title='Clark, Alvan'>Alvan Clark</a></p>
<p>I am not able to return yet. The last named<span class='line-break'> </span>here not paid the $50 for tomb rights.- This<span class='line-break'> </span>rule applies to all new purchases whether the tomb<span class='line-break'> </span>be a catacomb or otherwise.</p>
<p>I do not find any record of<span class='line-break'> </span>agreement about allowance on the <a href='/pages/subjects/60942' title='Larkin, Thomas C.'>Larkin</a> lots<span class='line-break'> </span>inquired about by you.--</p>
<p>Please receipt in turn bill to <a href='/pages/subjects/65238' title='Hosmer, Zelotes '>Z. Hosmer</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>for the draft of $10 which I send you. -</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secy.</p>
<p>33 School St ---<a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-12-26'>Dec<sup>r</sup>  26, 1863</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65279' title='Loring, George H.'>Geo. H. Loring</a> Esq<sup>r</sup> .<span class='line-break'> </span>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I am informed by<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. Winsor</a> that the deed of your<span class='line-break'> </span>lot does not correctly describe its location.<span class='line-break'> </span>that he was obliged to turn it about;<span class='line-break'> </span>for want of depth. If you will send<span class='line-break'> </span>the deed to me, I will correct it.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Secy.</p>
<p>107</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133597">
<h3><a name="page-1133597">CB01_0108</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-12-26'>Dec<sup>r</sup>  26th  [186]3</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65238' title='Hosmer, Zelotes '>Zelotes Hosmer</a> Esq<sup>r</sup>, <a href='/pages/subjects/65239' title='Beloit, WI'>Beloit, Wis.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 14<sup>th</sup> [last?] came <span class='line-break'> </span>duly to hand with draft for $10. for which I send<span class='line-break'> </span>you the enclosed receipted bill. The frost is now  &amp; has<span class='line-break'> </span>been since the receipt of your note quite deep &amp; the<span class='line-break'> </span>work will be done as soon as frost permits.</p>
<p>From the mound, I had always supposed you<span class='line-break'> </span>had a tomb, &amp; was quite surprised to learn from<span class='line-break'> </span>you that such is not the case. The tomb privilege<span class='line-break'> </span>there however is worth nothing, because the ground<span class='line-break'> </span>is so low, it would be wet, &amp; no one would be wil<span class='line-break'></span>ling to sink one there. We have abundance of side<span class='line-break'> </span>hill better adapted to the purpose. The price of lots<span class='line-break'> </span>there - the current rate - is 50 cts per foot. That is<span class='line-break'> </span>what our last sale was made at; making your<span class='line-break'> </span>lot worth $150, or with the posts &amp;c. $160. The<span class='line-break'> </span>mound would not be available in new<span class='line-break'> </span>grading, as the whole lot will need<span class='line-break'> </span>raising three or four feet.</p>
<p>What cost you $60 on the <date when='1881-11-18'>18<sup>th</sup> day of Nov<sup>r</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>1881</date> is now worth $150. You have had a<span class='line-break'> </span>venerable length of possession, viz. 32 years<span class='line-break'> </span>and with 192 per ct added for interest, you<span class='line-break'> </span>should be entitled to $115.20 + 60 = $175.20.<span class='line-break'> </span>But, although the prices have advanced enough<span class='line-break'> </span>to cover interest, in some cases, they will<span class='line-break'> </span>not in the case of the older proprietors: and<span class='line-break'> </span>rarely has it been the case that an old lot<span class='line-break'> </span>would bring a sum equal to interests added,<span class='line-break'> </span>because there are so many new ones equally<span class='line-break'> </span>eligible. Generally, however, where a proprietor<span class='line-break'> </span>wishes to sell out, he has had some use of his<span class='line-break'> </span>lot, which is deemed an offset to the failure to<span class='line-break'> </span>receive interest.</p>
<p>If you wish to authorize me to sell<span class='line-break'> </span>your lot for the sum named - $160 - I will do the<span class='line-break'> </span>best I can to dispose of it: and can probably<span class='line-break'> </span>do so in the Spring, if not earlier.</p>
<p>Very truly yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>108</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133598">
<h3><a name="page-1133598">CB01_0109</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School St --- <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-12-28'>Dec<sup>r</sup>  28, [186]3</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55348' title='Jones, Lewis'>Mr Lewis Jones</a></p>
<p>Sir,</p>
<p>In the  case of <ins><a href='/pages/subjects/65240' title='Stone, Lucy F.'>Lucy F. Stone</a></ins>,<span class='line-break'> </span>deposited in our <a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>Receiving Tomb</a>, <date when='1863-11-11'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 11, 1863</date>,<span class='line-break'> </span>you are said to have been the undertaker.<span class='line-break'> </span>No order has been rec<sup>d</sup> for the same, nor have<span class='line-break'> </span>the facts required been returned. You will<span class='line-break'> </span>please see that the order properly filled &amp; signed<span class='line-break'> </span>is sent to me, as soon as possible. -</p>
<p>Respy. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary Mt Auburn</p>
<p>33 School St --- <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1863-12-29'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 29, [186]3</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Enclosed I send you<span class='line-break'> </span>ready for execution the deed of<span class='line-break'> </span>the part of your lot which you<span class='line-break'> </span>propose to convey to <a href='/pages/subjects/65241' title='Parker, H. D., Mrs.'>Mrs. Parker</a>.</p>
<p>I also enclose a card of admission<span class='line-break'> </span>for her.-</p>
<p>Whenever you are ready, I will take<span class='line-break'> </span>your acknowlegment. - any hour after<span class='line-break'> </span>12 o'clock.</p>
<p>The deed to yourself has been sent to<span class='line-break'> </span>the Treas<sup>r</sup> <a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Mr Bond</a>, 167 Congress St.<span class='line-break'> </span>for delivery, as he wishes each proprietor<span class='line-break'> </span>to receipt for the deed upon his certificate<span class='line-break'> </span>book.-</p>
<p>Yours truly<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>-<a href='/pages/subjects/65242' title='Parker, H. D.'>H.D. Parker</a> Esq</p>
<p>109</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133599">
<h3><a name="page-1133599">CB01_0110</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>33 School Street, <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1863-12-30'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 30, [186]3</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65243' title='Blood, William H.'>Mr W<sup>m</sup> H. Blood</a>  77 Franklin St</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclose you a note written to <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65203' title='Blood, Arvilla'>Mrs John Blood</a> by myself &amp; rec<sup>d</sup> again by me from<span class='line-break'> </span>the dead letter office under date of <date when='1863-12-18'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 18<sup>th</sup></date> &amp; since <span class='line-break'> </span>writing it &amp; before its return from Washington, I have<span class='line-break'> </span>written her another addressed in the same way to<span class='line-break'> </span>her at <a href='/pages/subjects/54284' title='Charlestown, MA'>Charlestown</a>, to which I have rec<sup>d</sup> no reply .-<span class='line-break'> </span>Ascertaining who was cutting a curb for the lot,<span class='line-break'> </span>I inquired of Mr Hutchinson and obtained your <span class='line-break'> </span>address.</p>
<p>Will you please get the deed from our Trea.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Mr Bond</a> (167 Congress St.) and confer with your<span class='line-break'> </span>mother - then with me?  If the curb is being cut <span class='line-break'> </span>as <a href='/pages/subjects/25009051' title='Hutchinson, G. B.'>Mr Hutchinson</a> told me 16f x 17f x 18f x 18f the deed <span class='line-break'> </span>(which I returned to the Treas<sup>r</sup> despairing of hearing<span class='line-break'> </span>from <a href='/pages/subjects/65203' title='Blood, Arvilla'>Mrs Blood</a>, &amp; which gives the dimensions of<span class='line-break'> </span>lot as 15 x 20 f) should be corrected.</p>
<p>Please see that the other letter is not sent for<span class='line-break'> </span>to the dead letter office.</p>
<p>Yours resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y Mt.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, ----<date when='1863-12-31'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 31, [186]3</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a> Sup<sup>t</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Please report <span class='line-break'> </span>upon the condition of the <a href='/pages/subjects/61307' title='Cedar Hill'>Cedar <span class='line-break'> </span>Hill</a> Enclosure, belonging to <a href='/pages/subjects/54936' title='Appleton, William'>W<sup>m</sup> <span class='line-break'> </span>Appleton</a>.  I send a blank sup<span class='line-break'></span>posing you might not have the <span class='line-break'> </span>contents at hand.</p>
<p>Please not allude to <a href='/pages/subjects/63954' title='Appleton, Samuel, Mrs.'>Mrs Sam.<span class='line-break'> </span>Appleton</a>'s or <a href='/pages/subjects/65245' title='Peabody, Mary Jane'>Mrs Peabody's</a> lot-,<span class='line-break'> </span>as they form no necessary part of<span class='line-break'> </span>the enclosure, and Mr A. will<span class='line-break'> </span>not think of providing for them.</p>
<p>The lots <a href='/pages/subjects/65246' title='Lot 3363'>3363,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/65247' title='Lot 3364'>3364,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/65248' title='Lot 3388'>3388,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/65249' title='Lot 3389'><!--lot-->3389</a><span class='line-break'> </span>in the rear of <a href='/pages/subjects/59966' title='Acanthus Path'>Acanthus Path</a>, which I un<span class='line-break'></span>derstood you were posted, <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Curtis</a> has not<span class='line-break'> </span>on the plan.
