<p>I am directed [by]<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee on Lots to notify you<span class='line-break'> </span>that they have agreed to recommend to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees to assume the perpetual care<span class='line-break'> </span>of your lot for eight hundred dollars.</p>
<p>This sum may seem large, but<span class='line-break'> </span>it is not really so when the size of<span class='line-break'> </span>your lot and the increasing expenditures<span class='line-break'> </span>for such care are considered.</p>
<p>I am</p>
<p>Very Respy. Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>138</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133628">
<h3><a name="page-1133628">CB01_0139_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-03-22'>March 22, [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65940' title='Osgood, Samuel S.'>S.S. Osgood</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>54 East 20<sup>th</sup> St., <a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The subject of the amount<span class='line-break'> </span>requisite for the perpetual care of your <a href='/pages/subjects/65941' title='Lot 2151'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>no. 2151</a> in the Cemetery has been considered<span class='line-break'> </span>by the Committee on Lots, who have instructed<span class='line-break'> </span>me to inform you that they will<span class='line-break'> </span>recommend the Trustees to assume<span class='line-break'> </span>such care for the sum of five hun--<span class='line-break'> </span>dred dollars.</p>
<p>This amount may <ins>seem</ins> some<span class='line-break'></span>what large to you, but it is believed<span class='line-break'> </span>that the value of the lot and its erections<span class='line-break'> </span>together with the increased cost of such<span class='line-break'> </span>repair would not justify the Corporation in<span class='line-break'> </span>estimating it for a lower sum.—</p>
<p>I am very respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a>, Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1864-03-29'>March 29 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65940' title='Osgood, Samuel S.'>S.S. Osgood</a> Esq<sup>re</sup><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I regret to<span class='line-break'> </span>perceive from your note of 26<sup>th</sup> last which<span class='line-break'> </span>is just rec<sup>d</sup>, that my explanation of our<span class='line-break'> </span>regulations respecting the perpetual care<span class='line-break'> </span>of lots, when you were at my office, was<span class='line-break'> </span>to so little purpose.</p>
<p>If you will turn to Art. 29 of our printed<span class='line-break'> </span>by-laws, which are contained in the two<span class='line-break'> </span>last editions of the catalogue (1857, 1860) you<span class='line-break'> </span>will find the following language— "The Trus<span class='line-break'></span>tees will receive in trust from any pro<span class='line-break'></span>prietor a sum of money <ins>not less</ins> than<span class='line-break'> </span>one hundred dollars, the income of which<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be appropriated to the repair of his<span class='line-break'> </span>lot, according to the terms of trust given in<span class='line-break'> </span>the appendix".</p>
<p>"The Trustees may also <ins>guarantee</ins></p>
<p>139</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133629">
<h3><a name="page-1133629">CB01_0140_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>the <ins>perpetual</ins> repair of lots, containing<span class='line-break'> </span>three hundred feet and upwards, on the pay--<span class='line-break'> </span>ment of a sum <ins>not less than three hun--</ins><span class='line-break'> </span><ins>dred dollars</ins>, and of lots containing less<span class='line-break'> </span>than three hundred feet, on the payment<span class='line-break'> </span>of a sum not less than one hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars, according to the terms of Trust<span class='line-break'> </span>given in the appendix. In this case, if<span class='line-break'> </span>the Repair Fund should ever be lost, the whole<span class='line-break'> </span>property of the Corporation is held for the per--<span class='line-break'> </span>petual repair of such lots."—</p>
<p>Upon the supposition that you under--<span class='line-break'> </span>stood the above clauses, which I either<span class='line-break'> </span>showed or explained to you, when you wrote<span class='line-break'> </span>on <date when='1864-02-27'>27<sup>th</sup> Feby.</date> asking— "what will be the<span class='line-break'> </span>amount to be paid to secure <ins>perpetual</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>care of my <a href='/pages/subjects/65941' title='Lot 2151'>lot no. 2151</a>"?— I very nat--<span class='line-break'> </span>urally supposed you desired the <ins>guaranty</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>contract. With that supposition, I sub<span class='line-break'></span>mitted that question to the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots. Your lot contains 300 square feet<span class='line-break'> </span>as shown by the catalogue, and by the<span class='line-break'> </span>[Corporation?] [last sentence on page hard to read]</p>
<p>the only place proper for reference to obtain<span class='line-break'> </span>certain knowledge on that point. I have<span class='line-break'> </span>the usual examination made by the Super--<span class='line-break'> </span>intendent in back cases reported in writing<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Com<sup>ee</sup>, which paper is returned to me<span class='line-break'> </span>and placed on the files. In that paper is --<span class='line-break'> </span>"size of lot -- 300 square feet."— Your<span class='line-break'> </span>suggestion, therefore, that "the Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>must have made a mistake in the size of my<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65941' title='Lot 2151'>lot 2151</a>"— is, I must think, somewhat out<span class='line-break'> </span>of place.</p>
<p>You have evidently confounded the two<span class='line-break'> </span>kinds of contract. If you notice the lan--<span class='line-break'> </span>guage of the by-law again you will see that<span class='line-break'> </span>there is no absolute measure for the care of<span class='line-break'> </span>a lot. No sum <ins>less</ins> than $100 can be received.<span class='line-break'> </span>You can pay in $100, if you choose, and the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation will faithfully apply the income,<span class='line-break'> </span>to the purpose— but if it is insufficient for<span class='line-break'> </span>all that may be required, no one can<span class='line-break'> </span>certainly find fault for the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>not going beyond the means at their disposal.<span class='line-break'> </span>It is a <ins>trust</ins>. The Trustees are mere fiduciary</p>
<p>140</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133630">
<h3><a name="page-1133630">CB01_0141_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>agents, and have no right to involve the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation in obligations which are attended<span class='line-break'> </span>only with lots.</p>
<p>For the <ins>guaranty</ins> contract the Trustees decide<span class='line-break'> </span>in each case the amount according to the value<span class='line-break'> </span>of the lot &amp; its appurtenances. I notifed another<span class='line-break'> </span>gentleman on the same day that I did you. The<span class='line-break'> </span>amount in his case was $800. Your lot, if<span class='line-break'> </span>there was no monument or fence, could not be<span class='line-break'> </span>taken for less than $300. The measure of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporate obligation is for <ins>all time</ins>,<span class='line-break'> </span>and independently of any <ins>depreciation of money</ins>,<span class='line-break'> </span>and to the extent of the <ins>value of everything upon<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot</ins>. If the monument is struck by lightning<span class='line-break'> </span>or broken by a tornado, or the fall of a tree, or<span class='line-break'> </span>by malicious mischief or from any other cause,<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation is liable to replace it. --</p>
<p>I think now you will perceive the dif<span class='line-break'></span>ference between the two clauses. -- To give<span class='line-break'> </span>one, two or three hundred, as you please, is<span class='line-break'> </span>practically safe, and under it you get the<span class='line-break'> </span>full benefit; but many prefer the guaranty<span class='line-break'> </span>there whatever expense is required is borne by the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation.</p>
<p>The amount necessary for the annual care is<span class='line-break'> </span>a poor criterion. Every few years extra repair, as<span class='line-break'> </span>new grading, sodding, i.e, are needed, and these<span class='line-break'> </span>have been but little, if any, accumulation, under<span class='line-break'> </span>any of the contracts.</p>
<p>I am very happy to explain, &amp; only re--<span class='line-break'> </span>gret that you should be been misled in<span class='line-break'> </span>your information.</p>
<p>I am very respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1864-03-30'>March 30 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65961' title='Safford, William H.'>Mr W<sup>m</sup> H. Safford</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I saw <a href='/pages/subjects/52529' title='Bigelow, Jacob'>Dr Bigelow</a><span class='line-break'> </span>for you yesterday. He has no objection<span class='line-break'> </span>to the use of the  plate of the little map<span class='line-break'> </span>by you, if you will have the corrections<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; additions made upon it. <a href='/pages/subjects/81482' title='Shedd, J. H., Mr.'>Mr Shedd</a><span class='line-break'> </span>can give you a sketch of the changes in a<span class='line-break'> </span>suitable form for transfer to the copper. -<span class='line-break'> </span>I have the plate.</p>
<p>You will be at the expense of the im<span class='line-break'></span>provements, and can print 500 impress--<span class='line-break'> </span>ions &amp; return the plate. --</p>
<p>There are some 200 copies of views<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/53239' title='Bigelow Chapel'><!--Bigelow-->chapel</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/54814' title='Washington Tower'>Tower</a>, but they must be<span class='line-break'> </span>too large for such a book as your<span class='line-break'> </span>intend, aside from their being wanted to<span class='line-break'> </span>accompany the remaining copies of the his--<span class='line-break'> </span>tory.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>141</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133631">
<h3><a name="page-1133631">CB01_0142</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>[?]</p>
<p>Notice-</p>
<p>Proprietors who visit Mount <span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn on Sundays and <span class='line-break'> </span>Holidays, whether on foot or in car--<span class='line-break'> </span>riages, will please notice that they are <span class='line-break'> </span>required to show their cards of admis--<span class='line-break'> </span>sion at <a href='/pages/subjects/57664' title='Entrance Gateway'>the Gate.</a>  The large number<span class='line-break'> </span>of persons who seek admission on <span class='line-break'> </span>these days, render the enforcement of <span class='line-break'> </span>this rule necessary to the security of <span class='line-break'> </span>the grounds.  None but propri--<span class='line-break'> </span>etors are admitted on Sundays and <span class='line-break'> </span>Holidays.  <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1864-04-16'>April 16<sup>th</sup>, 1864.</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>Austin. J Coolidge</a>, Secy.</p>
<p><del>Transcript</del></p>
<p><del>Wed &amp; Sat 3w.</del><span class='line-break'> </span>*Sat. [?] and Wed. 4w.</p>
<p>The [?] not to exceed 6 mos. without <span class='line-break'> </span>inquiry as to continuance.</p>
<p><date when='1864-04-22'>April 22 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65940' title='Osgood, Samuel S.'>S.S. Osgood</a>, Esq<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York City</a></p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 15<sup>th</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>wish with draft for $200 enclosed<span class='line-break'> </span>^<sup>in [truth?]</sup> for the repair of your lot was rec<sup>d</sup> in <span class='line-break'> </span>due course, and I have been <span class='line-break'> </span>so much pressed as to have no <span class='line-break'> </span>earlier time for attention. I send <span class='line-break'> </span>you this usual form of contract <span class='line-break'> </span>for your signature.  Please put on<span class='line-break'> </span>a five cent stamp and cancel with your <span class='line-break'> </span>initials &amp; date, &amp; return to me for<span class='line-break'> </span>record.  For Treas<sup>r</sup>is absent at <a href='/pages/subjects/54469' title='Washington, DC'>Wash--<span class='line-break'> </span>ington</a> - when he returns I will get <span class='line-break'> </span>his receipt  on the document, record it  <span class='line-break'> </span>and return it to you.-</p>
<p>You may enclose $2 if you <span class='line-break'> </span>please as my fees.-  I will attend to <span class='line-break'> </span>your order for this year at the cem as <span class='line-break'> </span>requested. -</p>
<p>Very truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>142</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133632">
<h3><a name="page-1133632">CB01_0143</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-05-05'>May 5<sup>th</sup> [186]4</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir.</p>
<p>At a meeting of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees of Mount Auburn Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>held on the <date when='1864-05-02'>2<sup>nd</sup></date> [?]. at which were <span class='line-break'> </span>present Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/52529' title='Bigelow, Jacob'>Bigelow</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/62841' title='Cheever, James'>Cheever</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/62842' title='Crocker, Uriel'>Crocker</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54774' title='Little, Charles C.'><!--Charles-->Little,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/65964' title='Livermore, George'><!--George-->Livermore,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Nazro</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/56312' title='Norcross, Otis'>Norcross</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/63802' title='Rand, Edward S.'>Rand</a>.</p>
<p>"<a href='/pages/subjects/63802' title='Rand, Edward S.'>Mr. Rand</a> said that among the<span class='line-break'> </span>matters brought before the Board at its last<span class='line-break'> </span>meeting (at which he was unable to be present,)<span class='line-break'> </span>was one which he sincerely regretted<span class='line-break'></span>the resignation tendered by <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a><span class='line-break'> </span>as a member of this Board.  He had<span class='line-break'> </span>hoped his long and valuable services would<span class='line-break'> </span>be given to the Corporation able longer:<span class='line-break'> </span>and that he would be induced to<span class='line-break'> </span>withdraw his resignation.</p>
<p>To<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Chas. P. Curtis</a> Esq. (over)</p>
<p>It was then, on motion by <a href='/pages/subjects/63802' title='Rand, Edward S.'>Mr. Rand</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>voted <ins>unanimously</ins>, that <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>Curtis</a> be requested to withdraw <span class='line-break'> </span>his letter of resignation, and<span class='line-break'> </span>continue to serve at this Board."</p>
<p>I am respectfully</p>
<p>Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>Austin J Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secy</p>
<p>143</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133633">
<h3><a name="page-1133633">CB01_0144</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-05-05'>May 5 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Trustees last Monday<span class='line-break'> </span>ordered a team gate to be placed near<span class='line-break'> </span>or opposite the Engine house.—</p>
<p>The subject of your communication<span class='line-break'> </span>"personal"— was referred to a Com<sup>ee</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>of three to inquire and report,— consisting<span class='line-break'> </span>of Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Nazro</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/54774' title='Little, Charles C.'><!--Charles-->Little</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/65964' title='Livermore, George'><!--George-->Livermore.</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/62842' title='Crocker, Uriel'>Mr. Crocker</a> for this Com<sup>ee</sup> on Interment<span class='line-break'> </span>reported on the subject of burial fees—<span class='line-break'> </span>on which I wish to make a word of in--<span class='line-break'> </span>quiry.— ^<sup>first saying</sup> By suggestions &amp; modifications from<span class='line-break'> </span>Members of the Board, the Com<sup>ee</sup> reported, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>the following tariff of prices was ordered—<span class='line-break'> </span>without however appointing any time<span class='line-break'> </span>for the plan to go into operation:—</p>
<p>(over)</p>
<p>For opening grave &amp; record<sup>s</sup> int. 5.00<span class='line-break'> </span>"[for] "[opening] "[tomb] for child under 10 yrs 3.00<span class='line-break'> </span>opening &amp; closing tomb at discretion of Sup<sup>t</sup> $3.00 to $5.00<span class='line-break'> </span>Depost in [Rec..<sup>g</sup>?] Tomb 20.00<span class='line-break'> </span>Of which <ins>     </ins> will be refunded upon<span class='line-break'> </span>removal of the body to any part of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Cem.y within four months.<span class='line-break'> </span>Building a brick grave 20.00"</p>
<p>Nothing is contained in the report about<span class='line-break'> </span>the amount to be refunded in case<span class='line-break'> </span>of deposit in the R.T. <a href='/pages/subjects/62842' title='Crocker, Uriel'>Mr Crocker</a><span class='line-break'> </span>said he believed you proposed $14.—<span class='line-break'> </span>You perceive, if left when it is, you get<span class='line-break'> </span>but the same for putting body in R.T. &amp; remov--<span class='line-break'> </span>ing it to a lot which you get in the case<span class='line-break'> </span>of a first internment in a lot.</p>
<p>Then again, have you but one price for<span class='line-break'> </span>brick graves— or do you wish to promulgate other<span class='line-break'> </span>prices— or for other sizes?— When do you wish<span class='line-break'> </span>the rule to go into effect? I suppose we had<span class='line-break'> </span>better give notice to the undertakers. Trusted<span class='line-break'> </span>of throwing away all our blanks.</p>
<p>144</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133634">
<h3><a name="page-1133634">CB01_0145</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>I think we can alter [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>[?]. Please reply on the matter<span class='line-break'> </span>by mail tomorrow.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57824' title='Wolcott, J. Huntington'>Mr J. Huntington Wolcott</a> has<span class='line-break'> </span>finally arranged this matter of purchasing <span class='line-break'> </span>additions to his lot &amp; that of <a href='/pages/subjects/57825' title='Frothingham, Theodore'>T. Frothingham</a>.</p>
<p>I send you a tracing from plan made by<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/57826' title='Shedd &amp; Edson'>Shedd &amp; Edson</a>. One end of the paper shows<span class='line-break'> </span>you how the lots were laid out, as shown<span class='line-break'> </span>on the sectional survey. By bringing <a href='/pages/subjects/57827' title='Lot 1779'>lots 1779</a><span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/57828' title='Lot 1869'><!--lot-->1869</a> into uniformity of size &amp;c. with the four<span class='line-break'> </span>original lots, making now six lots in one<span class='line-break'> </span>arrangement, the lots are thrown back some-<span class='line-break'></span>what from <a href='/pages/subjects/57829' title='Snowdrop Path'>Snowdrop P.</a> &amp; we sell spaces for:<span class='line-break'> </span>burial purposes and a large spot of front as<span class='line-break'> </span>ornamental ground. The only stick has been on the<span class='line-break'> </span>price of this 421 ft.— which regularly would have<span class='line-break'> </span>been 25 cts. <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a> authorized me to do the<span class='line-break'> </span>best I could with <a href='/pages/subjects/57824' title='Wolcott, J. Huntington'>Mr. Wolcott</a>. He has ^<sup>finally</sup> offered<span class='line-break'> </span>17 cts. &amp; I have given him to understand that<span class='line-break'> </span>it would be so concluded— for the piece being<span class='line-break'> </span>in the front of their lots, it would<span class='line-break'> </span>have been a difficult thing to sell to other<span class='line-break'> </span>parties.</p>
<p>Will you then please report as surveyed—</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>Add<sup>n</sup></th> <th>to <a href='/pages/subjects/57827' title='Lot 1779'>lot 1779</a>-</th> <th>220 f.</th> <th>@ 50 ct.</th> <th>$110.—</th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td> "[Add<sup>n</sup>]</td> <td>"[to] "{<a href='/pages/subjects/57828' title='Lot 1869'>lot 1869</a>}</td> <td>120 f.</td> <td>" [@] " [50] " [ct]</td> <td>60. </td> </tr> <tr><td> Ornamental "Add<sup>n</sup></td> <td>" [to] " [lot 1869]</td> <td>421 f</td> <td>"[@] 17 " [ct]</td> <td>71.57 </td> </tr> <tr><td> space "Add<sup>n</sup></td> <td>" [to] " [lot 1869]</td> <td>124 f</td> <td>" [@] " [17]</td> <td><ins> 21.08</ins> </td> </tr> <tr><td> ___</td> <td>___</td> <td>___</td> <td>___</td> <td>262.65 </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> Two posts are also required on the<span class='line-break'> </span>easterly corners of <a href='/pages/subjects/57827' title='Lot 1779'>lots 1779</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/57828' title='Lot 1869'><!--lot-->1869</a>. What further<span class='line-break'> </span>indications of title by granite posts the<span class='line-break'> </span>parties may hereafter desire, I cannot say—<span class='line-break'> </span>Now they will have a plan in conformity<span class='line-break'> </span>with this sketch. If you need Shedd;<span class='line-break'> </span>^<sup>now</sup> to fix the location of bounds, say so. He will<span class='line-break'> </span>now likely have to go again to get exact loca<span class='line-break'></span>tion of the monuments.—</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>145</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133635">
<h3><a name="page-1133635">CB01_0146</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-05-10'>May 10. 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65968' title='Perry, Joseph Alfred'>J.A. Perry</a> Esq.<span class='line-break'> </span>Comptroller of <a href='/pages/subjects/65969' title='Green-wood Cemetery, Brooklyn'>Greenwood Cem.y</a></p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you be so kind<span class='line-break'> </span>as to write to the address of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Cha<sup>s</sup>. G. Nazro</a>, Esq. of our<span class='line-break'> </span>Board of Trustees, informing him<span class='line-break'> </span>what your Corporation is paying <span class='line-break'> </span>at present for the services of Super<span class='line-break'></span>intendent, and whether any and what<span class='line-break'> </span>increase ^<sup>of salary</sup> has been made on account<span class='line-break'> </span>of the inflated prices of living, am<span class='line-break'> </span>obliged</p>
<p>Yours very Resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>I shall be absent for some time is my <span class='line-break'> </span>for asking you to reply to <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Mr <!--Charles-->N.</a></p>
<p><date when='1864-05-10'>May 10, 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p>To the President or Treas<sup>r</sup> of the<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65971' title='Laurel Hill Cemetery, Philadelphia'>Laurel Hill Cem.y</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/64806' title='Philadelphia, PA'>Phil<sup>a</sup></a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you be so kind <span class='line-break'> </span>as to write to the address of <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Cha<sup>s</sup>.<span class='line-break'> </span>G. Nazro</a>, Esq<sup>r</sup> of our Board of Trus--<span class='line-break'> </span>tees, informing him what your Corpor--<span class='line-break'> </span>ation is paying at present for the ser--<span class='line-break'> </span>vices of Superintendent, and whether<span class='line-break'> </span>any and what increase of salary <span class='line-break'> </span>has been made on account of<span class='line-break'> </span>the inflated prices of living,<span class='line-break'> </span>and oblige</p>
<p>Yours very resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>I shall be absent for some time is my reason<span class='line-break'> </span>for asking you to reply to <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Mr Nazro</a> --</p>
<p>146</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133636">
<h3><a name="page-1133636">CB01_0147</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95421' title='Forest Hills Cemetery, Jamaica Plain'>Forrest Hill</a></p>
<p><date when='1864-05-10'>May 10 [186]4</date></p>
<p>To the City Clerk of <a href='/pages/subjects/54347' title='Roxbury, MA'>Roxbury</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you be so kind<span class='line-break'> </span>as to write to the address of <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Chas. G. Nazro</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>Esq. of our Board of Trustees at <ins>18 Kilby<span class='line-break'> </span>St</ins>., informing him what your Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>under the regulation of the City of R. is,<span class='line-break'> </span>at present, paying for the services of Super<span class='line-break'></span>intendent, and whether any and what<span class='line-break'> </span>increase of his salary has been made<span class='line-break'> </span>on account of the inflated prices of living,<span class='line-break'> </span>and oblige</p>
<p>Yours very resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>I shall be absent for some time, and<span class='line-break'> </span>hence request you to reply to Mr. N. as<span class='line-break'> </span>above designated. --</p>
<p><date when='1864-05-10'>May 10. [186]4</date></p>
<p>To the Secretary or Treas<sup>r</sup> of the<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65978' title='Spring Grove Cemetery, Cincinnati'>Spring Grove Cem.y</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65979' title='Cincinnati, OH'>Cincinnati</a> O.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you be so kind<span class='line-break'> </span>as to address <a href='/pages/subjects/54820' title='Nazro, Charles G.'>Cha<sup>s</sup> G. Nazro</a>, Esq<sup>r</sup> of<span class='line-break'> </span>our Board of Trustees, informing him<span class='line-break'> </span>what your Corporation is paying, at<span class='line-break'> </span>present, for the services of Superin<span class='line-break'></span>tendent, and whether any and what<span class='line-break'> </span>increase of his salary has been<span class='line-break'> </span>made on account of the inflated prices<span class='line-break'> </span>of living, and oblige</p>
<p>Yours very resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>I shall be absent for some time is my<span class='line-break'> </span>reason for asking you to address Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>N. at no 18 Kilby St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>.</p>
<p>147</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133637">
<h3><a name="page-1133637">CB01_0148</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-05-10'>May 10 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have made up a<span class='line-break'> </span>package, if you will let boy call in for it, as<span class='line-break'> </span>I leave in the morning.</p>
<p>It contains notices to undertakers ^<sup>ie</sup> of change<span class='line-break'> </span>of prices of int<sup>s</sup> -- I have sent to most in<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Bost.</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/53203' title='Cambridge, MA'>Camb.</a> &amp; some few others -- &amp; think<span class='line-break'> </span>you had better let your folks hand them to<span class='line-break'> </span>other undertakers as they come to <a href='/pages/subjects/57664' title='Entrance Gateway'>the Gate.</a></p>
<p>I also send you deed of <a href='/pages/subjects/65985' title='Pelham, Capt.'>Capt. Pelham's</a> <span class='line-break'> </span>lot, which <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a> requested me to have<span class='line-break'> </span>sold for the Capt. As I cannot attend to it I<span class='line-break'> </span>hand the job over to you. Anything over what he<span class='line-break'> </span>gave or has left, I believe will be satisfactory.</p>
<p>I also enclose some blanks &amp; as re<span class='line-break'></span>quested by <a href='/pages/subjects/52579' title='Safford, Truman H.'>Mr Safford</a> this P.M.</p>
<p>Truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>Mr Richardson will do as well, as he can [?] in my abcen.</p>
<p><date when='1864-05-17'>May 17, [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57826' title='Shedd &amp; Edson'>Messrs Shedd &amp; Edson</a>,</p>
<p>Gentlemen,</p>
<p>We have quite a number<span class='line-break'> </span>of lots sold &amp; laid out since your <span class='line-break'> </span>last survey. It would somewhat<span class='line-break'> </span>expedite the business of the Cemetery, as<span class='line-break'> </span>well as secure greater care, if you<span class='line-break'> </span>will survey and enter on the plan<span class='line-break'> </span>all the lots now ready.--</p>
<p>Yours very truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>148</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133638">
<h3><a name="page-1133638">CB01_0149</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-05-19'>May 19 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/56312' title='Norcross, Otis'>Otis Norcross</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you please<span class='line-break'> </span>take the enclosed report of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup> respecting the lot of est. of <a href='/pages/subjects/65987' title='Spring, Sarah'>Sarah<span class='line-break'> </span>Spring</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/65988' title='Lot 3324'>(3324)</a> with you and con--<span class='line-break'> </span>fer with <a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Mr Austin</a> 28 State St.<span class='line-break'> </span>(as <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>Mr Curtis</a> has enclosed his<span class='line-break'> </span>resignation) as to the amount deemed<span class='line-break'> </span>needful to secure the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>repair. -- I send to you as you<span class='line-break'> </span>can probably find Mr A. more<span class='line-break'> </span>easily than he can you. He is gen<span class='line-break'></span>erally at his office, I think, until<span class='line-break'> </span>past 12.</p>
<p>The Executor desires as early a<span class='line-break'> </span>reply as convenient. I told him<span class='line-break'> </span>probably within a day or two.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1864-05-21'>May 21, 4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65940' title='Osgood, Samuel S.'>S.S. Osgood</a> Esq.<span class='line-break'> </span>328 Bleeker St. <a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York</a></p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>I return the contract <span class='line-break'> </span>for repair of your lot in the Cemetery,<span class='line-break'> </span>which has been duly recorded. You retain<span class='line-break'> </span>the original as the evidence of such con--<span class='line-break'> </span>tract on your part, although it will <span class='line-break'> </span>not be likely to be lost sight of by the Corpor--<span class='line-break'> </span>ation.</p>
<p>I have sent to the Sup<sup>t</sup> a memorand.<span class='line-break'> </span>of what you requested done this<span class='line-break'> </span>year upon the lot, which will no doubt<span class='line-break'> </span>be attended to.</p>
<p>It will be hardly necessary for me to<span class='line-break'> </span>say that the $2 was received.</p>
<p>Very truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>149</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133639">
<h3><a name="page-1133639">CB01_0150</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-05-24'>May 24 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your explanations for<span class='line-break'> </span>my inquiries about certain lots were rec<sup>d</sup>.<span class='line-break'> </span>I fear there is still some error -- for if you<span class='line-break'> </span>give <a href='/pages/subjects/65991' title='Lot 3423'>3423</a> to <a href='/pages/subjects/65992' title='Phelps, Agnes R.'>Agnes R. Phelps</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/57829' title='Snowdrop Path'>Snowdrop Path</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>it leaves only four consecutive numbers for<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54770' title='Read, James'>Mr Read's</a> ^<sup>five</sup> lots, viz. <a href='/pages/subjects/65993' title='Lot 3419'>3419</a><a href='/pages/subjects/65994' title='Lot 3420'>-<!--34-->20</a><a href='/pages/subjects/65995' title='Lot 3421'>-<!--34-->21</a><a href='/pages/subjects/65996' title='Lot 3422'>-<!--34-->22</a>.</p>
<p>As there is always great liability to<span class='line-break'> </span>troublesome errors in reporting and making<span class='line-break'> </span>changed, and as several have occurred much <span class='line-break'> </span>to the disfigurement of the record, I beg<span class='line-break'> </span>leave to say that I prefer, if you have<span class='line-break'> </span>no objection, to seek explanation of difficult<span class='line-break'> </span>matters in your department, directly of you,<span class='line-break'> </span>instead of "asking <a href='/pages/subjects/79942' title='Safford, Frederick Marcy'>Fred</a>", as mature heads<span class='line-break'> </span>are required to bear the responsibility.</p>
<p>Please observe the accompanying order<span class='line-break'> </span>for <a href='/pages/subjects/65997' title='Marsh, Mr.'>Mr Marsh</a>.</p>
<p>Very truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1864-05-26'>May 26 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65998' title='Lears, William C.'>W<sup>m</sup> C. Lears</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have just rec<sup>d</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>the reply of the Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>in answer to the inquiry for what<span class='line-break'> </span>sum the Corporation will assume<span class='line-break'> </span>the Perpetual Care of <a href='/pages/subjects/65988' title='Lot 3324'>Lot no. 3324</a>.</p>
<p>The amount they name is<span class='line-break'> </span>six hundred and fifty dollars ($650) --<span class='line-break'> </span>which is less than I expected.</p>
<p>If you will call in the <ins>after<span class='line-break'></span>noon</ins> of almost any day, it will<span class='line-break'> </span>be a little better time for you, as<span class='line-break'> </span>we shall be less likely to be inter<span class='line-break'></span>rupted by calls. --</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p>150</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133640">
<h3><a name="page-1133640">CB01_0151</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-05-27'>May 27, .64</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclose the order <span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/57834' title='O&apos;Brien, Thomas'>Thomas O'Brien</a> dated May 10/64<span class='line-break'> </span>and handed to me last evening,<span class='line-break'> </span>in favor of <a href='/pages/subjects/57835' title='Black, James'>James Black</a>, making<span class='line-break'> </span>his wages now due from our Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation and all which may become<span class='line-break'> </span>due to the amount of $75 payable<span class='line-break'> </span>to said <a href='/pages/subjects/57835' title='Black, James'>Black.</a>—</p>
<p>Your acceptance of the same<span class='line-break'> </span>will enable you to pay to reserve<span class='line-break'> </span>for <a href='/pages/subjects/57835' title='Black, James'>Black</a>, without danger from trus<span class='line-break'></span>tee process.</p>
<p>Truly yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec<sup>y</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo. W<sup>m</sup> Bond</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1864-05-27'>May 27 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57836' title='Moulton, Newell'>Newell Moulton Esq</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/57837' title='Lynn, MA'>Lynn</a> Mass.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Please sign and<span class='line-break'> </span>return to me <ins>at this office</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>the accompanying order which<span class='line-break'> </span>should have been left at<span class='line-break'> </span>the <a href='/pages/subjects/57664' title='Entrance Gateway'><!--entrance-->Gate</a> at the time of<span class='line-break'> </span>removal.—</p>
<p>Yours respy.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.<sup>y</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57838' title='Moulton, Charles Henry'>Chas. Henry Moulton</a> removed from<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>Rec. Tomb</a> Apr. 4. 1864 to <a href='/pages/subjects/57840' title='Lot 2439'>lot no<span class='line-break'> </span>2439</a>.—</p>
<p>151</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133641">
<h3><a name="page-1133641">CB01_0152</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-05-27'>May 27 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53184' title='Goddard, Lucy'>Mrs Lucy Goddard</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54347' title='Roxbury, MA'>Roxbury</a>, Mass.</p>
<p>Dear Madam, A memorandum<span class='line-break'> </span>on a small slip of paper of the removal<span class='line-break'> </span>^<sup> on the 26<sup>th</sup>ultimo</sup> of the remains of <a href='/pages/subjects/57842' title='West, Martha'>Martha West</a> which were<span class='line-break'> </span>interred in <a href='/pages/subjects/57843' title='Lot 85'>No 85</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/61319' title='Public Lot'>St. James Lot</a>, <date when='1848-07-11'>July 11,1848</date>, <del>lot</del><span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/57844' title='Lot 3251'>lot No 3251</a>, which is represented by you,<span class='line-break'> </span>has been sent me for entry on the Register of<span class='line-break'> </span>Interments, be a regular order from the prop<sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>or representative of a lot should appear on our<span class='line-break'> </span>files, and to test the correctness of the record.<span class='line-break'> </span>I send the accompanying blank for your<span class='line-break'> </span>signature. Please return the same<span class='line-break'> </span>to me by mail, signed by you if all<span class='line-break'> </span>right.</p>
<p>Very respy yours<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p><date when='1864-05-31'>May 31. [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Edward Austin</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclose the<span class='line-break'> </span>report of the Superintendant upon<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/57845' title='Sturtevant, John D.'>John D. Sturtevant</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/57846' title='Lot 3367'>No 3367</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/57847' title='Fountain Path'>Fountain Avenue</a> (next<span class='line-break'> </span>lot to <a href='/pages/subjects/57848' title='Merriam, Charles'>Cha<sup>s</sup> Merriam's</a>) for the pur--<span class='line-break'> </span>pose of ascertaining for what sum<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation will assume the<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual care of the same.</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>152</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133642">
<h3><a name="page-1133642">CB01_0153</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-06-02'>June 2,  4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D. L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/66000' title='Howard, Henry O.'>Mr Henry O. How- <span class='line-break'> </span>ard</a>, one of the heirs of the lot of<span class='line-break'> </span>late <a href='/pages/subjects/58394' title='Howard, Abraham'>Abraham Howard</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/66001' title='Lot 331'>331.</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/61108' title='Alder Path'>Alder Path</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>wishes to purchase the land in the rear<span class='line-break'> </span>of both lots <a href='/pages/subjects/66001' title='Lot 331'>- 331</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/25004308' title='Lot 332'>332 -</a> as an addition to<span class='line-break'> </span>said lots, if he can arrange with the other heirs,<span class='line-break'> </span>which he will know in a few days.  In<span class='line-break'> </span>the meantime, please not sell it, if you<span class='line-break'> </span>have a call for it, without letting me<span class='line-break'> </span>know.</p>
<p>Please attend to the enclosed note<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/66003' title='Matchatt, William F.'>W<sup>m</sup> F. Matchatt</a>.</p>
<p>P. S. Also report on <a href='/pages/subjects/66001' title='Lot 331'>lots 331</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/25004308' title='Lot 332'>&amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>332</a> in reference to guaranty for<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual repairs.--</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1864-06-02'>June 2, 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A Special Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Trustees of this Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>who are charged with a final<span class='line-break'> </span>disposition of the matter pending<span class='line-break'> </span>between the <a href='/pages/subjects/66004' title='Granite Railway Company'>Granite Railway Company</a><span class='line-break'> </span>and this Corporation, on account of<span class='line-break'> </span>the facade for <a href='/pages/subjects/66005' title='Catacomb Tombs'>Catacomb Tombs</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>will hold a meeting on Saturday<span class='line-break'> </span>Morning, <date when='1864-06-4T09:00:00'><ins>4th next, at 9 o'clock</ins></date> at<span class='line-break'> </span>this office; and desire that you<span class='line-break'> </span>will be present with any papers<span class='line-break'> </span>that you may have relating to <span class='line-break'> </span>the contract.</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57479' title='Bryant, Gridley J. F.'>G. J. F. Bryant</a> Esq</p>
<p>153     <span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133643">
<h3><a name="page-1133643">CB01_0154</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-06-02'>June 2<sup>d</sup> 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57845' title='Sturtevant, John D.'>John D. Sturtevant</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Our Sup<sup>t</sup>, <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt.<span class='line-break'> </span>Winsor</a>, has, at your request I presume<span class='line-break'> </span>reported upon the condition of your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>for perpetual care: and the Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>upon lots have considered the applica--<span class='line-break'> </span>tion, and instructed me to inform<span class='line-break'> </span>you that the Corporation will<span class='line-break'> </span>assume the perpetual care of <a href='/pages/subjects/57846' title='Lot 3367'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>No. 3367</a>, for five hundred and<span class='line-break'> </span>fifty dollars.— ($550.)</p>
<p>Very Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1864-06-08'>June 8 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D.L. Winsor</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sup<sup>t</sup> Mt. Auburn</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>At the meeting <span class='line-break'> </span>of the Trustees of Mount Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>held on <date when='1864-06-06'>Monday the 6<sup>th</sup></date> [inst?], the<span class='line-break'> </span>following vote was adopted:—</p>
<p>"That, until otherwise ordered,<span class='line-break'> </span>no upland between <a href='/pages/subjects/58084' title='Yew Avenue'>Yew<!--Ave--></a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/58791' title='Central Avenue'>Central<span class='line-break'> </span>Avenues</a> be sold for less than two<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars per square foot, and no<span class='line-break'> </span>upland in other parts of the old<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery be sold for less than one dollar<span class='line-break'> </span>per square foot, except by approval of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee on Lots."</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>154</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133644">
<h3><a name="page-1133644">CB01_0155</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-06-16'>June 16 4 [1864?]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D. L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Mr Austin</a> states<span class='line-break'> </span>that "you have not been notified<span class='line-break'> </span>that lots <ins><a href='/pages/subjects/66008' title='Lot 1676'>1676</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/65941' title='Lot 2151'>2151,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/65988' title='Lot 3324'>3324,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/64083' title='Lot 126'><!--Lot-->126</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/62117' title='Lot 417'><!--Lot-->417</a>, <span class='line-break'> </span>+ <a href='/pages/subjects/65202' title='Lot 801'><!--Lot-->801</a></ins>, are to be taken care of by the <span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation", and requests me to<span class='line-break'> </span>so inform the Treas<sup>r</sup>-; but as the Treas<span class='line-break'> </span>is in <a href='/pages/subjects/54469' title='Washington, DC'>Washington,</a> I think it easier &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>safer to acquaint you directly. Lots<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/66008' title='Lot 1676'>1676</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/65988' title='Lot 3324'>3324,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/64083' title='Lot 126'><!--Lot-->126</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/65202' title='Lot 801'><!--Lot-->801</a> have the guaranty of<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>perpetual</ins> repair; <a href='/pages/subjects/65941' title='Lot 2151'><!--Lot-->2151</a> + <a href='/pages/subjects/57820' title='Lot 497'><!--Lot-->497</a> have not.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Mr. Austin</a> further wishes me to<span class='line-break'> </span>"obtain from the Superintendent, a list<span class='line-break'> </span>of <ins>all</ins> lots that are in bad order,<span class='line-break'> </span>that the proprietors may be notified."</p>
<p>If you had any conversation with him<span class='line-break'> </span>about this, I presume you know<span class='line-break'> </span>whether he refers to all lots in the<span class='line-break'> </span>cemetery coming under [identical?] [?],<span class='line-break'> </span>or only those cared for by the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation, &amp; subject to the inspection of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Committee on Lots. I don't know which<span class='line-break'> </span>he wishes, as I have not seen him. His<span class='line-break'> </span>request is in writing.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/66009' title='Churchill, Marion S. L.'>Mrs. Marion S. L. Churchill</a> has just<span class='line-break'> </span>deposited with the Corporation $300 to be added<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Repair Fund, for the perpetual care<span class='line-break'> </span>of her lot <ins><a href='/pages/subjects/66010' title='Lot 243'>no. 243</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/61302' title='Woodbine Path'>Woodbine Path</a></ins>, the<span class='line-break'> </span>northwesterly side of <a href='/pages/subjects/66011' title='Appleton Hill'>Appleton Hill</a>. Neither<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/66009' title='Churchill, Marion S. L.'>Mrs. C.</a> nor I could tell what amount would<span class='line-break'> </span>be sufficient - but I think this will do what<span class='line-break'></span>she wishes. She has for years been accumu--<span class='line-break'> </span>lating this sum and now puts it into the<span class='line-break'> </span>hands of the Corporation as a safe place of <span class='line-break'> </span>deposit &amp; accumulation, if more should be nec<span class='line-break'></span>essary. I will give you her idea, and<span class='line-break'> </span>you will please report about her lot.<span class='line-break'> </span>She has never had anything done to the lot - <span class='line-break'> </span>and wishes but little done - likes the pines<span class='line-break'> </span>there, but wishes a stump dug out - a</p>
<p>155</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133645">
<h3><a name="page-1133645">CB01_0156</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>"lily of the valley" planted - which she<span class='line-break'> </span>thinks will grow, as the sun falls there morn-<span class='line-break'></span>ings, but does not expect to have the<span class='line-break'> </span>grass kept green - perhaps would like<span class='line-break'> </span>a border. There are not more than four<span class='line-break'> </span>persons to be buried there - does not wish<span class='line-break'> </span>any fence or monument other than such<span class='line-break'> </span>headstones as may be needed for those who<span class='line-break'> </span>may be interred: wishes to reconvey the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot to the Corporation. With what she proposes,<span class='line-break'> </span>it cannot possibly cost the Corporation $5 per<span class='line-break'> </span>annum. The only question is, if we take<span class='line-break'> </span>it in the state in which it now is, what<span class='line-break'> </span>can be done to it annually. Will you sug-<span class='line-break'></span>gest the probable <ins>first outlay</ins> for what she<span class='line-break'> </span>wishes - viz. digging stump out, making border<span class='line-break'> </span>on path, and planting the lily of the valley.</p>
<p>If the $300 will be insufficient, she will<span class='line-break'> </span>probably let it remain accumulating until<span class='line-break'> </span>it amounts to enough, unless she should<span class='line-break'> </span>be able to add more to it. I told her<span class='line-break'> </span>that the trees would some time perhaps<span class='line-break'> </span>be taken down - then the lot ought to<span class='line-break'> </span>be put as a condition for green grass there - <span class='line-break'> </span>She prefers the trees there - selected the lot<span class='line-break'> </span>on account of them; but feels annoyed at<span class='line-break'> </span>its present forsaken appearance, and was led<span class='line-break'> </span>just now to giving the $300 partly because<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot looks so, and partly because the<span class='line-break'> </span>next lot <a href='/pages/subjects/66015' title='Fairchild, Mary Joy'>Mrs. Fairchild's</a> is left so neglected.</p>
<p>Please report on this Saturday if con-<span class='line-break'></span>venient.</p>
<p>And now descending the hill, view another<span class='line-break'> </span>which has been inquired about since<span class='line-break'> </span>I began to ask you to look at Mrs. Church<span class='line-break'></span>ill's -- the</p>
<p><ins><a href='/pages/subjects/66016' title='Murray, John'>Murray</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/66017' title='Lot 587'>lot no. 587</a>.</ins> belong-<span class='line-break'></span>ing to the <a href='/pages/subjects/66018' title='First Universalist Society'>1<sup>st</sup> Universalist Soc.y</a> - situ-<span class='line-break'></span>ated on <a href='/pages/subjects/61234' title='Moss Path'>Moss Path</a>. But little has <span class='line-break'> </span>been done to it for some years, &amp; if I <span class='line-break'> </span>remember, but little can be done to it.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/66018' title='First Universalist Society'>The<!--First Universalist Society--> Society</a> is about dissolving and wishes<span class='line-break'> </span>to convey this lot to the Corp<sup>n</sup> with a<span class='line-break'> </span>fund of about say $160 ($159 in March last)<span class='line-break'> </span>which has been accumulating for some time.<span class='line-break'> </span>It contains 136 square feet. This is somewhat<span class='line-break'> </span>different from a private lot. I suppose there<span class='line-break'> </span>may be nobody that feels enough interest to<span class='line-break'> </span>add to the fund if insufficient, but perhaps<span class='line-break'> </span>it is enough to put &amp; keep it in repair.</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>156</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133646">
<h3><a name="page-1133646">CB01_0157</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-06-16'>June 16, 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60695' title='Brigham, William'>W<sup>m</sup> Brigham</a> Esq<sup>r</sup> Ex<sup>or</sup> <a href='/pages/subjects/60696' title='Fuller, Abraham W.'>A.W. Fuller</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you as Ex<sup>or</sup> please<span class='line-break'> </span>take notice that lots nos. 1 + 1556 (H.H.<span class='line-break'> </span>+ <a href='/pages/subjects/60696' title='Fuller, Abraham W.'>A.W. Fuller</a>) in the Cemetery require atten--<span class='line-break'> </span>tion which the funds at the disposal of this<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation will not allow. There are but $200<span class='line-break'> </span>in each case and no <ins>guaranty</ins> was given<span class='line-break'> </span>for complete and perpetual repair. The<span class='line-break'> </span>Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots have directed me to<span class='line-break'> </span>say that the Corporation have kept<span class='line-break'> </span>the lots in order to the extent of the<span class='line-break'> </span>income, but there are certain defects in<span class='line-break'> </span>the curbing or fence &amp; which ought to<span class='line-break'> </span>be remedied before further more exten--<span class='line-break'> </span>sive repairs are made. <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Win--<span class='line-break'> </span>sor</a>, our Sup<sup>t</sup> can acquaint you with<span class='line-break'> </span>the nature of them. I have also written <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/66025' title='Howe, Jonathan'>Mr. Jona. Howe</a>, as am of the Ex<sup>or</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/53606' title='Fuller, Henry H.'>H. H. F.<!--Fuller--></a></p>
<p>Yours very respy.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1864-06-16'>June 16, 4 [1864]</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/66025' title='Howe, Jonathan'>Jon<sup>a</sup>. Howe</a> Esq<sup>r</sup> Ex<sup>or</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you, as Ex<sup>or</sup>, please<span class='line-break'> </span>take notice, or notify <a href='/pages/subjects/64859' title='Fuller, Mary B. S.'>Miss. Mary B. S. Fuller</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>if she is the proper person, that the Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots have for two successive years reported<span class='line-break'> </span>that Lot 1|lots nos. 1 ]]&amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/60755' title='Lot 1556'>1556</a> (<a href='/pages/subjects/53606' title='Fuller, Henry H.'>H. H.<!--Fuller--></a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/60696' title='Fuller, Abraham W.'>A. W. Fuller</a>),<span class='line-break'> </span>in the Cemetery require attention which this<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation is unable to meet from the funds<span class='line-break'> </span>in their hands --being but 200 on each lot.<span class='line-break'> </span>You know that the Corporation is not<span class='line-break'> </span>liable for <ins>perpetual</ins> care - nor present<span class='line-break'> </span>care beyond the income of the funds these<span class='line-break'> </span>not being among the <ins>guaranteed</ins> lots.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a>, Sup<sup>t</sup> can inform<span class='line-break'> </span>you what is needed. --</p>
<p>I have notified <a href='/pages/subjects/60695' title='Brigham, William'>Mr W<sup>m</sup> Brigham</a><span class='line-break'> </span>also. --</p>
<p>Very Respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>157<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133647">
<h3><a name="page-1133647">CB01_0158</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1864-06-16'>June 16 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/71976' title='Bacon, Joseph N.'>Jos. N. Bacon</a> Esq, Ex<sup>or</sup> --</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I am directed<span class='line-break'> </span>by the Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots in this Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>to say to you "that the two trees<span class='line-break'> </span>in front of <a href='/pages/subjects/67836' title='Lot 994'>lot 994</a> prevent the<span class='line-break'> </span>grass from growing. The lot could<span class='line-break'> </span>be always kept in order if they <span class='line-break'> </span>were taken away.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1864-06-06'>July 6<sup>th</sup> 4 [1864]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57824' title='Wolcott, J. Huntington'>J. Huntington Wolcott</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I send you the<span class='line-break'> </span>bill of <a href='/pages/subjects/57826' title='Shedd &amp; Edson'>Shedd &amp; Edson</a> for survey &amp; plans.<span class='line-break'> </span>The first charge was for survey &amp; plan to<span class='line-break'> </span>enable you to determine whether and<span class='line-break'> </span>how you would make the purchase:<span class='line-break'> </span>The last to make a fair and perma<span class='line-break'></span>nent delineation of your grounds as they<span class='line-break'> </span>will stand with the purchase. --</p>
<p>If you wish to have entirely new<span class='line-break'> </span>deeds of your lot and <a href='/pages/subjects/57825' title='Frothingham, Theodore'>Mr Frothingham's</a><span class='line-break'> </span>containing description in conformity with the<span class='line-break'> </span>plan, send in your old deeds, with<span class='line-break'> </span>transfer. You will see a blank on 3<sup>rd</sup> page. <a href='/pages/subjects/57825' title='Frothingham, Theodore'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>F.<!--Frothingham--></a> can transfer his in <a href='/pages/subjects/64806' title='Philadelphia, PA'>Phil<sup>a</sup></a> before a<span class='line-break'> </span>Justice of the Peace.</p>
<p>I send the first sketch made of the lots.<span class='line-break'> </span>If that is sufficient for your purpose</p>
<p>158</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133648">
<h3><a name="page-1133648">CB01_0159</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>it will cost you nothing for ^<sup>an</sup> additional<span class='line-break'> </span>plan. If you prefer a duplicate<span class='line-break'> </span>of the finished plan shown you last<span class='line-break'> </span>week, <a href='/pages/subjects/81482' title='Shedd, J. H., Mr.'>Mr Shedd</a> informs me that<span class='line-break'> </span>the cost will not <ins>exceed</ins> $6. They<span class='line-break'> </span>will furnish you a tracing on <span class='line-break'> </span>prepared cloth not to exceed $3. --</p>
<p>I presume he could furnish you<span class='line-break'> </span>a copy for each of the lot owners<span class='line-break'> </span>at $2.50 each.</p>
<p>I am very respy<span class='line-break'> </span>Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Ser<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>P.S. I think it may be well to <span class='line-break'> </span>put the figures representing size of the<span class='line-break'> </span>monuments and their distances from<span class='line-break'> </span>side lines of the lots, which you notice<span class='line-break'> </span>on the sketch, on to the plan to<span class='line-break'> </span>be filed. --</p>
<p><date when='1864-07-07'>July 7 [186]4</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Edward Austin</a><span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/56312' title='Norcross, Otis'>Otis Norcross</a> Esq<sup>s</sup> Com. on Lots</p>
<p>Gentlemen,</p>
<p>Article 13 of the By-laws<span class='line-break'> </span>of this Corporation invests the Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots, among other duties, with<span class='line-break'> </span>"the general supervision" x x "of all questions<span class='line-break'> </span>of right -- between individual proprietors, or<span class='line-break'> </span>between proprietors and the Corporation." --</p>
<p>Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/66033' title='Stickney, Rufus B.'>Stickney</a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/66034' title='Poor, John R.'>Poor,</a> who<span class='line-break'> </span>are the proprietors of <a href='/pages/subjects/66035' title='Lot 3118'>lots 3118</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/66036' title='Lot 3119'>&amp; 3119</a><span class='line-break'> </span>situated upon <a href='/pages/subjects/59984' title='Rosebay Avenue'>Rosebay Avenue</a>, con--<span class='line-break'> </span>taining 2000 square feet, a year or two<span class='line-break'> </span>since contracted with a granite man for<span class='line-break'> </span>a curb around their lots and last<span class='line-break'> </span>year employed the Superintendent to set<span class='line-break'> </span>the work up. -- After the work had<span class='line-break'> </span>been commenced, a difference of opinion<span class='line-break'> </span>arose between the Superintendent and</p>
<p>159</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133649">
<h3><a name="page-1133649">CB01_0160</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>these proprietors as to the manner of <span class='line-break'> </span>setting the curb, or the position of the lot,<span class='line-break'> </span>in consequence of which the work<span class='line-break'> </span>was stopped, and still stands un--<span class='line-break'> </span>finished. The proprietors state<span class='line-break'> </span>that they have been unable to<span class='line-break'> </span>come to any terms with the<span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent, and wish now<span class='line-break'> </span>to take their appeal to the Trus--<span class='line-break'> </span>tees. I have instructed them<span class='line-break'> </span>that your Committee, by the By laws,<span class='line-break'> </span>have jurisdiction in the matter,<span class='line-break'> </span>if they see fit to apply to you.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/66033' title='Stickney, Rufus B.'>Mr Stickney</a> will state the<span class='line-break'> </span>facts for the proprietors in such<span class='line-break'> </span>manner as you desire. Of course<span class='line-break'> </span>the Sup<sup>t</sup> will desire to be heard.</p>
<p>Accompanying this is a tracing from our<span class='line-break'> </span>plan of the position of the lots with respect<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Avenue, which I will say was fixed<span class='line-break'> </span>some time after purchase, upon the new survey,<span class='line-break'> </span>by finding these lots without bounds, and may therefore<span class='line-break'> </span>deviate from the original position. --</p>
<p>Very resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1864-07-13'>July 13, [186]4</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your application to<span class='line-break'> </span>know for what sum this Corpor--<span class='line-break'> </span>ation would contract to keep<span class='line-break'> </span>in perpetual repair your lot, <a href='/pages/subjects/66037' title='Lot 580'>num<span class='line-break'></span>bered 580</a> in the Cemetery, situ<span class='line-break'></span>ated upon the avenue or way<span class='line-break'> </span>called <a href='/pages/subjects/54338' title='Indian Ridge Path'>Indian Ridge Path</a>, has<span class='line-break'> </span>been reported to the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots and duly considered by them,<span class='line-break'> </span>and they have directed me to<span class='line-break'> </span>notify you that they will recom--<span class='line-break'> </span>mend the Corporation to assume <span class='line-break'> </span>said obligation for the sum of<span class='line-break'> </span>four hundred and fifty dollars.</p>
<p>When ready to pay over the funds,<span class='line-break'> </span>please notify me and I will prepare<span class='line-break'> </span>the necessary papers.</p>
<p>Yours very Respy.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/66038' title='Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth'>H.W. Longfellow</a> Esq</p>
<p>160</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133650">
<h3><a name="page-1133650">CB01_0161</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>161</p>
<p>33 School St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1864-08-08'>Aug. [8?] 1864.</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/66039' title='Green, Elizabeth T.'>Mrs Elizabeth T. Green</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/66040' title='Worcester, MA'>Worcester Mass.</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>The <a href='/pages/subjects/66046' title='Hallet, Esther'>widow<!--Esther Hallet--></a> of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/66041' title='Hallet, Ezekiel, Jr.'>Ezekiel<span class='line-break'> </span>Hallet Jr</a>, husband of your daughter the ^<sup>late</sup> proprietor of <a href='/pages/subjects/66042' title='Lot 2603'>lot 2603</a> in<span class='line-break'> </span>Mount Auburn, has just called at my office, supposing that<span class='line-break'> </span>she had an interest in said lot by reason of her husband and<span class='line-break'> </span>child's decease, and wished to make her interest appear by deed. I<span class='line-break'> </span>at once remembered the transfer to you, and went to my record,<span class='line-break'> </span>and showed her the evidence of the transfer to you. She was greatly<span class='line-break'> </span>surprised -- had never heard anything about the transfer --<span class='line-break'> </span>supposed that the lot, upon the decease of <a href='/pages/subjects/66043' title='Hallet, Elizabeth D.'>Mrs Elizabeth D. Hallet</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>went to her husband, and she is therefore apparently in some<span class='line-break'> </span>trouble of mind for what has occurred, which adds to her<span class='line-break'> </span>affliction. She recently came from her father's in Vermont, with<span class='line-break'> </span>her child and went to the Cape to visit your and his relations.<span class='line-break'> </span>While there her child died. As she was confined just before<span class='line-break'> </span>Mr Hallet's death, he asked her, in case the child should<span class='line-break'> </span>not live, that it might be laid in the same grave with<span class='line-break'> </span>himself. She therefore went to Mt Auburn last Saturday,<span class='line-break'> </span>with the body of the child. She says she knew nothing of the<span class='line-break'> </span>transfer to you, and asked to have the grave opened. Our<span class='line-break'> </span>employees at the gate knew nothing of the transfer to you,<span class='line-break'> </span>as we have not published a new catalogue for four<span class='line-break'> </span>years, and naturally presuming from the facts stated to<span class='line-break'> </span>them, of the burial of her husband in the lot, they obeyed<span class='line-break'> </span>her order to open a grave -- and by her wish in the</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133651">
<h3><a name="page-1133651">CB01_0162</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>162</p>
<p>matter was accomplished, her child was buried with<span class='line-break'> </span>the father. Today, in the same ignorance of facts, she<span class='line-break'> </span>went to a marble worker and engaged a ^<sup>marble</sup> tablet to<span class='line-break'> </span>erect over the grave, to the memory of the father and<span class='line-break'> </span>child, but had not given him the inscription, and was <span class='line-break'> </span>to go again to him. Meanwhile she called upon me, and<span class='line-break'> </span>learned, to her surprize, of the transfer to you, and stated<span class='line-break'> </span>all the circumstances. She has, innocently and ignorant<span class='line-break'> </span>of the <ins>legal</ins> facts, buried her child without your order.<span class='line-break'> </span>I told her it would be best to acquaint you with the<span class='line-break'> </span>facts and circumstances and obtain your consent, and<span class='line-break'> </span>she [then?], desired me to write you.</p>
<p>She expects to leave for Vermont <ins>next Tuesday noon</ins>:<span class='line-break'> </span>and I shall, therefore, feel obliged if you will reply at<span class='line-break'> </span>once, and state what you are willing should be done,<span class='line-break'> </span>so that I can receive your letter as early as Monday morning.</p>
<p>As I understand the matter -- there are now three graves<span class='line-break'> </span>in the lot -- one occupied by <a href='/pages/subjects/66045' title='Green, William E.'>your late husband<!--Green--></a>, Mr Collins,<span class='line-break'> </span>one by <a href='/pages/subjects/66043' title='Hallet, Elizabeth D.'>Mrs <!--Elizabeth D.-->Hallet</a> -- one by <a href='/pages/subjects/66041' title='Hallet, Ezekiel, Jr.'>Mr Hallet</a> and this child. There<span class='line-break'> </span>are also, I learn, some bones or remains <del>[few?]</del> of a brother<span class='line-break'> </span>of Mr Collins, <a href='/pages/subjects/66046' title='Hallet, Esther'>Mrs<!--Hallet--></a>, or Mr Hallet, (I did not notice which,)<span class='line-break'> </span>in one of the graves. This leaves space for two<span class='line-break'> </span>graves, and, I am told, if the interments had<span class='line-break'> </span>been properly made, there would be three graves.</p>
<p>I do not remember what ^<sup>spaces</sup> you wished to be reserved<span class='line-break'> </span>for grave or graves: but remember that you said your <span class='line-break'> </span>sons would never desire any resting place there.<span class='line-break'> </span>I don't remember whether you wished to reserve<span class='line-break'> </span>a place for yourself or anyone else, but have the im-</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133652">
<h3><a name="page-1133652">CB01_0163</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>163</p>
<p>pression you wished only one grave. --</p>
<p>My view of the matter is this. The <ins>legal</ins> title is in you,<span class='line-break'> </span>and the legal right to say who <del>shall</del> ^<sup>may</sup> be interred there -<span class='line-break'></span>but I think there was an <ins>equitable</ins> right to place<span class='line-break'> </span>the child with the father -- especially if he requested it.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/66046' title='Hallet, Esther'>Mrs H.<!--Hallet--></a> says that <a href='/pages/subjects/66041' title='Hallet, Ezekiel, Jr.'>Mr Hallet</a> told her that the lot was<span class='line-break'> </span>taken in his wife's name, but that he actually<span class='line-break'> </span>paid for it. I do not find that any right has been<span class='line-break'> </span>taken from you, as the child was placed in the same grave<span class='line-break'> </span>with the father. We should, however, have preferred to do<span class='line-break'> </span>this on your order: and our agents at the Cemetery would<span class='line-break'> </span>have so required, if they had promised the means of<span class='line-break'> </span>knowing the lot to be yours. It still stood, with them, in <a href='/pages/subjects/66041' title='Hallet, Ezekiel, Jr.'>Mr Hallet</a>'s<span class='line-break'> </span>name, and this lady told them ^<sup>that</sup> Mrs &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/66041' title='Hallet, Ezekiel, Jr.'>Mr Hallet</a> were both<span class='line-break'> </span>dead, and she supposed she had the right to order the inter<span class='line-break'></span>ment.</p>
<p>I have taken so much pains to give you the facts that you<span class='line-break'> </span>may see that blame appears to attach to no one.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/66046' title='Hallet, Esther'>Mrs Hallet</a> says she does not wish to wrong you or anyone<span class='line-break'> </span>else in the matter. She loved dearly this little child of 20 months,<span class='line-break'> </span>and would like the privilege of being laid beside it and her hus<span class='line-break'></span>band: but if you do not feel perfectly free to accord that<span class='line-break'> </span>to her, she should prefer to remove them both from the lot. -<span class='line-break'></span>She will stop the work on the marble tablet and pedestal until<span class='line-break'> </span>she hears from you. If you have no particular use for<span class='line-break'> </span>more than one grave, I should think it would be well to grant<span class='line-break'> </span>her this privilege, if <ins>she dies the widow of <a href='/pages/subjects/66041' title='Hallet, Ezekiel, Jr.'>Mr Hallet</a></ins>. Indeed, if he paid<span class='line-break'> </span>for the lot, I think it would be her <ins>moral</ins> right. But, as you have<span class='line-break'> </span>the <ins>legal</ins> right, it is for you to say. I advised her that it was</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133653">
<h3><a name="page-1133653">CB01_0164</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>164</p>
