<div id="page-1133705">
<h3><a name="page-1133705">CB01_0216</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133706">
<h3><a name="page-1133706">CB01_0217</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>217</p>
<p><date when='1865-03-01'>March 1<sup>st</sup> [186]5</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54774' title='Little, Charles C.'>C.C. Little</a> Esq</p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>When the question of compensa<span class='line-break'></span>tion came up last year, and gratuities were made<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Sup<sup>t</sup> and Gatekeeper, the Secretary made no<span class='line-break'> </span>request for increase of salary, but an increase<span class='line-break'> </span>was noted in the fees for making deeds, which resulted in<span class='line-break'> </span>increasing his compensation for the year about $48 or<span class='line-break'> </span>$50. As this increase of <ins>fees</ins> only related to the cost of making<span class='line-break'> </span>and recording deeds, and that is but a small part of the labor<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Secretary, it is manifest that no addition has been<span class='line-break'> </span>made to his pay (if addition were intended) commensurate with<span class='line-break'> </span>the increased cost of living, or as bearing any just relation to it.</p>
<p>Nearly the whole of my time is spent in the service<span class='line-break'> </span>of the [?]. I receive $800 salary, and under the present rate<span class='line-break'> </span>of fees may [?] upon $200 for deeds  = $1000: out of which I<span class='line-break'> </span>have to pay for office rent, postage and fuel &amp;c., about $240 --<span class='line-break'> </span>[?] say $760. I think you will<span class='line-break'> </span>[?] the most of my time is spent in the service of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation, [?] compensation is hardly commensurate with the pay of<span class='line-break'> </span>other officers, according to the talents employed.</p>
<p>As the officers have been reelected, and as there is some<span class='line-break'> </span>doubt whether any further reorganization of offices will be attempted this<span class='line-break'> </span>year, you and <a href='/pages/subjects/65944' title='Sleeper, Jacob'>Mr Sleeper</a> have a good opportunity to do us justice, at<span class='line-break'> </span>least so far as your report goes.</p>
<p>Very Respy yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133707">
<h3><a name="page-1133707">CB01_0218</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1865-03-08'>March 8 [186]5</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Edward Austin</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The following is a copy of<span class='line-break'> </span>record of doings at the meeting of the Trus<span class='line-break'></span>tees on Monday last:</p>
<p>The President submitted a model of a<span class='line-break'> </span>public monument in memory of the heroes<span class='line-break'> </span>who have fallen in the present war for the preser<span class='line-break'></span>vation of the Union, which he proposed should<span class='line-break'> </span>be erected in the Cemetery, to be paid for either<span class='line-break'> </span>out of the surplus funds of the Corporation,<span class='line-break'> </span>or by obtaining subscriptions for the same,<span class='line-break'> </span>as the Trustees may determine. --</p>
<p>Upon motion by <a href='/pages/subjects/54833' title='Bowditch, J. Ingersoll'>Mr Bowditch,</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Voted that the subject of this or of any<span class='line-break'> </span>monument for the purpose be referred to<span class='line-break'> </span>a Committee of three, to report upon at<span class='line-break'> </span>the next meeting: and</p>
<p>Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Austin</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/56312' title='Norcross, Otis'>Norcross</a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/63802' title='Rand, Edward S.'>Rand</a> were<span class='line-break'> </span>so chosen.</p>
<p>Very Resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1865-03-09'>March 9<sup>th</sup> [186]5</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>In the matter of <a href='/pages/subjects/67869' title='Sargent, Solomon'>Solo<span class='line-break'></span>mon Sargent's</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/56688' title='Lot 1397'>lot no. 1397</a> on <a href='/pages/subjects/55346' title='Asclepias Path'>Ascle<span class='line-break'></span>pias Path</a>, if you can now get at <span class='line-break'> </span>it, please report &amp; send estimate<span class='line-break'> </span>of cost of perpetual repair. --</p>
<p>Also cost of the two lots in one<span class='line-break'> </span>as they are enclosed. --</p>
<p>Respy. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>218</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133708">
<h3><a name="page-1133708">CB01_0219</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1865-03-10'>March 10, 1865</date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/67877' title='Browne, T. Quincy'>T. Quincy Browne Esq<sup>r</sup></a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I owe you an<span class='line-break'> </span>apology for seeming to neglect<span class='line-break'> </span>you so long in the matter of<span class='line-break'> </span>deed for <a href='/pages/subjects/65211' title='Hemenway, Mary Tileston'>Mrs A. Hemenway</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>but I have had an unusual<span class='line-break'> </span>pressure of business, besides being<span class='line-break'> </span>out of the State a short time.</p>
<p>However, I left the deed with <span class='line-break'> </span>the Treas<sup>r</sup> about a week since,<span class='line-break'> </span>that you might receipt for it on<span class='line-break'> </span>his books. I believe there is<span class='line-break'> </span>nothing due at the Treasurer's,<span class='line-break'> </span>at least, not on my account,<span class='line-break'> </span>but I send you a small<span class='line-break'> </span>bill for my services, which you<span class='line-break'> </span>can enclose to me at your con<span class='line-break'></span>venience. --</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>(see inside)</p>
<p>219</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65215' title='Hemenway, Augustus'>Augustus Hemenway Esq</a></p>
<p>To <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> [Dr?]</p>
<p><date when='1862-10-25'>1862<span class='line-break'> </span>Oct 25</date><span class='line-break'> </span><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>For going to <a href='/pages/subjects/72695' title='East Cambridge, MA'>E. Cambridge</a> &amp; purchasing <a href='/pages/subjects/65212' title='Lot 2297'>lot no 2297</a> of <a href='/pages/subjects/65213' title='Merrill, Lewis F.'>L.F. Merrill</a> for you</th> <th>5.</th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>" subsequent correspondence &amp; conference with <a href='/pages/subjects/65213' title='Merrill, Lewis F.'>L.F. M.</a> about clearing lot of encumbrences</td> <td>2.--</td> </tr> <tr><td>" preparing transfer from <a href='/pages/subjects/65213' title='Merrill, Lewis F.'>L.F.M.</a> of said lot &amp; recording</td> <td>2.--</td> </tr> <tr><td>" sending transfer <a href='/pages/subjects/65214' title='Lot 1463'>lot 1463</a> back to Corp<sup>n</sup></td> <td>1.--</td> </tr> <tr><td>" paid for N.S. Stamp of transf. of <a href='/pages/subjects/65214' title='Lot 1463'>lot 1463</a></td> <td>.50</td> </tr> <tr><td>" preparing &amp; recording new deed of lot containing 790 f. --</td> <td>2.</td> </tr> <tr><td/> <td>$12.50 </td> </tr> </tbody> </table></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133709">
<h3><a name="page-1133709">CB01_0220</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>220</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1865-03-12'>March 12<sup>th</sup> 1865</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/56312' title='Norcross, Otis'>Otis Norcross</a> Esq, Chairm<sup>n</sup>  Com. on Revision of By-Laws --</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The following is a copy of the vote adopted<span class='line-break'> </span>by the Trustees at the meeting <date when='1895-02-20'>Feby. 20.<sup>th</sup></date>  [treating?]<span class='line-break'> </span>the revision of the By-Laws. --</p>
<p>"That the subject of a revision of the By-Laws,<span class='line-break'> </span>and the printing of the same in connection with<span class='line-break'> </span>a new edition of the Catalogue be referred to<span class='line-break'> </span>a Committee of three Trustees.</p>
<p>The Chair nominated Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/56312' title='Norcross, Otis'>Norcross</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Austin</a> and<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/54833' title='Bowditch, J. Ingersoll'><!--J. L.-->Bowditch</a>, and they were so chosen." --</p>
<p>As your private engagements are numerous,<span class='line-break'> </span>you will naturally expect from me such aid, by way of<span class='line-break'> </span>suggestion of needful provisions, as my experience in assisting<span class='line-break'> </span>in the preparation of former by-laws, and ten years service<span class='line-break'> </span>for the Corporation, (during which time I have observed closely<span class='line-break'> </span>the workings of our system, and its defects or excellencies) may <span class='line-break'> </span>have enabled me to render. --</p>
<p>[next two paragraphs have been lightly crossed out]</p>
<p><del>I will confine myself to what has been talked of, and<span class='line-break'> </span>to which no objection, that I am aware of, has been raised:<span class='line-break'> </span>although, in the judgment of many, other reforms are possible.</del></p>
<p><del>I will take the by-laws in their order. -- </del></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133710">
<h3><a name="page-1133710">CB01_0220b</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><del>198</del> 220</p>
<p>I have myself experienced much incon<span class='line-break'></span>venience from a confused arrangement of<span class='line-break'> </span>the By-laws. This is not impugning the<span class='line-break'> </span>wisdom or skill of others, but merely stating<span class='line-break'> </span>that no printed by-laws had been used before<span class='line-break'> </span>1857, and the arrangement has not since been <span class='line-break'> </span>changed. Experience (which we were then without<span class='line-break'> </span>in this matter) has taught me that an<span class='line-break'> </span>improvement should be made in this<span class='line-break'> </span>particular. The difficulty chiefly occurs<span class='line-break'> </span>in finding a particular by-law. For exam<span class='line-break'></span>ple, the subject of the "laying out of lots" (art 17) is<span class='line-break'> </span>sandwiched in between "Interments" (art 16) and<span class='line-break'> </span>"<a href='/pages/subjects/61319' title='Public Lot'>Public Lots</a>" (art 18) which <del>two</del> last two are upon<span class='line-break'> </span>the same subject: and again art 18. "<a href='/pages/subjects/61319' title='Public Lot'>Public Lots</a>",<span class='line-break'> </span>which belongs in the category of Interments, comes in<span class='line-break'> </span>between 17, Laying out of lots &amp; 19 "Sales &amp; Conveyances." --</p>
<p>I could go an and instance other cases, but<span class='line-break'> </span>instead of doing so, propose to make such<span class='line-break'> </span>suggestions as have occurred to me, in the order<span class='line-break'> </span>in which the articles now stand, and conclude<span class='line-break'> </span>with the change which I propose in the arrange<span class='line-break'></span>ments. --</p>
<p>My first remark is: --</p>
<p>Under Art 2<sup>d</sup> which relates to the annual election of<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees -- No provision has been in the by laws as to the mode of</p>
<p>(continued on page 224)<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133711">
<h3><a name="page-1133711">CB01_0221</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>221</p>
<p>[page crossed out]</p>
<p>Art 1<sup>st</sup> and 2<sup>d</sup></p>
<p>In relation to ^<sup>whether a member of the Corporation can have more than one vote &amp; </sup> the <ins>mode</ins> of voting by proxy - [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>charter is [?]. The only allusion to proxy voting is in Sec. 56<span class='line-break'> </span>where, in stating that business may be transacted at any meeting<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation, it says: "And all questions shall be decided<span class='line-break'> </span>by a majority of the members present and voting either in per<span class='line-break'></span>son or by proxy." "Members" are defined in Sec 3.<sup>d</sup> to be<span class='line-break'></span>"All persons who shall hereafter become proprietors of lots in<span class='line-break'> </span>said Cemetery, of a size not less, each, than three hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>square feet."</p>
<p>It will be observed that there is nothing in the<span class='line-break'> </span>language of the charter, which indicates whether a member<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be entitled to a <ins>stock vote</ins> or one proportional to his<span class='line-break'> </span>interest; or only to his personal vote. - And I do not<span class='line-break'> </span>know that the question has ever been mooted in the Board<span class='line-break'> </span>of Trustees, or in the Corporation; but I have often heard it<span class='line-break'> </span>asked by individuals; and I have answered that, "so<span class='line-break'> </span>there are I am aware, each proprietor of a lot of 300 feet<span class='line-break'> </span>may cast only one vote in his own right: and if represent<span class='line-break'></span>ing the lot of another individual or the heirs of such, he <del>was</del> ^<sup>is</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>entitled to one other vote."</p>
<p>At the first, and for many years, scarcely a proprietor<span class='line-break'> </span>held more than one lot. Now there are quite a number,<span class='line-break'> </span>whom hold more than one, but not more than six or seven<span class='line-break'> </span>lots of 300 feet each: - which fact would seem to render it<span class='line-break'> </span>important to settle in the by-laws each one's right in<span class='line-break'> </span>this respect.</p>
<p>Upon examination of the Statutes relating to other kindred<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporations, I am satisfied that the analogy<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133712">
<h3><a name="page-1133712">CB01_0222</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title='222'>222</span></p>
<p>of this case leads to the conclusion that each proprietor<span class='line-break'> </span>of a lot containing 300 square feet &amp; upwards is entitled<span class='line-break'> </span>to a vote proportional to his interest.</p>
<p>[the rest of this page appears to be deleted?]</p>
<p>In. Gen. Stats. Ch. 28. Sec. 2. <u>Proprietors of Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporations</u> are invested with the powers and privileges,<span class='line-break'> </span>and are made subject to the duties, restrictions and liab<span class='line-break'></span>ities of Chap. 68, and the first sixteen sections of Ch. 67 of<span class='line-break'> </span>Gen. Stats. -</p>
<p>Chap. 68, Sec. 7, "Corporation may by their bylaws, where<span class='line-break'> </span>no other provision is specially made, determine xxx the<span class='line-break'> </span>number of shares that shall entitle the members to one or<span class='line-break'> </span>more votes; the mode of voting by proxy"; &amp;c.</p>
<p>If it were doubtful whether this was not [intend?]<span class='line-break'> </span>to apply to stock rather than Cemetery Corporations, it<span class='line-break'> </span>appears to me there can be no doubt of the applica<span class='line-break'></span>bility of Sec, 12 of Chap. 67 to our case, which is:</p>
<p>"Each proprietor shall be entitled to vote according<span class='line-break'> </span>to the number of his shares <u>or the [?] of his interest</u><span class='line-break'> </span>when the same is known, and when not known, the<span class='line-break'> </span>proprietors shall vote equally. Absent proprietors<span class='line-break'> </span>may vote by proxy authorized in writing."</p>
<p>As this provision (which is under "Proprietors of Wharves, Gen<span class='line-break'> </span>eral Fields and Real Estate lying in Common") not only goes<span class='line-break'> </span>back to the <del>General</del> Revised Statutes, but was enacted as early<span class='line-break'> </span>is 1785, and as the General Statutes relating to Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporations adopt that provision by way of reference, there<span class='line-break'> </span>can be no reasonable doubt that the same provis<span class='line-break'></span>ion is applicable &amp; the Charter of this Corporation; and<span class='line-break'> </span>that if the Trustees see fit to adopt the principle</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133713">
<h3><a name="page-1133713">CB01_0223</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>223</p>
<p>involved in it into the by-laws, such by-laws will not [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>repugnant to the laws of the Commonwealth.</p>
<p>How then does it apply here? It is the privilege usually<span class='line-break'> </span>accorded to a purchaser to receive the deed of as many<span class='line-break'> </span>lots as are divisible by 300 square feet: i.e. if he buys<span class='line-break'> </span>1500 feet, and wishes it laid out in five lots without<span class='line-break'> </span>passageways, no objection is made, any more [?] sell<span class='line-break'> </span>him five lots laid out contiguously, or [?] in<span class='line-break'> </span>the Cemetery, each of which he may transfer to differ<span class='line-break'> </span>ent persons, each of whom will have a vote. But<span class='line-break'> </span>if a purchaser has waived their right by taking his<span class='line-break'> </span>land in one enclosure as one lot, there is no reason<span class='line-break'> </span>to extend to him the advantages of this provision.</p>
<p>The owner of five lots each of which contains 300 square<span class='line-break'> </span>feet or upwards, upon the principle above laid down<span class='line-break'> </span>will be entitled to five votes. There would seem to be no<span class='line-break'> </span>more reason why this privilege should not enure here,<span class='line-break'> </span>than in the case of "proprietors of several fields," and<span class='line-break'> </span>those whose interest is greater should have more con<span class='line-break'></span>trol than others whose interest is less. - For example, <span class='line-break'> </span>the man who owns 299 feet has no voice at all. - <span class='line-break'> </span>If then a certain number of feet was requisite, in the judgment<span class='line-break'> </span>of the originators of their Cemetery, to give a man any voice or<span class='line-break'> </span>control, why should not twice, or three, or ten times as<span class='line-break'> </span>many give him more control. -</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133714">
<h3><a name="page-1133714">CB01_0224</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>224</p>
<p><del>As to</del> voting by proxy -- : authorized in the Charter</p>
<p>The provisions as to <ins>Banks</ins>, ch. 57 Gen. Stat.<span class='line-break'> </span>(p. 304) seem too cumbersome, and inapplicable to<span class='line-break'> </span>a Corporation like this.</p>
<p>The provisions as to Insurance Companies, Ch. 58,<span class='line-break'> </span>Sec. 27 (p. 323) are: "Each share shall be entitled to<span class='line-break'> </span>one vote. Proxies may be authorized in writing. No<span class='line-break'> </span>officer shall vote as proxy, and no stockholder shall<span class='line-break'> </span>either in person or by proxy cast more than <ins>thirty</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>votes. The record of the vote, whether cast in person<span class='line-break'> </span>or by proxy, made by the Secretary, or Clerk of the Company,<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be evidence of all such elections." --</p>
<p>The provisions stating to Manuf<sup>g</sup> &amp; other Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ations organized under Special Charters are: --</p>
<p>Ch. 60, p.337  "At all meetings of the Company about stockholders may<span class='line-break'> </span>vote by proxy authorized in writing: but no proxy shall be<span class='line-break'> </span>valid unless executed and dated within six months previous<span class='line-break'> </span>to the meeting at which it is used, if the maker thereof resides<span class='line-break'> </span>in the U.S.; and no person shall as proxy or attorney cast<span class='line-break'> </span>more than fifty votes, unless all the shares so represented<span class='line-break'> </span>by him are owned by one person; and no office of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation as proxy or attorney shall cast more than twenty<span class='line-break'> </span>votes." --</p>
<p>How far any of the foregoing provisions can be<span class='line-break'> </span>made to suit the case of our Corporation, if they can<span class='line-break'> </span>be made so at all, the Trustees must determine. --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133715">
<h3><a name="page-1133715">CB01_0225</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>225</p>
<p>My own impression is that the use of proxy<span class='line-break'> </span>votes, at all, does more harm than good, by<span class='line-break'> </span>giving encouragement to some designing or malicious<span class='line-break'> </span>man to obtain a large number among a constitu<span class='line-break'></span>ency so scattered, and overthrow or build up<span class='line-break'> </span>as he chooses: and especially, it does harm by<span class='line-break'> </span>leading members to send their proxy instead of<span class='line-break'> </span>personally attending the meetings.</p>
<p>Before the year <date when='1855'>1855</date>, I am informed it was<span class='line-break'> </span>not usual for a dozen persons to be present at<span class='line-break'> </span>the annual meetings, and since then, with one excep<span class='line-break'></span>tion, I doubt whether more than seventy five have<span class='line-break'> </span>been present). I believe the number will not average<span class='line-break'> </span>more than fifty voting members out of 3500<span class='line-break'> </span>proprietors. Any device which would secure<span class='line-break'> </span>the attendance of a larger number of persons ought to<span class='line-break'> </span>be adopted by the Trustees -- whether by personal<span class='line-break'> </span>notice, or regulating the manner of voting by proxy.</p>
<p>Of course proxy voting must be allowed, unless<span class='line-break'> </span>an amendment of the Charter is obtained. If you<span class='line-break'> </span>desire to restrict it, a certain definite time, as three<span class='line-break'> </span>[missing word] six months, within which proxies shall be obtained<span class='line-break'> </span>ought to be adopted. Then an acknowledgment before a<span class='line-break'> </span>Justice of the Peace or other magistrate would probably se<span class='line-break'></span>[cure?] some further restriction. But both, in my opinion,<span class='line-break'> </span>will not prevent the operations of a malicious person:<span class='line-break'> </span>[missing word], I think you will find that such mischievous works<span class='line-break'> </span>[are?] generally brought within the span of one month.</p>
<p>(continued two pages forward)</p>
<p>227<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133716">
<h3><a name="page-1133716">CB01_0226</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1865-03-18'>March 18, [186]5</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/67889' title='Marett, Philip H.'>Philip Marett</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/67890' title='New Haven, CT'>New Haven, Conn.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 16<sup>th</sup> relating<span class='line-break'> </span>to your <a href='/pages/subjects/68000' title='Lot 794'>lot no. 794</a>, addressed to our<span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup>  <a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo. W<sup>m</sup> Bond</a> has been han<span class='line-break'></span>ded to me.</p>
<p>I have taken steps to obtain<span class='line-break'> </span>for you the requisite informa<span class='line-break'></span>tion, and will report to<span class='line-break'> </span>you in a few days.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>226</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133717">
<h3><a name="page-1133717">CB01_0227</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>(From pg. 225) 227</p>
<p>Articles 3 &amp; 10 --</p>
<p>"The office of <ins>"Gardener"</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>having been abolished by the action of this Board,<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee recommend that the <ins>third</ins> Art.<span class='line-break'> </span>be amended by striking out the word where it occurs<span class='line-break'> </span>in the 10<sup>th</sup>  line, and that the <ins>whole of Art. 10</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>be stricken out.</p>
<p>Art. 6. Treasurer --</p>
<p>By a knowledge of the facts, you will perceive an<span class='line-break'> </span>inaptness in the amendment to Art. 6, which is embraced<span class='line-break'> </span>in writing after the figure^<sup>(2)</sup>. A committee having<span class='line-break'> </span>been chosen in 1861, to consider what reform was needed<span class='line-break'> </span>in the administration of "Affairs at the Cemetery", submitted<span class='line-break'> </span>their report, which was printed, (a copy of which -- <a href='/pages/subjects/64179' title='Lot 1'>no. 1</a> -<span class='line-break'></span>with amendments &amp; regulations adopted. Nos. 2 &amp; 3 -- are herewith<span class='line-break'> </span>submitted) in which, among other things they urged that<span class='line-break'> </span>the Chief office of the Treas<sup>r</sup> should be at Mount Auburn,<span class='line-break'> </span>and that he should attend every day during certain<span class='line-break'> </span>hours at the Secretary's office in <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>. The plan<span class='line-break'> </span>did not appear to be acceptable to the Board,<span class='line-break'> </span>and the amend<sup>t</sup>  referred to was adopted by way<span class='line-break'> </span>of compromise. But the Treas<sup>r</sup> does <ins>not</ins> "have an<span class='line-break'> </span>office at Mount Auburn" -- the Com. on Finance<span class='line-break'> </span>have never ordered him "to be in attendance there" -<span class='line-break'></span>(except <ins>once a month</ins> to pay the laborers) and he has<span class='line-break'> </span>never had "a Clerk" there in the sense intended<span class='line-break'> </span>in the by-law, but has arranged with the Gatekeeper<span class='line-break'> </span>to perform the duties of Clerk.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133718">
<h3><a name="page-1133718">CB01_0228</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>228</p>
<p>By reference to Art. 9. -- Gatekeeper -- he is<span class='line-break'> </span>authorized "<ins>in the absence of the Treasurer or<span class='line-break'> </span>his Clerk</ins>" to receive such burial fees as may be<span class='line-break'> </span>paid, and pass the sum immediately <ins>to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Treasurer, or his Clerk, upon his return"</ins>.</p>
<p>If the Committee propose to amend the by-laws<span class='line-break'> </span>to conform to the present established practice, then<span class='line-break'> </span>these clauses appear to need revision. --</p>
<p>For the same reason, the clause in the<span class='line-break'> </span>new amend<sup>t</sup>  under <ins>Superintendent</ins>, viz.</p>
<p>"He shall at the close of <ins>each week</ins> render<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Treasurer or his Clerk an accurate statement<span class='line-break'> </span>of the name of each laborer employed, the amount<span class='line-break'> </span>of labor performed, and the amount of wages ^<sup>to be</sup> paid," -<span class='line-break'></span>ought to be made to conform to the admitted prac<span class='line-break'></span>tice, or the practice ought to conform to the by law.</p>
<p>The amend<sup>t</sup>  proposed in the 1<sup>st</sup>  &amp; 2<sup>d</sup> printed reports,<span class='line-break'> </span>(just referred to) required him to render this account<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>every day</ins>. As a compromise it was made to<span class='line-break'> </span>read "each week." But it is done only <ins>monthly</ins>, as<span class='line-break'> </span>that is as often as the help are paid. --</p>
<p>Inasmuch as it is made the duty of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary, to keep a duplicate Register of Interments, with<span class='line-break'> </span>all orders or vouchers properly filled. -- There is<span class='line-break'> </span>needed a corresponding amend<sup>t</sup>  in Art 7. Sup<sup>t</sup>  -<span class='line-break'></span>in 16<sup>th</sup> line of 34<sup>th</sup>  page -- like the following: -<span class='line-break'></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133719">
<h3><a name="page-1133719">CB01_0229</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>229</p>
<p>"And transmit to the Secretary monthly,<span class='line-break'> </span>the orders for such interments to be revised and<span class='line-break'> </span>recorded on the duplicate Registers, one of which<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be kept at the office in <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, and one<span class='line-break'> </span>at Mount Auburn."</p>
<p>It will be understood that the foregoing does<span class='line-break'> </span>not add to the <ins>personal</ins> duties of the Superintendent,<span class='line-break'> </span>as he has a man under him whose whole duty it is to<span class='line-break'> </span>superintend funerals, and keep the record of them<span class='line-break'> </span>at the Gate: and what is proposed as an addition<span class='line-break'> </span>to the by-law above is already the practice. --</p>
<p>Art. 9. Gatekeeper --</p>
<p>In addition to what was said on last<span class='line-break'> </span>page under this head (in connection with Treas<sup>r</sup> )<span class='line-break'> </span>I will mention. --</p>
<p>That the Trustees some three years since <span class='line-break'> </span>passed a vote in connection with the Gatekeeper's<span class='line-break'> </span>salary, allowing him in addition thereto, "seventy<span class='line-break'> </span>five cents per week to enable him to compensate a<span class='line-break'> </span>substitute whom he shall procure to perform<span class='line-break'> </span>his duties as Gatekeeper <ins>one half of every Sabbath</ins>" -<span class='line-break'></span>since which this allowance has been made annu<span class='line-break'></span>ally. And as this exception appears to be established<span class='line-break'> </span>in his favor, the By-law should be made to read<span class='line-break'> </span>after the word "week" in the 3<sup>d</sup>  line. --</p>
<p>"Excepting one half of the Sabbath, when he may<span class='line-break'> </span>employ a substitute, who shall be satisfactory to the<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133720">
<h3><a name="page-1133720">CB01_0230</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>230</p>
<p>Trustees and at such expense to the Corporation as the<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees shall determine."</p>
<p>Reference to the amend<sup>t</sup> made in 1861, added in writing to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Art. on Gatekeeper was made in connection with Art. 6, to<span class='line-break'> </span>show the need of amending that article. But now as to this<span class='line-break'> </span>article itself, the language: --</p>
<p>"<ins>in the absence of the Treasurer,<span class='line-break'> </span>or his Clerk</ins>" --</p>
<p>appears more palpably absurd. -- The<span class='line-break'> </span>Gatekeeper is that Clerk -- collects burial fees, and sometimes<span class='line-break'> </span>other bills, and pays some bills for the Treasurer, and goes <span class='line-break'> </span>in to the Treasurer every few days -- perhaps once a fortnight -<span class='line-break'></span>and settles his [act?] with him. I have sometimes seen the<span class='line-break'> </span>Treasurer's books, and observed that the Gatekeeper<span class='line-break'> </span>must have had two or three hundred dollars in<span class='line-break'> </span>his hands.</p>
<p>In summer -- pleasant days -- this work is<span class='line-break'> </span>an interference with his regular vocation, and were it<span class='line-break'> </span>not for small boys who are kept at the Gate to sell<span class='line-break'> </span>Guide books and other knickknacks for the personal<span class='line-break'> </span>benefit of the Gatekeeper and Funeral Undertaker,<span class='line-break'> </span>and who attend to a good deal of the opening and<span class='line-break'> </span>shutting of <a href='/pages/subjects/57664' title='Entrance Gateway'>the Gate,</a> proprietors, I think, might be<span class='line-break'> </span>disposed sometimes to complain of neglect. In winter,<span class='line-break'> </span>the Gatekeeper's duties might be trebled without<span class='line-break'> </span>injury to his health.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133721">
<h3><a name="page-1133721">CB01_0231</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>231</p>
<p>Art. 10.<ins>Gardener</ins>. Abolish, as before suggested.</p>
<p>Art. 13. Com. on Lots.</p>
<p>After the words -- "indefinite time" -- (4<sup>th</sup>  line<span class='line-break'> </span>from bottom of page 37) add:</p>
<p>"And such contract shall be<span class='line-break'> </span>reported for ratification at the next subsequent meeting<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Board."</p>
<p>As such contract is only inchoate<span class='line-break'> </span>until the vote of the Board, punctuality is due to the<span class='line-break'> </span>person with whom the contract is made.</p>
<p>Art. 14. Com. on Grounds --</p>
<p>Under this head is a matter of a little delicacy, but<span class='line-break'> </span>of much importance. The President, from time immemor<span class='line-break'></span>ial, by general consent, has given new names to paths<span class='line-break'> </span>and avenues -- but it has never been made the duty<span class='line-break'> </span>of any one to report such names to the Board. The<span class='line-break'> </span>consequence is, that we have a record of them<span class='line-break'> </span>in only a few instances. It must be obvious<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Committee that every accepted avenue and<span class='line-break'> </span>path in Mount Auburn should be one <ins>of record</ins>.</p>
<p>Would it not be well then to pass a vote "that<span class='line-break'> </span>all the avenues and paths of which a list is<span class='line-break'> </span>contained in the catalogue of 1860, together with<span class='line-break'> </span>such as may have been since established,<span class='line-break'> </span>(calling them by name) shall be deemed and taken<span class='line-break'> </span>to be accepted avenues and paths in the Cemetery."</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133722">
<h3><a name="page-1133722">CB01_0231b</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>Then for the future incorporate into this article,<span class='line-break'> </span>at the end, the following: --</p>
<p>"They shall from time to time<span class='line-break'> </span>report, for the action of this Board, such new<span class='line-break'> </span>avenues and paths as they may deem it necessary<span class='line-break'> </span>to lay out, or any proposed change in existing<span class='line-break'> </span>ways." --</p>
<p>Art. 15. "Com. on Regulations &amp; Records of Interments".</p>
<p>I propose to strike out the words --</p>
<p>"Regulations &amp; Records of"<span class='line-break'> </span>in the title and in the article, as not giving and dis<span class='line-break'></span>tinctive meaning, and as very unwieldy to use. It is<span class='line-break'> </span>mere surplusage. The duties of the Committee are as well<span class='line-break'> </span>expressed under the words "Com. on Interments". One duty,<span class='line-break'> </span>viz. "inspecting the accounts of the Superintendent", you will per<span class='line-break'></span>ceive have nothing to do with interments.</p>
<p>Art. 16. Interments.</p>
<p>The second paragraph (page 39) needs to be amended<span class='line-break'> </span>by substituting the following in place of the whole paragraph: --</p>
<p>"Until otherwise ordered, five dollars shall be<span class='line-break'> </span>charged for opening an adult grave and making an<span class='line-break'> </span>interment, and three dollars for the same service in the<span class='line-break'> </span>case of a child under ten years of age. For each inter<span class='line-break'></span>ment in a tomb, a charge of not less than three nor<span class='line-break'> </span>more than five dollars shall be made by the Super<span class='line-break'></span>intendent, according to the amount of service rendered<span class='line-break'> </span>in the case."</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133723">
<h3><a name="page-1133723">CB01_0232</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>232</p>
<p>4</p>
<p>Then I think should be added: --</p>
<p>"No grave or tomb shall be opened for interment<span class='line-break'> </span>or removal by any person not in the employment<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation".</p>
<p>Art. 17 -- Lots and Spaces.</p>
<p>For 3<sup>d</sup> paragraph (p. 40) substitute the following:</p>
<p>"The price of land until otherwise ordered,<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be not less than one dollar, nor more than<span class='line-break'> </span>two dollars per square foot, according to the situation,<span class='line-break'> </span>unless the Committee on Lots shall in any specific case,<span class='line-break'> </span>consider the land to be of greater or less value. No<span class='line-break'> </span>variation in price shall be made for large or<span class='line-break'> </span>small lots."</p>
<p>Art. 18 -- <a href='/pages/subjects/61319' title='Public Lot'>Public Lots</a>. --</p>
<p>The clause beginning in the 5<sup>th</sup> line p. 41 --</p>
<p>"but not slab, monument or fence shall be erected<span class='line-break'> </span>upon or around said graves without the approval of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Committee on Lots": --</p>
<p>perhaps requires some change;<span class='line-break'> </span>because the Com. on Lots do not wish to be troubled every<span class='line-break'> </span>time a person desires to erect a headstone or tablet,<span class='line-break'> </span>and in point of practice, I have never known this<span class='line-break'> </span>consent to be asked. It has always been taken for<span class='line-break'> </span>granted that a headstone may be erected. But in<span class='line-break'> </span>respect to enclosing the grave or graves with a fence or<span class='line-break'> </span>curb, I think the rule should stand as it is. --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133724">
<h3><a name="page-1133724">CB01_0233</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>233</p>
<p>And I think there should be a restriction upon the height<span class='line-break'> </span>of headstones -- say <ins>three feet</ins>. For enclosures may<span class='line-break'> </span>encroach on the rights of others -- they <ins>do</ins> obstruct<span class='line-break'> </span>the passage between graves, and are often out of <span class='line-break'> </span>taste, and break up, by variety, the symmetrical<span class='line-break'> </span>appearance of the grounds. Tall headstones are<span class='line-break'> </span>unsightly, when their height obstructs the view<span class='line-break'> </span>of the other parts of the ground. --</p>
<p>I would suggest something like this:</p>
<p>"but no<span class='line-break'> </span>slab or monument shall be erected at any grave<span class='line-break'> </span>exceeding three feet in height, ^<sup>and under the supervision of the Sup<sup>t</sup></sup>, and no fence or curb<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be placed around a grave or graves, without<span class='line-break'> </span>the consent of the Committee on Lots."</p>
<p>The last clause in this article I think should<span class='line-break'> </span>be amended to read --</p>
<p>"If any grave shall become<span class='line-break'> </span>vacant by the removal of the body interred therein,<span class='line-break'> </span>the land shall revert to the Corporation, unless<span class='line-break'> </span>it shall be received in exchange and partial<span class='line-break'> </span>payment for other land in the Cemetery."</p>
<p>I propose this last amend<sup>t</sup> to prevent the impli<span class='line-break'></span>cation of a right on the part of a grave-owner to be<span class='line-break'> </span>reimbursed when he removes a body from the<span class='line-break'> </span>public lot to the lot of some other proprietor in the<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery, or anywhere else than to land purchased</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133725">
<h3><a name="page-1133725">CB01_0234</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>234</p>
<p>by him of the Corporation for the purpose -- which rule<span class='line-break'> </span>we have already adopted in practice, as the probable<span class='line-break'> </span>intention of the Trustees.</p>
<p>I then propose to add: --</p>
<p>"The Treasurer shall<span class='line-break'> </span>give to each purchaser of a grave in either of the Public<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots a certificate of such purchase, in accordance<span class='line-break'> </span>with the form contained in Appendix G." --</p>
<p>Art. 19. Sales and conveyances. --</p>
<p>Page 42 line 1, strike out the words</p>
<p>"customary or" -<span class='line-break'></span>as there is no customary price.</p>
<p>Page 42. 2<sup>d</sup> &amp; 3 <sup>d</sup> lines -- I propose instead of</p>
<p>"and the Secretary's fee of one dollar" -<span class='line-break'></span>the words --</p>
<p>"And the usual fee for a deed." --</p>
<p>Reasons -- 1<sup>st</sup>. Rather a flatfooted way of stating <span class='line-break'> </span>the stipend of an officer. The purpose of this charge<span class='line-break'> </span>to the proprietor was doubtless to lessen the expense<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Corporation: but it seems unnecessary to<span class='line-break'> </span>fix the attention of proprietors particularly upon<span class='line-break'> </span>the Secretary as the one to whom a portion of their money<span class='line-break'> </span>goes, when their money goes equally to the support of the<span class='line-break'> </span>other officers. I think any officer might modestly<span class='line-break'> </span>ask to be shielded under the above amendment.</p>
<p>2<sup>d</sup> The fee is at present <ins>two</ins> dollars. It <span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133726">
<h3><a name="page-1133726">CB01_0235</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>235</p>
<p>does not seem necessary to state it in the by<span class='line-break'></span>laws, as it is printed upon the certificate.</p>
<p>P. 42 line 3<sup>d</sup> -- After the amended form proposal<span class='line-break'> </span>above -- "and the usual fee for a deed" -- and the words,<span class='line-break'> </span>"and receive a certificate therefor" --</p>
<p>I would add the words:</p>
<p>"in the form con<span class='line-break'></span>tained in Appendix B." --</p>
<p>I would make this certif<span class='line-break'></span>icate express the <ins>number of the lot</ins> which will be<span class='line-break'> </span>a convenience both to the proprietor and the Cor<span class='line-break'></span>poration; and I would also amend further<span class='line-break'> </span>by striking out from the 7<sup>th</sup> &amp; 8<sup>th</sup> lines the words --</p>
<p>"presenting<span class='line-break'> </span>the certificate and" --</p>
<p>as the redelivery of this certificate<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Treasurer is often inconvenient, and cannot<span class='line-break'> </span>be of any use to the Corporation, the receipting for the<span class='line-break'> </span>deed rendering it null and void. It would be impos<span class='line-break'></span>sible for the holder to demand another deed for it, and<span class='line-break'> </span>it can only be available by way of transfer "<ins>on the<span class='line-break'> </span>books of the Corporation"</ins>. The Treasurer says there is<span class='line-break'> </span>no need of requiring the redelivery of the certificate.<span class='line-break'> </span>Usually when the party calls for his deed, he is found<span class='line-break'> </span>to have filed away the certif. as a receipt for the money paid.</p>
<p>The amended clause would then read -- changing the words -<span class='line-break'></span>"for said deed" -- into -- "therefor" -- and adding "upon the margin of the<span class='line-break'> </span>certificate book" -- as follows: --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133727">
<h3><a name="page-1133727">CB01_0236</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>236</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title=' 5 ='> 5 =</span></p>
<p>"The Secretary, on receiving the Treasurer's order<span class='line-break'> </span>for the deed of said lot, shall make, record, and<span class='line-break'> </span>return said deed to the Treasurer, who will deliver<span class='line-break'> </span>the same to the purchaser, upon his receipting therefor<span class='line-break'> </span>upon the margin of the certificate book."</p>
<p>The above is the best that can be done under the<span class='line-break'> </span>present system, perhaps. But there will always be a good<span class='line-break'> </span>deal of inconvenience to be endured by proprietors and<span class='line-break'> </span>the officers so long as the circumlocution of two sep<span class='line-break'></span>arate offices in Boston exists. As the question of the<span class='line-break'> </span>reorganization of these offices is not before the Trustees, I<span class='line-break'> </span>forbear to say anything further than necessarily occurs under<span class='line-break'> </span>this point -- that the method of making and delivering<span class='line-break'> </span>deeds has a tendency to stretch the patience of proprietors,<span class='line-break'> </span>and deprives the Secretary of the means of accuracy in his<span class='line-break'> </span>work, and of knowing the particular location of the parties<span class='line-break'> </span>in interest, to whom he is so often obliged to send notices for<span class='line-break'> </span>various purposes. -- In truth the deed ought to be deliv<span class='line-break'></span>ered by the Secretary, for the better convenience of both<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation and the proprietor. But this would re<span class='line-break'></span>quire the Superintendent's reports of sales also to be left<span class='line-break'> </span>at the Secretary's office, or, at least, a duplicate copy thereof.</p>
<p>P. 43<sup>d</sup> line 1 -- After the words: -- "recorded in the books of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation" -- add</p>
<p>"with the proper attestation thereof."</p>
<p>The attestation were unknown until within three or four years.<span class='line-break'> </span>All the deeds before that are unattested. --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133728">
<h3><a name="page-1133728">CB01_0237</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>237</p>
<p>I would strike out the next sentence: --</p>
<p>"One dollar shall be paid to the Secretary<span class='line-break'> </span>for recording any deed of transfer, and giving the due<span class='line-break'> </span>certificate of the same, if the Com. shall be satisfied<span class='line-break'> </span>with a new proposed article on "Records", in which<span class='line-break'> </span>I have embodied it.</p>
<p>Art 21. "Plans and Portfolios" --</p>
<p>I propose to change the title of Article to</p>
<p>"Surveys and Plans". --</p>
<p>The old wall plans referred to in the first sentence<span class='line-break'> </span>have been suffered to fall behind, and have been super<span class='line-break'></span>ceded by the new sectional plans, of which there is<span class='line-break'> </span>but one copy, which is kept at the Secretary's office,<span class='line-break'> </span>so that an amend<sup>t</sup> appears to be required, by<span class='line-break'> </span><u>striking</u> <u>out</u> the second clause of 1<sup>st</sup> sentence: -<span class='line-break'></span>"and a duplicate of the same at the Supt<sup>s</sup> office" --.<span class='line-break'> </span>unless the Trustees wish to incur the expense of a<span class='line-break'> </span>duplicate copy of the sectional plan to be kept there. -<span class='line-break'></span>which would, undoubtedly, be agreeable to the Superintend<sup>t</sup>.</p>
<p>Then amend the first sentence by making it read --</p>
<p>"A large sectional map or plan of the Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be kept at the Secretary's office, on which shall be<span class='line-break'> </span>entered" &amp;c. (as it stands now).</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Mr Austin</a> has proposed to add to the By-law, the fol<span class='line-break'></span>lowing, which will fit in after the 1<sup>st</sup> Par. of <del>art.</del></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133729">
<h3><a name="page-1133729">CB01_0238</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>238</p>
<p>Art. 21, near top of 45<sup>th</sup> page.</p>
<p>"The surveyor shall here<span class='line-break'></span>after measure and put upon the sectional plan both<span class='line-break'> </span>the interior and exterior lines of the lots, and express<span class='line-break'> </span>the interior distances of the side lines and diagonals<span class='line-break'> </span>in figures. The Superintendent shall give written<span class='line-break'> </span>notice to the surveyor of all changes made in the<span class='line-break'> </span>lines of the lots, or of avenues and paths, who shall<span class='line-break'> </span>mark all such changes upon the sectional plan<span class='line-break'> </span>in red ink, to distinguish them from the lines already<span class='line-break'> </span>drawn, which shall not be erased without the permis<span class='line-break'></span>sion of the Board of Trustees. The surveyor<span class='line-break'> </span>shall make his surveys at Mount Auburn, and<span class='line-break'> </span>enter the same quarterly."</p>
<p>I propose to add --</p>
<p>"He shall <span class='line-break'> </span>contract with and act under the direction of the Com<span class='line-break'></span>mittee on Lots in all matters pertaining to lots: and<span class='line-break'> </span>in respect to other surveys, shall act under the<span class='line-break'> </span>direction of the Committee on Grounds or the Board of<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees."</p>
<p>Art. 22 -- Treas.</p>
<p>There is a possibility of conflict between the duties of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Com. on Lots &amp; Com. on Grounds. The Com. on Lots "have<span class='line-break'> </span>the general supervision of all sales, locations, and en<span class='line-break'></span>largement of lots, also of all questions of right between<span class='line-break'> </span>individual proprietors, and between proprietors and the</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133730">
<h3><a name="page-1133730">CB01_0239</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>239</p>
<p>Corporation." -- In practice, I think the Com. on Grounds<span class='line-break'> </span>have directed the Superintendent where to lay out new<span class='line-break'> </span>lots. The Com. on Grounds "have general charge of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Grounds, <ins>trees</ins>, avenues and paths in the Cemetery:"<span class='line-break'> </span>and again, in this article -- "Trees standing <ins>within<span class='line-break'> </span>lots</ins> can be removed, if desired, by an application<span class='line-break'> </span>from the proprietor to the Sup<sup>t</sup>, subject to the ap<span class='line-break'></span>proval of the Com. on Grounds." --</p>
<p>Now, as the Com. on Lots are understood to<span class='line-break'> </span>have the general supervision of lots, and as nearly all<span class='line-break'> </span>the questions that can possibly arise between indiv<span class='line-break'></span>idual proprietors or between them and the Corpora<span class='line-break'></span>tion must have reference to their rights or wishes<span class='line-break'> </span>connected with their lots, it is manifest that the<span class='line-break'> </span>right of the Com. on Grounds to decide about the<span class='line-break'> </span>removal of trees <ins>within</ins> lots might easily involve<span class='line-break'> </span>the two Committees in a conflict of jurisdiction.</p>
<p>I merely suggest this for the consideration<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Com.<sup>ee</sup> without proposing a specific amend<sup>t</sup>.</p>
<p>Then as to the <ins>terms</ins> of removal of trees<span class='line-break'> </span>within lots. I think the Sup<sup>t</sup> is usually obliged<span class='line-break'> </span>to charge for such service; and it ought to be<span class='line-break'> </span>so stated. -- After the words "if desired" -- in the 2<sup>d</sup> line,<span class='line-break'> </span>add -- "at the expense of the proprietor." --</p>
<p>As the by-law now reads, I do not think this<span class='line-break'> </span>would be inferred. --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133731">
<h3><a name="page-1133731">CB01_0240</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>240</p>
<p><span class='depth3' depth='3' title=' 6 ='> 6 =</span></p>
<p>Art'. 25 -- <a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>Receiving Tomb</a><ins>s</ins>.</p>
<p>As the Corporation has now but one tomb, the plu<span class='line-break'></span>ral should be changed to the singular in the title,<span class='line-break'> </span>and in the 2<sup>d</sup> line.</p>
<p>In the last line on the 46<sup>th</sup> page<span class='line-break'> </span>the word "fifteen" should be changed to "fourteen,"<span class='line-break'> </span>to conform to the present tariff of prices.</p>
<p>I have never understood what the words -<span class='line-break'></span>"in a legal way", in the 7<sup>th</sup> line of the 47<sup>th</sup> page, unless<span class='line-break'> </span>it be that the removal shall not be made without<span class='line-break'> </span>the knowledge and sanction of the Sup<sup>t</sup>. As I have<span class='line-break'> </span>proposed to make the by-law on Interments (Art. 16)<span class='line-break'> </span>forbid persons not in the employ of the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>to open a grave or tomb for interment or removal,<span class='line-break'> </span>these would appear to me unnecessary. --</p>
<p>Art. 29 -- Repair Fund.</p>
<p>I insert here what I sometime since, with the<span class='line-break'> </span>approbation of the Committee on Lots proposed as a<span class='line-break'> </span>recommendation for amend<sup>t</sup> of this By law. --</p>
<p>"The Committee on Lots are satisfied from obser<span class='line-break'></span>vation that the language of the second clause of Art. 29 -<span class='line-break'></span>"Repair Fund" tends very much to mislead<span class='line-break'> </span>proprietors who are inquiring upon this subject,</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133732">
<h3><a name="page-1133732">CB01_0241</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>241</p>
<p>and that from having seen a definite sum of money<span class='line-break'> </span>mentioned, without remembering the particular limit<span class='line-break'></span>ation, they obtain an impression which acts un<span class='line-break'></span>favorably upon effecting contracts with them for the<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual repair of lots.</p>
<p>They therefore recommend<span class='line-break'> </span>the Trustees to amend the By-law upon that<span class='line-break'> </span>subject by striking out the following words in the<span class='line-break'> </span>second clause of Art. 29 --</p>
<p>"The Trustees may also<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>guarantee</ins> the perpetual repair of lots, containing three<span class='line-break'> </span>hundred feet and upwards, on the payment to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Treasurer of a sum not less than three hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars, and of lots containing less than three hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>feet on the payment of a sum not less than one hun<span class='line-break'></span>dred dollars." --</p>
<p>And inserting the following clause instead: --</p>
<p>"The Trustees may also <ins>guarantee</ins> the per<span class='line-break'></span>petual repair of any lot, on the payment to the Treas<span class='line-break'></span>urer of such sum of money as the Committee on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots shall deem sufficient for that purpose." --</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots further recommend<span class='line-break'> </span>that the present printed form of contract for per<span class='line-break'></span>petual repair be amended by inserting the word<span class='line-break'> </span>"forever" -- after the words, "to keep" -- in the 2<sup>d</sup> clause.<span class='line-break'> </span>and adding at the end of the clause. --</p>
<p>"this contract being intended to attach to said lot<span class='line-break'> </span>and its appurtenances, in the condition in which the same</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133733">
<h3><a name="page-1133733">CB01_0242</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>242</p>
<p>are described in a report thereon made by the<span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent of the Cemetery, dated<span class='line-break'> </span>18 [blank], and which report is entered, upon the Records<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation."</p>
<p>The paragraph at the bottom of page 49, beginning<span class='line-break'> </span>"The <ins>Treasurer</ins> shall keep the Superintendent constantly<span class='line-break'> </span>informed," &amp;c. --</p>
<p>ought to be amended so as to read. -<span class='line-break'></span>"The <ins>Secretary</ins> shall keep the Sup<sup>t</sup> constantly informed"<span class='line-break'> </span>for the reason that the Secretary prepares all these<span class='line-break'> </span>contracts, and keeps the <ins>record</ins> of them.</p>
<p><ins>Personally</ins>, I could find reason for omitting &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>suggest what will result in more labor to myself,<span class='line-break'> </span>while I happen to do the duties of Secretary, but I<span class='line-break'> </span>have no right to let my private interest stand in <span class='line-break'> </span>the way of the Corporation's.</p>
<p>Art. 31. Funerals.</p>
<p>I do not know but the Com<sup>ee</sup> will think the pro<span class='line-break'></span>hibition of "firing volleys" at military funerals is<span class='line-break'> </span>necessary for safety, but it is always practised by<span class='line-break'> </span>common consent, -- and I think it may be truly<span class='line-break'> </span>considered that the allowance of "music" within the<span class='line-break'> </span>grounds will operate as a sufficient notice to those<span class='line-break'> </span>who may be in there with horses. I have never known<span class='line-break'> </span>of an accident there resulting from "firing volleys".</p>
<p>As to danger to persons, the men are always ordered<span class='line-break'> </span>to "fire high". --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133734">
<h3><a name="page-1133734">CB01_0243</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>243</p>
<p>As two articles -- 8<sup>th</sup> &amp; 28<sup>th</sup>, have already<span class='line-break'> </span>been stricken out, and the 10<sup>th</sup> is to be, and the 28<sup>th</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>has been replaced by another, viz. "Work on Lots" -<span class='line-break'></span>and as I propose two or three other articles<span class='line-break'> </span>as essential or useful (hereinafter written out)<span class='line-break'> </span>and as some of the existing articles might<span class='line-break'> </span>be improved in collocation, for convenience of<span class='line-break'> </span>reference,</p>
<p>I recommend a reorganization and<span class='line-break'> </span>renumbering of the By-laws, to be arranged<span class='line-break'> </span>in the following order. --</p>
<p>No change occurs in the <span class='line-break'> </span>order of the first fifteen articles, which by the abolish<span class='line-break'></span>ment of the 8<sup>th</sup> &amp; 10<sup>th</sup>, become reduced to thirteen in<span class='line-break'> </span>number, and numbers 9, 11, 12, 13, 14 &amp; 15 become 8, 9,<span class='line-break'> </span>10, 11, 12 &amp; 13. --</p>
<p>As I illustrated some of the changes<span class='line-break'> </span>needed at the beginning of these notes, I will indi<span class='line-break'></span>cate what appears to me to be the best arrange<span class='line-break'></span>ment, according to the subjects, by drawing out<span class='line-break'> </span>a list of the titles of the different by-laws,<span class='line-break'> </span>annexing both the new and old numbers. --</p>
<p>Also a list of the titles of matters con<span class='line-break'></span>tained in the Appendixes --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133735">
<h3><a name="page-1133735">CB01_0244</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>244</p>
<p>7</p>
<p>Arrangement of<span class='line-break'> </span><u> Titles of Articles of By Laws --</u></p>

Lot</a></td> </tr> <tr><td>H.</td> <td>Form of Applic<sup>n</sup> &amp; Permit for Work on Lots</td> </tr> <tr><td>I.</td> <td>Form of Donation in Trust for Repair of Lot</td> </tr> <tr><td>K.</td> <td>Form of Don. in Tr. for <u>Perpet<sup>l</sup></u> Rep. of Lots with Guaranty</td> </tr> <tr><td>L.</td> <td>Regulations Concerning Visitors</td> </tr> </tbody> </table></p>

<div id="page-1133736">
<h3><a name="page-1133736">CB01_0245</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>245</p>
<p>Art. 18. Records -- (Proposed new Arts.)</p>
<p>"There shall be kept at the Office of the <span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary all the books necessary for recording the orig<span class='line-break'></span>inal deeds of lots, of Ornamental Ground, and<span class='line-break'> </span>of Spaces between Lots; of Transfers from pro<span class='line-break'></span>prietor to proprietor, or from proprietors to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation; and transfers by Will, or by Opera<span class='line-break'></span>tion of Law: also instruments of Donation in<span class='line-break'> </span>Trust, for the repair of lots, or for any purpose<span class='line-break'> </span>consistent with the objects of the Cemetery: and no<span class='line-break'> </span><del>other</del> record elsewhere shall be necessary<span class='line-break'> </span>to protect the rights of proprietors. But<span class='line-break'> </span>no record of any person's interest in a lot<span class='line-break'> </span>which is less than the entire ownership shall<span class='line-break'> </span>be made on the books of the Corporation.</p>
<p>The same fee shall be paid at the<span class='line-break'> </span>Office of the Secretary for the record of<span class='line-break'> </span>transfers and other instruments for propri<span class='line-break'></span>etors, and giving the due certificate of the<span class='line-break'> </span>same as is charged for making and recording<span class='line-break'> </span>original deeds. --</p>
<p>The Register of Interments shall also<span class='line-break'> </span>be made up by the Secretary in duplicate, one<span class='line-break'> </span>copy of which shall be kept at his office,<span class='line-break'> </span>and one at the Cemetery.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133737">
<h3><a name="page-1133737">CB01_0246</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>246</p>
<p>Art. 29. Neglected Lots.</p>
<p>"The Superintendent shall on or before the first<span class='line-break'> </span>Monday in April each year report to the Trustees<span class='line-break'> </span>a list of all lots which may be so much out<span class='line-break'> </span>of repair as to detract from the general good<span class='line-break'> </span>appearance of the Cemetery, upon which the propri<span class='line-break'></span>etors of said lots or other persons interested there<span class='line-break'></span>in, shall be notified by the Secretary of their con<span class='line-break'></span>dition, and be urgently requested to put them in<span class='line-break'> </span>repair.</p>
<p>In cases of gross neglect when proprietors shall<span class='line-break'> </span>omit or refuse to repair their lots, after such notice,<span class='line-break'> </span>it shall be within the discretion of the Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>to cause suitable repairs to be done at the expense of <span class='line-break'> </span>the proprietors.</p>
<p>Art. 28 Bounds of Lots</p>
<p>"The Superintendent, when a burial lot or other<span class='line-break'> </span>parcel of ground shall have been sold, shall within<span class='line-break'> </span>thirty days thereafter, at the expense of the proprietor of said<span class='line-break'> </span>lot or parcel of ground, put down suitable granite bound<span class='line-break'></span>ary posts, and cause the number of the lot to be<span class='line-break'> </span>legibly cut upon one of said posts, unless the proprietor shall<span class='line-break'> </span>within that time give a satisfactory obligation that he<span class='line-break'> </span>will immediately proceed to erect a fence or curb upon<span class='line-break'> </span>his lot, with the number unscribed.</p>
<p>(over)</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133738">
<h3><a name="page-1133738">CB01_0247</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>247</p>
<p>In all cases, where lots other than those<span class='line-break'> </span>above-described shall be found destitute of suitable<span class='line-break'> </span>bounds, or numbers, whether by original neglect,<span class='line-break'> </span>or by decay, the Superintendent shall report the<span class='line-break'> </span>same to the Trustees: and if the proprietors<span class='line-break'> </span>or owners shall not direct such bounds or<span class='line-break'> </span>numbers to be placed upon their lots within thirty<span class='line-break'> </span>days after being duly notified by the Secretary, the<span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent shall cause the same to be done<span class='line-break'> </span>at the expense of said proprietors or owners." --</p>
<p>Art. 32 Reconveyance to the Corporation.</p>
<p>In any case, where a proprietor shall<span class='line-break'> </span>have contracted with the Corporation, upon the pay<span class='line-break'></span>ment of a specific sum for the care and preser<span class='line-break'></span>vation of his lot forever, and shall desire to place<span class='line-break'> </span>his lot in perpetual trust for the purpose of<span class='line-break'> </span>restricting the right-of-burial, or for any other legit<span class='line-break'></span>imate object, he may, with the counsel<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Committee on Lots reconvey his lot to<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation, to hold the same forever, for<span class='line-break'> </span>the uses and trusts expressed in his deed of<span class='line-break'> </span>reconveyance; reserving to himself and such heirs<span class='line-break'> </span>as may be beneficiaries under the trust, the rights<span class='line-break'> </span>of admission: and such supervision as is not in<span class='line-break'></span>consistent with the rights which have vested in<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation." --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133739">
<h3><a name="page-1133739">CB01_0248</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>248</p>
<p>I had not expected, when commencing<span class='line-break'> </span>this work, <del>of</del> finding so much to be done,<span class='line-break'> </span>and of drawing out these remarks to such<span class='line-break'> </span>length.</p>
<p>I could not well omit anything which<span class='line-break'> </span>I have noted, nor have given the reasons<span class='line-break'> </span>for amendment in much shorter terms.</p>
<p>But now that I have gone through the<span class='line-break'> </span>by-laws, I am not at all surprized at<span class='line-break'> </span>finding so much which needs a change,<span class='line-break'> </span>as the necessities of the Corporation have<span class='line-break'> </span>been constantly growing, and the<span class='line-break'> </span>By-laws were nine years since launched<span class='line-break'> </span>forth for trial.</p>
<p>I shall be ready to attend any<span class='line-break'> </span>meeting of the Committee on revision, if<span class='line-break'> </span>desired, and should like, at least, to<span class='line-break'> </span>go over them with you.</p>
<p>Very Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133740">
<h3><a name="page-1133740">CB01_0249</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1865-03-09'>March 29. 5 [1865]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70539' title='Hale, George S.'>Geo. S. Hale</a> Esq -- Ex<sup>or</sup> &amp;c.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>have instructed me to notify you<span class='line-break'> </span>that they will contract, subject to<span class='line-break'> </span>the approval of the Trustees, for the per<span class='line-break'></span>petual care and preservation of <a href='/pages/subjects/56688' title='Lot 1397'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>no. 1397</a> belonging to the estate of the<span class='line-break'> </span>late <a href='/pages/subjects/67869' title='Sargent, Solomon'>Solomon Sargent</a>, for four hun<span class='line-break'></span>dred dollars; and of that lot<span class='line-break'> </span>together with <a href='/pages/subjects/70540' title='Lot 1398'>1398</a>, belonging to <a href='/pages/subjects/70541' title='Stearns, Thomas'>Thomas<span class='line-break'> </span>Stearns</a> -- being in one enclosure --<span class='line-break'> </span>for seven hundred dollars.</p>
<p>I am Respectfully</p>
<p>Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv.<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1865-03-29'>March 29 5 [1865]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/71286' title='Converse, James C.'>J.C. Converse</a> Esq<sup>re</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots have instructed me to<span class='line-break'> </span>notify you that they are ready<span class='line-break'> </span>to contract with, subject to the<span class='line-break'> </span>approval of the Trustees, for the<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetual care and preservation<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/70543' title='Lot 726'>lot no 726</a> belonging to the estate<span class='line-break'> </span>of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/70544' title='Peabody, Catherine'>Catherine Peabody</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>on payment of four hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>and fifty dollars.</p>
<p>If their terms are satisfactory,<span class='line-break'> </span>I will prepare the papers<span class='line-break'> </span>for you. --</p>
<p>Respectfully</p>
<p>Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>249</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133741">
<h3><a name="page-1133741">CB01_0250</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1865-03-29'>March 29 5 [1865]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/64830' title='Gassett, Henry'>Henry Gassett</a> Esq</p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have laid<span class='line-break'> </span>the subject of the perpetual care of your<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64829' title='Lot 2113'>lot, No 2113</a>, before the Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots,<span class='line-break'> </span>for a revision of their opinion, after<span class='line-break'> </span>obtaining from the Sup.<sup>t</sup> a new report<span class='line-break'> </span>on the same -- and they have instructed<span class='line-break'> </span>me to inform you that they will<span class='line-break'> </span>contract for such perpetual preservation<span class='line-break'> </span>for six hundred dollars. --</p>
<p>My own opinion is that you will<span class='line-break'> </span>do well to accept these terms, as those<span class='line-break'> </span>as low as any I have ever known<span class='line-break'> </span>upon so large a lot, with such val<span class='line-break'></span>uable appurtenances as yours. --</p>
<p>I mentioned that you were willing to<span class='line-break'> </span>pay $500, but they did not feel it safe<span class='line-break'> </span>to accept that sum. --</p>
<p>I am Very Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1865-04-11'>April 11<sup>th</sup>5 [1865]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70545' title='Norris, G. D.'>G.D. Norris</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/70546' title='Milwaukee, WI'>Milwaukee Wis.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A note from<span class='line-break'> </span>you which authorizes the interment of <a href='/pages/subjects/70547' title='Wilkins, Henry'>Henry<span class='line-break'> </span>Wilkins</a> in your lot on the <date when='1865-01-30'>30<sup>th</sup> Jany. 1865</date>, contains<span class='line-break'> </span>the information that your father <a href='/pages/subjects/70548' title='Norris, S. H.'>S.H. Norris</a> is not<span class='line-break'> </span>living. As our records do not show his interment<span class='line-break'> </span>in the lot, or in the Cemetery, I had no means<span class='line-break'> </span>of knowing the fact of his death. --</p>
<p>The accompanying blank contains informa<span class='line-break'></span>tion for the direction of heirs and devisees upon<span class='line-break'> </span>the decease of a proprietor. It is applicable<span class='line-break'> </span>in all cases, where the proprietor has left<span class='line-break'> </span>more than <ins>one</ins> heir at law, or where he has<span class='line-break'> </span>not devised his lot to one person, either directly<span class='line-break'> </span>or indirectly in his will. --</p>
<p>Will you please have it filled up and<span class='line-break'> </span>executed by the proper persons (if it applies to this<span class='line-break'> </span>lot) ^<sup>including yourself,</sup> and return it to me.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a>, Secretary</p>
<p>250</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133742">
<h3><a name="page-1133742">CB01_0251</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1865-04-12'>April 12 5 [1865]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I am informed<span class='line-break'> </span>by a lady that <a href='/pages/subjects/70549' title='Fales, Haliburton'>Haliburton Fales</a> of <a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Rep. of <a href='/pages/subjects/70550' title='Lot 518'>lot 518</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/61127' title='Beech Avenue'>Beech Av<sup>e</sup></a>, met <a href='/pages/subjects/70551' title='Gardner, Henry N.'>H.N. Gardner</a><span class='line-break'> </span>a few days ago at <a href='/pages/subjects/57664' title='Entrance Gateway'>the Gate,</a> who represented him<span class='line-break'></span>self as "the Gardener", and engaged him to take<span class='line-break'> </span>charge of his lot. The lady says she [orders?]<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/70549' title='Fales, Haliburton'>Fales</a> (I do not understand which as I did not<span class='line-break'> </span>see her) is very indignant to learn that he<span class='line-break'> </span>is not "the Gardener", and she desires me<span class='line-break'> </span>to ask you to see that he does not enter upon<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot. She positively forbids his touching it.<span class='line-break'> </span>She wishes the Corporation to take care of it.</p>
<p>I think you will have to put the permit<span class='line-break'> </span>rule in force. <a href='/pages/subjects/70551' title='Gardner, Henry N.'>Gardner</a> has not been after one,<span class='line-break'> </span>this year.</p>
<p>Will you please ask <a href='/pages/subjects/52579' title='Safford, Truman H.'>Mr Safford</a><span class='line-break'> </span>to have the March orders of interm<sup>t</sup> ready<span class='line-break'> </span>for me tomorrow morn (Fast Day.)</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1865-04-14'>April 14 5 [1865]</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
