Coolidge</a></p>
<p>342</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133834">
<h3><a name="page-1133834">CB01_0343</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1866-09-12'>Sept. 12 [186]6</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79767' title='Shute, James M.'>Jas. M. Shute Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots have directed me to notify<span class='line-break'> </span>you that they will contract for<span class='line-break'> </span>the perpetual repair of <a href='/pages/subjects/79729' title='Lot 2015'>lot no.<span class='line-break'> </span>2015</a> (late <a href='/pages/subjects/79730' title='Phelps, Sewall'>Sewell Phelps</a>) subject<span class='line-break'> </span>to the concurrence of of the Board<span class='line-break'> </span>of Trustees for five hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars. Without the sarcopha<span class='line-break'></span>gas of Italian Marble the estimate<span class='line-break'> </span>would probably have not exceeded<span class='line-break'> </span>$250 or $400. The guaranty im<span class='line-break'></span>plies the renewal of things des<span class='line-break'></span>troyed.</p>
<p>When notified of the acceptance<span class='line-break'> </span>of these terms, I will prepare the<span class='line-break'> </span>papers.</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1866-09-12'>Sept 12<sup>th</sup> [186]6</date></p>
<p>Hon. <a href='/pages/subjects/71385' title='Stevenson, J. T.'>J.T. Stevenson</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A charge of $2.<span class='line-break'> </span>stands against you on our books<span class='line-break'> </span>for recording transfer of <a href='/pages/subjects/71386' title='lot 920'>lot 920</a> to you.</p>
<p>In your note of <date when='1865-08-22'>Aug 22<sup>d</sup> 1865</date> when <span class='line-break'> </span>you sent the deed for record, at my re<span class='line-break'></span>quest, you say "I think that you err<span class='line-break'> </span>in supposing that it was not left with you<span class='line-break'> </span>for record on the <date when='1866-05-28'>28<sup>th</sup> of May 1866</date>."</p>
<p>My recollection of that matter is clear.<span class='line-break'> </span>Mr <a href='/pages/subjects/79769' title='Appleton, Charles'>Chas. Cook[?] Appleton</a> came in and<span class='line-break'> </span>said he wished to transfer the lot to you.<span class='line-break'> </span>I filled up the [deed?], went out of the office &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>got a $2 [Paid stamp?] for him -- he signed and acknow<span class='line-break'></span>ledged it before me. I asked him if he wished<span class='line-break'> </span>to leave it for record. He asked what was cus<span class='line-break'></span>tomary. I said it is the duty of the purchaser<span class='line-break'> </span>to record his deed. He said he would<span class='line-break'> </span>get his money and pass the deed to<span class='line-break'> </span>you, and let you attend to that.</p>
<p>343</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133835">
<h3><a name="page-1133835">CB01_0344</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>He paid me for drawing the transfer<span class='line-break'> </span>and the stamps.</p>
<p>The charge made to you is the<span class='line-break'> </span>same made to all other persons<span class='line-break'> </span>as regulated by vote of the Trustees,<span class='line-break'> </span>when a deed is sent for record.</p>
<p>It is not a matter of much<span class='line-break'> </span>consequence. We can afford to<span class='line-break'> </span>lose it, if you object to pay it:<span class='line-break'> </span>but I felt it my duty to <del>explain</del><span class='line-break'> </span>state the facts to you, and you <span class='line-break'> </span>can act your pleasure.</p>
<p>Very Respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79771' title='Worcester, F. A.'>F A. Worcester</a> Esq<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79772' title='Townsend, MA'>Townsend, Mass.</a></p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>I am anxious<span class='line-break'> </span>to learn what is the place of residence<span class='line-break'> </span>of any of the children of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/60693' title='Haskell, Aaron'>Aaron<span class='line-break'> </span>Haskell</a> of <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, who died in 1839,<span class='line-break'> </span>leaving a widow <a href='/pages/subjects/79773' title='Haskell, Eleanor J.'>Eleanor J. (</a>whose<span class='line-break'> </span>maiden name was Pitts and her<span class='line-break'> </span>residence until marriage Townsend)<span class='line-break'> </span>children, <a href='/pages/subjects/60694' title='Haskell, Friend P.'>Friend P.,</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/79774' title='Haskell, Waldo'>Waldo,</a><span class='line-break'> </span>and <a href='/pages/subjects/79775' title='Haskell, Lydia'>Lydia Haskell</a>. Friend<span class='line-break'> </span>P. is said to have been employed<span class='line-break'> </span>for some years on the <a href='/pages/subjects/79776' title='Boston &amp; Maine Railroad'>Bost. &amp; Me.<span class='line-break'> </span>Rail<sup>d</sup></a> (I didn't learn when) Waldo<span class='line-break'> </span>went to California -- became poor &amp; wished<span class='line-break'> </span>to return, &amp; Lydia died.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60693' title='Haskell, Aaron'>Aaron Haskell</a> was a native<span class='line-break'> </span>of [Templeton?] &amp; kept a public house<span class='line-break'> </span>at the north end of this city.</p>
<p>By the Probate records in</p>
<p>344</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133836">
<h3><a name="page-1133836">CB01_0345</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>in Suffolk, it appears that the<span class='line-break'> </span>widow -- <a href='/pages/subjects/79773' title='Haskell, Eleanor J.'>Eleanor J. <!--Haskell--></a>had, sometime<span class='line-break'> </span>before the 12<sup>th</sup> July 1841, married<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79779' title='Church, Asa'>Asa Church</a>, as she and her<span class='line-break'> </span>husband then rendered a guardian's<span class='line-break'> </span>account.</p>
<p>I have written to several persons --<span class='line-break'> </span>have rec<sup>d</sup> letters from <a href='/pages/subjects/79780' title='Winchendon &amp; Templeton'>Winchendon &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>Templeton</a>, the last of which advised<span class='line-break'> </span>me to write to the Postmaster at<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79772' title='Townsend, MA'>Townsend</a>, on the ground that he<span class='line-break'> </span>might ascertain what I wished<span class='line-break'> </span>from members of the Pitts<span class='line-break'> </span>family residing there, but I don't<span class='line-break'> </span>like to write to Postmasters, and if<span class='line-break'> </span>you know of any of the Pitts family,<span class='line-break'> </span>you will much oblige me by<span class='line-break'> </span>making the inquiry contained herein.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/60693' title='Haskell, Aaron'>Aaron Haskell</a> was the prop<sup>r</sup> of one<span class='line-break'> </span>of the earliest lots in the Cemetery, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>it is quite desirable to learn where<span class='line-break'> </span>either of the sons may be found.</p>
<p>Yours Very Resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>P.S. I do not yet hear from<span class='line-break'> </span>you relating to your brother's<span class='line-break'> </span>lot. Our catalogue has not yet<span class='line-break'> </span>gone to press, and I hope to hear<span class='line-break'> </span>soon.</p>
<p>345</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133837">
<h3><a name="page-1133837">CB01_0346</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1866-09-22'>Sept 22 [186]6</date></p>
<p>Miss <a href='/pages/subjects/79781' title='Haliburton, Georgiana'>Georgiana Haliburton</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>The Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots have directed me to notify<span class='line-break'> </span>you that the Corporation will assume<span class='line-break'> </span>the perpetual care of your <a href='/pages/subjects/73789' title='Lot 3572'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>no. 3572</a> for the sum of<span class='line-break'> </span>two hundred dollars. --</p>
<p>When notified of your accep<span class='line-break'></span>tance I will prepare the<span class='line-break'> </span>necessary papers.</p>
<p>Very Respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1866-10-03'>Octo. 3<sup>d</sup> [186]6</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79782' title='Flagg, Josiah Foster, Mrs.'>Mrs J. F. Flagg</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>The Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots, in accordance with your<span class='line-break'> </span>request, have considered the<span class='line-break'> </span>question of the perpetual repair of<span class='line-break'> </span>your <a href='/pages/subjects/79755' title='Lot 77'>lot, no. 77</a>; and they have<span class='line-break'> </span>directed me to inform you that<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation will guarantee<span class='line-break'> </span>the perpetual repair of the same<span class='line-break'> </span>for the sum of three hun<span class='line-break'></span>dred and fifty dollars.</p>
<p>When notified of your ac<span class='line-break'></span>ceptance, I will prepare the<span class='line-break'> </span>papers.</p>
<p>Very Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>346</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133838">
<h3><a name="page-1133838">CB01_0347</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>347</p>
<p><date when='1866-09-26'>Sept. 26, 1866</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>As the Committee on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>wish to pay you a visit, and the following lots, which <span class='line-break'> </span>are destitute of numbers, gave them some trouble on<span class='line-break'> </span>their last visit, it seems to me that it will be well<span class='line-break'> </span>for you forthwith to have the numbers cut on the stone post,<span class='line-break'> </span>or wherever you can to best advantage. Probably most of<span class='line-break'> </span>them will pay the bill, the remainder the Corporation must<span class='line-break'> </span>pay:</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th><a href='/pages/subjects/61545' title='Lot 692'><!--Lot-->692</a></th> <th><a href='/pages/subjects/61194' title='Greenbrier Path'>Greenbrier P.</a></th> <th><a href='/pages/subjects/79783' title='Mason, Lois'>Lois Mason's</a> heirs --</th> <th>Rep.</th> <th><a href='/pages/subjects/62306' title='Fiske, Nathan'>Nathan Fiske</a> - <a href='/pages/subjects/53203' title='Cambridge, MA'>Cambridge</a><span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/71795' title='Lot 833'><!--Lot-->833</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61304' title='Yarrow Path'>Yarrow P.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/71805' title='Doane, Caroline'>Caroline Doane</a>'s heirs --</td> <td>"</td> <td>? </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/74845' title='Lot 439'><!--Lot-->439</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/54338' title='Indian Ridge Path'>Indian Ridge</a> P.</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/58355' title='Shaw, Charles B.'>Charles B. Shaw</a> --</td> <td>-</td> <td>Tremont Bk. 41 State St</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/60668' title='Lot 473'><!--Lot-->473</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61127' title='Beech Avenue'>Beech Av.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/64019' title='Putnam, Catherine'>Catherine Putnam's</a> heirs</td> <td>-</td> <td>Corp<sup>n</sup> in trust</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/57820' title='Lot 497'><!--Lot-->497</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/60336' title='Willow Avenue'>Willow Av</a>.</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/53154' title='Lombard, Israel'>Israel Lombard</a>'s heirs</td> <td>Rep.</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/79784' title='Lombard, Israel, Mrs.'>Mrs Israel Lombard</a></td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/79785' title='Lot 575'><!--Lot-->575</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/79786' title='Pilgram Path'>Pilgrim P.</a></td> <td>Dr <a href='/pages/subjects/55020' title='Shattuck, George C.'>Geo. C. Shattuck</a></td> <td>-</td> <td>15 Pemberton Sq.</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/66017' title='Lot 587'><!--Lot-->587</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61234' title='Moss Path'>Moss P.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/66018' title='First Universalist Society'>First Universalist Soc.y</a></td> <td>-</td> <td>Corp<sup>n</sup> in trust</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/72204' title='Lot 680'><!--Lot-->680</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61304' title='Yarrow Path'>Yarrow P.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/79788' title='Fessenden Mont'>Fessenden Mon<sup>t</sup></a></td> <td>-</td> <td>Corp<sup>n</sup> in trust</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/64058' title='Lot 859'><!--Lot-->859</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/57829' title='Snowdrop Path'>Snowdrop P.</a> -</td> <td>Mrs Nathan <a href='/pages/subjects/54995' title='Appleton, Samuel'>Appleton</a></td> <td>-</td> <td>(late <a href='/pages/subjects/64060' title='Sumner, Jesse'>Jesse Sumner</a>'s)</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/65941' title='Lot 2151'><!--Lot-->2151</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/79789' title='Grange Path'>Grange P.</a></td> <td>Samuel S. Osgood</td> <td>-</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York</a></td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/59939' title='Lot 2354'><!--Lot-->2354</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/60336' title='Willow Avenue'>Willow Av</a>.</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/59938' title='Bacon, John'>Dr John Bacon</a></td> <td>-</td> <td>15 Somerset St.</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>I notified owners of lots 692, 497, &amp; 859, and one or more<span class='line-break'> </span>of them may have ordered you to do the work. I am quite<span class='line-break'> </span>sure Mrs Lombard has (<a href='/pages/subjects/57820' title='lot 497'>lot 497</a>.)</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>Sec.y<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133839">
<h3><a name="page-1133839">CB01_0348</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1866-10-12'>Octo. 12 [186]6</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Please bring in<span class='line-break'> </span>a report upon the lot of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79862' title='Booth, Edwin'>Edwin Booth</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/79863' title='Lot 3281'><!--Lot-->3281</a>, -- 300 feet --<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/61115' title='Anemone Path'>Anemone Path</a>, for perpetual repair.</p>
<p>Mr Booth is fond of flowers,<span class='line-break'> </span>and would like to have included<span class='line-break'> </span>in the estimate a "moderate display"<span class='line-break'> </span>of flowers. I think he has paid<span class='line-break'> </span>about $10 for care of lot. You <span class='line-break'> </span>always set some in the border.<span class='line-break'> </span>I do not know that he desires<span class='line-break'> </span>much beyond what you do -- but<span class='line-break'> </span>wishes to stipulate for the setting of them.</p>
<p>By our usual contracts, we are not<span class='line-break'> </span>obliged to set flowers.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>348</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133840">
<h3><a name="page-1133840">CB01_0349</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>349</p>
<p><date when='1866-11-10'>Nov<sup>r</sup> 10 [186]6</date></p>
<p>Hon. <a href='/pages/subjects/55029' title='Silsbee, Nathaniel'>Nath<sup>l</sup> Silsbee</a>, Treas<sup>r</sup> <a href='/pages/subjects/59943' title='Harvard College'>Harv<sup>d</sup> Coll.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have carefully inquired<span class='line-break'> </span>into the matter of complaint of <a href='/pages/subjects/79864' title='Folsom, George M.'>Geo. M. Folsom</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>contained in the enclosed note, respecting the alleged<span class='line-break'> </span>breaking of the <a href='/pages/subjects/79865' title='Damon, Edward T.'>Damon Monument</a> on "<a href='/pages/subjects/60405' title='Harvard Hill'>Harvard Hill</a>"<span class='line-break'> </span>and have learned from the Superintendent, whose<span class='line-break'> </span>statements are [?] by others having proper<span class='line-break'> </span>means of knowledge, that the monument was <span class='line-break'> </span>observed prostrated <del>what</del> a year or more [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>on the next day after a fierce northwest gale<span class='line-break'> </span>which blew down a large pine tree within a<span class='line-break'> </span>hundred and fifty feet of this monument, tearing<span class='line-break'> </span>the tree out by the roots. The stump of the tree<span class='line-break'> </span>still remains there in position as it fell. Both<span class='line-break'> </span>the tree and monument fell in the same direc<span class='line-break'></span>tion -- up hill, i.e. the S.E. -- The Superintendent feels<span class='line-break'> </span>confident that the gale prostrated the stone.</p>
<p>Not so much for curiosity, as to examine<span class='line-break'> </span>the form and strength of this stone, I determined<span class='line-break'> </span>to visit the spot: and this I was unable to<span class='line-break'> </span>do until yesterday, which must be my apology<span class='line-break'> </span>for so long delay in making a <ins>written</ins> reply<span class='line-break'> </span>to the charge. Having stated to you some time since<span class='line-break'> </span>the Superintendent's method of accounting for it</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133841">
<h3><a name="page-1133841">CB01_0350</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>350</p>
<p>I found the tree &amp; stone fallen as stated<span class='line-break'> </span>by <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a>. The Stone is in Gothic style,<span class='line-break'> </span>surmounted by a cross, had stood on a base made<span class='line-break'> </span>tapering upwards to the height of 15 or 16 inches, ter<span class='line-break'></span>minating in an oblong socket of about 2 inches in depth,<span class='line-break'> </span>[to receive?] the bottom of the tablet. The tablet is say<span class='line-break'> </span>2 or 3 inches thick, four feet three inches high and<span class='line-break'> </span>two feet wide, and differs but little from an or<span class='line-break'></span>dinary grave stone in the surface which it presents<span class='line-break'> </span>and its capacity -- for resisting a strong wind: excepting<span class='line-break'> </span>that its [single?] position on the base rendered it more<span class='line-break'> </span>liable to be blown down.</p>
<p>The Stone appeard to have fallen nearly clean<span class='line-break'> </span>from the bottom of the socket, and in its fall to have<span class='line-break'> </span>broken in two in the middle. A portion of the stone<span class='line-break'> </span>however was left in the socket, which I took out with<span class='line-break'> </span>my fingers and have brought along &amp; send you,<span class='line-break'> </span>to let you see the nature of the stone as to the strength<span class='line-break'> </span>of materials. I think you will perceive that<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a> did not overstate the matter, when<span class='line-break'> </span>he said that a weaker or meaner stand he never<span class='line-break'> </span>saw wrought into a monument.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79864' title='Folsom, George M.'>Mr Folsom's</a> informants should state his<span class='line-break'> </span>means of knowledge, when he says that the "workman<span class='line-break'> </span>at Mount Auburn have broken and infused the<span class='line-break'> </span>monument". So far as I can learn, this<span class='line-break'> </span>statement was made from an inference<span class='line-break'> </span>that no work was going on last summer<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133842">
<h3><a name="page-1133842">CB01_0351</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>351</p>
<p>just below that place, around the border<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/60405' title='Harvard Hill'>Harvard Hill</a>, the monument must have<span class='line-break'> </span>been then and there broken.</p>
<p>The fact is, it was broken more than a<span class='line-break'> </span>year ago, at which time, and until,<span class='line-break'> </span>last April or May, nothing at all was<span class='line-break'> </span>being done in the neighborhood. There are<span class='line-break'> </span>now some beautiful lots finished on<span class='line-break'> </span>the outskirts of the hill, which do great<span class='line-break'> </span>credit to the taste and skill of the Super<span class='line-break'></span>intendent.</p>
<p>I regret the accident to the stone,<span class='line-break'> </span>even though the elements were the only witness<span class='line-break'> </span>thereto: but I sincerely hope that the<span class='line-break'> </span>Class of 1857 will use proper vigilance in<span class='line-break'> </span>seeing that no other memorial stone of<span class='line-break'> </span>such frail materials is substituted therefore.</p>
<p>I am</p>
<p>Very Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133843">
<h3><a name="page-1133843">CB01_0352</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1866-11-12'>Nov 12 [186]6</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>In getting return<span class='line-break'> </span>from the Treas<sup>r</sup> of the lots paid for, I <span class='line-break'> </span>find that you have not reported<span class='line-break'> </span>the following: -</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th><a href='/pages/subjects/79875' title='Lot 3703'><!--Lot-->3703</a></th> <th>- p<sup>d</sup> for <date when='1866-09-19'>Sep. 19<sup>th</sup></date></th> <th>$186. -<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>Addit<sup>n</sup> to <a href='/pages/subjects/79876' title='Lot 812'><!--Lot-->812</a></td> <td>- p<sup>d</sup> for <date when='1866-11-08'>Nov. 8</date> -</td> <td>$118</td> </tr> <tr><td>Addit<sup>n</sup> to <a href='/pages/subjects/79877' title='Lot 1640'><!--Lot-->1640</a></td> <td>p<sup>d</sup> for <date when='1866-11-07'>Nov. 7</date></td> <td>$232</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>Please report in your next. It is<span class='line-break'> </span>probable I shall be absent after<span class='line-break'> </span>tomorrow for the rest of the week,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/73016' title='Barker, Alexander Augustus'>Mr Barker</a> agreed to report the form<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; size of <a href='/pages/subjects/79877' title='lot 1640'>lot 1640</a> as now to be. -</p>
<p>Have you even ^<sup>re-</sup>sold the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot on <a href='/pages/subjects/61217' title='Lantana Path'>Lantana P.</a> (<a href='/pages/subjects/71371' title='Lot 3588'>3588</a>) once<span class='line-break'> </span>reported to ____ Chaplain, which [G. E.?]<span class='line-break'> </span>Hubbard neglected to pay for?<span class='line-break'> </span>Reported <date when='1865-07-15'>July 15, 1865</date> -</p>
<p>Yours Respectfully</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>352</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133844">
<h3><a name="page-1133844">CB01_0353</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>353</p>
<p><date when='1866-11-22'>Nov. 22 [186]6</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have consulted the President<span class='line-break'> </span>in reference to the name and numbering of the new<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/61319' title='Public Lot'>public Lot</a>, and he had decided as follows:--<span class='line-break'> </span>Name - <ins>"<a href='/pages/subjects/61319' title='Public Lot'>St. Paul.</a>"</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>Numbers - <ins>Begin at "One"</ins>; and as the lot is <span class='line-break'> </span>a large one, reserve the two hundred old numbers<span class='line-break'> </span>which you say are on hand to the time when they<span class='line-break'> </span>will be wanted, or plant them, if you like, where<span class='line-break'> </span>they will eventually be wanted.</p>
<p>Please have the record of interments correspond<span class='line-break'> </span>with this. I think <a href='/pages/subjects/79781' title='Haliburton, Georgiana'>Miss Haliburton</a> had a certificate last<span class='line-break'> </span>Saturday which had been issued to Mr Cunard of<span class='line-break'> </span>Halifax as "247 ___ lot." which should be "1 St Paul."</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79880' title='Winship, F. Lyman'>Mr F. Lyman Winship</a>, prop<sup>r</sup>  of <a href='/pages/subjects/62830' title='Lot 422'><!--Lot-->422</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/58791' title='Central Avenue'>Central<span class='line-break'> </span>Av.</a> wishes a report made on that lot in respect<span class='line-break'> </span>to perpet. repair. He says there are no monuments, headstones<span class='line-break'> </span>or fence.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79881' title='Bond, Charlotte J.'>Mrs Charlotte J. Bond</a> of <a href='/pages/subjects/71564' title='Lowell, MA'>Lowell</a> wishes the work<span class='line-break'> </span>of resodding &amp;c. which was to the done on <a href='/pages/subjects/79882' title='Lot 1813'>lots 1813</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/79883' title='Lot 1814'><!--lot-->1814</a><span class='line-break'> </span>to be done this fall, if possible.</p>
<p>Yours Resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133845">
<h3><a name="page-1133845">CB01_0354</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>354</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> <date when='1867-01-12'>January 12, 1867</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79889' title='French, E. B., Hon.'>Hon E. B. French.</a></p>
<p>Sir,</p>
<p>In the case of <a href='/pages/subjects/79890' title='Gallagher, William'>W<sup>m</sup> Gallagher</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Co K. 59<sup>th</sup> Mass. Vols. Died <date when='1864-08-13'>Aug. 13. 1864</date>, <del>allow</del></p>
<p>Allow me to state why the claim should be<span class='line-break'> </span>taken from the suspended list, and settled in<span class='line-break'> </span>behalf of the claimant.</p>
<p>1<sup>st</sup> There is no real contradiction in the two<span class='line-break'> </span>deposition of witnesses Conolly and Delaney when under<span class='line-break'></span>stood -</p>
<p>2<sup>d</sup> The claimant and the witnesses are both of<span class='line-break'> </span>the highest respectability, so far as I can learn -</p>
<p>3<sup>r</sup> The necessities of claimant's family urges haste.</p>
<p>Under the first head there cannot have been the slightest<span class='line-break'> </span>intention to vary from the truth. The term "perjury" is a<span class='line-break'> </span>cruel word in this case. The claimant and witnesses told<span class='line-break'> </span>a fair story, with all the appearance of truthfulness. She stated<span class='line-break'> </span>that <a href='/pages/subjects/79893' title='Gallagher, John'>her brother John</a> was in the army, and she was ashamed<span class='line-break'> </span>to say deserted, that he was a "bad behaved boy," that he<span class='line-break'> </span>went away, and neither she nor her friends had heard from<span class='line-break'> </span>him for years, or I understood them. That they had seen<span class='line-break'> </span>an account of a destructive explosion and his name<span class='line-break'> </span>was among the names of the killed, and they verily believed<span class='line-break'> </span>that he was the person felt satisfied that he was.<span class='line-break'> </span>They had no doubt of his death, and as they were<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133846">
<h3><a name="page-1133846">CB01_0355</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>355</p>
<p>so well satisfied of it, although the means of verifica<span class='line-break'></span>tion were not at hand, I wrote out the testimony<span class='line-break'> </span>of the witnesses, without thinking a more particular<span class='line-break'> </span>statement necessary; and it was signed and<span class='line-break'> </span>sworn to as a bona fide statement according to their<span class='line-break'> </span>best knowledge and belief. They still believe their<span class='line-break'> </span>first statement to be true.</p>
<p>When you asked for more particular proof as to<span class='line-break'> </span>what had become of other heirs, I made a more<span class='line-break'> </span>formal inquiry, and found that I could not substan<span class='line-break'></span>tiate <a href='/pages/subjects/79893' title='Gallagher, John'>John Gallagher's</a> death from record evidence, and<span class='line-break'> </span>did not know of whom to inquire, as the alleged incident<span class='line-break'> </span>took place on the other side of the continent. It then<span class='line-break'> </span>occurred to me that I ought to have used the fact of<span class='line-break'> </span>his desertion, as that was positively stated. The claimant<span class='line-break'> </span>at first gave me the wrong regiment by mistake, and I<span class='line-break'> </span>could not find it for some time. But the moment she<span class='line-break'> </span>corrected the error, I found that <a href='/pages/subjects/79893' title='Gallagher, John'>John Gallagher</a> stands<span class='line-break'> </span>upon the Massachusetts rolls as a deserter, as shown<span class='line-break'> </span>by the certificate sent. I accordingly prepared the<span class='line-break'> </span>last testimony to meet their fact.</p>
<p>It is no less true now than before that the claimant<span class='line-break'> </span>and the witnesses are satisfied of the death of said John, but<span class='line-break'> </span>as the means of proof were not at hand, I shaped the<span class='line-break'> </span>language so as to leave that a matter of belief rather<span class='line-break'> </span>than certainty. I sent the paper to <a href='/pages/subjects/64824' title='Waltham, MA'>Waltham</a>, ten miles<span class='line-break'> </span>away, and the witness executed it there.</p>
<p>Under the 2<sup>d</sup> suggestion - I have to say, that I have<span class='line-break'> </span>never had two witnesses appear more intelligent and</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133847">
<h3><a name="page-1133847">CB01_0356</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>356</p>
<p>conscientious I think they were particularly careful<span class='line-break'> </span>to state^<sup>only</sup> what they felt a conviction of the truth of.<span class='line-break'> </span>They were both quite old men, &amp; are well known in<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64824' title='Waltham, MA'>Waltham</a> as men of high respectability. One I <span class='line-break'> </span>think is an uncle of claimant's husband, but neither<span class='line-break'> </span>have any interest in the claim. There are six young<span class='line-break'> </span>children and a husband between claimant and <span class='line-break'> </span>any other person who could have a possible interest.<span class='line-break'> </span>Both the claimant and her husband, so far as<span class='line-break'> </span>I can learn are highly respectable and industrious.</p>
<p>3<sup>d</sup> <a href='/pages/subjects/79894' title='Conolly, Francis'>Mr Francis Conolly</a> the husband is a <span class='line-break'> </span>weaver - has been out of business for two months,<span class='line-break'> </span>by reason of woolen mills stopping. He has been every<span class='line-break'></span>where looking for work, &amp; having a wife and six young<span class='line-break'> </span>children, is sorely pressed now for means to live.</p>
<p>For the sake of hungry children, let nothing, I<span class='line-break'> </span>entreat you, short of punishable fraud, make<span class='line-break'> </span>delay in their claim. The appeals made to me can only reach<span class='line-break'> </span>you through me. Personally, I care nothing about it, but<span class='line-break'> </span>I am persuaded of their righteousness of their case.</p>
<p>I have never knowingly or carelessly, that I can<span class='line-break'> </span>find, taken in hand an unjust claim. I am well known<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/79898' title='Sumner, Charles'>Senators Sumner</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/79899' title='Wilson, Henry'><!--Henry-->Wilson</a> &amp; many others I could<span class='line-break'> </span>name: among them ass<sup>t</sup> P.M. Gen<sup>l</sup> M<sup>c</sup> Lellan- and I assure<span class='line-break'> </span>you the Government will not suffer in this case.</p>
<p>I trust you may deem this explanation sufficient.</p>
<p>Very Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133848">
<h3><a name="page-1133848">CB01_0357</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-01-08'>Jany 80 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Please send the<span class='line-break'> </span>items who you gave the Doctor, if<span class='line-break'> </span>you returned a copy; if not I <span class='line-break'> </span>will send to him for the note.</p>
<p>I wish information<span class='line-break'> </span>of the location of the following<span class='line-break'> </span>numbers for the catalogue. I <span class='line-break'> </span>will give a list, &amp; insert any that<span class='line-break'> </span>I happen to know,  &amp; lots are un<span class='line-break'></span>sold. You will remember<span class='line-break'> </span>that you were to locate them<span class='line-break'> </span>for sale, &amp; have probably done<span class='line-break'> </span>so. Please state the <ins>contents</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>of each.</p>
<p>(Over)</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th/> <th>Location</th> <th>No. feet.</th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/72181' title='Lot 284'><!--Lot-->284</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/71554' title='Lot 341'><!--Lot-->341</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/72182' title='Lot 342'><!--Lot-->342</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/71557' title='Lot 348'><!--Lot-->348</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/72183' title='Lot 373'><!--Lot-->373</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/72184' title='Lot 374'><!--Lot-->374</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/79901' title='Lot 423'><!--Lot-->423</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/79902' title='Lot 424'><!--Lot-->424</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/67066' title='Lot 525'><!--Lot-->525</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/72187' title='Lot 531'><!--Lot-->531</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61147' title='Celastrus Path'>Celastrus P.</a></td> <td>300 - </td> </tr> <tr><td/> <td>not <a href='/pages/subjects/71298' title='Lot 541'><!--Lot-->541</a> as you reported Dec. 8 '66</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/71414' title='Lot 536'><!--Lot-->536</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61129' title='Bellflower Path'>Bellflower P.</a></td> <td>134 </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/72188' title='Lot 576'><!--Lot-->576</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/79903' title='Lot 1063'><!--Lot-->1063</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/57668' title='Chestnut Avenue'>Chestnut Av.</a></td> <td>300 </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/79904' title='Lot 1064'><!--Lot-->1064</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/57668' title='Chestnut Avenue'>Chestnut Av.</a></td> <td>300 </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/79905' title='Lot 2420'><!--Lot-->2420</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/59904' title='Spruce Avenue'>Spruce Av.</a> rear of <a href='/pages/subjects/79906' title='Lot 1987'><!--Lot-->1987</a></td> <td>300 </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/71371' title='Lot 3588'>3588</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61217' title='Lantana Path'>Lantana P.</a></td> <td>300 </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/79907' title='Lot 3691'><!--Lot-->3691</a></td> <td/> <td/> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>Please indicate if any of these<span class='line-break'> </span>are not yet used. Probably the<span class='line-break'> </span>last is not.</p>
<p>Yours truly <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>357</p>
</div>
</div>

<div id="page-1133849">
<h3><a name="page-1133849">CB01_0358</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-01-30'>Jany 30 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo W<sup>m</sup> Bond Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Shall I enter<span class='line-break'> </span>in the catalogues the name of<span class='line-break'> </span>____ Lenox, against <a href='/pages/subjects/79912' title='Lot 3628'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>3628</a> on <a href='/pages/subjects/58081' title='Halcyon Avenue'>Halcyon Av<sup>e</sup></a> ?<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79913' title='Lot 3672'>Lot 3672</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/61235' title='Mound Avenue'>Mound Av<sup>e</sup></a> <a href='/pages/subjects/79926' title='Winchester, A.'>[Amasa?] Winchester</a><span class='line-break'> </span>also appears to be unpaid for. Shall<span class='line-break'> </span>I enter that? $736 is amt. ow.<span class='line-break'> </span>Also <a href='/pages/subjects/79915' title='Lot 3727'>3727</a> - <a href='/pages/subjects/72315' title='Fountain Avenue'>Fountain Av.</a> [reported?] to<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79916' title='Tyler, J. S., Gen.'>Gen. J. S. Tyler</a> Nov. 24/66?</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1867-02-07'>Feby 7 [186]7</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/57848' title='Merriam, Charles'>Mr Chas. Merriam</a><span class='line-break'> </span>wishes you to report on sale at<span class='line-break'> </span>burial prices the space between<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79917' title='Lot 2922'>lots 2922</a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/67109' title='Lot 3366'>3366</a>, which by scale<span class='line-break'> </span>amounts to 140 f - i.e. 20 ft deep<span class='line-break'> </span>by 6 f front, and 8 ft back - On<span class='line-break'> </span>the matter of price he wished me to<span class='line-break'> </span>say that he though you ought<span class='line-break'> </span>to let them have it at $1.00 per<span class='line-break'> </span>foot. I gave him no assurance<span class='line-break'> </span>that you could do so, but told<span class='line-break'> </span>him I thought you would do what<span class='line-break'> </span>you considered to be just right.</p>
<p>As to the contents of space perhaps<span class='line-break'> </span>you had better measure it, although<span class='line-break'> </span>I don't doubt that this is practically<span class='line-break'> </span>correct.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79918' title='Merriam, Caroline'>Mrs Merriam</a> is to be credited<span class='line-break'> </span>with the amount paid for space</p>
<p>358</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133850">
<h3><a name="page-1133850">CB01_0359</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>between the two lots, and the amount<span class='line-break'> </span>paid for the westerly space which is<span class='line-break'> </span>in excess of what should have been<span class='line-break'> </span>charged.</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>The E. passageway is 30 x 3 =</th> <th>90<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>The W. passageway excess is 7 x 3 =</td> <td>21</td> </tr> <tr><td/> <td>111 f</td> </tr> <tr><td/> <td><ins>@ 33 1/3 cts.</ins></td> </tr> <tr><td/> <td>$37.00</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>Your certificate had better show<span class='line-break'> </span>the deduction to be made.<span class='line-break'> </span>The accompanying tracing will show<span class='line-break'> </span>the lots &amp; passageways.</p>
<p>Please report as an addition to<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79917' title='Lot 2922'>lots 2922</a> - <a href='/pages/subjects/79918' title='Merriam, Caroline'>Mrs Caroline Merriam</a></p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>P.S. I wish to know if the<span class='line-break'> </span>following numbers are free to be<span class='line-break'> </span>used, if so I propose to use two<span class='line-break'> </span>of them^<sup>one</sup> on the <a href='/pages/subjects/79925' title='Richardson, Henry L.'>Henry Richardson</a><span class='line-break'> </span>lot on <a href='/pages/subjects/57829' title='Snowdrop Path'>Snowdrop P.</a> &amp; one for the<span class='line-break'> </span>Lithgow lots.</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>The first is</th> <th><a href='/pages/subjects/79907' title='Lot 3691'><!--Lot-->3691</a><span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td> Which I do not find was ever used.</td> <td/> </tr> <tr><td> The 2<sup>d</sup> is one reported to <a href='/pages/subjects/79926' title='Winchester, A.'>A. Winchester</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/79913' title='Lot 3672'><!--Lot-->3672</a></td> </tr> <tr><td> The 3<sup>d</sup> is one eported to <a href='/pages/subjects/79916' title='Tyler, J. S., Gen.'>Gen. J. S. Tyler</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/79915' title='Lot 3727'>3727</a> - </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <a href='/pages/subjects/59725' title='Bond, George'>Mr Bond</a> says Gen. Tyler does not<span class='line-break'> </span>take <a href='/pages/subjects/79915' title='Lot 3727'>3727</a>.</p>
<p>If you wish to keep this number<span class='line-break'> </span>for the Winchester lot on <a href='/pages/subjects/61235' title='Mound Avenue'>Mound Av.</a> I<span class='line-break'> </span>can get along with the other two.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. C.</a></p>
<p>359</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133851">
<h3><a name="page-1133851">CB01_0360</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-02-08'>Feby 8<sup>th</sup> [186]7</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>As you propose<span class='line-break'> </span>to come in^<sup>early in the week,</sup> I thought it better<span class='line-break'> </span>to return to you the report<span class='line-break'> </span>of today, to allow you to add<span class='line-break'> </span>to it the 1448 feet for <a href='/pages/subjects/79927' title='Cotting, Charles A.'>Chas. A.<span class='line-break'> </span>Cotting</a>. Of this 330 ft should<span class='line-break'> </span>be reported as an addition to lot<span class='line-break'> </span>no. <a href='/pages/subjects/72193' title='Lot 3012'>3012</a> - <a href='/pages/subjects/79928' title='Bourne, Mary M.'>Mary M. Bourne</a> - <span class='line-break'> </span>and 1118 feet report as a new lot<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/65200' title='Cotting, Charles U.'>Chas. U. Cotting</a>, giving it a <span class='line-break'> </span>new number. You had better put<span class='line-break'> </span>it into our [?] for him to go<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Mr Bond</a> with &amp; enclose to him by<span class='line-break'> </span>mail Monday morning, or leave<span class='line-break'> </span>with me before 9 o'clock.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79907' title='Lot 3691'>No. 3691</a> I have applied to lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/79929' title='Richardson, Henry L., Mrs.'>Mrs<span class='line-break'> </span>Henry L. Richardson</a>, on <a href='/pages/subjects/57829' title='Snowdrop Path'>Snowdrop P.</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79915' title='Lot 3727'>No. 3727</a> to ^<sup>half of old</sup> lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/79930' title='Lithgow, Martha'>Martha Lithgow</a>, on<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/61289' title='Tulip Path'>Tulip Path</a>. I will report<span class='line-break'> </span>to which half as soon as I can<span class='line-break'> </span>ascertain from the heirs.</p>
<p>The iron numbers had better <span class='line-break'> </span>be transferred to those lots now<span class='line-break'> </span>in order to avoid mistakes.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.</p>
<p>360</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133852">
<h3><a name="page-1133852">CB01_0361</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-02-08'>Feby 8 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94113' title='Devens, Arthur L.'>A. L. Devens Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Trustees have<span class='line-break'> </span>authorized the division of <a href='/pages/subjects/79933' title='Lot 1594'>lot 1594</a><span class='line-break'> </span>into two, by reconveying to the Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation in taking two new deeds. The<span class='line-break'> </span>reconveyancec will need to be signed by<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79934' title='Devens, Jane C.'>Mrs Jane C. Devens</a>, yourself &amp; brother,<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79935' title='Devens, Charles'>Charles<!--Devens--></a>. If you will look for the deed,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; bring or send it in, I will prepare the<span class='line-break'> </span>transfer, if you wish. I find the deed<span class='line-break'> </span>was originally delivered to <a href='/pages/subjects/79936' title='Payson, John L.'>Mr John L.<span class='line-break'> </span>Payson</a>. This may give you some clue<span class='line-break'> </span>in case you do not find it readily.</p>
<p>Will you please also answer<span class='line-break'> </span>this question. We give you two numbers<span class='line-break'> </span>the old one <a href='/pages/subjects/79933' title='Lot 1594'>- 1594 -</a> and a new one<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79915' title='Lot 3727'>3727</a>. This is the best I can do.<span class='line-break'> </span>We will say 1594 to <a href='/pages/subjects/94115' title='Devens, Thomas W.'>Thos. M. Devens</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79915' title='Lot 3727'>3727</a> to heirs of <a href='/pages/subjects/79938' title='Devens, Mary'>Mary Devens</a>. In [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>[?] to locate correctly the numbers<span class='line-break'> </span>on the plan, &amp; avoid future mis<span class='line-break'></span>takes, it will be necessary to<span class='line-break'> </span>know which side of the lot belongs<span class='line-break'> </span>to Thos. M. &amp; his mother -- &amp; which<span class='line-break'> </span>to you &amp; brother. This is determined<span class='line-break'> </span>by the will, which gives to Jane C.<span class='line-break'> </span>that part which contains the remains<span class='line-break'> </span>of her late husband <a href='/pages/subjects/79939' title='Devens, Richard C.'>Rich<sup>d</sup> C. Devens</a><span class='line-break'> </span>and to you &amp; your brother the part<span class='line-break'> </span>in which your mother is buried.</p>
<p>As the snow covers the ground, it<span class='line-break'> </span>only remains for you to tell me which<span class='line-break'> </span>is the one &amp; which the other. For this<span class='line-break'> </span>purpose, I send you sketch from our<span class='line-break'> </span>plans. Please indicate, as you stand<span class='line-break'> </span>in <a href='/pages/subjects/61289' title='Tulip Path'>Tulip Path</a> &amp; face the lots, which is<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>left</ins>, &amp; which <ins>right</ins>.</p>
<p>I also enclose petition to be signed<span class='line-break'> </span>yourself &amp; brother.</p>
<p>Your immediate attention will enable me<span class='line-break'> </span>to insert the new arrangement in the catalogue<span class='line-break'> </span>now going to press.</p>
<p>Yours Respy</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>361<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133853">
<h3><a name="page-1133853">CB01_0362</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-02-11'>Feby. 11<sup>th</sup> [186]7</date></p>
<p>Messrs <a href='/pages/subjects/79941' title='Cutter, Tower &amp; Co.'>Cutter, Tower &amp; Co.</a></p>
<p>Gentlemen,</p>
<p>We will take <span class='line-break'> </span>of your 67 reams printing<span class='line-break'> </span>paper of the size 19 in x 29 in,<span class='line-break'> </span>26 lbs to the ream, at 23 cts<span class='line-break'> </span>per lb. provided it is of as good<span class='line-break'> </span>quality as the sample handed<span class='line-break'> </span>us, but with <ins>more sizing</ins>.<span class='line-break'> </span>The sample is deficient in<span class='line-break'> </span>sizing.</p>
<p>We wish the order executed<span class='line-break'> </span>within a fortnight.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1867-02-12'>Feby 12 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79942' title='Safford, Frederick Marcy'>Master F. M. Saffords</a>,</p>
<p>I will make the correction of the <span class='line-break'> </span>number of <a href='/pages/subjects/79943' title='May, P., Mrs.'>Mrs. P. May's</a> lot; but<span class='line-break'> </span>don't be deceived abt <a href='/pages/subjects/72187' title='Lot 531'><!--Lot-->531.</a> It <ins>once</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>stood on <a href='/pages/subjects/61270' title='Rose Path'>Rose Path</a> (on old plan) was never<span class='line-break'> </span>used and the spot is now covered by<span class='line-break'> </span>lot <a href='/pages/subjects/73806' title='Lot 3601'>3601</a>- heirs of <a href='/pages/subjects/79944' title='Clark, James'>Jas. Clark</a> (one of the <a href='/pages/subjects/79945' title='Jordan Marsh &amp; Company'>Jordan<span class='line-break'> </span>Marsh</a> &amp;c lots) I gave you 531 on<span class='line-break'> </span>the list to locate anew; &amp;, if you<span class='line-break'> </span>have not <del>found</del> <sup>lost</sup> that list, you will<span class='line-break'> </span>see it there. If you have, it is time<span class='line-break'> </span>you should be furnished with another.<span class='line-break'> </span>If the number has been located among<span class='line-break'> </span>those given, please find it and give<span class='line-break'> </span>it to the surveyor. Finally, now<span class='line-break'> </span>is your time to show the surveyor<span class='line-break'> </span>where all those spare numbers<span class='line-break'> </span>are located.</p>
<p>Yours respectfully</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>362</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133854">
<h3><a name="page-1133854">CB01_0363</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-02-12'>Feby 12 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52529' title='Bigelow, Jacob'>Dr Jacob Bigelow</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>At the meeting<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Trustees of Mount Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>held this day you were chosen<span class='line-break'> </span>for the twenty third time to<span class='line-break'> </span>preside over the deliberations<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Board &amp; the Corporation.</p>
<p>You were also chosen Chair<span class='line-break'></span>man of the Committee on Grounds.</p>
<p>The accompanying of <a href='/pages/subjects/79946' title='Babcock, William G.'>W<sup>m</sup> G.<span class='line-break'> </span>Babcock</a> was presented &amp; it was</p>
<p>Voted that the same be referred<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Committee on Grounds.</p>
<p>Very Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1867-02-12'>Feby 12 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Geo W<sup>m</sup> Bond Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>At the meeting<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Trustees of the Cemetery of<span class='line-break'> </span>Mount Auburn, held this day,<span class='line-break'> </span>you were rechosen Treasurer <span class='line-break'> </span>for the ensuing year.</p>
<p>It was further</p>
<p>"Voted that the salary of the <span class='line-break'> </span>Treasurer for the present year<span class='line-break'> </span>be one thousand dollars, in <span class='line-break'> </span>full of all services."</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> <span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>363<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133855">
<h3><a name="page-1133855">CB01_0364</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-02-12'>Feby 12 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have the honor<span class='line-break'> </span>to announce your reelection<span class='line-break'> </span>as Superintendent of the Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>of Mount Auburn at the meeting<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Trustees held this day.</p>
<p>It was further "Voted that<span class='line-break'> </span>the salary of the Superintendent<span class='line-break'> </span>be twenty two hundred &amp; fifty dollars,<span class='line-break'> </span>the use of house, and such wood<span class='line-break'> </span>as he needs for his own use gathered<span class='line-break'> </span>from the premises."</p>
<p>Yours Respectfully</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1867-02-12'>Feby 12 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/71445' title='Southack, George P.'>Geo. P. Southack Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>At the meeting<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Trustees of the Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>of Mount Auburn held <span class='line-break'> </span>this day, you were re<span class='line-break'></span>chosen Gatekeeper for<span class='line-break'> </span>the ensuing yeear.</p>
<p>It was further<span class='line-break'> </span>"Voted that the salary<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Gatekeeper be six<span class='line-break'> </span>hundred and fifty dollar and<span class='line-break'> </span>the usual Sunday allowance<span class='line-break'> </span>provided in the by-laws."</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>364</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133856">
<h3><a name="page-1133856">CB01_0365</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-02-13'>Feby 13 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79947' title='Hollingsworth, Amos'>Amos Hollingsworth Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>We are nearly<span class='line-break'> </span>ready to print a new plan of our<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery on a scale sufficiently large<span class='line-break'> </span>to show every proprietor his lot<span class='line-break'> </span>in good order. You being one of our <span class='line-break'> </span>constituents, I wish to make a<span class='line-break'> </span>personal appeal to you so for<span class='line-break'> </span>as such appeal is proper^<sup>can be made</sup> consistent<span class='line-break'> </span>with your own interests.</p>
<p>I do not find any map<span class='line-break'> </span>paper in this market and do<span class='line-break'> </span>not wish to be driven to New<span class='line-break'> </span>York to get it.</p>
<p>We wish about ten reams<span class='line-break'> </span>38 in x 46 in say <del>65</del> <sup>70</sup> lbs to rm.<span class='line-break'> </span>or about 700 lbs.</p>
<p>I inquired at <a href='/pages/subjects/79948' title='Jones, P. C., Mr.'>Mr. P.C.<span class='line-break'> </span>Jones'</a>, or rather got them<span class='line-break'> </span>to inquire of your house<span class='line-break'> </span>and my answer was that<span class='line-break'> </span>you were not for prepared to <span class='line-break'> </span>make so small a quantity,<span class='line-break'> </span>and would have to wait for<span class='line-break'> </span>an accumulation of orders. In<span class='line-break'> </span>that way I should suppose<span class='line-break'> </span>orders would naturally scatter<span class='line-break'> </span>as fast as the necessities of per<span class='line-break'></span>sons should drive them else<span class='line-break'></span>where.</p>
<p>However, that is of no conse<span class='line-break'></span>quence. The only thing is, can I<span class='line-break'> </span>within our limited time calculate<span class='line-break'> </span>upon a supply from your<span class='line-break'> </span>mills; say in one month<span class='line-break'> </span>or two months?</p>
<p>Your reply will much<span class='line-break'> </span>oblige.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>365<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133857">
<h3><a name="page-1133857">CB01_0366</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-02-13'>Feby 13 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>1  Unless you happen to have the<span class='line-break'> </span>means of telling me at hand, will you be<span class='line-break'> </span>so kind as to let <a href='/pages/subjects/79942' title='Safford, Frederick Marcy'>Fred</a>. see if the^<sup>the line dividing</sup> two <ins>tombs</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>built on <a href='/pages/subjects/64244' title='Lot 125'>lot 125</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/61202' title='Hemlock Path'>Hemlock Path</a> - <a href='/pages/subjects/79950' title='Darling, Edward Agushus'>Mr Darlings,</a><span class='line-break'> </span>divides then lot in two halves: if not, tell me<span class='line-break'> </span>how much is in one &amp; how much in the other<span class='line-break'> </span>since you reported addition of 40 feet<span class='line-break'> </span>your diagram shows it thus: -</p>
<p>[Diagram: Measurements of lot]</p>
<p>Darling wishes to con<span class='line-break'></span>vey one tomb, &amp; the ques<span class='line-break'></span>tion is whether it is half of lot, more<span class='line-break'> </span>or less.</p>
<p>2 If you can get at it, please report<span class='line-break'> </span>on <a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>C.P. Curtis</a>' lot - or upon both 389 right.</p>
<p>3 I forget whether you took [man. lot?]<span class='line-break'> </span>Sat. to report addition to Brown &amp; Davis<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/72315' title='Fountain Avenue'>Fountain Av </a>- <a href='/pages/subjects/67275' title='Lot 3482'>3482</a>-3. Mr B has [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>lot on <a href='/pages/subjects/79952' title='Celematis Path'>Clematis P. </a></p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1867-02-19'>Feby 19 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/54773' title='Curtis, Charles P.'>C.P. Curtis Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Superintendent<span class='line-break'> </span>has examined the lots of your<span class='line-break'> </span>father &amp; uncle (J.B.C) and I<span class='line-break'> </span>think the President happened to be<span class='line-break'> </span>with him. He^<sup>(Supt.)</sup> though it would<span class='line-break'> </span>be useless to make a written report<span class='line-break'> </span>with the lots should be put<span class='line-break'> </span>in order.</p>
<p>He says both want new<span class='line-break'> </span>grading and sodding, and<span class='line-break'> </span>the monument on your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>is somewhat cracked, although<span class='line-break'> </span>it may not give out for twenty<span class='line-break'> </span>or thirty years.</p>
<p>I suppose nothing can be done<span class='line-break'> </span>till spring, when you can examine<span class='line-break'> </span>and determine what course to<span class='line-break'> </span>pursue.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>366</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133858">
<h3><a name="page-1133858">CB01_0367</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-02-23'>Feby 23 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/65850' title='Humphrey, Benjamin'>Benj. Humphrey Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A few days since<span class='line-break'> </span>your brother Francis desired me<span class='line-break'> </span>to ascertain the am<sup>t</sup> for which<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation would <ins>guarantee</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>the perpetual repair of your family<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65849' title='Lot 1341'>lot no 1341</a>. and inform you<span class='line-break'> </span>of the result.</p>
<p>I wrote the Supt. asking him<span class='line-break'> </span>to report upon the condition of<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot in the usual manner,<span class='line-break'> </span>and instead of the report he<span class='line-break'> </span>has written me as follows:</p>
<p>"I have examined the <span class='line-break'> </span>"Humphrey Lot." It requires<span class='line-break'> </span>to be regraded and resodded<span class='line-break'> </span>especially the banks are very mossy.<span class='line-break'> </span>The pedestal which is attached<span class='line-break'> </span>to the figure, and^<sup>which</sup> is, with the<span class='line-break'> </span>statue, composed of one [piece?]<span class='line-break'> </span>of marble, is slightly cracked.<span class='line-break'> </span>The die of the monument is cracked<span class='line-break'> </span>in four or five different<span class='line-break'> </span>places and one of the<span class='line-break'> </span>cracks is a bad one, and<span class='line-break'> </span>probably the piece will come<span class='line-break'> </span>off in the course of twenty<span class='line-break'> </span>years." -</p>
<p>As the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>does not assume the care<span class='line-break'> </span>of any lot before being put<span class='line-break'> </span>in good order, the above<span class='line-break'> </span>suggestions are commended<span class='line-break'> </span>to your notice, which you<span class='line-break'> </span>will hardly be able to give<span class='line-break'> </span>attention to before spring opens.</p>
<p>Respectfully<span class='line-break'> </span>Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>367</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133859">
<h3><a name="page-1133859">CB01_0368</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-03-05'>March 5<sup>th</sup> [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79957' title='Hilliard, William'>W<sup>m</sup> Hilliard</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir: -</p>
<p>I have just<span class='line-break'> </span>rec<sup>d</sup> a note from <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. Winsor</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>our Sup<sup>t</sup> of which the following is<span class='line-break'> </span>a copy: -</p>
<p>"<a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>Austin J. Coolidge</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>It will cost<span class='line-break'> </span>to regrade, manure and resod <a href='/pages/subjects/66365' title='Hilliard, Abraham'>Abra<span class='line-break'></span>ham Hilliard's</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/66363' title='Lot 2000'>lot No. 2000</a>; and<span class='line-break'> </span>paint the fence $47<sup>00</sup>: what in<span class='line-break'> </span>another Die to the monument $225<sup>00</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>in all $272<sup>00</sup></p>
<p>There is a kind of harp &amp; flowers<span class='line-break'> </span>cut upon the front of the Die. He"<span class='line-break'> </span>(the marble man I suppose) "will make<span class='line-break'> </span>an exact copy, take down the <ins>old</ins><span class='line-break'> </span>and <ins>re</ins>set the <ins>new</ins> as above.</p>
<p>There are heavy banks to resod<span class='line-break'> </span>and it in take as many <span class='line-break'> </span>sods outside as inside, manure<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp;c. The figures for Perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>care are very low.</p>
<p>Very Resp.y Yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Daniel L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>You will remember that the<span class='line-break'> </span>report upon the lot which I showed<span class='line-break'> </span>you contained the endorsement of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots, aggreeing to<span class='line-break'> </span>guarantee the perpetual repair<span class='line-break'> </span>of said lot, when it shall<span class='line-break'> </span>have been put in condition as<span class='line-break'> </span>above described for <sup>four</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>hundred dollars. ($400.)</p>
<p>The total cost then of^<sup>present</sup> repairs,<span class='line-break'> </span>and of keeping forever in repair,<span class='line-break'> </span>will be six hundred &amp; seventy two<span class='line-break'> </span>($672. -)</p>
<p>I am truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p>368</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133860">
<h3><a name="page-1133860">CB01_0369</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-03-19'>March 19<sup>th</sup> [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79958' title='Rice, T.'>Mr T. Rice Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you be<span class='line-break'> </span>so kind as to inquire (if need<span class='line-break'> </span>be) and inform me of the<span class='line-break'> </span>present residence of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/79959' title='Smith, Jerome V. C.'>Dr Jerome V. C. Smith</a>, formerly<span class='line-break'> </span>mayor of <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, since resident <span class='line-break'> </span>in <a href='/pages/subjects/63804' title='New Orleans, LA'>New Orleans</a> at some time during<span class='line-break'> </span>the war.</p>
<p>Also <a href='/pages/subjects/79960' title='Peterson, Fredrick A.'>Fred<sup>k</sup> A. Peterson</a> who<span class='line-break'> </span>was in business in <a href='/pages/subjects/63804' title='New Orleans, LA'>New Orleans</a> ^<sup>in 1857,</sup> &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>perhaps still is, although I have a <span class='line-break'> </span>vague idea he went to Texas.<span class='line-break'> </span>He had a sister <a href='/pages/subjects/79961' title='Farnsworth, Margaret A.'>Mrs J. C. Farnsworth<span class='line-break'> </span>(Margaret A)</a> who died in 1861 aged 33 yr.<span class='line-break'> </span>She was in <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a> in 1857 &amp; subsequently<span class='line-break'> </span>as I lost track of her. At the time<span class='line-break'> </span>of her death she was described to<span class='line-break'> </span>be of <a href='/pages/subjects/72287' title='St. Louis, MO'>St. Louis</a>.</p>
<p>Both of these parties are pro<span class='line-break'></span>prietors of lots in the Cemetery.<span class='line-break'> </span>I don't wish you to take too much<span class='line-break'> </span>trouble, but if you can easily<span class='line-break'> </span>get information, I will thank<span class='line-break'> </span>you. Your early answer will oblige.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>369</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133861">
<h3><a name="page-1133861">CB01_0370</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>370</p>
<p><date when='1867 03 22'>March 22 [186]7<span class='line-break'> </span></date><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/81460' title='Thompson, S. Bent, Capt.'>Capt. S. Benton Thompson</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have long intended to send<span class='line-break'> </span>you the enclosed statement of am<sup>t</sup> due from<span class='line-break'> </span>you for land added to your <a href='/pages/subjects/81461' title='Lot 2026'>lot no. 2026</a> in the<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery - the same being $62.50 for 125 ft of land.</p>
<p>The Sup<sup>t</sup> not fully understanding who the parties<span class='line-break'> </span>were at the time made out two certificates for <a href='/pages/subjects/67138' title='Renton, Peter'>Dr<span class='line-break'> </span>Peter Renton</a>, one on your lot &amp; one on the westerly<span class='line-break'> </span>lot of the range. Hence the alteration in the one sent<span class='line-break'> </span>you. <a href='/pages/subjects/67138' title='Renton, Peter'>Dr Renton</a> long ago paid for his land<span class='line-break'> </span>the same price, and his burial in it.</p>
<p>The reason why you have not received<span class='line-break'> </span>this has been partly because it was mislaid.<span class='line-break'> </span>It was arranged on the interview which you<span class='line-break'> </span>and I had that this addition you would pay for.</p>
<p>I will thank you to remit $64.50 to the Treas<span class='line-break'></span>urer with the certif. sent, &amp; I will see that you<span class='line-break'> </span>have a deed of the addition. I am about issuing<span class='line-break'> </span>from press a new catalogue, &amp; I wish to have this<span class='line-break'> </span>matter included among the corrected matters.</p>
<p>You will see that we have charged only the<span class='line-break'> </span>old price of land. The land on both sides of you is worth<span class='line-break'> </span>more than double that - but I do not propose to make you<span class='line-break'> </span>pay for the accidental delay, if paid now.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> <span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133862">
<h3><a name="page-1133862">CB01_0371_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1867-04-19'>Apr. 19 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/85146' title='Holdbrook, Edward'>Edw<sup>d</sup> Holbrook Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>In my absence a<span class='line-break'> </span>day or two time ago you left a written <span class='line-break'> </span>request that <a href='/pages/subjects/74568' title='Fox, Joseph'>Joseph Fox</a> might work on<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/85147' title='Lot 890'>lot no 890</a>, standing in the name of <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/85146' title='Holdbrook, Edward'>Edward Holbrook</a> who died in 1841.</p>
<p>Some years since I urged upon you<span class='line-break'> </span>the importance of having the lot repre<span class='line-break'></span>sented by someone, but you decided not<span class='line-break'> </span>to do anything about it. Again in <span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1866-05-25'>1866 (May 25<sup>th</sup>)</date> I wrote you urging the<span class='line-break'> </span>importance [to the heir?] as well as the Cor<span class='line-break'></span>poration of having a representative appointed<span class='line-break'> </span>[but I?] have received no reply.</p>
<p>I have only to [?] that no<span class='line-break'> </span>one can receive my permit to work on<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot until the regulations have been<span class='line-break'> </span>complied with.</p>
<p>Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1867-04-30'>Apr 30 [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/85148' title='Young, F. M. W., Mrs.'>Mrs F. M. W. Young</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I send an affidavit<span class='line-break'> </span>for you to make before a judge ^<sup>or clerk</sup> of any Court<span class='line-break'> </span>of Record in your county: it is less expensive<span class='line-break'> </span>than before a Commissioner. Please fill the<span class='line-break'> </span>blanks for dates, name &amp;c. If your father<span class='line-break'> </span>died leaving other children than yourself &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>they have since died, you can easily have<span class='line-break'> </span>the blank altered to meet the case, by inter<span class='line-break'></span>lining, after the words [?] [expired?] &amp; heir -- the<span class='line-break'> </span>words -- "who is now living". --</p>
<p>I think it is best that the lot should<span class='line-break'> </span>be transferred directly to you: then we shall<span class='line-break'> </span>know who is the owner. In <date when='1855'>1855</date>, upon your<span class='line-break'> </span>request, <a href='/pages/subjects/62682' title='Arnold, Joseph'>Joseph Arnold</a> was appointed to<span class='line-break'> </span><ins>represent</ins> it; but I have not heard of him<span class='line-break'> </span>for years, &amp; it had better be changed now. If you<span class='line-break'> </span>get the affidavit back to me within a week, it will<span class='line-break'> </span>be in season to print in catalogue. At all events, send<span class='line-break'> </span>it as soon as you can, and I will get it in if not<span class='line-break'> </span>too late. I also send bill for the transfer fee.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y</p>
<p>371</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133863">
<h3><a name="page-1133863">CB01_0372_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>372</p>
<p><date when='1867-04-26'>April 26<sup>th</sup> [186]7</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/81482' title='Shedd, J. H., Mr.'>J. H. Shedd Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>For the sake of setting a<span class='line-break'> </span>few things right for my catalogue as well getting <del>the</del> <sup>some</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>deeds out of the way &amp; settling accts. I will you would<span class='line-break'> </span>give me this week or quite early next the following.</p>
<p>The actual measurement &amp; contents of lots <a href='/pages/subjects/72193' title='Lot 3012'>3012</a> &amp; <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/81483' title='Lot 3737'>3737 on</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/61250' title='Oxalis Path'>Oxalis P.</a> (Bourne). I think you will have<span class='line-break'> </span>to make a new sketch, or alter the old one so as to show<span class='line-break'> </span>the measures of the orig. tomb lot <a href='/pages/subjects/72193' title='Lot 3012'>3012</a>^<sup>[its?]</sup> addition on <a href='/pages/subjects/61237' title='Myrtle Path'>Myrtle<!--Path--></a><span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/81483' title='lot 3737'>lot 3737</a>, after correcting distances from path to back side.</p>
