<br />
<div id="page-1133918">
<h3><a name="page-1133918">CB01_0426</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>426</p>
<p>16 Pemberton Square,</p>
<p><date when='1868-06-25'>June 25, [186]8</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/93775' title='Bunker, F. R.'>Mr F.R. Bunker</a>, Gate Keeper &amp;c.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>For the greater facility of reg<span class='line-break'></span>ulating the accounts, and to render ourselves less<span class='line-break'> </span>liable to mistakes, you will please make the<span class='line-break'> </span>following changes in the practice of accounts &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>payments at the Gate: --</p>
<p>I wish your account such as we can<span class='line-break'> </span>enter upon the cash book in detail as rec<sup>d</sup> from<span class='line-break'> </span>you. So, instead of starting the account with a<span class='line-break'> </span>statement of the money you hold, &amp; ending in the same<span class='line-break'> </span>manner, I wish the account to correspond with the<span class='line-break'> </span>amount of money you remit me. Begin with<span class='line-break'> </span>the first item received, and transcribe from your<span class='line-break'> </span>cash book just as far as will make the amount<span class='line-break'> </span>of money you wish to remit, after charging the<span class='line-break'> </span>payments: So that the difference between receipts &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>payments will be the amount remitted.</p>
<p>Then as to paying bills -- such bills are can<span class='line-break'> </span>easily be paid at this office, as for instance, <a href='/pages/subjects/93776' title='Runey, John'>John<span class='line-break'> </span>Runey</a>, &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/93777' title='Morss &amp; Whyte'>Morss &amp; Whyte</a> in the <date when='1868-06-06'>June 12<sup>th</sup></date> a/c, get them<span class='line-break'> </span>approved, &amp; send them here for payment.</p>
<p>Instead of carrying the pay of ^<sup>casual</sup> laborers into the acct,<span class='line-break'> </span>pay them, keep the vouchers, enter the amt on the next payroll,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; I will settle with you when I pay.</p>
<p>Yours Resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133919">
<h3><a name="page-1133919">CB01_0427</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>427</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/93780' title='Warren, Edward Winslow'>"Little Eddie"<span class='line-break'> </span>Edw<sup>d</sup> Winslow</a>, only son of <a href='/pages/subjects/93781' title='Warren, Edward'>Edw<sup>d</sup> <!--Warren--></a>&amp;<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/93782' title='Warren, Anna Finslow'>Annie W. Warner</a></p>
<p>[diagram: Lot diagram showning measurements of lot with graves]<span class='line-break'> </span>(1)</p>
<p>No Stone E Warren</p>
<p>Here are faily, I think<span class='line-break'> </span><u>three</u> spaces —fir adykts</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/93783' title='Ward, John G.'>John G. Ward</a> died<date when='1840-09-12'> Sept 12 1840</date> aged 49 yrs</p>
<p>Here are <u>two</u> spaces, for and adult &amp; child or possibly two adults_</p>
<p>3 feet<span class='line-break'> </span>Mon<u><sup>t</sup></u><span class='line-break'> </span>3 feet</p>
<p>Here are <u>two</u> spaces.</p>
<p>(Front)</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/93784' title='Lot 767'>Lot 767</a> - Late of <a href='/pages/subjects/72743' title='Cutler, Pliny'>Pliny Cutler</a> -<span class='line-break'> </span>Now belonging to <a href='/pages/subjects/93785' title='Cutler, William'>Dr. W<sup>m</sup> W. Cutler</a> -</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/93786' title='Davenport, Henry'>Henry Davenport Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>As there was no one upon whom I could rely that I <span class='line-break'> </span>cared to call to get the sketch of the lot with graves as you desired, I went myself, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>this is the result. The measurements are substantially correct. The length of graves can only be<span class='line-break'> </span>judged by this appearance, as the mound is often not so long as the actual grave. I have given here<span class='line-break'> </span>what I supposed to be the actual length, &amp; some of these may therefore exceed the reality. There are usually three spaces<span class='line-break'> </span>in length in a lot 20 feet deep, &amp; I do not see why there should not be here. I think there is room for<span class='line-break'> </span><u>eight</u> more bodies, leaving the gateway to the monument.</p>
<p>Yours Respectfully</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>427</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133920">
<h3><a name="page-1133920">CB01_0428_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>428</p>
<p>16 Pemberton Sq.</p>
<p><date when='1868-07-02'>July 2<sup>d</sup> [186]8</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/93775' title='Bunker, F. R.'>Mr F.R. Bunker</a>,</p>
<p>Please make your ^<sup>next</sup> acct. agree<span class='line-break'> </span>with the accts. previously rendered me -- that is,<span class='line-break'> </span>after [finding? fixing?] up the amts. of bills collected stated<span class='line-break'> </span>in the acct. rendered me, and deducting the<span class='line-break'> </span>payment, in the same acct. -- then return<span class='line-break'> </span>the whole of the cash in your hands, and<span class='line-break'> </span>carry into a new account just items enough<span class='line-break'> </span>to make the difference of the two sides<span class='line-break'> </span>clear your hands of the remaining cash,<span class='line-break'> </span>which for sure, you had better pay in,<span class='line-break'> </span>and we can start with a new a/c.</p>
<p>After that you can retain what you recd,<span class='line-break'> </span>and stop on the books in [abstracting?] your<span class='line-break'> </span>acct. where you choose, only let the cash<span class='line-break'> </span>sent agree with that specific accts.<span class='line-break'> </span>To [?] any misunderstanding I will state it as<span class='line-break'> </span>it is up to the present.<span class='line-break'> </span>[this sentence indecipherable]</p>
<p>[last part of page financial accts.]</p>
<p>If you have enough in your hands to pay your quarter's salary<span class='line-break'> </span>$162.50, (I corrected your a/c from 162.48) I will settle it with<span class='line-break'> </span>you on Friday eve.y, when we pay, &amp; you can make<span class='line-break'> </span>up your a/c for enough to cover it.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133921">
<h3><a name="page-1133921">CB01_0429</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/81770' title='Hastings, A. Winthrop'>A.W. Hastings, Esq.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I am sorry that our<span class='line-break'> </span>honest attempt to reach the facts in <span class='line-break'> </span>the case of the charge for a brick grave<span class='line-break'> </span>for your father, of $20, on <date when='1865-08-17'>17<sup>th</sup> Aug. 1865</date> should<span class='line-break'> </span>be the occasion of any unpleasant feelings.</p>
<p>I wrote you on the 9<sup>th</sup> of July that the<span class='line-break'> </span>Lawrence bill <u>was</u> paid, as you state,<span class='line-break'> </span>on the <date when='1865-01-16'>16<sup>th</sup> of Jany. 1865</date>, at which time<span class='line-break'> </span>the charge in question had never been<span class='line-break'> </span>made. Your father died in August<span class='line-break'> </span>following, and the two charges of $20<span class='line-break'> </span>each are therefore entered distinct<span class='line-break'> </span>as our "order book" at Mt. A. shows,<span class='line-break'> </span>although in your reply of July 15<sup>th</sup>,<span class='line-break'> </span>to me, you seem to suppose them<span class='line-break'> </span>one and the same.</p>
<p>The order book referred to<span class='line-break'> </span>per, --</p>
<p>"<date when='1864-10-09'>Oct. 9, 1864</date>. <a href='/pages/subjects/58506' title='Hastings, Thomas'>Thos. Hastings</a>, Int.<span class='line-break'> </span>and record -- Body of <a href='/pages/subjects/60029' title='Lawrence, James K.'><u> James K.</u><span class='line-break'> </span>Lawrence</a>, (Birch Grave) $20. --<span class='line-break'> </span>Bill rec<sup>d</sup> Treas<sup>r</sup> some time in 1864".<span class='line-break'> </span>This was paid (as stated) <date when='1865-01-16'>Jany 16, 1865</date>.</p>
<p>The order book next shows<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1865-08-17'>Aug 17, 1865</date> <a href='/pages/subjects/81770' title='Hastings, A. Winthrop'>A. Winthrop Hastings</a> --<span class='line-break'> </span>Brick Grave, Int. &amp; Record. Body<span class='line-break'> </span>of Thos. Hastings -- $20. Bill rec<sup>d</sup> Treas.<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1865-10-05'>Oct. 5, 1865</date>".</p>
<p>I have taken the pains<span class='line-break'> </span>to examine carefully our books and<span class='line-break'> </span>also the accounts of moneys rec<sup>d</sup> at the<span class='line-break'> </span>Gate, from <date when='1865-08-17'>Aug. 17, 1865</date> to the present<span class='line-break'> </span>time, and they furnish no evidence<span class='line-break'> </span>that the $20 for your father's brick<span class='line-break'> </span>grave has been paid. There is not<span class='line-break'> </span>much chance of error on the <u>cash</u> book,<span class='line-break'> </span>even if journals &amp; ledgers are deficient.</p>
<p>If you find a receipted bill of this, I<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be very glad to enter it on the books --<span class='line-break'> </span>otherwise, will feel obliged if you will pay it.</p>
<p>Yours very Respy.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>429</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133922">
<h3><a name="page-1133922">CB01_0430</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1868-09-18'>Sept<sup>r</sup> 18 [18]68</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94097' title='Crane, Edward'>Edw<sup>d</sup> Crane</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Among the accounts<span class='line-break'> </span>due to this Corporation which have<span class='line-break'> </span>come into my hands from the late<span class='line-break'> </span>Treasurer, for collection, is one against<span class='line-break'> </span>you, amounting to five hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>fifteen 33/100 dollars ($515.33) for work<span class='line-break'> </span>done on your lot last year. --</p>
<p>I am informed that the pay<span class='line-break'></span>ment of this bill has been repeatedly<span class='line-break'> </span>demanded of you, and which<span class='line-break'> </span>demand I now repeat, but, for <span class='line-break'> </span>this time only.</p>
<p>I send herewith the account of<span class='line-break'> </span>the same.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1868-09-25'>September 25<sup>th</sup> [18]68</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94098' title='Johnson, J. C.'>J.C. Johnson</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have been to <span class='line-break'> </span>Mount Auburn and inquired about<span class='line-break'> </span>your bill. I learn that the<span class='line-break'> </span>work was done at a reasonable<span class='line-break'> </span>price -- in fact low. The confidential<span class='line-break'> </span>estimates of what later will cost made<span class='line-break'> </span>beforehand amount to nothing, &amp; I think<span class='line-break'> </span>we all learn to regard them of about<span class='line-break'> </span>as much value, as a carpenter's es<span class='line-break'></span>timate in his head for what a house<span class='line-break'> </span>will cost --</p>
<p>I have credited the four posts, $8.<span class='line-break'> </span>Upon reflection, the work has been done<span class='line-break'> </span>five months, &amp; I desire you to pay<span class='line-break'> </span>before you leave for the week.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>430</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133923">
<h3><a name="page-1133923">CB01_0431</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1868-10-05'>Octo. 5<sup>th</sup> [18]68</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/72297' title='Richardson, William H.'>W.H. Richardson</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I trust you<span class='line-break'> </span>understand that I shall<span class='line-break'> </span>enter the suit against you<span class='line-break'> </span>tomorrow, unless the same<span class='line-break'> </span>is previously settled.</p>
<p>I am unwilling to<span class='line-break'> </span>increase the costs unless<span class='line-break'> </span>you desire it. I never<span class='line-break'> </span>intended to subject you to <u>any</u><span class='line-break'> </span>costs, but your strange<span class='line-break'> </span>course compelled it.</p>
<p>Before tomorrow night, unless<span class='line-break'> </span>you pay, the costs will be<span class='line-break'> </span>doubled: &amp; you will certainly<span class='line-break'> </span>have to pay them. --</p>
<p>Now don't say you did not<span class='line-break'> </span>have sufficient notice.</p>
<p>Yours Respectfully</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>431<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133924">
<h3><a name="page-1133924">CB01_0432</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>432</p>
<p><date when='1868-10-21'>Octo. 21<sup>st</sup> [18]68</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Trustees of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/94100' title='Lorey, Abby M.'>Abby M. Lorey's</a> lot are ready to pay the $1200 stipu<span class='line-break'></span>lated for perpet<sup>l</sup> repair of so much of <a href='/pages/subjects/67074' title='lot 1250'>lot 1250</a> as<span class='line-break'> </span>is enclosed within the iron fence &amp; curb -- and<span class='line-break'> </span>wish the repairs which are desired necessary<span class='line-break'> </span>to be completed. These you reported to be -- <span class='line-break'> </span>"fence wants painting &amp; marble requires washing".<span class='line-break'> </span>On the inside of report, the Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots<span class='line-break'> </span>say -- "a tree is gradually pushing the fence down,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; should be looked after".</p>
<p>I trust you will let ^<sup>work</sup> there proceed at once,<span class='line-break'> </span>so we shall get the money as soon as done.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/93771' title='Deblois, Stephen G.'>Mr Stephen G. Deblois</a> is ready to pay the gra<span class='line-break'></span>ding bill of $149.34 on <a href='/pages/subjects/81725' title='lot 3808'>lot 3808</a>, now due for ten<span class='line-break'> </span>months, as soon as the number is cut on the post.<span class='line-break'> </span>The charges is included in the bill -- "4 eight inch posts<span class='line-break'> </span>set with number cut $15.00". --</p>
<p>Please do this &amp; notify me --</p>
<p>Mr <a href='/pages/subjects/66872' title='Emmons, John L.'>John L. Emmons</a> says he has several times, but<span class='line-break'> </span>without success, tried to get a settlement of a bill<span class='line-break'> </span>made to him for regrading &amp; resodding lots --</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133925">
<h3><a name="page-1133925">CB01_0433</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>433</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/61187' title='Geranium Path'>Geranium Path</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/94106' title='Lot 1228'>nos 1228</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/94107' title='Lot 1232'>1232.</a> He says <a href='/pages/subjects/73016' title='Barker, Alexander Augustus'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>Barker</a> went with him &amp; measured the lots<span class='line-break'> </span>in regard to sodding, &amp; that he admitted he<span class='line-break'> </span>was charged for too many feet of sod in<span class='line-break'> </span>1400 feet -- The bill is 67.45, &amp; he is ready to<span class='line-break'> </span>pay it.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94109' title='Wise, William G.'>W<sup>m</sup> G. Wise</a> prop<sup>r</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/94110' title='Lot 620'>lot no. 620</a><span class='line-break'> </span>replies to my demand of payment of bill of<span class='line-break'> </span>$75.00 that he has written you that there was<span class='line-break'> </span>something to be done &amp; covered by the $75.00 which<span class='line-break'> </span>is not included within the bill, &amp; that he is only<span class='line-break'> </span>waiting to know that the same is done to settle<span class='line-break'> </span>his bill. --</p>
<p>I also send you a bill against me,<span class='line-break'> </span>which if I understand, is contrary even to the<span class='line-break'> </span>bad precedent which we have in cases<span class='line-break'> </span>of 2<sup>d</sup> interment in same grave. -- If<span class='line-break'> </span>I owe for a 2<sup>d</sup> int. I should not be charged<span class='line-break'> </span>with $20. for the 1<sup>st</sup>. If for the 1<sup>st</sup>, as there was<span class='line-break'> </span>but one opening of the grave, I should not<span class='line-break'> </span>be charged for the 2<sup>d</sup>--</p>
<p>Please report upon <a href='/pages/subjects/94111' title='Lot 3678'>lot no 3768</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/94112' title='Scott, Mary Ann'>Mary Ann<span class='line-break'> </span>Scott</a> for perpetual repair. She has paid<span class='line-break'> </span>her bill today.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133926">
<h3><a name="page-1133926">CB01_0434_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-01-05'>Jany 5<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I presume you cannot be<span class='line-break'> </span>more averse to receiving an old bill<span class='line-break'> </span>than I am to sending one -- but I do not<span class='line-break'> </span>feel that I am chargeable with neglect in<span class='line-break'> </span>the present case, as I have repeatedly<span class='line-break'> </span>endeavored to get the bill settled, I think<span class='line-break'> </span>even before <a href='/pages/subjects/94113' title='Devens, Arthur L.'>Mr Arthur L. Devens</a> died.</p>
<p>I enclose bill once more to you,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; trust it will be settled. -- $7.50</p>
<p>I also send the bill of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation for the care of the lot<span class='line-break'> </span>in 1866 -- the charge is $5.00 -- The order<span class='line-break'> </span>was signed by "<a href='/pages/subjects/94114' title='Sherburne, F. P.'>F.P. Sherburne</a> -- bill to<span class='line-break'> </span>Mr Devens 31 India Wharf --.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Secretary &amp; Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94115' title='Devens, Thomas W.'>Thos. W. Devens</a> Esq.</p>
<p><date when='1869-01-12'>Jany 12<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 4<sup>th</sup> inst. relating<span class='line-break'> </span>to our claim against the estate<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/94116' title='Taylor, J. W.'>J.W. Taylor</a> is at hand --</p>
<p>It will be quite "agreeable to me"<span class='line-break'> </span>to receive the amt of bill $57.50<span class='line-break'> </span>and interest as soon as pos<span class='line-break'></span>sible, as the account has stood<span class='line-break'> </span>over two years and the<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees wish me to close<span class='line-break'> </span>all old accounts at the earliest<span class='line-break'> </span>day.</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>Am<sup>t</sup> bill</th> <th>57.50<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>say 2 yrs int. --</td> <td><u>6.90</u></td> </tr> <tr><td/> <td>$64.40</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94117' title='Van Vordt, W. H.'>W.H. Van Vordt</a> Esq</p>
<p>434</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133927">
<h3><a name="page-1133927">CB01_0435_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>435</p>
<p><date when='1869-01-12'>Jany 12 [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95729' title='York, William F.'>W.F. York Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your reply of <date when='1868-12-24'>Dec<sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>24<sup>th</sup></date> to my request to pay bill of $12.55<span class='line-break'> </span>in connection with lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/94119' title='Towne, L. G., Mrs.'>Mrs L.G. Towne</a><span class='line-break'> </span>I have referred to the Sup<sup>t</sup>, &amp; he states<span class='line-break'> </span>that the work was done by your order,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; it is the invariable custom for the<span class='line-break'> </span>party who sets a monument or stones to<span class='line-break'> </span>pay for cleaning up &amp; new sodding re<span class='line-break'></span>quired by the activity. I have just rend<sup>d</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>a bill to <a href='/pages/subjects/64030' title='McDonald, Alexander'>Mr M<sup>c</sup>Donald</a> amounting to<span class='line-break'> </span>more than $100 for such work &amp; he says<span class='line-break'> </span>it is all right.</p>
<p>The new sodding &amp;c on Mrs Towne's<span class='line-break'> </span>lot was required by your setting the mon<span class='line-break'></span>ument. I don't see with what propri<span class='line-break'></span>ety we could ask her to pay for bill<span class='line-break'> </span>of this work. The contract for monument &amp; setting<span class='line-break'> </span>properly include all here charged you. Please send<span class='line-break'> </span>amount with bill.</p>
<p>Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1869-01-12'>Jany 12<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/104026' title='Lamson, H.'>H. Lamson Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclose the<span class='line-break'> </span>deed of <a href='/pages/subjects/73774' title='Lot 3556'>lot 3556</a> for you to execute<span class='line-break'> </span>the transfer to the <a href='/pages/subjects/104054' title='Hadley, Israel P.'>Hadley heirs</a> at<span class='line-break'> </span>the request of <a href='/pages/subjects/104055' title='Howe, Rowena H.'>Mrs <!--R. H.-->Howe</a> the one who<span class='line-break'> </span>takes the most interest &amp; pays the<span class='line-break'> </span>bills. As you have repeatedly<span class='line-break'> </span>told me that you have nothing<span class='line-break'> </span>to do with the lot &amp; the estate<span class='line-break'> </span>is now settled, you will no<span class='line-break'> </span>doubt be glad to get it off your<span class='line-break'> </span>hands.</p>
<p>You can sign, &amp; acknowledge be<span class='line-break'></span>fore some neighbor of yours who<span class='line-break'> </span>is a Justice of the Peace, &amp; return<span class='line-break'> </span>the deed to me at 16 Pemb<span class='line-break'></span>erton Square, <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>.</p>
<p>Yours Respy</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133928">
<h3><a name="page-1133928">CB01_0436_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-01-12'>Jany 12 [18]69</date></p>
<p>Mr Coolidge regrets to have to write<span class='line-break'> </span>Mrs Belknap again on what seems<span class='line-break'> </span>to him so plain a case. Mrs<span class='line-break'> </span>B. still ignores the fact that the<span class='line-break'> </span>bill presented her is <u>not</u> for the same<span class='line-break'> </span>year as the one which she claims<span class='line-break'> </span>she paid <date when='1865-11-30'>Nov. 30, 1865</date>, &amp; which<span class='line-break'> </span>it is allowed she paid on that date.<span class='line-break'> </span>That was $17.00 for the year <u>1865</u>, as<span class='line-break'> </span>her receipt shows.</p>
<p>The bill sent by the present Treas<span class='line-break'></span>urer is for the year <u>1864</u>, amounting<span class='line-break'> </span>to $7. This was ordered by Mrs<span class='line-break'> </span>Codman, &amp; the books do not show,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; Mrs Belknap does not show that<span class='line-break'> </span>it has ever been paid.</p>
<p>It is hoped that said bill will<span class='line-break'> </span>be paid without further trouble.</p>
<p>To <a href='/pages/subjects/94123' title='Belknap, J., Mrs.'>Mrs J. Belknap</a></p>
<p><date when='1869-01-16'>Jany 16<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94124' title='Cains, William'>W<sup>m</sup> Cains</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>A bill for care<span class='line-break'> </span>of lot in 1867 of $10. is still due.<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/94125' title='Cains, Mrs.'>Mrs Cains</a> thought bill was paid, but<span class='line-break'> </span>would look for receipt. I have since<span class='line-break'> </span>sent bill for 1868 --</p>
<p>Allow me to press once more<span class='line-break'> </span>upon your attention the fact that<span class='line-break'> </span>the old accts. must be settled, either<span class='line-break'> </span>by payment or evidence of previous<span class='line-break'> </span>payment. We have searched our<span class='line-break'> </span>books, &amp; they do not show a payment.</p>
<p>Mrs Cains also requested me<span class='line-break'> </span>to prepare deed for you to execute,<span class='line-break'> </span>which has been waiting for you these<span class='line-break'> </span>two months.</p>
<p>Respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>436<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133929">
<h3><a name="page-1133929">CB01_0437_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-01-22'>Jany 22<sup>d</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p>Mr <a href='/pages/subjects/65213' title='Merrill, Lewis F.'>L.F. Merrill</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>If the bill<span class='line-break'> </span>due from you to the Prop<sup>rs</sup> of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Cemetery of Mount Auburn<span class='line-break'> </span>is not paid forthwith, I<span class='line-break'> </span>shall proceed to recover the<span class='line-break'> </span>same by process of law.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1869-03-16'>March 16<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94138' title='Goldsbury, John'>John Goldsbury</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The Committee<span class='line-break'> </span>on Lots have fixed upon<span class='line-break'> </span>four hundred dollars as<span class='line-break'> </span>the amount to be paid<span class='line-break'> </span>for the perpetual care of the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot owned by you as trustee<span class='line-break'> </span>of estate of <a href='/pages/subjects/94139' title='Goddard, Jonathan'>Jona. Goddard</a>.</p>
<p>Very Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p>437<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133930">
<h3><a name="page-1133930">CB01_0438_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-03-16'>March 16<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94140' title='Drew, C. H.'>C.H. Drew</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I think <a href='/pages/subjects/60688' title='Hildreth, Mr.'>Mr Hildreth</a><span class='line-break'> </span>will not say that <a href='/pages/subjects/94141' title='Bassett, Mr.'>Mr Bassett</a><span class='line-break'> </span>applied to him for $9,000. Today<span class='line-break'> </span>is the first any such request has<span class='line-break'> </span>been made to me. I have<span class='line-break'> </span>agreed however to ask the<span class='line-break'> </span>Committee further, and am<span class='line-break'> </span>willing to abide by their decision.</p>
<p>If they are unwilling to increase<span class='line-break'> </span>the sum, I shall hold <a href='/pages/subjects/94141' title='Bassett, Mr.'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>Bassett</a> responsible for the<span class='line-break'> </span>bargain made with his agent,<span class='line-break'> </span>and to some extent with me,<span class='line-break'> </span>by <a href='/pages/subjects/94141' title='Bassett, Mr.'>Mr Bassett</a>. I am to<span class='line-break'> </span>reply to <a href='/pages/subjects/60688' title='Hildreth, Mr.'>Mr Hildreth</a> by 5 p.m.<span class='line-break'> </span>if possible. I do not wish<span class='line-break'> </span>to make Mr B. any trouble,<span class='line-break'> </span>but I confess I don't like this<span class='line-break'> </span>feature of the affair. I also<span class='line-break'> </span>stated to <a href='/pages/subjects/60688' title='Hildreth, Mr.'>Mr Hildreth</a> that<span class='line-break'> </span>I had but $8,000 to loan on<span class='line-break'> </span>mortgage, &amp; , he tells me that<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/94141' title='Bassett, Mr.'>Mr Bassett</a> said in his<span class='line-break'> </span>application to him -- he wanted<span class='line-break'> </span>"eight or nine thousand", and<span class='line-break'> </span>never before today that he<span class='line-break'> </span>must have $9,000. --</p>
<p>The Commissioner's valuation<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; the City valuation are $10,000. The<span class='line-break'> </span>estate I am told was sold to<span class='line-break'> </span>Mr Pitman for $13,000, and even<span class='line-break'> </span>if it were worth $20,000, I am<span class='line-break'> </span>not pleased with what seems to<span class='line-break'> </span>me an alteration of the [proposal?]<span class='line-break'> </span>after the terms had been agreed<span class='line-break'> </span>upon by his agent.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y &amp; Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>438</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133931">
<h3><a name="page-1133931">CB01_0439_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-03-16'>March 16<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94142' title='Kimball, Daniel'>Daniel Kimball</a> Esq<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>At your request, an<span class='line-break'> </span>examination of and report upon your<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/94143' title='Lot 874'>lot no 874</a> in the Cemetery has been<span class='line-break'> </span>made, and the Committee upon<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots have considered your<span class='line-break'> </span>application and have directed <span class='line-break'> </span>me to inform you that this<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation will contract to keep<span class='line-break'> </span>said lot forever in good repair<span class='line-break'> </span>for four hundred and fifty<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars. ($450.)</p>
<p>If this amount shall be sat<span class='line-break'></span>isfactory, I will prepare the nec<span class='line-break'></span>essary papers, when so notified.</p>
<p>Very Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1869-03-16'>March 16<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94144' title='Peck, A. G.'>A.G. Peck</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your request<span class='line-break'> </span>has been duly laid before the<span class='line-break'> </span>Com. on Lots, together with the<span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent's report upon lots num<span class='line-break'></span>bered <a href='/pages/subjects/94145' title='Lot 2498'><!--Lot-->2498</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/94146' title='Lot 2499'><!--Lot-->2499</a> belonging to you &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>the heirs of late <a href='/pages/subjects/94147' title='Boles, John'>John Boles</a>: and after<span class='line-break'> </span>due consideration I have been directed<span class='line-break'> </span>to inform you that this Corpora<span class='line-break'></span>tion will contract for the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>care of both said lots and tomb,<span class='line-break'> </span>on payment of five hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>and fifty dollars -- ($550)</p>
<p>If the amount is satisfactory<span class='line-break'> </span>to you, I will when requested by<span class='line-break'> </span>you prepare the necessary<span class='line-break'> </span>papers. --</p>
<p>Very Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec &amp; Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>439<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133932">
<h3><a name="page-1133932">CB01_0440_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>440</p>
<p><date when='1869-03-19'>March 19 [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I wish you would put down the<span class='line-break'> </span>following things to be done sure before you get<span class='line-break'> </span>busy with spring work -- The surveyor has minutes,<span class='line-break'> </span>and will cooperate with you the moment you<span class='line-break'> </span>are ready, which I trust will be within a fort<span class='line-break'></span>night as the frost will not trouble you much then.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94149' title='Bonney, William L.'>William L. Bonney</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/93772' title='Lot 3821'>Lot 3821</a> -- 405 feet --<span class='line-break'> </span>Ornamental Gr. 124 [feet]</p>
<p>The surveyor has put the lot upon the plan as<span class='line-break'> </span>the posts ^<sup>are</sup> set I presume -- but he did not know<span class='line-break'> </span>anything about a portion of it being ornamental<span class='line-break'> </span>ground to be made and shown in a different<span class='line-break'> </span>deed from the lot proper. I wish him informed<span class='line-break'> </span>where the line falls between burial lot &amp; ornamental,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; he will mark same on plan -- with figures, so that<span class='line-break'> </span>I can make the deed.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/67275' title='Lot 3482'>Lot 3482</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/93774' title='Brown, Joseph A.'>Joseph A. Brown</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/72315' title='Fountain Avenue'>Fountain Av<sup>e</sup></a> --</p>
<p>Addition of 163 feet. Your men set the posts wrong.<span class='line-break'> </span>Let them set them in presence of surveyor. I suppose<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/93774' title='Brown, Joseph A.'>Mr Brown</a> has called nearly a dozen times for this deed.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59203' title='Lot 459'>Lot 459</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/64297' title='Suter, John'>John Suter</a>'s heirs: <a href='/pages/subjects/60390' title='Holly Path'>Holly Path</a> -- 309 feet --<span class='line-break'> </span>Posts to be set on both sides of fence. French has staked it.<span class='line-break'> </span>I send herewith Mr Suter's order. This land<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133933">
<h3><a name="page-1133933">CB01_0441_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>441</p>
<p>was purchased two years ago last November. --</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95393' title='Gibson, Charles Dana'>Chas. Dana Gibson</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/73831' title='Lot 3629'>Lot 3629</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/58081' title='Halcyon Avenue'>Halcyon Av<sup>e</sup></a> --<span class='line-break'> </span><u>Ornamental Ground</u> -- 80 feet. That everlasting<span class='line-break'> </span>triangle --purchased <date when='1865-12-13'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 13, 1865</date> = 3 yrs. 3 mos. 6 ds.<span class='line-break'> </span>since. Do set three posts. There is an exact<span class='line-break'> </span>copy of the sketch you then reported. How near<span class='line-break'> </span>it is to the fact I cannot say. Mr Foss<span class='line-break'> </span>stake it, [diagram: measurements] if you will execute.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95394' title='Thomas, William'>W<sup>m</sup> Thomas</a> --<a href='/pages/subjects/95395' title='Lot 1520'> 1520</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/61156' title='Columbine Path'>Columbine <!--Path-->--</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Addition of 11 in x 20 = 18 feet reported <date when='1868-05-16'>May 16, 1868</date>.<span class='line-break'> </span>Is this on the east or west side of lot? --</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95396' title='Lot 3125'>3125</a> --<a href='/pages/subjects/95397' title='Turpin, John P.'>John P. Turpin's</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/59966' title='Acanthus Path'>Acanthus P.</a> --<span class='line-break'> </span>Addition -- never paid for, but buried upon --<span class='line-break'> </span>you reported [diagram: measurements] 33 ft -- He has always<span class='line-break'> </span>contended that he wished only enough to clear the<span class='line-break'> </span>grave properly -- I think abt 21 feet. He refuses<span class='line-break'> </span>to pay for 33 ft -- says he distinctly ordered only enough<span class='line-break'> </span>for the grave of <a href='/pages/subjects/95398' title='Rogers, Capt.'>Capt Rogers</a>. If you can re-report it<span class='line-break'> </span>so as to suit him, I should like to end it.</p>
<p>This was reported <date when='1867-09-21'>Sept. 21, 1867</date> --</p>
<p>Under the rule, I do not think you should wait<span class='line-break'> </span>longer for <a href='/pages/subjects/93755' title='Bates, Martin'>Martin Bates</a> heirs -- <a href='/pages/subjects/72194' title='Lot 3599'>3599</a> -- <a href='/pages/subjects/61234' title='Moss Path'>Moss Path</a> -- reported<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1865-12-30'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 30, 1865</date> -- and <a href='/pages/subjects/25004530' title='Tufts, Nathan, Jr.'>Nathan Tufts Jr.</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/81490' title='Lot 3734'>3734</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/59984' title='Rosebay Avenue'>Rosebay<span class='line-break'> </span>Ave.</a> -- reported <date when='1866-12-22'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 22, 1866</date> -- but post them. --</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133934">
<h3><a name="page-1133934">CB01_0442_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-03-23'>March 23  [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>As soon as the ground<span class='line-break'> </span>will permit, please report upon<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/73831' title='Lot 3629'>lot no. 3629</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/58081' title='Halcyon Avenue'>Halcyon Av<sup>e</sup></a> -- of<span class='line-break'> </span>late <a href='/pages/subjects/95393' title='Gibson, Charles Dana'>Chas. D. Gibson</a>, for perpetual repair.</p>
<p>I enclose letter of our old<span class='line-break'> </span>friend <a href='/pages/subjects/95409' title='Whipple, Hannah G.'>Mrs Hannah G. Whipple</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>who does not appear yet to have been "put<span class='line-break'> </span>in that hole in some back corner". There<span class='line-break'> </span>is an order for 1866 by "DLH" -- none<span class='line-break'> </span>for 1867 or 1868 --</p>
<p>The books show charge for 1866 -  5.00<span class='line-break'> </span>[for] 1867 -- 5.00<span class='line-break'> </span>[for] 1868 -- 4.00<span class='line-break'> </span>[total] 14.00</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/56312' title='Norcross, Otis'>Mr Norcross</a> asked me to <span class='line-break'> </span>send you the note &amp; ask for reply --<span class='line-break'> </span>Please return note of Mrs Whipple.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>I sent letter to <a href='/pages/subjects/95410' title='Parks, John A.'>Mr<span class='line-break'> </span>John A. Parks</a>, now<span class='line-break'> </span>prop<sup>r</sup> of the Maverick Hon.<span class='line-break'> </span>E. Boston amounting to <span class='line-break'> </span>$26.50 -- who replies that<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corp<sup>n</sup> have cut off<span class='line-break'> </span>a part of his lot by the<span class='line-break'> </span>path into <a href='/pages/subjects/59983' title='Hazel Dell'>Hazel Dell</a>.</p>
<p>His <a href='/pages/subjects/95411' title='Lot 2319'>lot is 2319</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/58791' title='Central Avenue'>Central<span class='line-break'> </span>Av<sup>e</sup></a>. Will you please<span class='line-break'> </span>put the tape on to lot,<span class='line-break'> </span>see if he has not still<span class='line-break'> </span>300 sq. feet?</p>
<p>I should not say<span class='line-break'> </span>judging from the plan that<span class='line-break'> </span>he has lost any land.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J.C</a>.</p>
<p>442</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133935">
<h3><a name="page-1133935">CB01_0443_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-03-24'>Mar. 24 [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have sent to the<span class='line-break'> </span>Superintendent of the Cemetery &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>asked him to measure your<span class='line-break'> </span>lot, &amp; he reports that it con<span class='line-break'></span>tains the full measure of<span class='line-break'> </span>300 feet. But this is a singular<span class='line-break'> </span>objection to be ayed the first time<span class='line-break'> </span>at least ten years after the path<span class='line-break'> </span>was made into <a href='/pages/subjects/59983' title='Hazel Dell'>Hazel Dell</a>. The<span class='line-break'> </span>path is made upon Corporation land,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; the Trustees had a perfect right to<span class='line-break'> </span>make it -- and it is without injury <span class='line-break'> </span>to you.</p>
<p>I am sorry to say that unless<span class='line-break'> </span>you pay the bills presented (which<span class='line-break'> </span>you talk about <u>offsetting</u> by claim for land)<span class='line-break'> </span>I shall have to put them in suit.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Treas<sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/95410' title='Parks, John A.'>J.A. Parks Esq</a></p>
<p>443<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133936">
<h3><a name="page-1133936">CB01_0444_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>444</p>
<p><date when='1869-04-13'>April 13<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95415' title='Post, S. A., Mrs.'>Mrs S.A. Post</a>, 15 Washington Place <a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>N.Y. City</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I have had occasion through<span class='line-break'> </span>several recent calls made upon me for the pur<span class='line-break'></span>pose which is hereinafter stated, to examine<span class='line-break'> </span>the will of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/64871' title='Pelby, William'>W<sup>m</sup> Pelby</a>: and a more<span class='line-break'> </span>involved piece of legal lore I have rarely met<span class='line-break'> </span>with -- speaking from a lawyer's standpoint.<span class='line-break'> </span>I have studied it severely, and learned what<span class='line-break'> </span>I could from the other sources of the parties in interest<span class='line-break'> </span>and can only say -- "It's a pity that <a href='/pages/subjects/64871' title='Pelby, William'>Mr Pelby</a><span class='line-break'> </span>could not have looked through the maze of history<span class='line-break'> </span>of his family, and seen what it would come to --<span class='line-break'> </span>and all but a few sentences would have been <span class='line-break'> </span>saved of this long document.</p>
<p>So much for preamble. I am informed<span class='line-break'> </span>that <a href='/pages/subjects/95417' title='Hague, Julia'>Mrs Julia Hague</a>, and <a href='/pages/subjects/95418' title='Roby, Sophia'>Mrs Sophia Roby</a> --<span class='line-break'> </span>the half sisters of <a href='/pages/subjects/64871' title='Pelby, William'>Mr Pelby</a> -- are the only surviving<span class='line-break'> </span>heirs. If I am right in this, then my<span class='line-break'> </span>business is with these two ladies alone, through<span class='line-break'> </span>you (if you please) as a friend.</p>
<p>When a proprietor dies, by the provisions of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Charter of our Coporation, the Board of Trustees<span class='line-break'> </span>are required to designate <u>which one</u> of his heirs<span class='line-break'> </span>(if he leaves more than one) shall represent his lot in the</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133937">
<h3><a name="page-1133937">CB01_0445_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>445</p>
<p>Cemetery -- and this designation generally lasts<span class='line-break'> </span>for the lifetime of the person so appointed. -- If  <a href='/pages/subjects/95417' title='Hague, Julia'>Mrs<span class='line-break'> </span><del>you</del> Hague</a> and <a href='/pages/subjects/95418' title='Roby, Sophia'>Mrs Roby</a> are the only heirs they should<span class='line-break'> </span>both sign a petition to the Trustees to appoint<span class='line-break'> </span>one of them to represent the lot. Where there are<span class='line-break'> </span>but two they should both agree, as neither con<span class='line-break'></span>stitutes a majority. I have heard it intimated<span class='line-break'> </span>that there is but little intercourse between these<span class='line-break'> </span>ladies, but know nothing about it, and only refer<span class='line-break'> </span>to the matter to say that in a matter of this<span class='line-break'> </span>kind it is important that they should waive<span class='line-break'> </span>differences, so that the lot may not go unrepresen<span class='line-break'></span>ted. If, however, parties will not concur, the<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees are authorized to appoint a person --<span class='line-break'> </span>one or the other heir. I trust this will not<span class='line-break'> </span>be necessary. It has hardly ever been resorted<span class='line-break'> </span>to, <del>without the</del> and should be avoided, as<span class='line-break'> </span>no fair opportunity can be given for a hearing.</p>
<p>I therefore send you a blank made out<span class='line-break'> </span>as far as it can be for signature. I am half<span class='line-break'> </span>inclined to think <a href='/pages/subjects/64871' title='Pelby, William'>W<sup>m</sup> R. Pelby</a> had died <u>before</u><span class='line-break'> </span>his father -- if so the pen should be drawn across<span class='line-break'> </span>that line.</p>
<p>If you get the concurrence of the ladies --<span class='line-break'> </span>that is -- their signature in favor of one of them --<span class='line-break'> </span>so much of the work will have been done. It<span class='line-break'> </span>is a pity that this tomb should be left without<span class='line-break'> </span>heirs: and the Corporation cannot recognize<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133938">
<h3><a name="page-1133938">CB01_0446_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>446</p>
<p>any but those of record; and this is<span class='line-break'> </span>the only way now to get on record-</p>
<p>If <a href='/pages/subjects/95417' title='Hague, Julia'>Mrs. H.<!--Hague--></a> declines to confer with <a href='/pages/subjects/95418' title='Roby, Sophia'>Mrs<span class='line-break'> </span>R.<!--Roby--></a>, you had better state how I can find her,<span class='line-break'> </span>or who here knows, if you don't know her<span class='line-break'> </span>address.</p>
<p>I presume this; some friend of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/95419' title='Hodges, Sarah'>Mrs Sarah Hodges</a>, now 86 yrs old &amp; very<span class='line-break'> </span>feeble- has written you that Mrs S. expects<span class='line-break'> </span>soon to die, and wishes burial in this tomb,<span class='line-break'> </span>under a promise from <a href='/pages/subjects/64871' title='Pelby, William'>Mr Pelby</a> himself. I<span class='line-break'> </span>know nothing of the propriety of the request - it<span class='line-break'> </span>is a matter for the heirs to decide. But<span class='line-break'> </span>as the case standa today, no one has any<span class='line-break'> </span>right to order the tomb opened, or to give any<span class='line-break'> </span>direction about anything on the lot --</p>
<p>Although the request of Mrs. Hodges<span class='line-break'> </span>may have been the <u>immediate</u> occasion of my<span class='line-break'> </span>writing you, through a promise to do so to quiet<span class='line-break'> </span>the mind of the old lady -- yet you perceive that<span class='line-break'> </span><u>my</u> part of the errand more particularly re<span class='line-break'></span>lates to the matter first stated -- the re<span class='line-break'></span>solution of the lot.</p>
<p>Hoping soon to hear from you, I<span class='line-break'> </span>am</p>
<p>Respectfully your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a>, Secretary<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133939">
<h3><a name="page-1133939">CB01_0447_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-04-20'>Apr. 20<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95415' title='Post, S. A., Mrs.'>Mrs S.A. Post</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I am sorry for <span class='line-break'> </span>the brevity of your communication<span class='line-break'> </span>in reply to mine respecting the Pelby<span class='line-break'> </span>lot. I must suppose either that<span class='line-break'> </span>][Hague, Julia|Mrs Hague]] is indifferent to the<span class='line-break'> </span>matter, or regards me as soliciting<span class='line-break'> </span>some favor -- which is certainly<span class='line-break'> </span>not so. If Mrs H. disclaims all<span class='line-break'> </span>connection with and ownership<span class='line-break'> </span>in the tomb, it is very proper to<span class='line-break'> </span>say so, and if her sister does the<span class='line-break'> </span>same, the Trustees will then under<span class='line-break'></span>stand what course to pursue.<span class='line-break'> </span>They will order the tomb closed<span class='line-break'> </span>and regard everyone as barred<span class='line-break'> </span>from exercising any authority in<span class='line-break'> </span>regard to it. But if, on the<span class='line-break'> </span>other hand, Mrs Hague desires<span class='line-break'> </span>to retain her interest in and right <span class='line-break'> </span>over the lot, I think she should<span class='line-break'> </span>answer more particularly the<span class='line-break'> </span>questions I asked. She has<span class='line-break'> </span>indeed signed the paper sent, but<span class='line-break'> </span>has not indicated her wishes<span class='line-break'> </span>in case <a href='/pages/subjects/95418' title='Roby, Sophia'>Mrs Roby</a> refuses.<span class='line-break'> </span>But I first wish to know<span class='line-break'> </span>where <a href='/pages/subjects/95418' title='Roby, Sophia'>Mrs Roby</a> is, before<span class='line-break'> </span>I can ascertain whether she<span class='line-break'> </span>refuses. You say -- "the last<span class='line-break'> </span>she knew of <u>her,</u> she was living<span class='line-break'> </span>at her daughter's in <a href='/pages/subjects/95420' title='Portland, ME'>Portland Maine</a>".<span class='line-break'> </span>What is her daughter's name -- to<span class='line-break'> </span>whom married, if a married<span class='line-break'> </span>woman. I must be able to address<span class='line-break'> </span>some one, particularly in so large<span class='line-break'> </span>a place.</p>
<p>Now, although this is not my duty,<span class='line-break'> </span>I am willing to assist so far as you<span class='line-break'> </span>desire.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>Did <a href='/pages/subjects/64871' title='Pelby, William'>W<sup>m</sup> R. Pelby</a> die before<span class='line-break'> </span>his father?</p>
<p>447</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133940">
<h3><a name="page-1133940">CB01_0448_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>Apr. 20<sup>th</sup> [18]69</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/81833' title='Chapman, T. A.'>T.A. Chapman</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>In reply to your<span class='line-break'> </span>communication of <date when='1869-04-20'>Jany 26<sup>th</sup></date> re<span class='line-break'></span>specting care of your lot this season,<span class='line-break'> </span>I have waited to inquire at Mt<span class='line-break'> </span>Auburn before replying.</p>
<p>No proper care can be given<span class='line-break'> </span>to your lot for "three or three<span class='line-break'> </span>and a half dollars". It is<span class='line-break'> </span>a fine lot among other beautiful<span class='line-break'> </span>lots, none of which have less<span class='line-break'> </span>than $8.00 worth of work for<span class='line-break'> </span>cutting grass &amp; plants.</p>
<p>If you wish it to be in <span class='line-break'> </span>keeping with other lots in the<span class='line-break'> </span>neighborhood, you should <span class='line-break'> </span>give us your order for "care <span class='line-break'> </span>of lot for 1869, with <u>plants</u> $8.00."</p>
<p>Or we will keep the grass<span class='line-break'> </span>well cut for $5. -- Your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>has 400 feet, &amp; these rates<span class='line-break'> </span>are the same that we have<span class='line-break'> </span>for lots of 200 feet --</p>
<p>Only the smallest lots<span class='line-break'> </span>can be taken for such rates<span class='line-break'> </span>as you named.</p>
<p>The price at <a href='/pages/subjects/95421' title='Forest Hills Cemetery, Jamaica Plain'>Forest Hills<span class='line-break'> </span>Cemetery</a> (as per circular before <span class='line-break'> </span>me) "for the annual care of a lot<span class='line-break'> </span>of 300 feet, with flowers is 8.00:<span class='line-break'> </span>for a lot of 300 feet without<span class='line-break'> </span>flowers $5.00."</p>
<p>I trust you will not<span class='line-break'> </span>let so beautiful a lot<span class='line-break'> </span>fall behind -- for after all,<span class='line-break'> </span>a fine [lot] cannot well be neglected<span class='line-break'> </span>for a single year. "This proprietor<span class='line-break'> </span>does not visit his lot" -- is the judgment<span class='line-break'> </span>of the passer by on lots uncared for.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>448</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133941">
<h3><a name="page-1133941">CB01_0449_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-05-15'>May 15<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95426' title='White, J. J.'>J.J. White</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclose bills due<span class='line-break'> </span>from your mother &amp; sister. They<span class='line-break'> </span>have been sent sometime since to <a href='/pages/subjects/62295' title='Newton, MA'>Newton</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; returned through the dead letter office.<span class='line-break'> </span>It was some time before I found out<span class='line-break'> </span>that your mother had gone to your<span class='line-break'> </span>place, &amp; your sister to Europe.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95545' title='Kinmouth, Mrs.'>Mrs Kinmouth</a> (who I learn has<span class='line-break'> </span>again married) ^<sup>(I don't know the name)</sup> has bill of $23.06 for<span class='line-break'> </span>grading &amp; $17. for gardening -- which I presume<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/60695' title='Brigham, William'>Mr Brigham</a> will pay if directed.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95546' title='White, Mrs.'>Mrs White's</a> bills are $57.85 for foun<span class='line-break'></span>dation for mon<sup>t</sup> &amp;c. &amp; $21.00 for gardening.</p>
<p>Early attention to said bills<span class='line-break'> </span>will much oblige.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1869-05-15'>May 15<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 5<sup>th</sup> with enclosure<span class='line-break'> </span>of deed of lot <a href='/pages/subjects/67262' title='Lot 3469'>3469</a> &amp; $13 to pay bills<span class='line-break'> </span>was duly rec<sup>d</sup>. I return the deed whc.<span class='line-break'> </span>has been recorded.</p>
<p>As $2. the fee for record was requisite<span class='line-break'> </span>I took that amt from the $13. &amp; applied<span class='line-break'> </span>$1. for interest -- making the old bill<span class='line-break'> </span>$11 &amp; fee for deed $2 -- &amp; than return<span class='line-break'> </span>all to you free of charge.</p>
<p>I sent out at once to <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. Win<span class='line-break'></span>sor</a>, the Sup<sup>t</sup>, to have an estimate<span class='line-break'> </span>of the cost of the work you desire to<span class='line-break'> </span>be done, &amp; when I get his answer,<span class='line-break'> </span>I will inform you --</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y &amp; Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95428' title='Messinger, C. R.'>C.R. Messinger</a> Esq</p>
<p>449<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133942">
<h3><a name="page-1133942">CB01_0450_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-05-20'>May 20 [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/72272' title='Channing, Henrietta A. S.'>Mrs.Mrs H.A.S. Channing</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I sent the bill of<span class='line-break'> </span>$4.00 for care of <a href='/pages/subjects/72269' title='Lot 1145'>lot 1145</a>, for year 1868,<span class='line-break'> </span>some time since to <a href='/pages/subjects/95435' title='Smith, C. C.'>C.C. Smith</a> Treas<sup>r</sup> of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/95436' title='Rev. Dr. Gannett&apos;s Society'>Dr Gannett's Society</a>, &amp; he refuses to<span class='line-break'> </span>pay the same, on the ground that<span class='line-break'> </span>the Society has nothing to do with this<span class='line-break'> </span>lot. <a href='/pages/subjects/95437' title='White, B. F., Mr.'>Mr B.F. White</a>, who has always<span class='line-break'> </span>had direction in the matter of care<span class='line-break'> </span>of late <a href='/pages/subjects/95438' title='Channing, William Ellery'>Dr W<sup>m</sup> Ellery Channing's</a> lot,<span class='line-break'> </span>has for several years, paid a bill<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/63917' title='O&apos;Brien'>O'Brien</a> -- our Irish gardener<span class='line-break'> </span>in <a href='/pages/subjects/53203' title='Cambridge, MA'>Cambridge</a> -- of $15.00. I think<span class='line-break'> </span>this bill covers the lot of <a href='/pages/subjects/58496' title='Channing, George G.'>Geo. G.<span class='line-break'> </span>Channing</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/72266' title='Lot 677'>no 677</a> &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/95439' title='Channing, R. Gibbs'>R. Gibbs Channing</a> [67?]<span class='line-break'> </span>both containing 900 square feet --</p>
<p>Your <a href='/pages/subjects/72269' title='Lot 1145'>lot (1145)</a> contains 250 feet<span class='line-break'> </span>and, what makes the case a dis<span class='line-break'></span>agreeable one, is in one enclosure<span class='line-break'> </span>with the other two: for which<span class='line-break'> </span>reason the lots should be [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>fer by only one gardener --</p>
<p>As <a href='/pages/subjects/95437' title='White, B. F., Mr.'>Mr White</a> appears to be <span class='line-break'> </span>partial to <a href='/pages/subjects/63917' title='O&apos;Brien'>O'Brien</a> we do not<span class='line-break'> </span>care to disturb his wishes that<span class='line-break'> </span>O'B should take care of the <span class='line-break'> </span>W. E. C. lot. As to your own<span class='line-break'> </span>we can take charge of it if<span class='line-break'> </span>you wish: but they would appear<span class='line-break'> </span>to better advantage if taken care<span class='line-break'> </span>of together.</p>
<p>The bill of $4. for [1868?] is therefor<span class='line-break'> </span>now returned to you for payment.<span class='line-break'> </span>If you desire us to continue<span class='line-break'> </span>care ^<sup>for [1869?]</sup> you should give a written<span class='line-break'> </span>order to that effect.</p>
<p>Respe.y Your Ob<sup>t</sup> Serv<sup>t</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>450</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133943">
<h3><a name="page-1133943">CB01_0451_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-05-27'>May 27 [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt Winsor</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The following lots are all that<span class='line-break'> </span>have been taken for perpetual repair since<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1868-06'>June 1868</date>. --</p>

Stone</a>'s heirs }</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95491' title='Lot 900'><!--Lot-->900</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/60336' title='Willow Avenue'>Willow Av</a>. E. Gr.</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/56312' title='Norcross, Otis'>Otis Norcross</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>400</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95492' title='Lot 2239'><!--Lot-->2239</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61175' title='Elm Avenue'>Elm Av.</a> Nor. Gr.</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/101519' title='Norcross, Mary C.'>Mary C. Norcross</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>500</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/72268' title='Lot 678'><!--Lot-->678</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61235' title='Mound Avenue'>Mound Av.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/95493' title='White, Abigail'>Abigail White</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>450</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95494' title='Lot 799'><!--Lot-->799</a>}</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/59585' title='Pine Avenue'>Pine Av.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/95495' title='Whitney, William F.'>W<sup>m</sup> F. Whitney</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>450</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95496' title='Lot 800'><!--Lot-->800</a>} </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/65931' title='Lot 1350'><!--Lot-->1350</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61250' title='Oxalis Path'>Oxalis P.</a></td> <td>Heirs <a href='/pages/subjects/66845' title='Loring, Abby M.'>Abby M. Loring</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>1200 --</td> </tr> <tr><td/> <td>(central lot of 600 ft) </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/70564' title='Lot 561'><!--Lot-->561</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/58791' title='Central Avenue'>Central Av.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/70563' title='Lovejoy, Loyal'>Loyal Lovejoy</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>450 --</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95497' title='Lot 3767'><!--Lot-->3767</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/58084' title='Yew Avenue'>Yew Av.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/95498' title='Egerton, James'>James Egerton</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>450</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/81484' title='Lot 3638'><!--Lot-->3638</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61184' title='Galanthus Path'>Galanthus P.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/94138' title='Goldsbury, John'>John Goldsbury</a> Trustee,</td> <td>G.</td> <td>400</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95499' title='Lot 3140'><!--Lot-->3140</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61174' title='Elder Path'>Elder P.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/95500' title='Richardson, Catherine M. E.'>Cath. M. E. Richardson</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>250</td> </tr> <tr><td/> <td>(new sodding &amp; steps first for $50. -- ) </td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/65849' title='Lot 1341'>1341</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/61146' title='Cedar Avenue'>Cedar Av</a>.</td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/65850' title='Humphrey, Benjamin'>Benj. Humphrey</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>850</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95501' title='Lot 3655'><!--Lot-->3655</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/58079' title='Garden Avenue'>Garden Av.</a></td> <td><a href='/pages/subjects/95502' title='Gardner, Leavitt'>Leavitt Gardner</a></td> <td>G.</td> <td>400</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1869-05-27'>May 27<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have just rec<sup>d</sup> from<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/95503' title='Messenger, Charles R.'>Mr Chas. R. Messenger</a> of <a href='/pages/subjects/95504' title='Toledo, OH'>Toledo<span class='line-break'> </span>Ohio</a>, prop<sup>r</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/67262' title='Lot 3469'>lot 3469</a>, the enclosed<span class='line-break'> </span>orders, with his draft to cover the<span class='line-break'> </span>amount -- $65.00 -- paid in advance,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; he desires you to proceed to execute<span class='line-break'> </span>the orders forthwith. $50. for new<span class='line-break'> </span>grading &amp; sodding -- $6. for care of lot<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; plants, &amp; $9. to be "expended in a<span class='line-break'> </span>few suitable flowers, the selection of<span class='line-break'> </span>which I will leave to your Superin<span class='line-break'></span>tendent's taste."</p>
<p>He intends at some day to enclose<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot with curb, but thinks the expen<span class='line-break'></span>ditures here ordered will greatly improve<span class='line-break'> </span>his lot. --</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/71310' title='Richards, Joel'>Mr Joel Richards</a> has<span class='line-break'> </span>just called in, &amp; desires me to say</p>
<p>451<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133944">
<h3><a name="page-1133944">CB01_0452_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>that an order left you <u>yesterday</u> (I think,) by<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/95544' title='Constant, Samuel S.'>Mr Sam. S. Constant</a> of <a href='/pages/subjects/64140' title='New York, NY'>New York</a>, for marble<span class='line-break'> </span>headstones, will be honored when the money<span class='line-break'> </span>is wanted. I can vouch for R. &amp; he vouches for<span class='line-break'> </span>Constant.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1869-05-31'>May 31<sup>st</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95426' title='White, J. J.'>J.J. White</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Yours of 29<sup>th</sup> is rec<sup>d</sup>.<span class='line-break'> </span>I regret the position of the accounts<span class='line-break'> </span>against the lots of your mother &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>sister. I heard that your sister<span class='line-break'> </span>was married again &amp; gone to Europe<span class='line-break'> </span>but supposed your mother was <span class='line-break'> </span>with you. The lots are entirely<span class='line-break'> </span>distinct. Cannot the account<span class='line-break'> </span>against your mother's lot be set<span class='line-break'></span>tled?</p>
<p>We are working now upon<span class='line-break'> </span>written orders? We do not wish<span class='line-break'> </span>to neglect these lots; if <a href='/pages/subjects/95546' title='White, Mrs.'>Mrs White</a><span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/95545' title='Kinmouth, Mrs.'>Mrs Kinmouth</a> wish them cared<span class='line-break'> </span>for -- but as the matter stands we<span class='line-break'> </span>shall certainly have to, unless you<span class='line-break'> </span>can take or procure the respon-</p>
<p>452</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133945">
<h3><a name="page-1133945">CB01_0453_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>sibility necessary for us.</p>
<p>Last year the charge for care<span class='line-break'> </span>on each lot was $12. = $24. besides<span class='line-break'> </span>$5. for myrtle on <a href='/pages/subjects/95545' title='Kinmouth, Mrs.'>Mrs Kinmouth's</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; $7 on your mother's --</p>
<p>My impression is that you had<span class='line-break'> </span>better pay the bills for care of lots,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; planting myrtle, &amp; leave the<span class='line-break'> </span>other bills completed with the<span class='line-break'> </span>monument &amp; sodding, if you<span class='line-break'> </span>think necessary.</p>
<p>We do not like to neglect so pro<span class='line-break'></span>minent lots, &amp; presume the pro<span class='line-break'></span>prietors, when considering the matter,<span class='line-break'> </span>would feel the same aversion;<span class='line-break'> </span>but they must not find fault<span class='line-break'> </span>with the Corporation for neglect, if<span class='line-break'> </span>no evidence of their wishes can be<span class='line-break'> </span>gathered.</p>
<p>I enclose a blank order, which if<span class='line-break'> </span>you sign &amp; return ^<sup>will be</sup> all right.<span class='line-break'> </span>Please give me the name of Mrs K's husband in full.</p>
<p>Yours Respy.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1869-06-04'>June 4<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/66238' title='Langmaid, Samuel P.'>S.P. Langmaid</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I cannot find the evi<span class='line-break'></span>dence, &amp; do not remember, that I have<span class='line-break'> </span>written you stating the conclu<span class='line-break'></span>sion of the Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots as to<span class='line-break'> </span>the am<sup>t</sup> which the Corporation re<span class='line-break'></span>quires for the perpetual guaranty<span class='line-break'> </span>of your <a href='/pages/subjects/73832' title='Lot 170'>lot no. 170</a> -- .</p>
<p>Lest I have neglected to do so,<span class='line-break'> </span>I here state the sum fixed upon by them<span class='line-break'> </span>five hundred dollars. --<span class='line-break'> </span>$500. --</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p>453<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133946">
<h3><a name="page-1133946">CB01_0454_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-06-12'>June 12<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95555' title='Reynolds, B., Mrs.'>Mrs B. Reynolds</a>,</p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>In reply to your <span class='line-break'> </span>note of <date when='1869-05-13'>May 13<sup>th</sup></date> respecting care of <span class='line-break'> </span>your lot last year, I have inquired<span class='line-break'> </span>at the Cemetery, and the Gardener says<span class='line-break'> </span>that he supposed from seeing you frequently<span class='line-break'> </span>there that you felt satisfied to have<span class='line-break'> </span>your lot taken care of -- he moreover<span class='line-break'> </span>thought care was continued on a<span class='line-break'> </span><u>general</u> order, as in many other cases.</p>
<p>We are very glad to have proprietors<span class='line-break'> </span>sufficiently interested in their lots &amp; have<span class='line-break'> </span>them cared for, -- but do not compel<span class='line-break'> </span>such care. Many complain if we<span class='line-break'> </span>do not continue the care, even though<span class='line-break'> </span>they may not themselves go out for the<span class='line-break'> </span>whole year. If you wish your lot cared<span class='line-break'> </span>for this year, you must give a special<span class='line-break'> </span>order. --</p>
<p>Yours Respectfully</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><date when='1869-06-12'>June 12<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95556' title='Coffin, Martha A.'>Miss Martha A. Coffin</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>I rec<sup>d</sup> yours of<span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1869-05-14'>May 14<sup>th</sup></date> in reply to bill of $6 for care<span class='line-break'> </span>of lot last year. We do not <u>compel</u><span class='line-break'> </span>proprietors to pay for annual<span class='line-break'> </span>care -- but most appear to do so cheer<span class='line-break'></span>fully. If you object to pay last year's<span class='line-break'> </span>bill, we shall remit it -- although<span class='line-break'> </span>I have no doubt the lot was cared<span class='line-break'> </span>for as others are -- by continued care,<span class='line-break'> </span>many persons feeling aggrieved, if<span class='line-break'> </span>we neglect their lots.</p>
<p>If you wish anything done this<span class='line-break'> </span>year, there must be a special<span class='line-break'> </span>order. --</p>
<p>Yours Respectfully</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec.y &amp; Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>454<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133947">
<h3><a name="page-1133947">CB01_0455_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-06-12'>June 12<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I sent you bill<span class='line-break'> </span>for $64.75 for grading your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>in Mount Auburn some months<span class='line-break'> </span>since. You complained of dissat<span class='line-break'></span>isfaction, and made an appoint<span class='line-break'></span>ment <del>with the</del> ^<sup>to meet the</sup> <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'><!--Winsor-->Superintendent</a><span class='line-break'> </span>here on a certain day &amp; hour,<span class='line-break'> </span>but you failed to meet the appoint<span class='line-break'></span>ment -- You have not been<span class='line-break'> </span>here to arrange it since,<span class='line-break'> </span>that I can learn --</p>
<p>I must once more request<span class='line-break'> </span>your immediate attention to<span class='line-break'> </span>the bill.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95558' title='Simpson, Robert'>Robert Simpson</a> Esq</p>
<p><date when='1869-06-18'>June 18<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55348' title='Jones, Lewis'>Lewis Jones</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have carefully gone<span class='line-break'> </span>over again the accounts against you<span class='line-break'> </span>and believe them to be correct.</p>
<p>I struck from the charges against<span class='line-break'> </span>you one of $3.00 for unloading stone<span class='line-break'> </span>on <a href='/pages/subjects/95559' title='Lot 510'>lot 510</a> -- sold by you to <a href='/pages/subjects/95560' title='Richardson, H. L.'>H.L. Richardson</a>.</p>
<p>I trust you will settle these<span class='line-break'> </span>forthwith.</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>Am<sup>t</sup> against you personally</th> <th>$54.00<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>" " you for a/c <a href='/pages/subjects/95561' title='Jones, H. H.'>H.H. Jones</a></td> <td>55.95</td> </tr> <tr><td>[total]</td> <td>$109.95</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>455</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133948">
<h3><a name="page-1133948">CB01_0456_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-06-19'>June 19<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
