<p>A letter rec<sup>d</sup> by you some time<span class='line-break'> </span>since by my predecessor was mislaid, so<span class='line-break'> </span>that I didn't know to whom to send the<span class='line-break'> </span>enclosed bills -- and now I am in doubt<span class='line-break'> </span>of one of the initials of your first name --<span class='line-break'> </span>In replying, please write out your name<span class='line-break'> </span>in full. The bills sent herewith are<span class='line-break'> </span>more than 6 mos. overdue --</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>Gardening --</th> <th>$12.00<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>Foundation for headstones</td> <td>4.50</td> </tr> <tr><td>[total]</td> <td>16.50</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>Please also state whether the prop<sup>r</sup> left<span class='line-break'> </span>a will -- if so, how thereunder the lot<span class='line-break'> </span>is disposed of either specifically, or by effect.<span class='line-break'> </span>Also who are his heirs at law -- names, res<span class='line-break'></span>idence &amp; degree of relationship. I will<span class='line-break'> </span>then enclose you one of our blank peti<span class='line-break'></span>tions to represent lot.</p>
<p>Resp.y yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec. &amp; Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95562' title='Stearns, A. C.'>A.C. Stearns</a> Esq</p>
<p><date when='1869-06-18'>June 18<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Will you inquire ^<sup>[?]</sup> send<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/95563' title='Safford, Robert B.'>Robert B. Safford</a> on the following,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; make me a specific answer? --</p>
<p>We have a gardening bill against<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/95564' title='Burge, Lorenzo'>Lorenzo Burge</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/95565' title='Lot 3670'>Lot no. 3670</a>, for 1868,<span class='line-break'> </span>amounting to $8.00 -- on which Mr B. (whom<span class='line-break'> </span>I believe to be a gentleman, &amp; would not<span class='line-break'> </span>intentionally misstate) gives me this ex<span class='line-break'></span>planation --</p>
<p>He paid $20. for deposit of body of his<span class='line-break'> </span>son <a href='/pages/subjects/95566' title='Burge, Lorenzo E.'>Lorenzo E. Burge</a> in <a href='/pages/subjects/57656' title='Receiving Tomb'>R.T.</a> <date when='1866-02-04'>Feby 4, 1866</date><span class='line-break'> </span>and on his removal to <a href='/pages/subjects/95565' title='lot 3670'>lot 3670</a>, <date when='1866-07-02'>July 2 [18]66</date><span class='line-break'> </span>he became entitled to a drawback of<span class='line-break'> </span>$14.00 which has never been refunded.</p>
<p>When R.B.S. brought to him a gar<span class='line-break'></span>dening bill in Dec. 1866 amounting to $11.00<span class='line-break'> </span>Mr B. supposing this had no connection<span class='line-break'> </span>with the interment matter in settlement</p>
<p>456<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133949">
<h3><a name="page-1133949">CB01_0457_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>did not ask to have it taken from<span class='line-break'> </span>the $14. but paid it to <a href='/pages/subjects/95563' title='Safford, Robert B.'>R.B.S. --</a><span class='line-break'> </span>When <a href='/pages/subjects/95563' title='Safford, Robert B.'>R.B.S.</a> brought the bill of $6.00 for<span class='line-break'> </span>care of <a href='/pages/subjects/95577' title='Lot 1867'>lot for 1867</a>, (<a href='/pages/subjects/95564' title='Burge, Lorenzo'>Mr B.<!--Burge--></a> not having then<span class='line-break'> </span>rec<sup>d</sup> anything back of his $14.00) asked <a href='/pages/subjects/95563' title='Safford, Robert B.'>R.B.S.</a><span class='line-break'> </span>if this should not come out: to<span class='line-break'> </span>which <a href='/pages/subjects/95563' title='Safford, Robert B.'><!--R.B.-->Safford</a> assented, and then<span class='line-break'> </span>promised to take good care of his<span class='line-break'> </span>lot for 1868 also for $8.00, and that<span class='line-break'> </span>then the 6.00 &amp; 8.00 would square<span class='line-break'> </span>the account. He therefore asks to<span class='line-break'> </span>pay the 1868 bill in this way. --</p>
<p>I find however (whether cor<span class='line-break'></span>rect or not) on the cash book of Treas<sup>r</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>and also on <a href='/pages/subjects/95563' title='Safford, Robert B.'>R.B.S.'s list</a>, that the $6.<span class='line-break'> </span>for 1867 was p<sup>d</sup> <date when='1867-12-18'>Dec<sup>r</sup> 18, 1867</date>. -- Unless<span class='line-break'> </span>that should have been credited to some<span class='line-break'> </span>other person, &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/95564' title='Burge, Lorenzo'>Mr Burge's</a> story is cor<span class='line-break'></span>rect, we shall still owe him after this<span class='line-break'> </span>last year's bill is settled.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>The following is the vote adopted<span class='line-break'> </span>by the Trustees at the last meeting --</p>
<p>"Voted -- That the practice of charging<span class='line-break'> </span>for land in case of a second interment<span class='line-break'> </span>in a <a href='/pages/subjects/61319' title='Public Lot'>public lot</a> be abolished, and that<span class='line-break'> </span>the by laws relating to interments be<span class='line-break'> </span>so amended as to substitute further clause --</p>
<p>"Where more than one interment is made<span class='line-break'> </span>in the same grave, the last shall be at<span class='line-break'> </span>least three feet below the surface of the ground,"<span class='line-break'> </span>the following --</p>
<p>"Not more than two in<span class='line-break'></span>terments shall be made in the same<span class='line-break'> </span>grave, the latter of which shall<span class='line-break'> </span>be at least three feet below the<span class='line-break'> </span>surface of the ground."</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p><date when='1869-06-18'>June 18, 1869</date></p>
<p>Please show ^<sup>or state</sup> this to the Gatekeeper &amp; undertaker --</p>
<p>457<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133950">
<h3><a name="page-1133950">CB01_0458_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-06-22'>June 22<sup>d</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95707' title='Baldwin, Edward'>Edward Baldwin</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir: --</p>
<p>Yours of 9<sup>th</sup> with $4. for<span class='line-break'> </span>bill of 1868 on the <a href='/pages/subjects/95708' title='Davis, I. T., Mr.'>I.T. Davis</a> lot was duly re<span class='line-break'></span>ceived, as also yours of 21<sup>st</sup> inquiring after<span class='line-break'> </span>same. --</p>
<p>I have had yours of 9<sup>th</sup> with bill receipted<span class='line-break'> </span>and an envelope addressed to you lying before<span class='line-break'> </span>me ever since, waiting for me to see <a href='/pages/subjects/95713' title='Prince, F. O., Mr.'>F.O.<span class='line-break'> </span>Prince</a> Esq about the succession to the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot, so that I might reply to you<span class='line-break'> </span>understandingly. I called several times<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; could not find him in, and on Satur<span class='line-break'></span>day did see him, &amp; should have<span class='line-break'> </span>written you yesterday if I had had<span class='line-break'> </span>time.</p>
<p>As I am accustomed to gather<span class='line-break'> </span>from the Probate offices the facts con<span class='line-break'></span>nected with the estate of deceased<span class='line-break'> </span>persons as bearing upon the<span class='line-break'> </span>inheritance of their burial lots, I had<span class='line-break'> </span>noted an intricate class of facts con<span class='line-break'></span>nected with the Davis Estate. By our<span class='line-break'> </span>Charter, a burial lot is <u>real estate</u>,<span class='line-break'> </span>subject to the rules of descent &amp; devise<span class='line-break'> </span>applicable to other real estate. -- And <span class='line-break'> </span>when a proprietor dies our board<span class='line-break'> </span>of Trustees are required to designate<span class='line-break'> </span><u>which one</u> of his heirs or devisees<span class='line-break'> </span>shall represent a lot. After the death<span class='line-break'> </span>of Mr Davis, <a href='/pages/subjects/95710' title='Davis, Mrs.'>Mrs <!--I. T.-->Davis</a> was so<span class='line-break'> </span>designated. Upon her death a vacancy<span class='line-break'> </span>has occurred in the representation.</p>
<p>I find from Mr Davis' will that<span class='line-break'> </span>one half of his estate was disposed<span class='line-break'> </span>of to certain of his heirs under trust --<span class='line-break'> </span>the other half to Mrs D. for life,<span class='line-break'> </span>with power in her to appoint in what<span class='line-break'> </span>manner it should go after her death.<span class='line-break'> </span>Mrs Davis, after certain legacies, gives<span class='line-break'> </span>her half of the residence to Mrs Wood &amp;</p>
<p>458<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133951">
<h3><a name="page-1133951">CB01_0459_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95711' title='Prince, F. O., Mrs.'>Mrs<!--F. O.--> Prince</a>, <u>her</u> neices. I learn<span class='line-break'> </span>that no children of <a href='/pages/subjects/95708' title='Davis, I. T., Mr.'>Mr <!--I.T.-->Davis</a> (and I believe)<span class='line-break'> </span>no grandchildren survive -- but that his<span class='line-break'> </span>half has descended to certain nephews &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>neices -- one or both. However that may<span class='line-break'> </span>be, by the operation of his will, his lot<span class='line-break'> </span>belongs, one half to his heirs &amp; one<span class='line-break'> </span>half to <a href='/pages/subjects/95712' title='Davis, I. T., Mrs.'>Mrs <!--I.T.-->D's</a> heirs, or rather devisees.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95713' title='Prince, F. O., Mr.'>Mr Prince</a> desires me to say to you<span class='line-break'> </span>that <a href='/pages/subjects/95712' title='Davis, I. T., Mrs.'><u>Mrs</u> <!--I.T.-->Davis'</a> heirs are provided<span class='line-break'> </span>with a burial lot, and will relin<span class='line-break'></span>quish all their intereset to the Davis<span class='line-break'> </span>heirs.</p>
<p>Upon your reply to this proposition of<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/95713' title='Prince, F. O., Mr.'>Mr Prince</a>, and stating to me who<span class='line-break'> </span>the Davis heirs now are, their degree<span class='line-break'> </span>of relationship &amp;c. -- I will send you one<span class='line-break'> </span>of our representative blanks, filled<span class='line-break'> </span>out so far as may be, for the signatures<span class='line-break'> </span>of the parties in interest.</p>
<p>Truly yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec. &amp; Tr.</p>
<p><date when='1869-07-20'>July 20<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/66698' title='Hunnewell, H. H.'>H.H. Hunnewell</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The few week since<span class='line-break'> </span>I wrote you inquiring about <a href='/pages/subjects/95714' title='Smith, Eliza'>Mrs Eliza<span class='line-break'> </span>Smith's</a> decease, but presume you have over<span class='line-break'></span>looked the note, as I have rec<sup>d</sup> no reply.</p>
<p>The question is whether <a href='/pages/subjects/95714' title='Smith, Eliza'>Mrs Eliza<span class='line-break'> </span>Smith</a> prop<sup>r</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/95715' title='Lot 132'>lot 132</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/60336' title='Willow Avenue'>Willow Av<sup>e</sup></a> is dec<sup>d</sup>, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>if so, when she died? <date when='1868-05-12'>May 12, 1868</date> you signed<span class='line-break'> </span>an order for interm<sup>t</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/95716' title='Greenleaf, F. S.'>F.S. Greenleaf</a> in her lot<span class='line-break'> </span>in the words -- "<a href='/pages/subjects/66698' title='Hunnewell, H. H.'>H.H. Hunnewell</a> Ex<sup>or</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/95714' title='Smith, Eliza'>Eliza Smith</a>."</p>
<p>I find <a href='/pages/subjects/95714' title='Smith, Eliza'>Eliza Smith</a> (whom I sup<span class='line-break'></span>pose to be the mother of Mr Durant) was<span class='line-break'> </span>interred in <a href='/pages/subjects/95717' title='Lot 484'>lot 484</a> upon order signed by<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/95718' title='Durant, Henry F.'>Henry F. Durant</a>, <date when='1868-02-20'>Feby 20, 1868</date>.</p>
<p>Unless she is the same as your testa<span class='line-break'></span>tor, I do not find any record of the<span class='line-break'> </span>death &amp; burial of the prop<sup>r</sup> of <a href='/pages/subjects/95715' title='Lot 132'>lot 132</a>.</p>
<p>Your ready reply will oblige.</p>
<p>Yours very Respy</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>459</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133952">
<h3><a name="page-1133952">CB01_0460_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-07-23'>July 23<sup>d</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95725' title='Whittier, Joseph M.'>Joseph M. Whittier</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I sent you a<span class='line-break'> </span>bill to Vienna Me. on the <date when='1869-06-23'>12<sup>th</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>of June</date> containing sundry items<span class='line-break'> </span>for work on your lot in years<span class='line-break'> </span>past. As you have been gone<span class='line-break'> </span>for some time, there has been no <span class='line-break'> </span>opportunity to present you the bill.<span class='line-break'> </span>Indeed in June last I did not<span class='line-break'> </span><u>know</u> that your residence was<span class='line-break'> </span>in Vienna. I have since ascer<span class='line-break'></span>tained that such is the fact.</p>
<p>I enclose another bill with<span class='line-break'> </span>interest added, and I ask<span class='line-break'> </span>your earliest attention to<span class='line-break'> </span>the discharge of the same.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1869-07-27'>July 27<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95726' title='Brown, John A.'>John A. Brown</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Allow me again<span class='line-break'> </span>to call your attention to<span class='line-break'> </span>bill of $49.63 due for<span class='line-break'> </span>work upon your lot since<span class='line-break'> </span>August last -- almost one<span class='line-break'> </span>year -- We do not usually<span class='line-break'> </span>allow our bills to stand<span class='line-break'> </span>so long -- but as you made<span class='line-break'> </span>objection ^<sup>to pay</sup> until you could see<span class='line-break'> </span>the Sup<sup>t</sup> in the Spring, I have<span class='line-break'> </span>not pressed you. Spring has <span class='line-break'> </span>come and gone; and I must<span class='line-break'> </span>now request payment of<span class='line-break'> </span>the bill. --</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>460</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133953">
<h3><a name="page-1133953">CB01_0461_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-07-27'>July 27 [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95728' title='Basiel, L. F., Mr.'>L.F. Basiel</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The bill due<span class='line-break'> </span>this Corporation for work on your<span class='line-break'> </span>lot stands unpaid since<span class='line-break'> </span>August last -- almost one<span class='line-break'> </span>year.</p>
<p>I must request your<span class='line-break'> </span>immediate attention to the<span class='line-break'> </span>same.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1869-09-14'>Sept. 14<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95729' title='York, William F.'>W<sup>m</sup> F. York</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your note of last<span class='line-break'> </span>Dec<sup>r</sup> objecting to pay for fixing up round<span class='line-break'> </span>monument of <a href='/pages/subjects/94119' title='Towne, L. G., Mrs.'>Mrs Towne</a>, I replied to<span class='line-break'> </span>that, it was the custom for the man who<span class='line-break'> </span>set the monument in a lot to repair all<span class='line-break'> </span>damage to the lot which such setting had<span class='line-break'> </span>occasioned: that such is the practice<span class='line-break'> </span>with our best marble men. But you have<span class='line-break'> </span>taken no further notice of the matter.</p>
<p>Not admitting the correctness of your<span class='line-break'> </span>position, for the sake of settlement, I now<span class='line-break'> </span>send you bill for <span class='line-break'> </span><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>men &amp; derrick</th> <th>$9.80<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>&amp; interest for more than 4 yrs</td> <td>2.49</td> </tr> <tr><td>[total]</td> <td>12.29</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <span class='line-break'> </span>This of course you cannot<span class='line-break'> </span>object to pay. I regret that we should<span class='line-break'> </span>have found ground to differ on so<span class='line-break'> </span>small a point.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>461</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133954">
<h3><a name="page-1133954">CB01_0462_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-09-16'>Sept<sup>r</sup> 16<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95733' title='Snow, Catherine P.'>Mrs<!--747--> Snow</a> is in while<span class='line-break'> </span>I write. I have just been to see <a href='/pages/subjects/95736' title='Ware, William Robert'>Mr <!--lot 202-->Ware</a><span class='line-break'> </span>who is very willing to do his share<span class='line-break'> </span>towards the drain on <a href='/pages/subjects/61224' title='Locust Avenue'>Locust Av<sup>e</sup></a>.<span class='line-break'> </span>He says he told <a href='/pages/subjects/54832' title='Austin, Edward'>Mr Austin</a> he was<span class='line-break'> </span>willing to give $25.00. He now says<span class='line-break'> </span>if it is necessary, he is willing to<span class='line-break'> </span>give even thirty or forty dollars.<span class='line-break'> </span>If Mrs Snow, whom we have put <span class='line-break'> </span>down at $50. could have her as<span class='line-break'></span>sessment thereby reduced to $40, I<span class='line-break'> </span>doubt not <a href='/pages/subjects/95736' title='Ware, William Robert'>Mr <!--lot 202-->Ware</a> would pay<span class='line-break'> </span>forty dollars.</p>
<p>We have made the matter<span class='line-break'> </span>as definite as it can be or<span class='line-break'> </span>need be, for all practical pur<span class='line-break'></span>poses -- and I think you<span class='line-break'> </span>need not wait longer to hear<span class='line-break'> </span>from the parties.</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>If we put <a href='/pages/subjects/95733' title='Snow, Catherine P.'><!--747-->Mrs Snow</a> at</th> <th>40.00<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95736' title='Ware, William Robert'>Mr <!--Lot 202-->Ware</a> [at]</td> <td>40.00</td> </tr> <tr><td><a href='/pages/subjects/95737' title='Hurd, Mr.'>Mr <!--lot 2387-->Hurd</a> [at]</td> <td>25.00</td> </tr> <tr><td>Mr Davis [at]</td> <td>10.00</td> </tr> <tr><td>We have [total]</td> <td>$115.00</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> something from one other party --<span class='line-break'> </span>but that I do not reckon on.</p>
<p>I would like the report<span class='line-break'> </span>on the <a href='/pages/subjects/95735' title='Lincoln, Ezra'>Ezra Lincoln</a> lot,<span class='line-break'> </span>if you please.</p>
<p>Yours Resp.y</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>462</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133955">
<h3><a name="page-1133955">CB01_0463_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>463</p>
<p><date when='1869-09-16'>Sept 16<sup>th</sup> [186]9</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95740' title='Hanscom, William L.'>W.L. Hanscom</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclosed certain bills to you<span class='line-break'> </span>last year, but learned soon that you had<span class='line-break'> </span>gone to Europe, to be absent several months.<span class='line-break'> </span>Hoping that you might call here when in <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a><span class='line-break'> </span>I have not so far sent again. I am however<span class='line-break'> </span>very anxious to close up certain old accts,<span class='line-break'> </span>and trust therefore that you will so far as<span class='line-break'> </span>your lot is that of <a href='/pages/subjects/108156' title='Farrar, Mr.'>Mr Farrar</a> is concerned,<span class='line-break'> </span>enable me to do so.</p>
<p>My predecessor's clerk made certain errors<span class='line-break'> </span>in charges on your account by reason of the number<span class='line-break'> </span>of your lot being accidentally included with <a href='/pages/subjects/95741' title='Lot 3208'>lots<span class='line-break'> </span>3208</a>-<a href='/pages/subjects/95742' title='Lot 3211'><!--3211-->11</a> (the Hitchcock brothers) where a charge of $36.00<span class='line-break'> </span>was divided between their four lots &amp; yours, instead<span class='line-break'> </span>of their four alone. That made bill of $7.20<span class='line-break'> </span>apparently for care of <a href='/pages/subjects/95743' title='Lot 2903'>lot 2903</a> for 1867. You paid<span class='line-break'> </span>that charge to me by mistake instead of your<span class='line-break'> </span>regular bill for both lots of $12.00: and <a href='/pages/subjects/54274' title='Bond, George William'>Bond</a>'s<span class='line-break'> </span>clerk had credited you already with 7.20 by<span class='line-break'> </span>mistake -- the ^<sup>4</sup> Hitchcocks paying 36.00 or 9.00<span class='line-break'> </span>each, and they were each credited 7.20 &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>you 7.20 -- He erroneously credited the<span class='line-break'> </span>amount to you, they having paid [?]</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133956">
<h3><a name="page-1133956">CB01_0464_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>464</p>
<p>bill, and you receiving a bill of it, came in &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>paid it to me (before I had sifted the accts.)<span class='line-break'> </span>instead of the $12.00 which you owed, and an old<span class='line-break'> </span>bill of 4.75 for foundation for headstones.</p>
<p>This explains the whole cause of the error.<span class='line-break'> </span>I have gone over the accts, thoroughly, and know<span class='line-break'> </span>that I am right. I subjoin the account<span class='line-break'> </span>as it should &amp; does truly stand, giving you<span class='line-break'> </span>credit for all that you have paid. --</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>1864</th> <th>Dr</th> <th/> <th>Cr</th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td><date when='1864-05-30'>May 30</date> --</td> <td>For building found<sup>n</sup> in 3097 =</td> <td>4.75</td> <td/> <td/> </tr> <tr><td><date when='1865-02'>1865 Feby</date></td> <td>[For] care of <a href='/pages/subjects/95743' title='Lot 2903'>lots 2903</a> <a href='/pages/subjects/97251' title='Lot 3097'>&amp; 3097</a> for 1864</td> <td>10.00 --</td> <td>1865 Feby By cash</td> <td>10.00</td> </tr> <tr><td>1866 Nov.</td> <td>[For care of <a href='/pages/subjects/95743' title='Lot 2903'>lots 2903</a> &amp; 3097 for] 1866</td> <td>12.00 --</td> <td><date when='1867-10-31'>1867 Oct 31</date> [By cash]</td> <td>12.00</td> </tr> <tr><td>1867 Dec 31</td> <td>[For care of <a href='/pages/subjects/95743' title='Lot 2903'>lots 2903</a> &amp; 3097 for] 1867</td> <td>12.00</td> <td>1868 June  [By cash]</td> <td>7.20</td> </tr> <tr><td>1868 [Dec 31]</td> <td>[For care of <a href='/pages/subjects/95743' title='Lot 2903'>lots 2903</a> &amp; 3907 for] 1868</td> <td>12.00</td> <td/> </tr> <tr><td/> <td>[total]</td> <td>50.75</td> <td>[total]</td> <td>29.20</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> Showing to be due from you $21.55 --</p>
<p>The last three years $7. was charged on your lot<span class='line-break'> </span>and $5.00 on lot 3097 --</p>
<p>If you will be so kind as to send me<span class='line-break'> </span>check for the above am<sup>t</sup> ($21.55) I shall<span class='line-break'> </span>very cheerfully give you the proper receipts.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133957">
<h3><a name="page-1133957">CB01_0465_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>Mount Auburn Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>16 Pembroke Square<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, <date when='1869-09-20'>September 20, 1869</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95744' title='Hodgkinson, Frank'>Frank Hodgkinson</a> Esq.<span class='line-break'> </span>Agent &amp; Trustee</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your communication<span class='line-break'> </span>to the Board of Trustees respecting the<span class='line-break'> </span>charge for porterage was duly presen<span class='line-break'></span>ted at the last meeting by <a href='/pages/subjects/63802' title='Rand, Edward S.'>Mr Rand</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>and was referred to the Committee of Finance<span class='line-break'> </span>with full power, which committee have<span class='line-break'> </span>considered the matter, and directed<span class='line-break'> </span>me to inform you that they<span class='line-break'> </span>cannot see the validity of the<span class='line-break'> </span>charge, and they are of opinion<span class='line-break'> </span>that it should not be paid.</p>
<p>I am</p>
<p>Respectfully yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Secretary</p>
<p><date when='1869-09-30'>Sept 30 [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95745' title='Merrill, William D.'>Mr W<sup>m</sup> D. Merrill</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>13 Grand St <a href='/pages/subjects/95746' title='Jersey City, NJ'>Jersey City N.J.</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I enclose a bill for<span class='line-break'> </span>work on your lot which I find has<span class='line-break'> </span>been standing nearly four years, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>which you would have rec<sup>d</sup> long since<span class='line-break'> </span>if your residence had been known.</p>
<p>I have just learned your residence<span class='line-break'> </span>also that Mr Holman &amp; wife, <a href='/pages/subjects/62295' title='Newton, MA'>Newton</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>Mrs Merrill's sisters -- are with you. I<span class='line-break'> </span>am rather glad therefore to take this<span class='line-break'> </span>opportunity to send to you, as we <span class='line-break'> </span>like to have our distant proprietors<span class='line-break'> </span>remember the care of their lots as well<span class='line-break'> </span>as those who live nearer, and if<span class='line-break'> </span>you will advise with them and<span class='line-break'> </span>let them communicate to us upon<span class='line-break'> </span>their return, your wishes, we</p>
<p>465</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133958">
<h3><a name="page-1133958">CB01_0466_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>will endeavor to execute them.<span class='line-break'> </span>I am aware that the lot is smaller<span class='line-break'> </span>but small lots as well as large,<span class='line-break'> </span>reflect the care which they receive.</p>
<p>An interment of a child<span class='line-break'> </span>of <a href='/pages/subjects/95748' title='Eaton, E. A., Rev.'>Rev E.A. Eaton</a> was lately<span class='line-break'> </span>made in your lot, the order<span class='line-break'> </span>for which we did not get<span class='line-break'> </span>until afterwards, I think, and thus<span class='line-break'> </span>not signed by you. If you<span class='line-break'> </span>affirm that order it is<span class='line-break'> </span>all right.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Sec. &amp; Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1869-10-01'>Octo. 1<sup>st</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your neighbor, <a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jona. Mann</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>holds a certificate dated <date when='1864-06-02'>June 2, 1864</date>, for<span class='line-break'> </span>a lot in the Cemetery, to contain 300 square<span class='line-break'> </span>feet, which has never been located. I<span class='line-break'> </span>have just written him that none but the<span class='line-break'> </span>old certificate of twenty or twenty five years<span class='line-break'> </span>ago contain the right of selection, &amp; of<span class='line-break'> </span>course his is cut off. He is obliged<span class='line-break'> </span>to take such land as was then selling at<span class='line-break'> </span>the price paid by him -- 50 cts per foot.</p>
<p>There may be other such cer<span class='line-break'></span>tificates outstanding -- but I am not<span class='line-break'> </span>aware of them.</p>
<p>I write simply to say, that if<span class='line-break'> </span>this question is presented to you, that<span class='line-break'> </span>through him or any one else, they have<span class='line-break'> </span>no right of selection unless so expressed in the<span class='line-break'> </span>certificate.</p>
<p>Respectfully,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Capt D.L. Winsor</a></p>
<p>466</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133959">
<h3><a name="page-1133959">CB01_0467_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-10-01'>Octo. 1<sup>st</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/59191' title='Mann, Jonathan'>Jona. Mann Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I find correctly<span class='line-break'> </span>entered on the cash book $150.<span class='line-break'> </span>rec<sup>d</sup> from you <date when='1864-06-02'>June 2, 1864</date> for<span class='line-break'> </span>a lot of 300 square feet.</p>
<p>As there is not likely to be another<span class='line-break'> </span>rise of land for a long time, I hope<span class='line-break'> </span>you will get your lot located,<span class='line-break'> </span>as that is the only advantage which<span class='line-break'> </span>can be derived from neglecting to do<span class='line-break'> </span>so, while there is the disadvantage<span class='line-break'> </span>of the best average land being taken.</p>
<p>I hope you are not laboring under<span class='line-break'> </span>the error that one holding a certif<span class='line-break'></span>icate like yours, can go in and<span class='line-break'> </span>select where he chooses. The right<span class='line-break'> </span>of choice was for some time ex<span class='line-break'></span>pressed in the old certificates --<span class='line-break'> </span>but it many years since the<span class='line-break'> </span>practice was done away. --</p>
<p>I can show you the difference<span class='line-break'> </span>between the receipt which you<span class='line-break'> </span>hold, and that formerly given.</p>
<p>Of course you will receive this<span class='line-break'> </span>as friendly advice. <u>I</u> have no objection<span class='line-break'> </span>to your getting as good a lot as you<span class='line-break'> </span>can, but there is now no advantage<span class='line-break'> </span>to be derived, I think, from buying<span class='line-break'> </span>unlocated land. --</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>467</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133960">
<h3><a name="page-1133960">CB01_0468_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-10-11'>Octo. 11<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97417' title='Blake, Geoge C.'>Geo. C. Blake</a> Esq.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/95778' title='Parker, A., Mr.'>Mr A. Parker</a> states<span class='line-break'> </span>that the bill of $232.50 lately<span class='line-break'> </span>sent you belongs to him to pay, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>he will meet it next week.</p>
<p>I sent it to you as it came<span class='line-break'> </span>in from <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'><!--Winsor-->the Sup<sup>t</sup></a> who perhaps<span class='line-break'> </span>did not know the arrange<span class='line-break'></span>ment between you &amp; <a href='/pages/subjects/95778' title='Parker, A., Mr.'>Mr Parker</a> --<span class='line-break'> </span>if he did, it was overlooked.</p>
<p>I write at Mr P.'s request<span class='line-break'> </span>to say that we are willing<span class='line-break'> </span>to lift the obligation from you<span class='line-break'> </span>to his shoulders.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p><date when='1869-10-15'>Octo. 15<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/94097' title='Crane, Edward'>Edward Crane</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Our Corporation holds<span class='line-break'> </span><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>against you an execution for</th> <th>539.14<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>debt, and for costs</td> <td>23.28</td> </tr> <tr><td>Amounting to</td> <td>$582.42.</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> and the officer informs me that you<span class='line-break'> </span>have taken no notice of his demand<span class='line-break'> </span>upon you for payment thereof. --</p>
<p>I shall regret the necessity of instructing<span class='line-break'> </span>the Sheriff to arrest you, but unless you<span class='line-break'> </span>respond to the demand without delay,<span class='line-break'> </span>shall certainly do so.</p>
<p>I do not write this to ascertain<span class='line-break'> </span>what may be secured by threat,<span class='line-break'> </span>but that you may not hereafter<span class='line-break'> </span>complain that sufficient courtesy<span class='line-break'> </span>was not shown you in giving proper notice.</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>468</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133961">
<h3><a name="page-1133961">CB01_0469_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-10-15'>Octo. 15 [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/83700' title='Prichard, Jane Anna'>Mrs Jane Anna Prichard</a></p>
<p>Dear Madam,</p>
<p>Upon the<span class='line-break'> </span>application of the son and daughter<span class='line-break'> </span>of the late <a href='/pages/subjects/83702' title='Prichard, William Henry'>W<sup>m</sup> H. Prichard</a>, pro<span class='line-break'></span>prietor of <a href='/pages/subjects/83699' title='Lot 683'>lot no. 683</a>, it has<span class='line-break'> </span>been deemed proper to desig<span class='line-break'></span>nate the said son, <a href='/pages/subjects/25004011' title='Prichard, Henry M.'>Henry M.<span class='line-break'> </span>Prichard</a>, of <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a>, to represent<span class='line-break'> </span>said lot. He resides here,<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; is not only desirous to im<span class='line-break'></span>prove the lot, but willing<span class='line-break'> </span>to bear the expense of the same.</p>
<p>He will not of course<span class='line-break'> </span>deprive you or Mr Prichard's<span class='line-break'> </span>other child of any rights which<span class='line-break'> </span>you may have therein; but all<span class='line-break'> </span>orders should be made through the<span class='line-break'> </span>representative. His appointment<span class='line-break'> </span>is always made ^<sup>to continue</sup> during the<span class='line-break'> </span>pleasure of the Board of<span class='line-break'> </span>Trustees. --</p>
<p>I am</p>
<p>Most Respectfully yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.y</p>
<p>469</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133962">
<h3><a name="page-1133962">CB01_0470_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-10-15'>Octo. 15 [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97284' title='Fiske, J. M., Mr.'>J.M. Fiske Esq</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>The report of the Sup<sup>t</sup> on<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/65933' title='Lot 203'>lot no 203</a> -- heirs of <a href='/pages/subjects/65932' title='Fiske, Benjamin'>Benj. Fiske</a> --<span class='line-break'> </span>has been laid before the Com<sup>ee</sup> on<span class='line-break'> </span>Lots. The Sup<sup>t</sup> reports that the<span class='line-break'> </span>lot front of the monument is much<span class='line-break'> </span>sunken, and needs raising &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>resodding: that the cost of repairing,<span class='line-break'> </span>painting fence, cleaning marble &amp;c will<span class='line-break'> </span>be about $49.00 -- The Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>does not accept a lot for <u>per<span class='line-break'></span>petual</u> care without requiring<span class='line-break'> </span>it first to be put in proper<span class='line-break'> </span>condition.</p>
<p>The Com<sup>ee</sup> have authorized<span class='line-break'> </span>me to notify you that, when<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot shall have so been put<span class='line-break'> </span>in order, the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>will guarantee the perpetual<span class='line-break'> </span>repair of the same for four<span class='line-break'> </span>hundred and fifty dollars.<span class='line-break'> </span>($450). --</p>
<p>I took the opportunity<span class='line-break'> </span>to look at the lot the other<span class='line-break'> </span>day when out, and from its<span class='line-break'> </span>prominent situation it seems<span class='line-break'> </span>to me of great importance<span class='line-break'> </span>that its perpetuity should<span class='line-break'> </span>be secured. I earnestly<span class='line-break'> </span>hope that you may find<span class='line-break'> </span>it practicable to do so.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>470<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133963">
<h3><a name="page-1133963">CB01_0471_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1869-10-16'>Octo. 16<sup>th</sup> [18]69</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97286' title='Coleman, John W.'>John W. Coleman</a> Esq</p>
<p>My dear Sir,</p>
<p>I should have written<span class='line-break'> </span>you before on the following matter, if I<span class='line-break'> </span>had not the impression that you were<span class='line-break'> </span>still ^<sup>at the</sup> South.</p>
<p>The Committee on Lots have<span class='line-break'> </span>considered your application to know<span class='line-break'> </span>for what sum the Corporation will<span class='line-break'> </span>assume the perpetual care of <a href='/pages/subjects/74143' title='Lot 1114'>lot<span class='line-break'> </span>no. 1114</a> in the Cemetery, and have<span class='line-break'> </span>directed me to inform you that<span class='line-break'> </span>such contract will be entered into<span class='line-break'> </span>on payment of <u>five hundred<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars</u> ($500) when the lot shall<span class='line-break'> </span>have been put in good repair. --</p>
<p>The repairs estimated each<span class='line-break'> </span>needed by the Sup<sup>t</sup> are<span class='line-break'> </span>as follows: --</p>
<p><table class='tabular'><thead><span class='line-break'> </span><tr><th>1000 feet sods</th> <th>37.50<span class='line-break'> </span></th></tr></thead> <tbody> <tr><td>1 cord manure</td> <td>12.00</td> </tr> <tr><td>Cleaning monument</td> <td>8.00</td> </tr> <tr><td>10 days labor</td> <td>23.80</td> </tr> <tr><td>[total]</td> <td>81.30</td> </tr> </tbody> </table> This you perceive does not take<span class='line-break'> </span>in painting fence, which you propose<span class='line-break'> </span>now to do. I presume the <a href='/pages/subjects/55278' title='Winsor, Daniel L., Capt.'>Sup<sup>t</sup><!--D.L.W.--></a> thought<span class='line-break'> </span>it would do a year or two<span class='line-break'> </span>longer. I remember it is painted<span class='line-break'> </span>white, but looks much better than<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot generally.</p>
<p>The ^<sup>estimated</sup> cost of repairs seems large --<span class='line-break'> </span>but is not really so: for instance<span class='line-break'> </span>1000 feet sods -- There is, you know,<span class='line-break'> </span>a very high bank on the avenue side<span class='line-break'> </span>of your lot.</p>
<p>From the prominent position of<span class='line-break'> </span>this lot, I sincerely trust you<span class='line-break'> </span>may find it convenient to carry<span class='line-break'> </span>out your design to place it in charge<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Corporation.</p>
<p>Yours truly</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>471</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133964">
<h3><a name="page-1133964">CB01_0472_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>472</p>
<p><date when='1869-11-24'>Novem<sup>r</sup> 24 [18]69 </date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/81482' title='Shedd, J. H., Mr.'>J. H. Shedd Esq</a>.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have for the last three or four<span class='line-break'> </span>been trying to get a personal interview with you, as<span class='line-break'> </span>I could in ten minutes get further some, than in<span class='line-break'> </span>ten days by correspondence. But failing in that,<span class='line-break'> </span>and feeling that after all, you may view the matter<span class='line-break'> </span>about which I now write very much in the same<span class='line-break'> </span>way that I do, I commit it to paper.</p>
<p>Our corporation has for years been at arms<span class='line-break'> </span>length (or rather I should say practically beyond reach)<span class='line-break'> </span>in access to the <ins>note books</ins> containing the original and<span class='line-break'> </span>additional surveys of land &amp; lots in the Cemetery.</p>
<p>Not that you have not given me all facilities<span class='line-break'> </span>for ascertaining any given point, for I confess<span class='line-break'> </span>we ought to have <ins>possession</ins> of all matter<span class='line-break'> </span>that can be of value in ascertaining or correcting<span class='line-break'> </span>or confirming any surveys or plans. A Cor<span class='line-break'></span>portion as well off as Mt Auburn Cemetery,<span class='line-break'> </span>and which should be able to refer back to its<span class='line-break'> </span>records of surveys as well as transactions<span class='line-break'> </span>of its Trustees for coming generations—is, <span class='line-break'> </span>I think, not sufficiently mindful of its<span class='line-break'> </span>possible future wants, in allowing</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133965">
<h3><a name="page-1133965">CB01_0473_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>473</p>
<p>the note books of its surveys to be in private<span class='line-break'> </span>hands. A surveyor dies or removes to a dis<span class='line-break'></span>tance, or sells out; and the Corporation that<span class='line-break'> </span>employs him, is in the case before us, obliged<span class='line-break'> </span>to follow the records of his work into other<span class='line-break'> </span>hands, or in case of their loss or destruction,<span class='line-break'> </span>to begin again anew.</p>
<p>Our plan is a good record as far as<span class='line-break'> </span>it goes, and I don't wish to be understood<span class='line-break'> </span>as regarding the suveyor's notebooks to be<span class='line-break'> </span>of <ins>immense</ins> value to the Corporation, but as<span class='line-break'> </span>having <ins>some</ins> value, chiefly as I said for<span class='line-break'> </span>comparison &amp; confirmation. In this light,<span class='line-break'> </span>they are of <u>some</u> value: and the evidence of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Corporation should not be regarded<span class='line-break'> </span>as complete without the <ins>possession</ins> of them.</p>
<p>Now then, I wish to know if you<span class='line-break'> </span>will dispose of the note books of surveys<span class='line-break'> </span>in Mount Auburn to the Corporation if<span class='line-break'> </span>so on what terms.</p>
<p>We do not wish them for the purpose<span class='line-break'> </span>of making a change in surveyor—although<span class='line-break'> </span>that possibility must in every case at some<span class='line-break'> </span>time become a certainly, i.e. with an enduring<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation.  We wish to own them, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>have the general custody, &amp; have it hence<span class='line-break'></span>forth understood, that the surveyor's notes<span class='line-break'> </span>shall be the property of the Corporation.</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133966">
<h3><a name="page-1133966">CB01_0474_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>474</p>
<p>I am Secretary &amp; Treas. (for illustration,)<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; I often collect information which I cannot<span class='line-break'> </span>by the law compelled to do, but I regard that<span class='line-break'> </span>as the property of the Corporation &amp; not my pri<span class='line-break'></span>vate property. I do not see why a Corpor<span class='line-break'></span>ation surveyor's work that is paid for<span class='line-break'> </span>wholly by the Corporation, should not be the<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation's property.</p>
<p>In this light, you should, perhaps,<span class='line-break'> </span>transfer the books to the Corporation, without<span class='line-break'> </span>further pecuniary consideration. Still if you<span class='line-break'> </span>view the matter in a different light, please<span class='line-break'> </span>state, at what price you will make the<span class='line-break'> </span>transfer. You may perhaps, remember that<span class='line-break'> </span><del>when</del>, after your first survey under a con<span class='line-break'></span>tract for $750, you were paid as a matter<span class='line-break'> </span>of equity about double that view. The<span class='line-break'> </span>Corporation &amp; you have been good neighbors, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>I trust that good feeling may continue. I<span class='line-break'> </span>have upheld your side of the question, when<span class='line-break'> </span>I confess, in some cases it has been hard for<span class='line-break'> </span>me to do so, owing to the inconvenience suf<span class='line-break'></span>fered through frequent changes, irrespon<span class='line-break'></span>sible assistants.</p>
<p>I need not say, of cause, that your<span class='line-break'> </span>employees, will have the same access to the<span class='line-break'> </span>notes as heretofore, with the foregoing limitations,<span class='line-break'> </span>if you see fit to transfer them.<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133967">
<h3><a name="page-1133967">CB01_0475_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>475</p>
<p>Your brother, has today brought me<span class='line-break'> </span>a bill for about three months, of between<span class='line-break'> </span>three &amp; four hundred dollars—rather more<span class='line-break'> </span>than, any of your previous bills that I remember.<span class='line-break'> </span>He would like to get the pay, I suppose, this<span class='line-break'> </span>much, as Curtis is about going to Europe.</p>
<p>I would however, like first to hear<span class='line-break'> </span>from you, on the matter suggested <del>If<span class='line-break'> </span>you can</del>. Please write by or as near return<span class='line-break'> </span>mail as your time will allow. I hear<span class='line-break'> </span>that you have but little leisure.—</p>
<p>Very Truly Yours,</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133968">
<h3><a name="page-1133968">CB01_0476_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1870-03-22'>March 22 [18]70</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97291' title='Fisher, Nathaniel'>Nath<sup>l</sup> Fisher</a> Esq</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Your favor of 6<sup>th</sup><span class='line-break'> </span>inst. is before me: and I have laid<span class='line-break'> </span>your communication with the report<span class='line-break'> </span>of the Sup<sup>t</sup> upon the condition of<span class='line-break'> </span>the lot before the Com<sup>ee</sup> on Lots, who<span class='line-break'> </span>have carefully considered the matter<span class='line-break'> </span>and have directed me to inform<span class='line-break'> </span>you that this Corporation will<span class='line-break'> </span>assume the perpetual care of your<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/97292' title='Lot 645'>lot no. 645</a> in the Cemetery<span class='line-break'> </span>"for three hundred &amp; twenty five<span class='line-break'> </span>dollars ($325.) provided the Cor<span class='line-break'></span>poration has the right to take and<span class='line-break'> </span>hold the present iron fence and posts<span class='line-break'> </span>and substitute therefor at its own<span class='line-break'> </span>cost four ten inch granite ^<sup>site</sup> posts<span class='line-break'> </span>with the number of the lot cut<span class='line-break'> </span>upon one of them".</p>
<p>There is no <u>material</u> difference<span class='line-break'> </span>between your views and those of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Com<sup>ee</sup>. The Superintendent in his<span class='line-break'> </span>note of last August, of which I<span class='line-break'> </span>sent you a copy, overestimated the<span class='line-break'> </span>value of your fence and old<span class='line-break'> </span>posts, as he now states. Upon<span class='line-break'> </span>looking over the lot &amp; fence again,<span class='line-break'> </span>he thinks that the whole thing<span class='line-break'> </span>would not bring more than<span class='line-break'> </span>$25.00. The old posts, owing to<span class='line-break'> </span>the fence being set with brim<span class='line-break'></span>stone are entirely ruined for<span class='line-break'> </span>any other purpose, as you may<span class='line-break'> </span>know that the action of sulphur<span class='line-break'> </span>with iron out of doors disinte<span class='line-break'></span>grates the granite.</p>
<p>The four new posts with<span class='line-break'> </span>number cut will cost $19.00.</p>
<p>The Com<sup>ee</sup>, in looking over</p>
<p>476<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133969">
<h3><a name="page-1133969">CB01_0477_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>the lot with the monument<span class='line-break'> </span>and grave marks which are worth<span class='line-break'> </span>not less than $500, and con<span class='line-break'></span>sidering the risks of injury to, &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>perishability of granite in our<span class='line-break'> </span>climate, think that $325.<span class='line-break'> </span>is a moderate estimate for<span class='line-break'> </span>assuming the perpetual repair.</p>
<p>They would be very glad<span class='line-break'> </span>to meet you on $300, if they<span class='line-break'> </span>deemed it consistent with the<span class='line-break'> </span>interests of the Corporation.</p>
<p>But, considering the small <span class='line-break'> </span>amount which your fence will<span class='line-break'> </span>bring, the labor of removing it &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>of setting the new posts, the price<span class='line-break'> </span>named is no better than $300<span class='line-break'> </span>would be upon the estimate of<span class='line-break'> </span>the Sup<sup>t</sup> in August last. --</p>
<p>The Committee are decided<span class='line-break'> </span>in their view, &amp; I trust, so<span class='line-break'> </span>small a difference will not<span class='line-break'> </span>[indecipherable last line- off page]<span class='line-break'> </span>perpetuating the care of your<span class='line-break'> </span>lot.</p>
<p>If you signify your accept<span class='line-break'></span>ance of the terms, I will<span class='line-break'> </span>prepare the necessary papers.</p>
<p>Most Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A.J. Coolidge</a> Sec.</p>
<p>477<span class='line-break'> </span></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133970">
<h3><a name="page-1133970">CB01_0478</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>478</p>
<p><date when='1870-06-09'>June 9<sup>th</sup> [18]70</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97294' title='Getchell, Joshua'>Joshua Getchell</a>, Esq &amp;<span class='line-break'> </span>Exetor. &amp;c.</p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>I have just been<span class='line-break'> </span>informed that you are the Trustee for the<span class='line-break'> </span>Creditory ^<sup>of</sup> [Ochane?] E. Gravelle, on insolvent<span class='line-break'> </span>debtor - that his estate has paid forty per<span class='line-break'> </span>cent, and that probably think more will be<span class='line-break'> </span>paid. Enclosed please find bill one<span class='line-break'> </span>from him to this Corporation for [?] on<span class='line-break'> </span>his lot. They [predictions?] have [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>to collect it, but the removal of [?]<span class='line-break'> </span>Gravelle from place to place, has probably<span class='line-break'> </span>been the reason why they have been un<span class='line-break'></span>able to reach him.</p>
<p>If you [?] our claim presented in<span class='line-break'> </span>any different form, please so state.-</p>
<p>Respectfully yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70476' title='Mackintosh, Henry B.'>H. B. Mackintosh</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treasu<sup>r</sup></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133971">
<h3><a name="page-1133971">CB01_0479_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>479</p>
<p><date when='1870-06-10'>June 10<sup>th</sup> [18]70</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79942' title='Safford, Frederick Marcy'>Mr. F. M. Safford</a>.<span class='line-break'> </span>Gatekeeper pro tem<span class='line-break'> </span>Mr. Aub. Cemetery</p>
<p>Dear Sir.</p>
<p>Herewith enclosed please find<span class='line-break'> </span>your Statement of Cash receipts &amp; expenditures for<span class='line-break'> </span>week ending <date when='1870-06-03'>June 3<sup>d</sup> 1870</date>. Which you handed<span class='line-break'> </span>me a few days since, (without cash balance).</p>
<p>I do not know what has been the custom heretofore,<span class='line-break'> </span>but it seems proper that where money is paid out for<span class='line-break'> </span>Expressage, or other expenses, and to entered in the account,<span class='line-break'> </span>that vouchers for said payments should accompany the<span class='line-break'> </span>account.</p>
<p>I observe in the credit of amt. paid by <a href='/pages/subjects/55348' title='Jones, Lewis'>Lewis Jones</a><span class='line-break'> </span><date when='1870-05-31'>May 31<sup>th</sup></date> for [sic] intermint, no name is entered, tho. in<span class='line-break'> </span>other instances they are.</p>
<p>Please give these matters your consideration &amp; let<span class='line-break'> </span>me hear from you in regard to them at your con<span class='line-break'></span>venience.</p>
<p>Respy. yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70476' title='Mackintosh, Henry B.'>H. B. Mackintosh</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133972">
<h3><a name="page-1133972">CB01_0480</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>480</p>
<p><date when='1870-06-10'>June 10<sup>th</sup> [18]70</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/52528' title='Folsom, Charles W.'>Col. C.W. Folsom</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Supt. Mt Aub. Cem.</p>
<p>Dear Sir</p>
<p>Herewith enclosed<span class='line-break'> </span>please find copy of writ served upon me this day<span class='line-break'> </span>attaching all monies due this day from the Corporation<span class='line-break'> </span>to <a href='/pages/subjects/57835' title='Black, James'>James Black</a> of <a href='/pages/subjects/53203' title='Cambridge, MA'>Cambridge</a>. The Plaintiff in<span class='line-break'> </span>the case is <a href='/pages/subjects/97299' title='Edgehill, S. St. Clair.'>S. St. Clair. Edgehill</a>, of <a href='/pages/subjects/53203' title='Cambridge, MA'>Cambridge</a>, physician.</p>
<p>The sum <a href='/pages/subjects/57835' title='Black, James'>Black</a> was trusteed last month &amp; I hold<span class='line-break'> </span>in reserve $38.59 subject to the decision of the Court in<span class='line-break'> </span>this case. --</p>
<p>Will you please notify <a href='/pages/subjects/57835' title='Black, James'>Mr Black</a>, if there is any<span class='line-break'> </span>monies due him on this months account, and make<span class='line-break'> </span>such [?] on your time book, as may be needed<span class='line-break'> </span>when the monthly payment is made out.</p>
<p>Very respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70476' title='Mackintosh, Henry B.'>H.B. Mackintosh</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas.<sup>r</sup></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133973">
<h3><a name="page-1133973">CB01_0481_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>481</p>
<p><date when='1870-06-13'>June 13<sup>th</sup> [18]70</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/79942' title='Safford, Frederick Marcy'>Mr F.M. Safford</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Gate Keeper Pro. tem.<span class='line-break'> </span>Mt. Auburn Cemetery</p>
<p>[written sideways between address &amp; date]</p>
<p>Is it not most time<span class='line-break'> </span>to send out some<span class='line-break'> </span>bills? I am running <span class='line-break'> </span>short of funds.</p>
<p>Dear Sir --</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97304' title='Perham, J., Jr.'>Mr J. Perham Jr.</a>, <a href='/pages/subjects/97305' title='Lot 1464'>Lot 1464</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>has called for his bill. I find no charge against that<span class='line-break'> </span>lot on my books; if you have a charge please make out<span class='line-break'> </span>the bill in detail &amp; send to me.</p>
<p>In your receipts of money at the gate some of the amounts<span class='line-break'> </span>are placed directly to the Labor &amp; Material Account, and other<span class='line-break'> </span>sums are carried to the same account; <u>also</u> to the credit of the<span class='line-break'> </span>Lot in the ledger -- What I desire is, that you should put<span class='line-break'> </span>against each item that is to be credited on the ledger such mark<span class='line-break'> </span>as will enable me to distinguish it from other credits -- for<span class='line-break'> </span>instance; you credit in your acct. $5. for Wood Sold; that sum<span class='line-break'> </span>is credited in my cash book to Labor &amp; Materials -- But, if you<span class='line-break'> </span>receive money for reforms or improvements on lots, or for care for<span class='line-break'> </span>the year, you will also at some other time (before or after the<span class='line-break'> </span>recups of the money) render me an a/c, or bills, made from<span class='line-break'> </span>the order book, and such amts. charged from the a/c, bills, or<span class='line-break'> </span>order book, I shall place to the debit of that a/c in the Ledger,<span class='line-break'> </span>if I know when it should so be placed. -- Don't be troubled about<span class='line-break'> </span>this; I will explain more clearly the first time you are in <span class='line-break'> </span>my office.</p>
<p>Yours truly --</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70476' title='Mackintosh, Henry B.'>H.B. Mackintosh</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133974">
<h3><a name="page-1133974">CB01_0482</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>482</p>
<p><date when='1870-06-22'>June 22<sup>d</sup> [18]70</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97309' title='Smith, Jemima'>Miss Jemima Smith</a><span class='line-break'> </span>33 Willow St. <a href='/pages/subjects/71564' title='Lowell, MA'>Lowell Mass.</a></p>
<p>Your letter of the <date when='1870-06-21'>21<sup>st</sup></date> inst. Enclosing<span class='line-break'> </span>Check for Two hundred forty four &amp; 50/100 dollars<span class='line-break'> </span>($244 50/100) in payment for <a href='/pages/subjects/97310' title='Lot 4019'>Lot &amp; Dead N<sup>o</sup> 4019</a>,<span class='line-break'> </span>with certificate from <a href='/pages/subjects/52528' title='Folsom, Charles W.'>Supt. C. W. Folsom</a>, was <span class='line-break'> </span>duly received, and here with I enclose a receipt<span class='line-break'> </span>for the Amount (say Lot 242.50 - Deed $2.00)</p>
<p>The Sec'y <a href='/pages/subjects/54731' title='Batchelder, Samuel, Jr.'>Sam<sup>l</sup>Batchelder Jr.</a> Esq. will notify<span class='line-break'> </span>you when the dead is ready for delivery.</p>
<p>Very respy yours</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70476' title='Mackintosh, Henry B.'>H. B. Mackintosh</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Trea<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>P.S.</p>
<p>You will please return the enclosed receipt<span class='line-break'> </span>when you send for the deed.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70476' title='Mackintosh, Henry B.'>H.B.M.<span class='line-break'> </span>Treas</a></p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133975">
<h3><a name="page-1133975">CB01_0483</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>483</p>
<p><date when='1870-06-23'>June 23<sup>d</sup> [187]0</date></p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/97315' title='Maynard, H. G., Mr.'>Mr. H.G. Maynard</a><span class='line-break'> </span>506 Tremont St. <a href='/pages/subjects/52559' title='Boston, MA'>Boston</a></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>It appears from our books<span class='line-break'> </span>that you signed an order for the care of<span class='line-break'> </span>your <a href='/pages/subjects/97316' title='Lot 3794'>Lot #3794</a> for the year 1868.<span class='line-break'> </span>If you will state your objection ^<sup>in writing,</sup> to paying the<span class='line-break'> </span>bill ($5.00) I will lay the matter before the Trustees<span class='line-break'> </span>and ask for an abatement -- and then I think<span class='line-break'> </span>we can settle it to our mutual satisfaction.</p>
<p>I hope you will fully understand that I<span class='line-break'> </span>am not responsible for the acts of the former<span class='line-break'> </span>Treasurer -- The amount involved is small<span class='line-break'> </span>&amp; I trust you will oblige me by acceding<span class='line-break'> </span>to my request as above --</p>
<p>Very resp.y</p>
<p>Your Obt. Svt.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70476' title='Mackintosh, Henry B.'>H.B. Mackintosh</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup> </p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133976">
<h3><a name="page-1133976">CB01_0484</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p><date when='1870-06-24'>June 24<sup>th</sup> [187]0</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>Herewith enclosed <span class='line-break'> </span>please find bill for <a href='/pages/subjects/97317' title='Powers, A. H., Mr.'>Mr. A.H. Powers</a><span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/97318' title='Lot 2017'>Lot 2017</a>. amt. $68 97/100, which I<span class='line-break'> </span>send you, as per your request to<span class='line-break'> </span>the late Treas<sup>r</sup> Mr. <a href='/pages/subjects/53157' title='Coolidge, Austin J.'>A. J. Coolidge</a></p>
<p>Very respy</p>
<p>Your obt. svt.</p>
<p><a href='/pages/subjects/70476' title='Mackintosh, Henry B.'>H. B. Mackintosh</a><span class='line-break'> </span>Treas<sup>r</sup></p>
<p>To <span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/97319' title='Livermore, John'>John Livermore</a> Esqr<span class='line-break'> </span><a href='/pages/subjects/64864' title='Cambridgeport, MA'>Cambridgeport<span class='line-break'> </span>Mass.</a></p>
<p>484</p>
</div>
</div>
<br />
<div id="page-1133977">
<h3><a name="page-1133977">CB01_0485_1</a></h3>
<div class="page-content">
<p>485</p>
<p><date when='1870-06-27'>June 27 [18]70</date></p>
<p>Dear Sir,</p>
<p>On examination of the Reports of the Superinten<span class='line-break'></span>dent since February 1869, I find the following Lots &amp; additions<span class='line-break'> </span>to Lots represented as <ins>paid for</ins>, no deeds of which appear to<span class='line-break'> </span>have been made.  Will you please advise me whether there<span class='line-break'> </span>is anything in the condition of these Lots which, by the rules of<span class='line-break'> </span>the corporation, or by custom, would preclude the making and<span class='line-break'> </span>delivery of the deeds to the purchasers forthwith?</p>
